title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOLMES, JOHN C. (JACK)
description: HOLMES--John C. (Jack), 72. On February 23, at his home in Manhattan. Musical Director/Conductor, Composer/ Lyricist, and Author. Jack's multifaceted forty - year career includes Off-Broadway's original Little Mary Sunshine, O Say Can You See! (Music) and Dames At Sea; NBC's The Reluctant Dragon (Score), Broadway's I Do! I Do!, No, No, Nanette! and Raisin' (Tours). His review songs were featured in Broadway's From A To Z, New Faces of '62 and in dozens of Julius Monk, Ben Bagley and Wit's End reviews. A protege of Lehman Engel, Jack conducted many stars in over 100 shows in major stock productions at St. Louis, Atlanta, Dallas, Kansas City, and Pittsburgh's CLO. He recently wrote book, music and lyrics, with typical wit, for God Songs, a full length musical which was produced at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. He was manager of Rodgers & Hammerstein's Concert Library for twelve years and was Artistic Director of Ben Bagley's Painted Smiles Records. Jack was a renowned rollercoaster enthusiast, and wrote numerous published articles on the subject. He is survived by a sister Lollie Peckham of Fort Myers, FL, a brother Robert Holmes of Loveland, OH, several nieces and nephews, longtime partner of 32 years Stephen Miller and many beloved friends. A true champion, he will be missed by all.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Ready To Vote On Constitution
description: French legislators cleared the way for a referendum on the European Union's new constitution, voting in a joint session of Parliament to remove remaining legal obstacles to the ratification process. France is one of nine countries that have opted to ratify the union's core document by referendum. The remaining members have chosen to ratify the constitution by parliamentary vote. President Jacques Chirac will meet political leaders this week to decide on a date. Meanwhile, Denmark set Sept. 27 as the date for its referendum on the constitution. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Hidden Daughter Speaks Out
description: Mazarine Pingeot, left, the daughter of former President Franois Mitterrand, has published a book recalling her life as Mr. Mitterrand's hidden child. In "Bouche Cousue" ("Sealed Lips") Mrs. Pingeot, a 30-year old novelist and columnist, depicts her secretive father and anonymous life. "Officially I did not have a father," she wrote. "The pact of silence was more than a family affair. I was born out of wedlock and hidden. The shame of the republic, an affront to morality." Her existence was disclosed in 1994, two years before her father died. Hlne Fouquet (NYT)

Technology Briefing | Software: Midway Games Posts Profit
description: Midway Games reported its first profit in more than four years in the fourth quarter as it sold more mature-themed games. Net income was $17.6 million, or 19 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $27.8 million, or 52 cents a share, a year earlier, when the company had reorganization expenses, Midway said yesterday. Sales more than doubled to $77.2 million, compared with the $79.4 million expected by analysts. The company, which is based in Chicago, benefited last quarter from an emphasis on fighting and sports titles pitched to players aged 17 and older, said Michael Pachter, an analyst at Wedbush Morgan Securities. The company released a new version of its popular Mortal Kombat series in October and acquired the game's maker, Paradox Development, in November. Midway stock rose 4 cents, to $10.47.

title: CIRCUIT CITY SEVERS TIES TO AMAZON.COM
description: The electronics retail chain Circuit City Stores said yesterday that it was halting merchandise sales through Amazon.com to focus on its own Web store. Circuit City wants to concentrate on increasing sales at its Internet site rather than continue a three-and-a-half-year relationship with Amazon.com, Bill Cimino, a Circuit City spokesman, said. Separately, the company said that its chief operating officer, John W. Froman, was resigning after 18 years, effective today. The departure of Mr. Froman, 51, comes two weeks after Circuit City got a $3.25 billion takeover offer from Highfields Capital Management, a Boston hedge fund, and promoted its chief merchandising officer, Philip Schoonover, to president. Mr. Cimino said that Circuit City, which is based in Richmond, Va., would announce Mr. Froman's successor shortly.

Stephen King's Pulp Fiction
description: A new novel by Stephen King, to be published in October, will begin the second season of the Hard Case Crime line of noir thrillers, a series that is bringing back classics of the pulp paperback genre as well as publishing new pulp fiction. Mr. King's new novel, "The Colorado Kid," left, is the story of two newspaper reporters and their investigation of the death of a man on an island off Maine. It will be issued only in paperback, as are all of Hard Case Crime's novels, complete with a stylized cover reminiscent of the noir novels of old. In its first season, which runs through September, the company will publish 12 novels, seven of them reissues of out-of-print thrillers, including the forthcoming "Home Is the Sailor" by Day Keene, a well-known practitioner of the pulp genre in the 1950's. Hard Case Crime will publish 15 more books, about half of them reissues, in its second year, said Charles Ardai, editor and a founder of the series. EDWARD WYATT

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Economic Growth Slows
description: Canada's gross domestic product grew by an annualized rate of 1.7 percent in the fourth quarter, a decline from 2.9 percent in the previous period, Statistics Canada reported. The decline in the growth rate was partly a result of a 0.9 percent decline in exports, the second consecutive quarter of falling exports. Some of the loss resulted from lower shipments of forestry products because of slower housing demand in the United States, the agency said, and a strong Canadian dollar also led to flat manufacturing output. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sumitomo Raises Bad-Loan Provision
description: A Japanese bank, the Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, reclassified some of its loans as uncollectible and warned that as a result it expected a net loss of 240 billion yen ($2.3 billion) for the fiscal year ending March 31, in contrast to an earlier forecast of a profit of 180 billion yen. Sumitomo Mitsui, which is based in Tokyo, plans to take a charge of 950 billion to cover expected losses from bad loans for the year, more than the 650 billion yen it had previously forecast. Todd Zaun (NYT)

Ira Cook had filled the position on an interim basis. The chief executive, David Nagel, is expanding the company beyond hand-held computers to mobile phones that can send e-mail, hold customer information and get access to the Internet and other wireless devices.

Mideast Climate Change
description: It's not even spring yet, but a long-frozen political order seems to be cracking all over the Middle East. Cautious hopes for something new and better are stirring along the Tigris and the Nile, the elegant boulevards of Beirut, and the impoverished towns of the Gaza Strip. It is far too soon for any certainties about ultimate outcomes. In Iraq, a brutal insurgency still competes for headlines with post-election democratic maneuvering. Yesterday a suicide bomber plowed into a crowd of Iraqi police and Army recruits, killing at least 122 people -- the largest death toll in a single such bombing since the American invasion nearly two years ago. And the Palestinian terrorists who blew up a Tel Aviv nightclub last Friday underscored the continuing fragility of what has now been almost two months of steady political and diplomatic progress between Israelis and Palestinians.

description: Denying British news media reports, the producers of "Jerry Springer: The Opera," the British musical that has drawn the ire of an outspoken Christian religious group, say they still plan to mount the show on Broadway in spring 2006. John Barlow, the American spokesman for the show, said yesterday that the show had indeed lost a Broadway investor in recent weeks after Christian Voice, a small British Christian group, had protested the show's broadcasting on the BBC in January. The musical, which recently closed its money-losing commercial run in the West End, features Jesus as a character and pokes fun at organized religion. But yesterday Mr. Barlow reiterated that plans for the show's transfer remain. "While the widely covered but small scale religious protests in the U.K. surrounding 'Jerry Springer: The Opera' have not been helpful in the completion of raising the capital for the Broadway production, they have by no means brought an end to our New York plans," he said. Stephen Green, national director of Christian Voice, said that "Jerry Springer" was blasphemous and depicted Jesus as a sexual deviant who is "a little bit gay." "I certainly hope it doesn't play on Broadway," Mr. Green said, "because it brings shame on whatever nation that it's played in." The show was short of its Broadway capitalization even before the protests; in October, the producer, Jon Thoday, said he still needed $7 million of an estimated $11 million budget before the show could open in New York. JESSE McKINLEY

description: The Royal Academy of Music in London has begun a campaign to raise $2.1 million by March 31, in addition to the $1.92 million already raised, to keep in Britain what it describes "as arguably the most important violin in the history of the instrument." The violin, the Viotti Stradivari, is named for Giovanni Battista Viotti (1753-1824), the most influential violinist of his day in Europe, who first alerted the world to the power of Stradivari's model when he played it before audiences in Paris and London in the 1780's and 90's. On condition of anonymity and in lieu of paying $2.69 million in inheritance taxes on its father's estate, the family of the owner has agreed with the British tax authorities, who have valued the instrument at $6.72 million, to accept $4.02 million to enable it to remain in Britain, although a spokesman for the Royal Academy says it would undoubtedly fetch more on the open market. The Royal Academy, which already has a collection of 15 Stradivari violins on public view, says its main reason for seeking this particular instrument is that of 550 of the violins that still exist, the Viotti is extraordinary, not just for its tonal qualities but also for its almost unbelievably fresh state of preservation. It has hardly been played in 200 years. PAM KENT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POLLITT, BASIL R.
description: POLLITT--Basil R., 85, born December 26, 1919 in Huntington, WV, died February 25, 2005 in Brooklyn, NY, of a cerebral hemorrhage. Harvard 1940, Army Air Corps 1942-45, Columbia Law School 1948. Of his many legal and political activities, Basil was proudest of his service to the United Electrical Workers, his defense of Steve Nelson, Andy Onda, John Killian and others during the McCarthy era, and his many decades of work for civil liberties and social justice. His meticulously researched brief demonstrating the unconstitutionality of racial and gender discrimination in grand jury selection helped lead to the reform of the system by which grand juries are chosen. In his later years he developed housing cooperatives for people of modest means. The beloved "mayor" of Sidney Place, he enjoyed gardening, reading, researching family history, dinner at The Queen, and helping his many friends and neighbors with their legal issues. Predeceased by his wife, Leanora Levine, survived by his daughter Katha, granddaughter Sophie PollittCohen, brother Daniel, sister Betty Kenney, companion Marlyn Klee, in-laws Zeena and Harry Kassel and thirteen nieces and nephews. "While there is a lower class, I am in it; while there is a criminal element, I am of it; while there is a soul in prison, I am not free." In lieu of flowers, donations would be welcomed to the Rosenberg Fund for Children or Berea College (KY). Memorial service April 2, 2 PM at Grace Church, 50 Grace Court, Brooklyn Heights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRAUSS, GIDEON
description: STRAUSS--Gideon, 89, on February 26, 2005 in NYC. An extraordinary, multi-faceted man -banker, diplomat, art collector, musician -his rich life spanned most of the 20th century in Europe, Palestine/ Israel, and New York. Arriving in Palestine from Europe in 1935, he spent 13 years with the Anglo-Palestine Bank; he later opened the first New York branch of Bank Leumi Le-Israel. In 1948 he came to New York, and was immediately recruited to work for the new State of Israel, which he served as Consul for two years. From 1966 to 1999, he was a senior officer at Rosenthal & Rosenthal, a private finance company, where he created a subsidiary devoted to art financing. He completed and published his memoir in late 2004. Predeceased by his wife of 45 years, Renate Cale Strauss, he is survived by his devoted children Yair, Noa, Sharon (Mark), Eran (Geula) and Adin (Yoko); loving grandchildren Namane, Goapele, Nave, Eli, Ari, Naomi, Aya, and Reina; beloved partner Eva Popper; brother Peter Ettlinger; relatives and friends in Israel, Europe and the US. Plans for a memorial service will be announced later. A truly special person of immense intellectual curiosity, his death leaves a huge vacuum in the hearts of those who loved him. But we are grateful to have had the joy of sharing his life for so many years. "We shall not see his like again."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Silver Urges Stem-Cell Spending
description: Warning that California's plan to spend $3 billion on stem-cell research could lure top scientists away from New York, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, left, called yesterday for $300 million to be spent on stem-cell research over the next two years. Past legislation to promote stem-cell research has passed the Democratic-led Assembly and died in the Republican-led Senate. But Senator Nicholas A. Spano, a Westchester Republican, said that at least five other Republicans have agreed to co-sponsor his bill calling for $100 million to be spent each year over the next decade. Asked about the Assembly's proposal, Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, said, "Of course it's attractive; the question is, how do you fund it?" Michael Cooper (NYT)

description: WASHINGTON, March 1 - President Bush's drive to overhaul Social Security is in trouble, and while it is far too soon to declare it doomed, it faces obstacles on all sides.

description: WEEHAWKEN, N.J., Feb. 28 - The upscale development called Port Imperial stretches over a sliver of prime waterfront real estate here two and a half miles long, wedged between the Hudson River and the Palisades cliffs.

title: Excerpts From Opinions on Juvenile Death Penalty
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision yesterday that the Constitution bars capital punishment for crimes committed before the age of 18. The majority opinion was written by Justice Anthony M. Kennedy. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justice Clarence Thomas joined in a dissent by Justice Antonin Scalia. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote a separate dissent. The full ruling is online at nytimes.com/washington.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Holocaust Denier Expelled
description: After more than four decades in Canada, Ernst Zundel, the internationally known Holocaust denier and white supremacist, was deported to his native Germany, where he faces hate-crime charges. News agencies reported that he was immediately taken into custody on his arrival in Frankfurt last night. Denial of the Holocaust is a crime in Germany. Mr. Zundel, 65, abandoned any last-ditch effort to appeal a federal court decision last week that deemed him a threat to national security and ruled him eligible for deportation. He arrived in Canada in 1958 but was never granted citizenship. Colin Campbell (NYT)

The lead was a bust, except for some frank advice from the shopkeeper: we asked where we could find a great Indonesian restaurant, and he unflinchingly replied, "Indonesia."

title: Who'd Want Peanuts and Cracker Jack?
description: As your favorite sluggers begin to swing their bats, consider a new treat to munch after the hot dogs at the ballpark. The Cooperstown Cookie Company, in the New York town that is home to the National Baseball Hall of Fame, is selling tins of shortbread cookies printed with baseball stitching. The buttery cookies are baked at Pathfinder Village, a residential community for people with Down syndrome. The cookies are $10.99 for six, $18.99 for 12, and $143.64 for 36 packages of two cookies each (all plus shipping) from www.cooperstowncookiecompany.com, (607)435-5789, and at shops in Cooperstown and the gift shop of the Baseball Hall of Fame. Part of the proceeds go to Pathfinder Village.

description: GENEVA, March 1 - It was crisp and sunny last weekend at San Sicario, Italy perfect weather for an Alpine World Cup ski race. More than $3 million was invested in the slope to prepare it for the Winter Olympics, now less than a year away. Some 700 people bustled around the mountain in blue uniforms, tending to more than 12 miles of safety netting, or grooming the snow with rakes normally intended for sand traps on a golf course.

title: Supreme Court, 5-4, Forbids Execution in Juvenile Crime
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 - Concluding that the United States and the world have turned against the death penalty for youthful offenders, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that the Constitution categorically bars capital punishment for crimes committed before the age of 18.

title: Globally Speaking, Astoria's Best
description: Astoria may lack decent straight-ahead Chinese food, but it has a fine alternative in the Asian hybrid cuisine of JJ'S FUSION KITCHEN (37-05 31st Avenue, 718-626-8888). Among the dumpling appetizers, the edamame pot stickers ($4.50), which come floating in an ambrosial wasabi cream, and the pork gyoza ($4.50) are the best bets. Temperature control was just right: the delicately flavored udon noodle soup with seafood and vegetables ($7.95) arrived fragrant and piping hot. Crispy duck salad ($7.95) featured tender duck and fresh, cool mesclun. Even green tea ice cream, both regular ($3) and fried ($4.50), made it home intact. The sushi list is gigantic. "Sushi A" ($9.95) is a good sampler; when we asked if we should choose our own, the friendly woman on the phone said, "Don't worry, we pick the best ones." She didn't lie.

title: Are women responsible for their own low pay?
Sometimes Food Gets a Bumpy Ride
description: NEW YORK'S restaurants and shops have developed techniques and containers for getting the food to the customer as fast and as hot as possible. But for all their expertise, none of these places has ever figured out a way to keep certain foods palatable if they have to travel more than two minutes.

description: VIENNA, March 1 - The United Nations nuclear watchdog on Tuesday listed several instances where Iran had blocked investigation of its nuclear development program or failed to provide information sought by the agency.

title: A World of Taste in the East Village
description: Freeze! Put your hands in the air and step away from the burrito. Don't you think it's time you tried something new? How about dinner down Venezuela way from CARACAS AREPA BAR (91 East Seventh Street, 212-228-5062). The Pabelln Criollo ($11.95) -- rice, black beans, braised beef and fried sweet plantains -- is as good a one-plate meal as anyone is bringing up to your apartment, the restaurant's arepas are justifiably well regarded (if slightly less crispy after the bike ride from the kitchen), and desserts are uniformly excellent.

description: In the middle of a snowstorm on a deserted Queens street early yesterday, an intoxicated teenager punched and kicked to death a 52-year-old Guyanese immigrant returning home from his job as a school bus mechanic, the police said.

World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Drug Maker Expects Higher Profit
description: The newly merged drug company Sanofi-Aventis reported an 18 percent increase in profit, beating expectations. The company, which was formed by the union of Sanofi-Synthlabo and Aventis last year, said net profit, excluding revamping charges, was 5.2 billion euros ($6.9 billion). Sanofi-Aventis is now the world's third-largest drug maker behind Pfizer and GlaxoSmithKline. The company said it would reap 1.6 billion euros in cost savings by the end of 2006 from the merger. Heather Timmons (NYT)

description: With Martha Stewart's release from prison a few days away, the longtime publisher of her company's magazines has resigned.

description: IN the 1950's, not the most hallowed era in the kitchen, cookbooks often advised readers to add dashes of color to their cooking "for interest." I've often been wary of such advice, not least because too much attention to the decoration of food -- the insistence on a garnish, for instance -- seems to wander into what my maternal grandfather called the school of "landscape cookery."

title: New drugs fuel Sanofi profit rise

In New York, the World Is Brought to Your Door
description: YOU can see them in any kind of weather and at almost any time of day. On bicycles that look sturdy enough to withstand a collision with a tank, the seats often wrapped in old plastic bags, they surge ahead through snow and rain, heat and, yes, especially gloom of night. No marble carving will ever exalt their heroic efforts, yet they are fixtures of almost any residential neighborhood in New York City. They deliver dinner, and sometimes lunch and breakfast, too. Yet within the reinforced bags dangling from their handlebars, the prepared dishes in their plastic, microwave-proof containers convey far more than a meal. They speak of the evolving stew of cultures that simmers throughout the five boroughs. They speak of the typical New Yorker's contradictory character: brash but overworked, stoic but requiring rewards, impatient but willing to wait. Most of all they embody what many New Yorkers regard as an inalienable right: to have meals of almost any conceivable sort delivered to their door, hot, fragrant and appetizing.

title: Empty House on the Prairie

title: Best Eating-In on the Upper West Side
description: MONSOON (435 Amsterdam Avenue, at 81st; 212-580-8686) was a clear winner among Vietnamese spots, with its crisp, spiced lobster rolls, Hue shrimp dumplings, roast duck, prawns with black pepper and stir-fried string beans. Except for the classic pho soup, it's best to avoid complicated Vietnamese dishes that involve noodles or crepes. At Monsoon the pho noodles, meat and garnishes are packed separately to add at will, but plan to reheat the broth first.

description: PARIS, March 1 - All the talk about the new volume in Milan underscored just how little there was to say. The new volumes turned out to be the old volumes. But here nothing obscures the fact that fashion's direction now comes from a handful of young designers who use the old principle of line as a modern weapon. The linear coats in pale camel wool and natural fox that opened the Balenciaga show on Tuesday owed everything to that belief, and to Nicolas Ghesquiere's determination to build a successful brand.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Army Accused Of Killing Peasants
description: Human rights groups are calling for an investigation into allegations that Colombian soldiers killed eight villagers in northern San Jos de Apartado late last month, including a 6-year-old girl and a 2-year-old boy. The United Nations said gunmen also killed a leader of the town, which residents call a "peace community," presumably under the pretext that he and others were colluding with Marxist rebels. A local Roman Catholic priest, as well as divergent rights groups, said the army's 17th Brigade appeared responsible, an accusation denied by Defense Minister Jorge Alberto Uribe. Juan Forero (NYT)

description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 1 - The last time Victor Zambrano pitched in a game, his outing ended in the clubhouse at Coors Field in Denver, where he slid white rosary beads off his neck and bowed his head in prayer.

title: CIRCUIT CITY NAMES RETAIL STORES PRESIDENT
description: Circuit City Stores, the electronics chain, promoted George D. Clark Jr. to president of its retail stores division and named two other executives to senior positions. One of the executives, Douglas T. Moore, was appointed senior vice president and chief merchandising officer, and the other, Ronald G. Cuthbertson, was named senior vice president. The three will assume the duties of the chief operating officer, John W. Froman, who resigned on Monday.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Labor Chief Who Led Crippling Strike Is Arrested
description: Carlos Ortega, left, the fiery former head of Venezuela's largest labor confederation, has been arrested in Caracas and charged with treason and inciting rebellion for leading a two-month antigovernment oil strike that devastated the economy two years ago, the government announced. Opposition leaders cast the arrest as a rights violation, but the government said Mr. Ortega had violated the law by leading a strike that was intended to end the presidency of Hugo Chvez. By the time the strike ended in February of 2003, it had virtually stopped crude oil shipments from the country and cost it an estimated $4 billion. Mr. Ortega fled the country and received asylum in Costa Rica. But Costa Rica later canceled his asylum, forcing him to return to Venezuela last summer and go into hiding. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUBELMANN, BARTON GREEN
description: GUBELMANN--Barton Green. Died in Palm Beach on Saturday, February 26, 2005. Born on the memorable date of December 12, 1916, she becaue unforgettable to all who knew her. Raised as an only child in Jacksonville, Florida, she had a life-long love of the ocean. A passionate shell-collector, she was a well-known competitor on the high seas. Barton held the world record for a 50 pound Dolphin caught on 20 lb test line in 1960, and was a founding member of the International Women's Fishing Association. She enjoyed competitive sailing with her husband. Walter S. Gubelmann, whom she married in 1941. Together, they successfully campaigned their yacht Windigo, as well as successfully defending the America's Cup in 1964 with Constellation. Mrs. Gubelmann was educated in Art at the Ringling School in Sarasota, FL, as well as the Traphagen School in New York City. Her sure eye resulted in more awards in Flower Shows, Croquet Tournaments (she is an inductee in the Croquet Hall of Fame) and Skeet Shooting. But it was her tremendous sense of humor, love of her fellow man, and her unending generosity that made her the true champion she was. Whether in Long Island, Palm Beach or Newport, she was at home, entertaining her many friends, often with parties that are still remembered today. Besides being the consummate hostess, she was a member of the Colonial Dames, the Mayflower Society, The New York Yacht Club, the Garden Club of Palm Beach, The Bath and Tennis Club, The Everglades Club, and the Spouting Beach Rock Association. Barton was beloved by all who knew her, especially her family. She is survived by her sons, William & James, their wives, Shelley and Kate, five grandchildren, Marjorie G, Raein, Wyeth S. Gubelmann, Tantivy G. Bostwick, Phoebe G. Gubelmann, James G. Gubelmann, and one great-grandchild, Cyrus P. Raein. The funeral will be held on Friday, March 4, 2005, at 11:00 AM, at The Episcopal Church of Bethesda-By-TheSea. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in memory of Barton G. Gubelmann to the Society of the Four Arts for the Garden Restoration Project.

Directors and officers holding 28 percent of the company's stock have agreed to the sale, Blue Martini, based in San Mateo, Calif., said yesterday. (Bloomberg News)

Its interior is a pastiche of styles from successive remodeling efforts, and its exterior has a fortresslike appearance that betrays its 1961 origins.

Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Replacement Surrogate Judge Is Named
description: Albert Tomei, a longtime justice of the New York State Supreme Court, will handle Surrogate Court matters in Brooklyn while the elected surrogate judge appeals a ruling removing him from the bench, court officials said yesterday. Last month, the Commission on Judicial Conduct voted to oust Surrogate Michael H. Feinberg, contending that he improperly awarded millions of dollars in legal fees to a longtime friend. The judge asked the Court of Appeals to review the ruling, a process that is expected to last at least six months. Justice Tomei was appointed by Jonathan Lippman, the state's chief administrative judge, who said in a telephone interview that Justice Tomei was "widely respected and admired for his integrity and for his judicial scholarship." Leslie Eaton (NYT)

World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: 3 Held In Killing Of Journalist
description: Ukrainian investigators arrested three high-ranking security officers in the murder of a prominent journalist in 2000. President Viktor A. Yushchenko, who has repeatedly vowed to solve the case, announced that the suspects included the killers of Georgy Gongadze, whose death became a symbol of crime and corruption during the presidency of Leonid D. Kuchma. Mr. Yushchenko did not identify them and offered few other details, adding that the investigators were still working to solve "the most important thing: who organized and ordered the murder," according to news reports. A spokesman for the prosecutor general's office, Yuri V. Boychenko, said in a telephone interview that the suspects included a general and two colonels working from the Interior Ministry, but he declined to elaborate. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Staying Hot in Union Square
description: Can fried chicken travel with its crustiness intact? At ACME BAR & GRILL (9 Great Jones Street, at Lafayette Street; 212-420-1934), which delivered in 28 minutes, the answer was yes. The chicken ($13.95) was moist, the skin crunchy and the temperature hot. Barbecued St. Louis ribs ($14.95) were smoky and tender, lightly dabbed with a piquant sauce that was subtly spiced and not cloying. The accompanying side of collard greens was al dente, with a hint of Tabasco, and the corn bread moist.

description: WASHINGTON, March 1 - Walter Anderson, the telephone entrepreneur accused of being the biggest tax cheat in American history, started playing with his name when he was 12 years old.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Unemployment Rate Steady
description: Japan's unemployment rate held steady at a six-year low of 4.5 percent in January, unchanged from December, as the economy added 470,000 jobs, the government said. The rate was slightly higher than the 4.4 percent forecast by economists. Employment conditions have been steadily improving in Japan and corporate profits have shown solid increases. The government previously reported an unemployment rate of 4.4 percent for December but revised that figure to 4.5 percent. The unemployment rates in December and January were the lowest since January 1999. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Pope Can Speak, Cardinal Says
description: Portraying a pope engaged in church business despite his illness, a top cardinal visited Pope John Paul II in the hospital and reported him "alert" and even able to converse in Italian and German. Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, the German prelate responsible for church doctrine, said he conferred with the pope on unspecified church work. "He will work on the issues that I have brought to him," the cardinal said. "I am happy that the Holy Father is mentally fully present, and also able to say essential things with his own words." The extent to which the pope has been able speak has been in question since he underwent an emergency tracheotomy last Thursday after being taken to the Gemelli hospital complex in Rome for second time in a month. Ian Fisher (NYT)

description: CNN has shown a commercial for Grey Goose vodka, making it the first national cable TV news network to carry liquor advertising.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Discloses Plans For Dual-Core Chips
description: Intel, the largest semiconductor company, yesterday outlined an ambitious schedule for introducing as many as 15 next-generation dual-core chips, beginning in the second quarter with the release of its first desktop dual-core chip, code-named Smithfield. Dual-core technology essentially puts two processing engines on a single piece of silicon. The high-end desktop chip will run at 3.2 gigahertz, slightly slower than today's equivalent single-core chip, but will perform some tasks in as little as half the time. By the end of 2006, roughly 70 percent of Intel's desktop chips and 85 percent of its server chips will be based on dual-core technology, according to company executives speaking at Intel's semiannual developers' conference in San Francisco. title: Arts, Briefly; Actors Ratify Contract
description: It's final. The tentative three-year contract that includes pay raises and more money for health plans for the two major Hollywood actors unions was overwhelmingly ratified on Monday night after nationwide mail-in voting ended. The 119,000 union members representing the combined membership of the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists voted to accept the contract by a margin of 76.5 percent to 23.5, said Seth Oster, a spokesman for the Screen Actors Guild. "We're very pleased that we were able to achieve some very important gains for working actors, and at the same time keep performers working for another three years uninterrupted," he said. The tentative deal with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers was reached on Jan. 20. Although the actors had hoped to win a larger share of DVD sales, the contract includes a 9 percent minimum pay raise over three years and the most employer money ever contributed to the unions' health and pension plans. There will also be 75,000 new jobs, the highest increase in 13 years, for background actors (known as extras). The contract will run from July 1, 2005, through June 30, 2008. CATHERINE BILLEY

description: JORDAN--Cheryl Faithe, age 57, a flight attendant, died January 4, 2005 of breast cancer. She graduated from CCNY in 1969 where she made Dean's list and became the first black cheerleader, then cheerleader captain for the basketball team. She earned a Master's degree in French from Columbia University in 1971 on full fellowship. She spent a joyous half year in Paris, then joined Pan Am, making lifelong friends around the world, especially in Australia. In Sydney she became an enthusiastic fan of surf life-saving and was made a member of the Bronte Surf Life-Saving Club, then an unusual honor for a woman. She attended the Melbourne Cup and briefly shared ownership of a race horse. For her family, she was a dedicated and elegant caregiver, arranging flights at need, providing escort herself. Our beloved Cherrie-in Oz, affectionately Chezza-leaves her father G. Whitte and wife Amy, brother Achille Edward, sisters Blanche (Eugene) and Naomi, in-laws Francine and Elliott, nephew David, nieces Elizabeth, Miriam and Tanya. Hundreds of friends she cherished as family have said farewell in a seaside service in Sydney, and family and beloved friends held services in Seattle and Oklahoma where she was born December 10, 1947, and is buried. Other friends close to her heart will celebrate a final farewell in Honolulu. She leaves a life she loved to join our dear mother, Olivia Hebert Jordan. May Heaven grant them joy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GENET, LEON M.
description: GENET--Leon M., of Short Hills, NJ, a commercial real estate broker who dedicated the majority of his life to supporting the arts, cancer research and a variety of Jewish concerns died February 27 in New York City of heart failure. He was 74 years old. The son of Russian immigrants, Mr. Genet graduated from Syracuse University in 1953 and served as an Army Lieutenant during the Korean War. Mr. Genet's philanthropic activities started in memory of his first wife, Sue Ann Mackta Genet, with the establishment of the Genet Gallery of Textile Arts at Slocum Hall at Syracuse University. Designed to provide students with a link to internationally prominent figures from retailing, fashion, costuming and the decorative arts. He created the Sue Ann Genet Lecture Series. He was a recipient of the Chancellor's Medal at Syracuse University and the Syracuse University Award for Outstanding Service. Mr. Genet's support for Jewish causes ranged from being an active leader for AIPAC to serving as Chairman of the Industry and Commerce Division of Israel Bonds. He was also on the Board of Directors of the Rabbinical College of America. More recently he and his wife, Eileen, established the Eileen Genet Ovarian Cancer Research Fund at Memorial Sloan - Kettering Hospital, New York City. The focus of the fund is on early detection. In addition to his wife Eileen, Mr. Genet is survived by a sister, Sarah Fisch of West Orange, NJ; a brother and sister-in-law, Gerald and Randy of Manhattan; three daughters, Pam Barsh of Somers, NY, Jill Waller of Manhattan and Wendy Kaplan of Millburn, NJ; two stepchildren, Pamela and Jonathan; and ten grandchildren, Sueann, Jack, Sidney, Charlie, Myles, Jordana, Randy, Zachary, Sophie and Caroline. Funeral services at Bernheim-ApterKreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ on Wednesday, March 2 at 11:00AM. For more information please call 1-800-938-6372. GENET--Leon M. To Leon, my adoring and affectionate husband, you have been my devoted soulmate and my champion for eighteen years. Our time together has been wonderful. I cherished every single moment of it. I love you and will miss you dearly. You will remain in my hearts and thoughts forever. Eileen GENET--Leon M. We mourn the loss of our dearly loved, longtime friend. He was an uncle to our children, Mark, Meg & Irwin. His tremendous warmth and perpetual good humor will be sorely missed but remembered always. Our deepest condolences to his bereaved family. May beautiful memories comfort those who mourn his passing. Marian and Robert Baum GENET--Leon. We will sorely miss your passion for friends, family and food. Your fundraising for worthwhile causes has made the world a better place. Our sincerest condolences to your family and your beloved Eileen. Rosalind and Gene Glaser GENET--Leon. One of the best friends and human beings we have ever known. Our hearts are heavy. Our condolences go out to Eileen and the entire family. Dear Leon--beloved by all. Sandy and Danny Teitelbaum and Family GENET--Leon. A loving relationship of almost 10 years. We will treasure the times we shared with our children, grandchildren and each other. Love, Leslie and Jim GENET--Leon. A cherished man who defined friendship and family. For all of us who love and were loved by him. Jayne, Barry, Dan, Adrienne and Jeff Mackta

title: Arts, Briefly; The Exclusive Soprano
description: Apparently even the soprano Deborah Voigt, above right, can be overexposed in the Twin Cities. A small but venerable concert organization in St. Paul, Minn., the Schubert Club, was forced to cancel Ms. Voigt's recital at the Ordway Center on Nov. 15 because she was already scheduled to sing with the Minnesota Orchestra in Minneapolis seven months later. Ms. Voigt has an exclusivity clause with the orchestra -- meaning, no other Voigt performance within 50 miles next season -- and the orchestra decided to enforce the clause after the Schubert Club announced her appearance nine days ago. The Star Tribune of Minneapolis first reported the flap. It did not matter to the orchestra that its Voigt dates, in May, consist of concert performances of Puccini's "Tosca," a far cry from a simple recital. A spokeswoman for the orchestra, Gwen Pappas, said it typically has exclusivity clauses with major artists because of the small size of the market, to protect ticket sales. "She was such a linchpin of our season," Ms. Pappas said. "We were really banking on the marquee value of her name." As for how the mixup happened, Bruce Carlson, president of the Schubert Club, said that he had a signed contract with Ms. Voigt and that her managers at Columbia Artists admitted overlooking the exclusivity clause. A spokesman for Ms. Voigt, Albert Imperato, denied that a contract was ever signed with the Schubert Club and said the two sides had only discussed the possibility of her performance. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: Arts, Briefly; Approving 'Private Ryan'
description: The Federal Communications Commission has concluded that ABC did not violate indecency regulations when it broadcast the film "Saving Private Ryan," right, last year. The commission said it had received thousands of comments, most of them critical, about the broadcasting of the film on Veterans Day. According to Nielsen Media Research, 159 of ABC's 225 affiliated stations showed the movie, which graphically depicts World War II carnage and includes vulgarities. But the film was unavailable to viewers in Dallas, Atlanta and dozens of other cities. Under its licensing agreement with DreamWorks, the studio that produced the Steven Spielberg film, ABC was obligated to show the movie in its entirety and without censoring. It did, however, carry warnings about the film's content. ABC said that broadcasting the film was a timely tribute to the sacrifices and valor of those who served during the war. "In light of the overall context in which this material is presented," the commission said, it determined that "it was not indecent or profane." JOHN FILES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUEWEISS, PHYLLIS RUTH
description: BLUEWEISS--Phyllis Ruth. A 50 year resident of Long Island died peacefully on February 26, 2005. Born in Brooklyn, NY on June 22, 1924, the eldest of three daughters of Benjamin and Marion Schwartz. An adventurous teenager and accomplished pianist she traveled from Crown Heights to Upper Manhattan to attend the High School of Music and Art. In 1944 she enlisted in the United States Coast Guard, attended boot camp in West Palm Beach, FL and became a Seaman Second Class. Due to a punctuation error, she was stationed in Seattle, WA rather than her intended first choice--Washington, DC. A stylish beauty, prior to enlisting in the service she worked at Macy's 34th Street taking foreign dignitaries on personal tours of the "world's greatest department store." After being honorably discharged, Mrs. Blueweiss returned to New York, married twice and had four children. She settled on Long Island in 1955 where she and her husband Murray lived and raised their three children; her eldest daughter Susan died in 1994. A devoted mother, she returned to the work force as a customer service manager in order to help put her children through college and law school. In the spring of 2004, at the age of 80, Phyllis was hired by her son James, a TV producer, to be a casting consultant on a new TV pilot he was producing called, "Live In the East...It's Comedy Tonight!" A talented cook and musician, a devoted wife, mother, sister, aunt, cousin and grandmother she is survived by her husband Murray, her children, Michael, Nancy and James, her sisters Penny Rothchild and Betty Reich, her grandsons, Joshua, Benjamin and David and many loving nephews, nieces, cousins and friends. Donations may be made to the Hospice Care Network in Westbury, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HANDLEMAN, JOSEPH
description: HANDLEMAN--Joseph. The Officers, Board of Directors and Staff of American Red Magen David for Israel (ARMDI) deeply mourn the passing of our Honorary Chairman at the age of 99. Mr. Handleman served as President, Chairman and Chairman of the International Committee of Magen David Adom. Through his leadership the people of Israel have modern emergency medical and blood services. Joe would often say "You have to take advantage of all of life's challenges." This perspective coupled with his love of the Jewish people and Israel led to the building of the ARMDIMagen David Adom Blood Services Center, the only such center in Israel. In 1985 Mr. Handleman and his wife Sally, commissioned sculptor Nathan Rapoport to do the powerful "Brotherhood of Man" sculpture which today is in the Handleman Plaza in front of the ARMDI-Magen David Adom National Blood Services Center in Ramat, Gan, Israel. Mr. Handleman was an internationally known management and sales consultant. He was a pioneer in the distribution of health and beauty products to the supermarket industry. Handleman Company was founded in 1934 in Detroit, Michigan and today remains an industry leader. For more than 25 years his close contact, wise counsel and astute judgment helped American Red Magen David for Israel become the main diaspora supporter of Magen David Adom Israel. It was his vision that has enabled ARMDI and the American Jewish community to help insure safety for all the citizens of Israel. Mr. Handleman is survived by his wife of 69 years, Sally ( Kabaker); his children Joan Sadoff (Dr. Robert), Joyce Mueller (Hans) and Lynn Handleman. Grandchildren Debra Sadoff (Dr. Richard Seidelman), David Sadoff ( Dr. Claudia), Dr. Julie Sadoff (Dr. Malek Moazzan - Doulat), Sherry Hanck ( Brian), Christian Mueller, Marissa Mueller, Scott Handleman. Great Grandchildren; Jessica and Eric Seidelman, Haley, Rachel and Jacob Sadoff, Azad and Maya Dulat and CassidyHanck. His brother and business partner, David Handleman of Detroit survives him as well. May his memory be for a blessing. At the family's request, contributions may be made to American Red Magen David for Israel, 888 Seventh Avenue, New York, New York, 10106. Baruch Dayan Emet. Mark Lebow, President. ARMDI -American Red Magen David for Israel Stuart Jackson, Chairman International Committee of Magen David Adom Daniel R. Allen, Executive Vice President Benjamin Saxe, Executive Vice President Emeritus

title: Arts, Briefly; Silencing the Playwright
description: The meaning in Harold Pinter's plays can sometimes be unclear but the playwright was very clear when he said on BBC radio that he would not be writing any more plays. In an interview on Monday evening on the arts program "Front Row," Mr. Pinter, left, 74, said: "I've stopped writing plays. I've written 29 plays. My energies are going in different directions. I'm certainly writing a lot of poetry, and I'm using a lot of energy, more specifically about political states of affairs, which I think are very, very worrying as things stand." His last play was "Remembrance of Things Past" in 2000, an adaptation with Di Trevis of Marcel Proust's classic. Recently he was named the recipient of the Wilfred Owen Poetry Award, for poetry opposing the Iraq war, which will be presented on March 18 in London. PAM KENT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MONTGOMERY, GRATIA ''TOPSY''
description: MONTGOMERY -- Gratia "Topsy", of Round Hill in South Dartmouth, MA, died Sunday, February 20, 2005 at her home. She was 77 years old. Topsy was known for her boundless enthusiasm and generosity, which she spread over a vast array of charitable organizations which included Southeastern Massachusetts University, The Animal Rescue League, St. Luke's Hospital, The New Bedford Whaling Museum, Dartmouth Natural Resource Trust, and Woodshole Oceanographic Institute. Born and raised in New York City, she was the daughter of the late Alan G. Rinehart and Gratia Houghton Rinehart. Topsy came to South Dartmouth for the summers at a young age and eventually settled here. While often traveling the world on various philanthropic quests, she always looked forward to returning to the peace and serenity of South Dartmouth. A long - time friend, supporter and Honorary Trustee of the Woodshole Oceanographic Institute, Topsy had been affiliated with WHOI for more than three decades. While involved, she supported a number of the Institute's education programs, helping dozens of summer student fellows, graduate students, and post-doctoral fellows launch oceanographic careers. Her commitment to coastal research was recognized by WHOI when she was awarded the Cecil H. Green Award for outstanding individual contributions to oceanographic research. Topsy came from a distinguished family. She was the greatgreat - granddaughter of Amory Houghton Sr., founder of Corning, Inc.; granddaughter of mystery writer Mary Roberts Rinehart; and daughter of the late Alan G. Rinehart, former editor and producer for Paramount Pictures. In addition, her late uncle, Arthur Houghton Jr., owned the historic Wye Plantation on Maryland's Eastern Shore. She is survived by her son and daughter-in-law, Peter and Nancy Allatt of Greenwich, CT, three grandchildren, one step-granddaughter and two greatgrandchildren, two nieces and one nephew. Her memorial service will take place on Saturday the 19th of March at 11AM in Grace Episcopal Church, 422 County St., New Bedford, MA, followed by a reception at the Wamsutta Club across the street from the church. Information: Wilson Chapel, 479 County St., New Bedford. Remembrances may be made in her name to the Taiping Foundation, which she founded in 1964, C/O Market St. Trust, 80 E. Market Street, Corning, NY 14830.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUELER, HANS G.
description: BUELER--Hans G. of Somers, New York, died peacefully on March 1, 2005, after a long illness. He is survived by his devoted wife of 20 years, "Pat" Bueler and by his son, Roland G. Bueler of New York City. He was born in Amriswil, Switzerland, the youngest of four children of Martha and Gustav Bueler, an architect. In 1935, Hans left for Cochin, India, thereby beginning a 37-year affiliation with Volkart Bros., a distinguished Swiss commodity firm operative worldwide. After 15 years in India, Hans joined the firm's principal office in Winterthur, Switzerland and between 1965 and 1972 was president and chief executive of Volkart USA. Hans was a man of great integrity and strength of character, who actively embraced every aspect of life. In Switzerland he is presently survived by seven nieces and nephews. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, New York on Thursday from 2-5PM. Private interment will be at Putnam Cemetery, Greenwich, CT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GASS, DR. J. DONALD
description: GASS--Dr. J. Donald. The Macula Foundation, Inc. mourns the passing of an esteemed colleague and friend, Dr. J. Donald Gass. During his illustrious career, Don made numerous clinical and scientific contributions making him one of the most respected experts on diseases of the retina and macula. His career resulted in many honors and awards of merit, including the establishment of the Gass Medal given for outstanding contributions to macular diseases by the prestigious Macula Society; he was the first recipient in 1987. To his patients, he was an extraordinary healer and restorer of sight; to his students, he was a teacher with wisdom, wit and warmth; and to his colleagues, he was a master of original and innovative thinking -a leader who helped shape the specialty of retinal diseases. He was the ultimate scholar and motivator whose work will be a source of inspiration in perpetuity. He is survived by his wife, MargyAnn, their four children and their grandchildren. Dr. Lawrence A. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Motorman Reported Shuttle Crash

It was not clear last night whether the radio in the train operator's cab, which is supposed to allow communication with dispatchers, was functioning. The motorman lost control of the four-car train moments before the accident, which damaged the front car and temporarily reduced service on the crosstown shuttle. Transit officials said they were still investigating whether the operator fell asleep or somehow lost consciousness before the accident. title: Arts, Briefly; Kennedy Center Festivals
description: The Kennedy Center in Washington has announced that its next season will include a country music festival in partnership with the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, and a festival of China's arts involving about 600 of that country's musicians, dancers, actors, puppeteers and acrobats. The 2005-6 season will include dance, theater, classical music and jazz. It will also include special productions for young audiences, reflecting what the center's president, Michael M. Kaiser, called "a dichotomy of classic and new works." The center's $5 million Chinese festival, with performances by the National Ballet of China, the Hong Kong Chinese Orchestra, the Beijing People's Art Theater and the China National Peking Opera Company, will take place in October. The country music festival, with performances by Vince Gill and Emmylou Harris, below, will run from March 23, 2006, through April 16. The center will celebrate the 75th anniversary of the National Symphony Orchestra with an opening night-gala on Sept. 24, featuring the pianist Emanuel Ax, the violinist Itzhak Perlman and the cellist Yo-Yo Ma. In "All Shook Up," which is set in the mid-50's, a hip-swiveling, guitar-playing Elvis-like character roars into a dreary Midwestern town on his motorcycle, and Mr. Rockwell has designed the town to respond. "The buildings move and pick up the energy of Elvis, and have a hiplike sway to them," he said, as does a derelict structure on the town's abandoned fairground, above.

title: Arts, Briefly; Omarion Bumps Grammy Winners

B2K itself -- singers of "Bump, Bump, Bump" and players in "You Got Served," a movie in the time-honored dance duel tradition -- rose no higher than No. 2 during its brief lifetime. Charles's "Genius Loves Company" (Concord) and Green Day's "American Idiot" (Reprise) had big sales spikes after the Grammys, but last week each sold about 50 percent less: "Genius Loves Company" is at No. 2 with 110,000 sales, and "American Idiot" reached No. 3 with 109,000. Tori Amos's "Beekeeper" (Epic) is at No. 5 in its first week of release, with sales of 83,000. But all eyes are on today's release of 50 Cent's "Massacre" (Interscope), which is poised to top next week's chart; if the strength of his last album's 11 million sales around the world wasn't enough, the recent news of gunfire amid the excommunication of his former associate the Game should provide plenty of publicity. title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia Gains Market Share
description: Nokia, the world's biggest mobile phone maker, increased its market share for a third straight quarter with lower-priced phones, the research firm Gartner said yesterday. Nokia's global share rose to 33 percent in the fourth quarter from 30.9 percent in the previous quarter, Gartner said in an e-mail statement. The company, based in Espoo, Finland, cut prices and introduced new clamshell-style phones after its global market share declined to a five-year low at the beginning of last year. Motorola regained the No.2 position from the Samsung Electronics Company. The share of Motorola rose to 16.3 percent from 13.4 percent in the third quarter, Gartner said.

title: Arts, Briefly; NBC Corrects an 'Exclusive'
description: "NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams" led its Tuesday evening broadcast with the report, billed as exclusive, that the presiding judge in the trial of Saddam Hussein had been assassinated. Jim Miklaszewski, NBC's chief Pentagon correspondent, reported that "35-year-old Raid Juhi was apparently gunned down today as he left his home in Baghdad." But the report, though attributed to United States officials, was erroneous: it was another member of the special tribunal who had been killed along with his son, a tribunal lawyer. NBC learned of the error at 7:05 and corrected it during the 7 p.m. broadcast. In an e-mail response to a question about the correction, Barbara Levin, NBC News's spokeswoman, said: "We got the information from multiple high-level sources who confirmed the story's accuracy. It was wrong, and we corrected it immediately beginning with the 7 p.m. feed." Meanwhile, at Fox News, Brit Hume, host of "Special Report," began the show's 6:45 p.m. panel discussion segment with the same erroneous news. Mr. Hume cited "U.S. government sources." Reached by phone, a Fox spokesman confirmed that the report was corrected on the Fox News Web site at 7:45 and at 7:52 during a later broadcast. "Was it a government source?" the spokesman, Paul Schur, said. "Yes. Did they get it wrong? Yes." Asked about NBC's exclusive claim to the story, he added: "You know how it works. These guys are always working on the same thing." JOEL TOPCIK

title: My Little Chickadee
description: Bird feeders across much of America are mobbed with black-capped chickadees at this time of year. Can you tell them apart, one by one? Probably not; it's hard enough to distinguish male from female in this species, let alone recognize individuals in a flock. But scientists are starting to suggest that if we look closely enough, we can distinguish birds of a single species by personality. A team of Dutch scientists, testing a European relative of the chickadee, has found that some birds are shy and others are bold, broad personality differences that have a genetic foundation. This finding doesn't erode the basic differences between Homo sapiens and Poecile atricapillus (the black-capped chickadee). But it substantially enlarges the similarities.

title: A Force for Good

This is worth bearing in mind, especially now that President Bush's request for $82 billion in emergency military spending has re-opened the argument over Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld's longstanding plan for remaking the armed forces as a leaner, more flexible military machine.

The Green Goddess of English Gardens
description: HATFIELD, England - AS a child in Ireland in the 1930's, Mollie Wyndham-Quin tended a plot just large enough for a schoolgirl to manage. Like many gardens geared to pint-size toilers, its contents were Lilliputian: no sunflowers, no gunnera, no towering Asiatic lilies tethered to stakes. Instead she cultivated a rock garden of alpine plants, tenacious little ground-hugging perennials that grow agonizingly slowly in rocky mountain crevices, plants whose tiny succulentlike leaves glisten as if sugar dusted and that sprout spiky flowers in raucous fireworks colors.

Most of the men were from Central America, Mexico, the Dominican Republic and Haiti. Their arrests were part of an effort to arrest and deport illegal immigrants guilty of serious crimes. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HANDELSMAN, DR. LEONARD
description: HANDELSMAN--Dr. Leonard. 59, of Durham, NC, the son of the late Pauline Weingott and Hyman Handelsman of NYC, died on February 27, 2005 at Duke University Medical Center. He was Clinical Professor at Duke University in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Medicine, Medical Director of the Duke Addictions Program, and Co-Principal Investigator of the North Carolina Node, National Institute on Drug Abuse Clinical Trails Network. He established mental health services at the Triangle Residential Options for Substance Abusers in Durham, NC. He was a practicing psychiatrist. He was formerly a professor of Psychiatry at Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, the Director of the Division of Chemical Dependence, and Medical Director of the Drug Dependency Treatment Program at the Bronx VA Medical Center. He was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School and Columbia College (Phi Beta Kappa) in NYC. He attended the University of Chicago graduate school in Sociology and received his MD degree from Albert Einstein College of Medicine in NYC and was inducted into AOA honor society. He completed post-graduate training at Albert Einstein College of Medicine in Psychiatry and Mt. Sinai School of Medicine as a Fellow in Substance Abuse. He was a Fulbright and Woodrow Wilson Scholar, Falk Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association and received the Heiman Research Prize at the Mt. Sinai School of Medicine. Dr. Handelsman is survived by his life partner, Dr. Gregory Strayhorn, five children, cousins, numerous friends, colleagues, associates, and patients. Observance, Sunday, March 6, 2005, 1 p.m., Carolina Club, University of North Carolina campus, Chapel Hill, N.C. Send contributions to the Triangle Residential Options for Substance Abusers, Attn: Keith Arden, 1820 James St., Durham, NC 27707, 919-419-1059.

description: FITZGERALD--Joseph Patrick. On March 2, 2005. Brooklyn native and W.W. II naval veteran (USS Terror). Retired Trainmaster of 39 years with the NYC MTA. Loving and devoted husband of Eileen (nee Hassett) for 49 years. Beloved father of Beth, John, Regina, Denis, Eileen Hall, Mary, Thomas and Joseph. Fun-loving Papa to Matthew, Cassidy, Corrina, Alex, Joseph and Jeffrey. Dear brother of Jack, Mary O'Leary, Nancy Hartmann, his late twin Thomas, Robert, and Kathleen Olsen Wall. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9PM, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial on Monday, 9:30AM, Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church. Interment in Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Repeat Of Summer Job Program
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund announced yesterday that for the third consecutive year it would create 1,000 summer jobs for low-income teenagers in New York City. The emergency program, which will begin on July 5, responds to continued prospective cuts in government-financed summer jobs. Many of the employees will work in day camps, summer schools and other programs for children. Financing of $1.5 million will come from the Neediest Cases Fund endowment.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Arrest In 2002 Hotel Bombing
description: The police in Karachi arrested a man sentenced to death in absentia in 2003 for his role in organizing a car bombing at the Sheraton Hotel that killed 11 French engineers and 3 Pakistanis in 2002. The arrest of the man, Muhammad Sohail, came after a shootout with the police. Mr. Sohail, said to belong to the militant Islamic group Harkat Jihad-e-Islami, is also suspected of involvement in the kidnapping and beheading of Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter, in 2002 and an assassination attempt on President Pervez Musharraf in 2003. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Officer Admits Beating Homeless Man
description: A Metropolitan Transportation Authority police officer who was accused of beating a homeless man outside Pennsylvania Station last year pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to assault, a misdemeanor. The officer, Michael Koenig, has resigned from the force and has agreed to perform 200 hours of community service. In court yesterday, Mr. Koenig admitted hitting the man, Maurice Cherry, in the head and intending to cause him harm. A sergeant, Joseph Camean, was also charged. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

description: HONG KONG, March 2 - The expected resignation of Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's unpopular chief executive, may gratify some pro-democracy protesters but is far from a victory for democracy, politicians and experts said Wednesday.

title: Designer Tweaks the Old And Creates Some New
description: Jens Risom set his sights on furniture design at age 6 and, as a young man in the 1930's, came to the United States from Denmark to investigate the American Modern furniture scene. "There wasn't one," he discovered. Settling in New York, Mr. Risom designed a few pieces of his own and soon afterward met Hans Knoll, whose first furniture line carried 15 Risom designs. Today Mr. Risom's early Modern furniture is included in the permanent collections of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum and the Museum of Modern Art.

Now, young, little-known billionaires who manage hedge funds are roiling the art market, using the vast pools of capital they have accumulated to snatch up some of the world's most recognizable images.

title: The Musical Odyssey of Min Xiao-Fen
description: In his well-known Norton lectures at Harvard in 1973, "The Unanswered Question," Leonard Bernstein asked, "Whither music in our time?" The influences of Schoenberg and Stravinsky were duly pondered; the question remained unanswered. Today, at the beginning of the 21st century, the answer is all around us. The future is global. Non-European and popular music, not 12-tone rows and Neo-Classicism, are what have refreshed and expanded the musical traditions Bernstein held dear.

title: Verizon Gives MCI Time to Review Qwest Bid
description: Verizon Communications, which had been set to buy MCI, said yesterday that it would grant MCI two weeks to further consider a rival offer from Qwest Communications International.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: New Evidence In Quadruple Homicide
description: The Hudson County prosecutor said yesterday that his office had identified the vehicle used by a suspect who withdrew thousands of dollars from a bank account belonging to a Jersey City family found slain in their home. The prosecutor, Edward J. DeFazio, said that the suspect used the card at automated teller machines several times after the family was murdered, and that he tried to use the card several more times after the bodies were discovered, but was denied access by the bank's computer system. On Jan. 14, the Jersey City police found the bodies of the family, Hossam Armanious, 47; his wife, Amal Garas, 37; and their daughters, Sylvia, 15, and Monica, 8. All had been bound and their throats slashed. John Holl (NYT)

title: TENET HEALTHCARE NAMED IN LAWSUIT BY FLORIDA
description: Tenet Healthcare, a hospital chain, was accused in a lawsuit filed yesterday by Florida's attorney general of inflating charges for medical procedures to obtain $1 billion in Medicare reimbursements. The lawsuit "makes some very strong allegations that are unwarranted, and we will defend ourselves vigorously," said E. Peter Urbanowicz, Tenet's general counsel. The suit comes as Trevor Fetter, Tenet's chief executive, seeks to restore confidence after the company disclosed in 2002 that it raised prices to increase Medicare income, touching off investigations and payment reductions from the government and insurers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDMAN, SAM
description: GOLDMAN--Sam, 88, on March 1. A super-special husband, brother, father, grandfather and uncle. He leaves behind his beloved Shirley, his wife and best friend for 56 years, brother David, sister Goldie Miller (Stanley), children Ed (Judith Riven), Lisa Polito (Eddie) and Nina Kritter (Peter). He was always so proud of his four grandsons-Andrew, Peter, Dylan and Remy and our Sambo was a beloved Uncle Sam to his eight nephews. His warmth, generosity, leadership and expert guidance were always there for our entire family, and he was unfailing in his readiness to help all he came in contact with. During Sam's 60-plus years in the printing and bookbinding industries, his smile and helpful and sage counsel were a constant. Members of his profession and his employees respected Sam for his positive outlook, and his consistently thoughtful consideration. If you would like to make a tribute, please consider the Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation, 5 Channel Dr., Port Washington, NY 11050. Farewell, sweet mensch.

Admiral Mullen, a 1968 graduate of the United States Naval Academy, would succeed Adm. Vern Clark. Thom Shanker (NYT)

title: Round-the-World Flight Continues Despite Shortage of Fuel
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 - Unexpectedly and mysteriously low on fuel, the pilot of an experimental airplane seeking to circle the world nonstop and unrefueled decided late Wednesday near Hawaii to push on across the Pacific, to California and then to his destination, and origin, in Kansas on Thursday.

title: For Yanks, Even the Exhibition Games Count
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 2 - George Steinbrenner's kingdom will sparkle on Thursday. Baseball's grandest spring training stage, Legends Field, will be stuffed with 10,000 fans. The Yankees' logo will be freshly painted on the grass behind home plate, the home team will wear its pinstripes and ESPN will be there.

title: Lorin Maazel Celebrates Himself by Conducting His Own Music
description: Since taking over the New York Philharmonic in 2002, Lorin Maazel has conducted a wide array of contemporary scores, and conducted them very well. But until Tuesday night he had never performed a work of his own with the Philharmonic. Though it's hard to think of Mr. Maazel as being shy about anything, he has been reluctant to show this side to New York concertgoers.

title: Brave, Young and Muslim
description: The last couple of years have not been easy for anyone, myself included, who hoped that the Iraq war would produce a decent, democratizing outcome. And even in the wake of the remarkable Iraqi election, the toppling of the Lebanese cabinet and the reforms brewing in Egypt, it is too soon for anyone to declare victory. We're dealing with some very unstable chemicals. But what makes me more hopeful today is precisely what made me hopeful that the Iraq war might work out, and that is the number of Arab-Muslim youth I've encountered since 9/11 who have urged me to keep writing about the need for democracy and reform in their part of the world.

title: Labor Leaders Reject Rival Plan to Shift More Money to Organizing
description: LAS VEGAS, March 2 - In a vote likely to create deeper tensions inside the labor movement, the leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O rejected a proposal on Wednesday to cut in half individual unions' contributions to the federation to free up more money for organizing.

title: Home Makeover Where Surprises Are Negotiated, Not Sprung
description: In "reDesign," HGTV expands the home renovation genre by homing in on designer-client relations. In other programs, like "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" and "Trading Spaces," the owners are blind to the process of transformation and, in the final minutes, their eyes widen with delight or surprise. (It would be a far more interesting "reveal" to watch the client look at the tax bill for all these freebies.)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Bill To Strengthen 'Honor Killing' Law Rejected
description: Parliament defeated a bill that sought to amend and strengthen a law passed last year that outlawed honor killings, the murder of girls and women by their relatives on the ground that their behavior -- adultery or marrying without familial consent -- has soiled the family's reputation. Rights activists and opposition parties have criticized the law, saying it is weak and ineffective and has loopholes. Lawmakers who support the government sided with opposition hard-line Islamists and rejected the amendments as un-Islamic. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Vermont: The National Guard Question
description: Forty-nine cities and towns passed a resolution at annual town meetings asking the State Legislature to investigate the impact National Guard deployments to Iraq are having on the state. The nonbinding measure, organized by antiwar activists, was debated at meetings in 57 of Vermont's 251 cities and towns. Four communities rejected the resolution, which also called for the withdrawal of troops from Iraq. Katie Zezima (NYT)

In "Retratos da Bahia" ("Portraits of Bahia"), a full-length work choreographed by the company's artistic director, Jelon Vieira, and performed at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night, they juggled distress and joy with furrowed brows, tossing heads and smiles reminiscent of those plastered on the frozen faces of beauty-pageant contestants. It's not that Mr. Vieira's dancers aren't polished technicians; several are outrageously good. But often, the largely hollow choreography renders them as two-dimensional as models in a Gap commercial.

description: BUELER--Hans G. of Somers, New York, died peacefully on March 1, 2005, after a long illness. He is survived by his devoted wife of 20 years, "Pat" Bueler and by his son, Roland G. Bueler of New York City. He was born in Amriswil, Switzerland, the youngest of four children of Martha and Gustav Bueler, an architect. In 1935, Hans left for Cochin, India, thereby beginning a 37-year affiliation with Volkart Bros., a distinguished Swiss commodity firm operative worldwide. After 15 years in India, Hans joined the firm's principal office in Winterthur, Switzerland and between 1965 and 1972 was president and chief executive of Volkart USA. Hans was a man of great integrity and strength of character, who actively embraced every aspect of life. In Switzerland he is presently survived by seven nieces and nephews. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUBELMANN, BARTON GREEN
description: GUBELMANN--Barton Green. Died in Palm Beach on Saturday, February 26, 2005. Born on the memorable date of December 14, 1916, she becaue unforgettable to all who knew her. Raised as an only child in Jacksonville, Florida, she had a life-long love of the ocean. A passionate shell-collector, she was a well-known competitor on the high seas. Barton held the world record for a 50 pound Dolphin caught on 20 lb test line in 1960, and was a founding member of the International Women's Fishing Association. She enjoyed competitive sailing with her husband. Walter S. Gubelmann, whom she married in 1941. Together, they successfully campaigned their yacht Windigo, as well as successfully defending the America's Cup in 1964 with Constellation. Mrs. Gubelmann was educated in Art at the Ringling School in Sarasota, FL, as well as the Traphagen School in New York City. Her sure eye resulted in more awards in Flower Shows, Croquet Tournaments (she is an inductee in the Croquet Hall of Fame) and Skeet Shooting. But it was her tremendous sense of humor, love of her fellow man, and her unending generosity that made her the true champion she was. Whether in Long Island, Palm Beach or Newport, she was at home, entertaining her many friends, often with parties that are still remembered today. Besides being the consummate hostess, she was a member of the Colonial Dames, the Mayflower Society, The New York Yacht Club, the Garden Club of Palm Beach, The Bath and Tennis Club, The Everglades Club, and the Spouting Beach Rock Association. Barton was beloved by all who knew her, especially her family. She is survived by her sons, William & James, their wives, Shelley and Kate, five grandchildren, Marjorie G, Raein, Wyeth S. Gubelmann, Tantivy G. Bostwick, Phoebe G. Gubelmann, James G. Gubelmann, and one great-grandchild, Cyrus P. Raein. The funeral will be held on Friday, March 4, 2005, at 11:00 AM, at The Episcopal Church of Bethesda-By-TheSea. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in memory of Barton G. Gubelmann to the Society of the Four Arts for the Garden Restoration Project.

Sales rose 15 percent, to 1.3 trillion won, the company said. The company is building a $2 billion factory in China to keep up with its larger rival, Samsung Electronics, and to stay ahead of smaller rivals like Micron Technology. Paid Notice: Deaths   SAWYER, CHARLES H.
description: SAWYER--Charles H. Died February 25, 2005 at age 98. Born Andover, MA October 20, 1906. Graduated Phillips Academy with AB from Yale in 1929. Began Harvard prelaw, also took Paul Sachs' museum class and was hired in 1930 as first curator of Addison Gallery of American Art, Phillips Academy. Married Katharine Clay in 1934. Became Director of Worcester Museum of Art in 1940. Joined OSS during WWII, documenting and repatriating works of art confiscated by the Nazis. Returned to Yale in 1947 where he took on a challenging position as Dean of the School of Architecture and Design and Director of the Division of the Arts. In 1957 he became Director of the University of Michigan Museum of Art in Ann Arbor. He created a landmark program to train museum administrators and many graduates have directed major museums. The revitalized program, named in his honor, will be housed in a new section of the Museum. Sawyer received honorary degrees from Amherst College, University of New Hampshire; and Clark University. He was on art advisory commissions for Harvard, Amherst, Smith, and Notre Dame; a trustee of the Corning Museum of Glass and the Smithsonian Art Commission with an honorary life-time appointment; a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences; and member of the Century Association. He was preceded in death in 1998 by his wife Katharine. He is survived by his niece, Elizabeth Sawyer Klaeson of Durham, NH, his nephew George F. Sawyer, Jr. also of Durham, and Katharine's nieces, Phebe (Andrew) Leighton of Cambridge, MA, Susan (Costan) Berard of Fripp Island, SC, and Paula (John) Bungen of San Rafael, CA, and by long-time personal business associate Susan Else Wyman of Ann Arbor. A funeral was held in Chelsea, MI on Tuesday, March 1st with interment of ashes to take place in Dover, NH. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, March 10th at 1pm at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Ann Arbor. A recognition of his life in the arts will be held at the University of Michigan Museum of Art in the spring. Memorial contributions may be made to the U-M Museum of Art, 525 S. State, Ann Arbor, MI 48109 and designated for the Charles H. Sawyer Center for Museum Studies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADAMS, RUTH S.
description: ADAMS--Ruth S. With great sadness and a deep sense of loss, the American Academy mourns the death of Ruth Salzman Adams, former editor of the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists and a Fellow of the Academy since 1985. Throughout her life, Ruth worked for the cause of peace and international cooperation. She was one of the first participants in the Pugwash International Conferences on Science and World Affairs--a movement long supported by the Academy--and she worked tirelessly to promote nongovernmental exchange between Western and Soviet scientists. At the Academy, she was a leader in the establishment of the International Centre for Insect Physiology and Ecology in Nairobi Kenya and the co-author (with William McNeill) of a book on the historical and contemporary impact of human migration. We extend our sincere condolences to her husband, Robert, also a member of the Academy, and to her family. For all those who shared her commitment to international understanding and were fortunate to know her sensitivity and kindness, her generosity and friendship, she will remain in our thoughts. Patricia Meyer Spacks, President Leslie Berlowitz, Executive Officer Louis W. Cabot, Vice President Emilio Bizzi Secretary John S. Reed, Treasurer
