title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Judge Dismisses Rambus Patent Suit
description: Shares of Rambus, a designer of high-speed computer memory chips, fell 10 percent yesterday after a federal judge threw out a patent-infringement case against the German chip maker Infineon Technologies. Dismissing the lawsuit was the "only appropriate action" to punish Rambus for destroying documents related to its patents and litigation strategy, Judge Robert Payne said at a hearing in Richmond, Va. The ruling might hurt Rambus's chances of winning patent suits against other memory-chip makers. The company, which gets most of its sales from royalties and does not make the chips it designs, contends that its inventions cover aspects of all memory chips in the $26 billion industry. Losing the cases could cost Rambus hundreds of millions of dollars in royalties. Rambus, based in Los Altos, Calif., said it would appeal the ruling. Rambus has a "strong case on appeal," the company's general counsel, John Danforth, said in an interview. Hynix Semiconductor, the world's No.2 memory-chip maker, and No.3 Micron Technology also have cases pending against Rambus. Hynix is seeking the dismissal of its case, with arguments scheduled next month in San Jose, Calif. Rambus shares fell $1.71, to $15.45.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Will Introduce New Mobile Phone Chip

The chip will be available after June. With consumers increasingly using their phones for surfing the Internet and playing video games, phone makers might sell as many as 740 million phones this year, according to the iSuppli Corporation. Mr. Maloney was put in charge of tapping that demand when he took over Intel's money-losing communications-chip unit in January 2004. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., failed to win clients for an older version of its baseband processor, code-named Manitoba. The new model, known as Hermon, uses a technology called wideband-code division multiple access, or w-C.D.M.A. The market for those chips will reach $10 billion in the next three years, according to the industry research firm IDC. No phones have been sold so far with the Manitoba chip, an Intel spokesman, Robert Manetta, said.

description: MARKS -- Elaine Miller. Elaine was born in the Bronx in 1926, the daughter of Sig and Dora Miller. She attended Taft High School and New York University. title: The Listings; NOAH SHELDON: 'ALMOST VEGETARIAN'
description: It's nice when art is exciting, but sometimes you just want to power down and relax, which is what this solo show, Noah Sheldon's first in New York City, lets you do. Mr. Sheldon, who is 29, studied composition at the New England Conservatory of Music before he studied art, so it's no surprise that the aural component of this charming show is important to creating a mellow mood, and creating that mood is the purpose of the work. To do so, Mr. Sheldon alters, enhances and invents realities in large and small -- and always very simple -- ways. He not only wants to transport us to someplace nice; he wants to make it extra nice. At the beginning of the show is a video he took of a forest in Venezuela, to which he's added digital fireflies that twinkle like a field of stars. To a nonblooming potted succulent plant in the gallery he's pasted plastic blossoms. The tinkle of wind chimes is always nice. No wind in the gallery, so he's made a simple little mechanical device that gives some hanging chimes a periodic jerk. To open all of this up a bit, he's installated a continuous slide show from his collection: pretty landscapes, distant horizons, dramatic clouds, interspered with comfy hints of home life. Finally, as the pice de rsistence, he's installed a functioning fountain, made of plywood (above). There are benches to sit on, the lights are low, the music, Enya's "Oronoco Flow" -- a traveling song -- plays extra slowly. You can practically feel your pulse slow down. One of the things that's nice about all of this is that the work isn't stuck in self-conscious handmade-ness, managing to have objects without being about objects, or about installation either. It's smart enough not to try to look smart, which too often these days means cute. That's such a relief. (Southfirst, 60 North Sixth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718)599-4884, through March 27; free.) HOLLAND COTTER

title: Women Who Conquered Europe With Their Wit

Her name was Berta Zuckerkandl, an art critic and champion of Viennese modernism, a name whose obscurity today contrasts sharply with the enduring fame of many who gathered around her: Gustav Klimt, Auguste Rodin, Maurice Ravel, Arthur Schnitzler and Hugo von Hofmannsthal, to name a few. They all came to her home for one of the liveliest salons of late 19th-century Vienna, credited by one guest as the birthplace of the Vienna Secession. Zuckerkandl was duly proud. "On my divan," she once said, "Austria comes alive."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUBELMANN, BARTON GREEN
description: GUBELMANN--Barton Green. Died in Palm Beach on Saturday, February 26, 2005. Born on the memorable date of December 14, 1916, she becaue unforgettable to all who knew her. Raised as an only child in Jacksonville, Florida, she had a life-long love of the ocean. A passionate shell-collector, she was a well-known competitor on the high seas. Barton held the world record for a 50 pound Dolphin caught on 20 lb test line in 1960, and was a founding member of the International Women's Fishing Association. She enjoyed competitive sailing with her husband. Walter S. Gubelmann, whom she married in 1941. Together, they successfully campaigned their yacht Windigo, as well as successfully defending the America's Cup in 1964 with Constellation. Mrs. Gubelmann was educated in Art at the Ringling School in Sarasota, FL, as well as the Traphagen School in New York City. Her sure eye resulted in more awards in Flower Shows, Croquet Tournaments (she is an inductee in the Croquet Hall of Fame) and Skeet Shooting. But it was her tremendous sense of humor, love of her fellow man, and her unending generosity that made her the true champion she was. Whether in Long Island, Palm Beach or Newport, she was at home, entertaining her many friends, often with parties that are still remembered today. Besides being the consummate hostess, she was a member of the Colonial Dames, the Mayflower Society, The New York Yacht Club, the Garden Club of Palm Beach, The Bath and Tennis Club, The Everglades Club, and the Spouting Beach Rock Association. Barton was beloved by all who knew her, especially her family. She is survived by her sons, William & James, their wives, Shelley and Kate, five grandchildren, Marjorie G, Raein, Wyeth S. Gubelmann, Tantivy G. Bostwick, Phoebe G. Gubelmann, James G. Gubelmann, and one great-grandchild, Cyrus P. Raein. The funeral will be held on Friday, March 4, 2005, at 11:00 AM, at The Episcopal Church of Bethesda-By-TheSea. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in memory of Barton G. Gubelmann to the Society of the Four Arts for the Garden Restoration Project.

title: The Listings; 'TEMPEST FANTASY'
description: It all began when the composer Paul Moravec wrote a series of pieces for solo piano dedicated to various friends. When one of those friends, the violinist Maria Bachmann, asked him to expand her piece into something longer, he obliged -- with a vengeance. The piece that finally resulted was a half-hour work in five movements for four musicians, depicting, this time, not Mr. Moravec's friends but characters from his favorite Shakespeare play, "The Tempest." Mr. Moravec, above, called it a "musical meditation" on the piece and considered it one of the best things he'd ever written. Others evidently agreed. In 2003, Trio Solisti (Ms. Bachmann's trio) and the clarinetist David Krakauer gave the first performance of "Tempest Fantasy," and it won the Pulitzer Prize last year. On Sunday, the trio and Mr. Krakauer are performing the piece -- which they've since recorded -- once again, framed by trios of Brahms and Ravel. "David Del Tredici once told me, 'There's life before the Pulitzer Prize and life after, and they are not the same thing,"' Mr. Moravec said. Coming events in his post-Pulitzer life include world premieres of songs at Symphony Space in April and at Alice Tully Hall in May. Mr. Stern, 50, heir to one of France's oldest banking families, was chairman of Delta, a British engineering company. His 1983 marriage to Batrice David-Weill, a daughter of the chairman of the investment bank Lazard, had made him the obvious successor to that empire but he left in 1997 after alienating his father-in-law and other partners. title: Old San Juan, P.R.
description: BY 1521, more than 80 years before the founding of Jamestown in what is now Virginia, Juan Ponce de Len, the first governor of Puerto Rico, had already scrapped his original colony and moved north across San Juan Bay to a windy, defensible headland. There, Spanish men and women began creating a city, with a fortress of towering 20-foot-thick walls that would later withstand naval attacks by the British, the Dutch and, eventually, the Americans. Old San Juan, almost 500 years later, is still surrounded by ancient walls of sand, gravel and limestone, its streets lined with deep-blue cobblestones used as ballast by Spanish ships. Centuries-old churches and meticulously preserved pastel houses huddle side by side within its seven-by-seven-block confines, yet Old San Juan is more than just a living, breathing museum. It has plazas, parks, a Polo outlet and restaurants featuring cuisines from Transylvanian to French to Nuevo Latino to Italian. You could walk every block in an afternoon or spend a lifetime soaking in the details. And because Puerto Rico is easy and inexpensive to get to - and, of course, a Caribbean island where the average winter temperature is around 75 degrees - Old San Juan is a great place to get away from the blizzard blues.

title: Arts, Briefly; Can They Make Book on Dostoyevsky?
description: Fyodor Dostoyevsky was notorious for his gambling, but his great-grandson is suing a Russian government-affiliated sports lottery for issuing tickets bearing the image of Dostoyevsky, who wrote "Crime and Punishment," "The Brothers Karamazov" and "The Gambler." The great-grandson, Dmitri Dostoyevsky, right, a former tram driver in St. Petersburg, has filed suit in a Moscow court against Chestnaya Igra, or Honest Game, seeking 200,000 rubles, or about $7,150, in damages. Mr. Dostoyevsky said he registered the family name as a trademark last year. "To be honest, I never thought that something like this would be necessary," he told the newspaper Trud. "But there was no other way to stop the flood of outrageous advertising," he added, noting that the name Dostoyevsky has graced a casino, cafe, shopping mall and jewelry store in the city where the writer lived. A spokeswoman for the lottery defended the use of Dostoyevsky's image as a public service. "Lottery participants receive the opportunity to familiarize themselves with the biography of their great fellow countryman on the reverse side of the ticket," she told the newspaper Izvestia. Mr. Dostoyevsky said that the Nobel Prize-winning author Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn had offered to cover the family's legal expenses. SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Cooking Fuels Pollution
description: Most of the sooty pollution that creates a chronic brown plume over India and the Indian Ocean originates from cooking fires in which the fuels are dung or wood, according to an analysis published in the journal Science. This kind of pollution contributes to hundreds of thousands of premature deaths, mainly of women and children, and also alters climate, cooling the surface and warming the atmosphere in ways that can alter patterns of drought and rainfall, experts said. The authors of the study, from the Indian Institute of Technology and the University of California, Los Angeles, said many benefits could result from reducing such emissions by spreading cleaner cooking methods. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: The Listings; LISA HOWARD AND JAY REISS
description: They don't sing much, and they don't get to sweat the syllables in words like "weltanschauung," but Lisa Howard and Jay Reiss (above far right) provide a fair portion of the comic zest in "The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee," the hit musical at the Second Stage Theater that marches off to Broadway next month. Ms. Howard brings a tart blend of geniality and officiousness to the role of Rona Lisa Peretti, the hostess at the county meet, who has fond memories of her own glory days as a spelling champ. She doles out the absurd biographical tidbits in Rachel Sheinkin's book. "Mr. Barfee has a rare mucous membrane disorder," she says brightly of one young contestant, as if describing a prized achievement. Mr. Reiss plays Douglas Panch, vice principal of Lake Hemingway-Dos Passos Junior High, who is charged with giving the kids their words and providing the sentences that give them context. Mr. Reiss intones these entirely unhelpful phrases -- "Sally's mother told her it was her cystitis that made her special" -- with a deadpan gravity that provides the perfect comic seasoning. (This weekend's schedule: Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m. and Sunday at 3 p.m., Second Stage Theater, 307 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212)246-4422. Tickets: $75, but most performances are sold out.) CHARLES ISHERWOOD

title: F.D.A. PANEL SEEKS MORE STUDY OF IMAGING PRODUCT
description: Combidex, an imaging solution developed by Advanced Magnetics that is intended to improve diagnostic scans for cancer, failed to win the approval yesterday of a federal regulatory panel. The panel, a Food and Drug Administration advisory group, voted 15 to 4 to recommend that the agency reject Combidex until studies involving more patients were done. Combidex, when combined with magnetic resonance imaging, is intended to detect the spread of cancer to the lymph nodes. The F.D.A. usually follows the advice of its panels. The product caused allergic reactions in some cases, leading to a patient's death during clinical trials. Advanced Magnetics, based in Cambridge, Mass., and its marketing partner, the Cytogen Corporation, is based in Princeton, N.J., argued that Combidex worked better than current methods and was safe.

The Mexican Chamber of Deputies is now considering whether to strip Mr. Lpez of his legal immunity from criminal prosecution -- the first step toward eliminating him from the presidential contest.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Witnesses Contradict Rapper
description: Two men testified yesterday at the federal perjury trial of the rapper Lil' Kim that her manager was involved in a 2001 shootout with a rival rap duo, contradicting the account she gave to a grand jury. James Lloyd, a rapper known as Lil' Cease, said that he and Damion Butler, the manager, were among those outside a West Village radio station on Feb. 25, 2001, when members of the duo, Capone-N-Noreaga, approached and the shooting began. Lawyers for Lil' Kim, whose real name is Kimberly Jones, have admitted that she told a grand jury that Mr. Butler was not at the shooting, but they say she misspoke. Kiam Holley, known as Capone, also testified at the trial. Mr. Holley said he was nearing the station, Hot 97, while Ms. Jones and her group were waiting outside. He denied to someone who approached him that he had a "problem" with Lil' Kim. Another member of Ms. Jones's group then suggested that a conflict was about to take place, Mr. Holley said. "I heard a shot and ran." Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: ICAHN BUYS STAKE IN KERR-MCGEE AND SEEKS BOARD SEAT
description: Carl C. Icahn, the financier, reported buying a stake in the Kerr-McGee Corporation, an oil and natural gas producer, and urged the company to sell its chemicals business and appoint him and another investor to its board. Mr. Icahn and affiliated investors acquired about 11.6 million shares, or 7.6 percent of Kerr-McGee's stock, according to a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In addition to shedding its chemicals unit, Kerr-McGee could sell some of its future oil and gas output to raise $8.75 billion, Mr. Icahn said in the filing. Proceeds should be used to buy back stock, he said. Kerr-McGee said last month that Mr. Icahn and a related partnership planned to buy as much as $1 billion of stock in the company. Kerr-McGee, based in Oklahoma City, recommended on Wednesday that shareholders reject a bid by Mr. Icahn and Barry Rosenstein, an investor affiliated with Mr. Icahn, to obtain seats on the board.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 43 Charged In Cocaine Ring
description: Forty-three people were charged with operating a drug market in a housing project in Mott Haven, David N. Kelley, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, said in a statement. Those arrested were members of a gang, known as Hellbound, who sold crack cocaine in the Mitchel Houses from 1999 to this year, the statement said. The arrests were made in a joint operation by the New York Police Department and the F.B.I. Each defendant was charged with a count of participating in a conspiracy to distribute crack cocaine. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

Arts, Briefly; A Shorter 'Idol'
description: After last week's hourlong exercise in cruel suspense, Wednesday night's "American Idol" results show was shortened to a half-hour. That way, the four eliminated contestants were not subjected to needless trickery to extend the show's running time, but were simply ousted. Because of that reduction, Fox placed second in households on a Wednesday -- the last night of February sweeps -- for the first time since the new season of "American Idol" began. NBC was No. 1 in that measurement of Nielsen's overnight ratings. Fox, however, did rank first in total viewers and among 18-to-49-year-olds. ABC placed second in those two categories, on the strength of "Lost" at 8 p.m. That mystery show finally told the back story of Hurley, a fan favorite played by Jorge Garcia. From flashbacks, an audience estimated at 18.83 million viewers learned that the easygoing castaway won the lottery and believes the numbers he picked were cursed. KATE AURTHUR

title: Village Gang-Rape Sentences Are Upset by Court in Pakistan

A sixth man convicted in the case, which set off worldwide outrage, had his death sentence commuted to life in prison, lawyers in the case said.

title: The Red (White and Blue) Guide
description: Paris - IS it possible and desirable for the Michelin Red Guide to judge the restaurants of New York, as announced last week? Of course. It's possible because the guide has done this work for a century. Its inspectors have seated themselves at all the tables of Europe, and if only in deference to its principles of free speech, New York should welcome their judgments, just as Paris welcomed the Zagat Survey in 1998. The guide of Tim and Nina Zagat has become established here even if the results are rather baffling for connoisseurs: Taillevent is really the favorite restaurant of Parisians? It's beyond belief -- indeed, it's a reflection of how difficult it is to find Parisians civic-minded enough to fill out a survey and thus provide a true measure of public opinion -- but the true gastronomes have learned to take it in stride.

title: Arts, Briefly; Short Films, Big Prize
description: Robert De Niro, right, and the other founders of the TriBeCa Film Festival announced a new short-film competition, with a $50,000 first prize. Beginning on April 13, aspiring filmmakers can submit their short films to the Amazon.com Web site. The films can be two to seven minutes long and have G, PG or PG-13 content. Visitors to the Amazon site can view the submissions and rate them on a scale from one to five. The five highest-rated films will be screened at the TriBeCa Cinemas and will run for four weeks on the Amazon.com home page. The winner will receive $50,000 toward a subsequent film in the form of a prepaid card from American Express, a founding partner of the festival. "This competition will undoubtedly help discover important new filmmakers," Mr. De Niro said. "It doesn't cost a lot, and it enables a person to get their work shown." LILY KOPPEL

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Verizon Wireless Gets Approval Of Airwaves Purchase
description: Verizon Wireless won approval from federal regulators to complete its $3 billion purchase of NextWave Telecom's airwaves for sending mobile telephone calls in New York and 22 other cities. The decision by the Federal Communications Commission, released Wednesday, becomes final in 40 days, an agency spokeswoman, Lauren Patrich, said. Verizon Wireless, the nation's second-largest cellphone operator, will use the airwaves to send more calls and Internet traffic across its network. The company is eager to win back its spot as the No.1 cellphone company, when ranked by customers, which it lost to Cingular Wireless in October. NextWave filed for bankruptcy protection in 1998 after it was unable to pay the F.C.C. for the licenses it won in auctions. On Tuesday, NextWave, based in Greenwich, Conn., won court approval of a plan to exit bankruptcy by giving shareholders as much as $3.2 billion and repaying creditors. Most of the funds are coming from Verizon Wireless, which in October bought another NextWave license to airwaves in the New York metropolitan area for $930 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISHER, MAX M.
description: FISHER--Max M. The leadership, Board of Trustees and staff of United Jewish Communities notes with deep sorrow the loss of Max M. Fisher, the quintessential Jewish leader and visionary. He died Thursday, March 3rd at 96. For nearly half a century, Fisher was among North America's leading industrialist and charitable givers, supporting Jewish and general causes worldwide. For decades he served as a trusted advisor to U.S. presidents and Israeli prime ministers. By quietly forging new ties between Washington and Jerusalem, Fisher pioneered a new era in American Jewish activism and politics. "In the world of Jewish volunteer leaders, Max Fisher was a giant. He was known to all as a prime mover, as someone who made things happen," said Howard Rieger, president and chief executive officer of United Jewish Communities (UJC). Fisher served as the top leader of UJC's predecessor organizations: United Jewish Appeal, Council of Jewish Federations, and United Israel Appeal. He was also president of the Jewish Federation of Metropolitan Detroit. He was an honorary chair of UJC and founding chairman of the Board of Governors of UJC's overseas partner, the Jewish Agency for Israel. His daughter, Jane Sherman, serves as chairperson of the UIA and is co-chair of JAFI's Israel Committee. In recognition of his lifelong devotion, commitment and generosity to Jews everywhere, UJC and the Jewish Federations of North America named their New York headquarters in September, 2002 as the Max M. Fisher Headquarters of United Jewish Communities. "May it stand as a memorial to him and his lifelong interest in UJC and the Jewish Federations of North America," Rieger said. To Max's wife, Marjorie Switow Fisher, his children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren, we extend our heartfelt condolences. May Max Fisher's name be a blessing and may his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Robert Goldberg, Chairman Morton B. Plant, Chairman of the Executive Committee Howard M. Rieger, President and CEO

title: The Listings; JUANES
description: The Colombian rocker Juanes, shortened from Juan Esteban Aristizabal, sings about love and war, particularly the civil war that has torn Colombia apart. Amid the violence, Colombia has somehow generated extraordinary music, not only from Juanes but from musicians and bands as determinedly upbeat and proud of their country as Shakira, Carlos Vives, Cabas and Aterciopelados. Juanes, above, has not courted a North American audience by writing songs in English, but he's headlining at Madison Square Garden tonight anyway. He has become one of Latin America's superstars, with nine Latin Grammys among his many awards, and his popularity stems from something more than his good looks and his tunes, which draw easily on anything from Colombian cumbia to funk, new wave rock to bossa nova, reggae to waltz. He touches down in local music, then looks outward. For listeners across Latin America and Spanish speakers elsewhere, what comes across in Juanes's songs is an intense longing that spans romance, love of country and the yearning for peace. In "Nada Valgo Sin Tu Amor" ("Nothing Matters Without Your Love"), a declaration of love that has been a hit in Colombia since last summer, he sings, "I want to take back all the nights I lost, to conquer this overwhelming fear of death." For all his earnestness, Juanes never despairs. His songs are not complaints; they insist on hope. Straightforward love songs and songs like "Sueos," ("Dreams") in which Juanes imagines "an end to this unjust war" and "walking the streets of my country and finding only peace," reinforce one another's seriousness and determined optimism, rallied by music that makes its way toward buoyant choruses. The songs envision the possibility of happy endings even if, for the moment, they seem far away. (Tonight at 8, Madison Square Garden, 33rd Street and Seventh Avenue, Manhattan, (212)465-6741.; tickets are $45 to $75.) JON PARELES

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Manufacturing Orders Slip
description: Manufacturing orders in Germany fell less than expected in January after increasing the most in more than a decade in December. Orders fell 3.4 percent from December, when they gained 7.6 percent, the Economy and Labor Ministry said. Economists expected a 4.5 percent decline. December's surge in orders brightened the outlook for Germany's $2.7 trillion economy, improving the prospects for an increase in investment and consumption after an unexpected economic contraction in the fourth quarter. Since then, a 29 percent increase in the price of oil has imposed additional costs on producers and consumers. "It's positive that the orders figure wasn't as bad as expected," said Andreas Speer, an economist at Bayerische Landesbank in Munich. "But the economy is still standing on one leg, and rising oil costs are making us more pessimistic."

description: BROSNAN -- Irene Frances McKenna. Born on October 30, 1921 in Elmhurst, NY, and died on Friday, February 25, 2005 in Portland, OR. Irene was married on September 8, 1949 to Robert Emmet Brosnan. Irene and Robert lived on Long Island, in Great Neck and Port Washington where her children Robert, Terence, Michael and Elizabeth were born. Her husband Robert Emmet was a partner in the New York law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam, & Roberts when he passed away on May 16, 1982. Irene then moved to Portland, Oregon to live with her daughter Elizabeth Brown. Irene was one of five children born to George and Theresa McKenna. In Port Washington, Irene was active in the parish of St. Peters of Alcantara. Her passions in her later years were her faith, her family, reading and crossword puzzles. She was a devoted lifelong subscriber to the "New York Times" and its puzzle and always referred to New York simply as "The City." She is survived by her four children, their spouses, 11 grandchildren and beloved nieces and nephews. Donations to be made to the St. Andrew Nativity School in Portland, Oregon. A Memorial Mass will take place on Saturday, March 12th at 3:00 p.m. in the Chapel of Regis High School, 55 E. 84th St., New York, NY.

An Army spokesman in Cuba said the case did not involve detainees held at the base. Other officials said the inquiry involved accusations of improper consensual sexual acts. The military statement said a colonel and two lieutenant colonels had been suspended by Brig. Gen. Jay W. Hood, the Guantnamo commander, while the case of a higher-ranking officer was referred to the Department of the Army.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Steel Import Tariffs Lifted
description: The Brazilian government temporarily lifted import tariffs on 15 steel products used mostly by automakers and home appliance manufacturers to keep rising domestic steel prices from driving up inflation. The move was hailed by the association of automakers, which has been lobbying for more than a year to suspend the duties. But some analysts questioned the effectiveness of the move, noting that domestic steel prices tend to rise with global prices. The announcement came shortly after the world's largest supplier of iron ore, Companhia Vale do Rio Doce of Brazil, said it secured a 71.5 percent price increase from Arcelor, Europe's biggest steel company. The increase was the latest in a series that has set the stage for more expensive steel globally. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Essence of Chanel: Coco? Karl? Both

Other designers have only one personality to play with, and that can leave the rest of us stranded in the middle of their neurosis, life-changing experience or trek to Machu Picchu. But Mr. Lagerfeld also has Chanel's personality, and he can manipulate it with Photoshop precision, as he did today in a show that had models in white shirts and floppy ties (his) and in tweed cardigan jackets and plus fours (hers).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRICK, RAYMOND AUGUSTUS, SR.
description: FRICK--Raymond Augustus, Sr. Age 86 years, of Pittstown, NJ, on March 2nd in Hunterdon Medical Center, Flemington, NJ. Born January 16, 1919, Bloomfield, NJ, son of William French Frick and Gertrude Small Frick, he was a graduate of Bloomfield High School where he was a star athlete receiving AllState honors in football and basketball. Graduate of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in 1941, he was All-American center of the football team in 1940 and was also the team captain. He was University of Pennsylvania Man of the Year Distinguished Alumnus in 1957. An Army Air Corp veteran of WWII serving as a B24 pilot, he was shot down, survived by parachute and spent 11 months in a POW camp 1943-1944. His entire business career was with Abex Corp with his final 19 years there as President of Railroad Products Group and its predecessor company, American Brake Shoe Co. He graduated from Harvard University Advanced Management Program in 1954. After retiring, he fulfilled a longtime dream and purchased a horse farm, Chestnut Tree Farm, Pittstown, NJ, which he operated for eight years with daughter, Tracey Frick, and partner, Stephanie Levick. His wife, Betsy Osborne Frick, and two brothers, William Frick and Louis Frick, predeceased him. Mr. Frick is survived by four children and their families, Raymond A. Frick, Jr. and his wife Elizabeth of Boston, MA, Gregory Frick and his wife Iliana of Coral Gables, FL, US Air Force Chaplain Col. Steve Frick and his wife Donna in Germany, and Tracey Frick of Pittstown, NJ, and grandchildren, Samantha, Channing, Daniel and Stephanie Frick. Funeral arrangements and interment are private. Memorial contributions to be made to Hunterdon Humane Animal Shelter, 576 Stamets Rd., Milford, NJ 08848.

"We need to be an international business," Cochlear's chief executive, Chris Roberts, said on a conference call from Sydney, Australia, where the company is based. Mr. Roberts said the number of people who need implants is rising. The acquisition will immediately add to earnings per share, he said.

The suit, filed in Los Angeles Superior Court on Thursday, says that for the last four years, Warner/Chappell failed to account for and pay at least $250,000 in royalties pursuant to agreements made in 1965 by Sonny and Cher with York Records and the Atlantic Recording Corporation that were later modified when Warner/Chappell acquired Atlantic. Before their divorce in 1977, Sonny and Cher produced a daughter, Chastity Bono, also a plaintiff in the suit. Mr. Bono's widow, Mary Bono-Baxley, took over his seat as the United States Representative for California's 45th Congressional District after he died in January 1998. title: MCI'S BIGGEST SHAREHOLDER OPPOSES VERIZON DEAL
description: Carlos Slim Hel, the biggest shareholder of MCI Inc., opposes the company's planned sale to Verizon Communications, a spokesman for the Mexican billionaire said yesterday. Arturo Elias, a spokesman for Mr. Slim, who holds a 13.7 percent stake in MCI, said in an interview that Verizon's $6.76 billon offer and an $8 billion bid from Qwest Communications International are both too low. Directors at MCI now face pressure from holders of at least 26 percent of the company's shares to seek a higher offer. Mr. Slim gave an indication of his views in comments in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing on Thursday, stating that he would take an active interest in MCI's takeover and that an agreement should "maximize value for the owners of the common shares."

The lack of freshness did not turn viewers away: CBS came in first in the Nielsen overnights in households and among adults 18 to 49. In fact, the episode of "CSI" was the most-watched show of the night, drawing 25.48 million viewers. NBC, which came in second for the night, showed the series premiere of "Law & Order: Trial by Jury" in the time slot "ER" usually occupies. The fourth show in the "Law & Order" franchise, it won the hour and did marginally better than the season average for "ER." An audience of 17.11 million watched "Trial by Jury," which will normally be broadcast on Fridays at 10 p.m. It featured one of Jerry Orbach's last performances as Detective Lenny Briscoe before his death in December. KATE AURTHUR

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON TO BUY CLOSURE MEDICAL
description: Johnson & Johnson agreed to buy the Closure Medical Corporation, a maker of medical glue, for $370 million, the companies said yesterday. Johnson & Johnson said it would pay $27 in cash for each share of Closure Medical, 21 percent more than the company's closing share price on Thursday. Closure, based in Raleigh, N.C., makes Dermabond, which replaces sutures and staples for wounds, and Liquid Bandage. The deal comes just weeks after the company's Omnex surgical sealant, its first product for use inside the body, was approved in Europe. Johnson & Johnson already has alliances with Closure Medical, distributing Liquid Bandage under Johnson's Band-Aid brand name and marketing Dermabond. Closure Medical shares rose $4.28 to $26.68. Shares of Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, N.J., gained 99 cents, to $67.74.

A practicing member of the New York bar for more than 47 years, Mr. Schneider began his legal career with the Waterfront Commission and then with the N.Y.C. Housing and Redevelopment Board. He authored "A Guide to the Court System" under the aegis of the Institute for Judicial Administration. He was a long term President of the Gustave Hartman Y in Rockaway Beach, Queens. Mr. Schneider is survived by his children Daniel, William and Elizabeth and by his grandchildren, Taryn, Dean, Max, Tyler, Cole and Preston. Graveside services Sunday March 7th, 11:00 A.M. at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale. Donations in his memory may be made to "Roy Reuther Senior Center" 718-471-3110, in lieu of flowers.

title: Arts, Briefly; Trans-Atlantic Comedy
description: Whoever first said "what goes around comes around" might have been thinking of the sitcom "The Office." Created and first seen in Britain, it also won popularity and critical acclaim in the United States on BBC America, whereupon NBC acquired the rights to make an American version. Now BBC has reached an agreement with NBC Universal International Television Distribution to import the new show, "The Office: An American Workplace." In the British sitcom, Ricky Gervais, above, who wrote and directed the series with Stephen Merchant, plays David Brent, a manager with delusions of grandeur and popularity. In the American version, the office is set in the Dunder Mifflin paper supply company in Scranton, Pa., where the Brent character is Michael Scott, a regional manager played by Steve Carrell, who has the same inappropriate management style as David Brent. "The Office: An American Workplace" begins on NBC on March 24 and will be broadcast in Britain later in the year. "There will be huge curiosity around the U.S. version of 'The Office,"' said George McGhee, the BBC controller of acquisitions, "and we are delighted that the BBC is bringing this series to U.K. audiences." title: Socialist Monarch, Portrayed as a Man
description: PARIS, March 4 - Franois Mitterrand, who was in office longer than any other French head of state since Napoleon III, always seemed comfortable in the role of socialist monarch. Publicly aloof, secretively manipulative, privately seductive, he orchestrated his every public appearance to project an image popular and regal. When he died in January 1996, eight months after retiring, he remained a mystery.

(PVC, or polyvinyl chloride, is used to make the shiny black material that is commonly worn by dominatrixes.) Ms. Agbabi earned this label during her recent, unusual assignment: writer in residence at Eton College, one of the oldest boarding schools in Britain, and almost certainly its grandest.

title: MAXTOR TO CUT UP TO 5,500 JOBS IN SINGAPORE
description: The Maxtor Corporation, which makes hard-disk drives for personal computers, said yesterday that it planned to reduce the work force at its Singapore manufacturing operations by up to 5,500 people. Maxtor, based in Milpitas, Calif., said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that about 2,500 of the planned job cuts would be achieved through attrition and the rest by severance. The company said it planned to close one of its two plants in Singapore and move its manufacturing of desktop products to China. The plant shutdown was expected to be completed by 2006, according to the filing. Severance expenses were expected to lower first-quarter earnings by $12 million, the filing said.

title: Arts, Briefly; New Museum in Stuttgart
description: An $87 million museum opens its doors today in Stuttgart, Germany. Eighty years after the Marquese Silvio della Valle di Casanova donated his collection of paintings to the city, the collection has moved into a new glass cube in the central square, the Kunstmuseum Stuttgart. With 54,000 square feet of space, the museum features a major collection of the works of the German painter Otto Dix. Also strongly represented are Adolf Hlzel, Willi Baumeister, Dieter Roth, Fritz Winter, Dieter Krieg, Wolfgang Laib, Joseph Kosuth, Karin Sander and Simone Westerwinter. The museum's 15,000 works are primarily by 20th-century artists, many linked to Stuttgart and southwestern Germany. The inaugural exhibition is "Arrived: The Collection in Our Own House." VICTOR HOMOLA

title: Too, Too Perfect
description: The photographs in Brian McKee's "Detritus" series feel serendipitous, as if he scouted and shot buildings on leisurely trips to Asia and then sorted through the results, culling the best images. But the scouting happens before he ever leaves Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Mr. McKee, 27, typically does four to six months of Internet and library research to find his subjects; when he arrives, he heads to the selected sites, shoots some Polaroids and then takes one picture. One picture? "That's it," he says. "One picture. And if it doesn't work, it doesn't work." That purist approach is risky -- not every site turns out to have the haunting quality Mr. McKee is after. The 12 Indian interiors, like the one at right, in his show "Urbanus," which opens on Wednesday at the Mitchell-Innes & Nash gallery in Manhattan, weren't the only ones he visited. Here is his account of his arrival at the Red Fort at Agra, as told to Ted Loos.

On the obverse is a portrait of Thomas Jefferson, who seems to loom into the porthole of the coin. The word "Liberty" appears in a facsimile of Jefferson's handwriting and is dwarfed by "In God We Trust." On the reverse, a bison stands on a small patch of prairie, fenced in by the words "United States of America," which nearly surround him. It is perhaps a meaningless artifact of design that this bison is facing to the right.

description: LITTLE BLACK BOOK OF STORIES, by A. S. Byatt. (Vintage International, $12.95.) These five haunting Gothic stories bear all the hallmarks of Byatt's style: they're carefully constructed, allusive meditations on art and its place in the world. The collection's first entry, "The Thing in the Forest," reunites two women who shared a horrific vision as children during their wartime evacuation from London. title: Halfway House And Garden
description: NOTHING like five months of canned peas, white potatoes instead of freshly dug fingerlings, iceberg lettuce and rock-hard tomatoes from the hothouse served up in the Big House to make one pine for the backyard garden again, eh? As a gardener in the Hudson Valley, I have to confess that no garden writing I've read in the last 10 years has touched me as much as something Martha Stewart said last fall. About to enter the slammer -- staring at five months of intimate contact with drug felons, hardened guards and a miserable cot -- what was on her mind? She hoped she would be released in time to start her spring garden. Gardeners everywhere, rejoice. Ms. Stewart is one of us. And once again among us, well, almost -- for the next five months she's confined to her estate in Bedford.

title: A Fairy Tale for Grown-Ups
description: Who can forget the frenzied public anticipation -- not to mention the media blitz -- surrounding the photogenic and, as it would turn out, fatally ill-conceived union of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer? That summer in 1981, when a sober Charles wed a certifiably virginal Diana -- she looking more like a demure, pretty milkmaid than the attention-craving glamourpuss she would become -- I was staying at a writer's colony in upstate New York. The atmosphere was heavy with literary concerns, and it was definitely not the thing to evince interest in the choreographed nuptials of two silly anachronistic royals. I worried that I would have to forgo the pleasures of watching the ceremonies along with 750 million other viewers when several days before the event I discovered another writer who shared my dclass fascination. The two of us hatched an ornate plan to depart the colony at 5 a.m. on the day of the wedding, having arranged to drive to a town nearby where my friend knew someone with a house and, most important, a TV. While our colleagues back at the colony lingered in their dreams, we settled down to gaze, wide-eyed with vicarious inner-princess gratification, at the regal fantasy, replete with a gilded chariot, unfolding on the small screen.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE only problem with Morgan Spurlock's SUPER SIZE ME (2004) is that his experiment is more intriguing than the film he made to document it. Mr. Spurlock, a healthy young 185-pound man, decides to prove the evils of fast food by eating nothing but McDonald's meals for 30 days. He gains 24 pounds, raises his cholesterol from 168 to 230 and almost destroys his liver. Mr. Spurlock works in unsettling information about fast-food "nutrition," horrifying reports about school lunches and entirely too many gross-out close-ups of gastric bypass surgery. Still, the film is well worth watching. And by the time you read this, it may have won a best-documentary Oscar -- Monday at 8:15 p.m. on Showtime.

UP FRONT
description: The Dec. 13, 2004, issue of The New Republic published an ambitious essay, "A Fighting Faith: An Argument for a New Liberalism," by the magazine's editor, Peter Beinart. In it, Beinart argued that many liberals were trapped in the past, unwilling to confront the new challenges of the post-9/11 era. What liberalism needed, he wrote, was a commitment to a vigorous foreign policy, a willingness to use American power to face down enemies and dictators around the world. The article caused a considerable stir and helped begin a family conversation among people who generally agree on liberal principles but often disagree sharply on specifics like the Iraq war. The Book Review asked Beinart and the editors of two other influential liberal magazines to continue that discussion. The three spent two hours in the Times's offices hashing out liberalism's problems and prospects. An edited version of their discussion can be found beginning on Page 14; a longer audio version has been posted on The Times's Web site at nytimes.com/books. The three editors also recommended books for readers interested in pursuing this subject, and their suggestions can be found on Page 15.

title: And Now for Something Completely Different . . .

Before that, when he was just David Pierce (the Screen Actors Guild, already having a member by that name, Hyded him in 1993), he was a theater and English major at Yale -- which is where I met him, in 1977. Steady and buttoned-down, with a keen but very dry sense of humor, he was not like the rest of us flamboyant theater types; and yet today, in his first Broadway appearance since his sitcom success, he is starring in perhaps the silliest musical ever: "Monty Python's Spamalot," which is in previews at the Shubert Theater and opens on March 17. Directed by Mike Nichols and also starring Tim Curry and Hank Azaria, "Spamalot" features Mr. Pierce, 45, as not-so-brave Sir Robin (among other roles): singing and dancing, clutching chickens, blessing hand grenades and generally putting his Yale education to good use. On Feb. 14, he took time off from writing Valentine's Day cards for his castmates -- yes, really -- to talk about how low he's sunk. JESSE GREEN

description: SHUDOFSKY--Dr. Noam. It is with a heavy heart and enormous sadness that the Board of Directors, Staff and Students of the Columbia/Barnard Hillel announce the passing of Dr. Noam Shudofsky, beloved father of our dear colleague, friend and mentor, Leora Shudofsky. Dr. Shudofsky passed away peacefully during the morning of March 2, 2005. In his forty years as an educator, Dr. Shudofsky served as Administrator of the Ramaz Day School where he shaped and guided the lives of many young Jewish minds and managed the day-to-day operations of the school. His career at Ramaz helped to make it the world-renowned institution that it is today. He was in its truest, fullest definition, a community builder and dedicated servant of the Jewish people. Our hearts and thoughts go out to his wife, children and grandchildren at this most difficult time. SHUDOFSKY--Dr. Noam. The Zamir Choral Foundation mourns the passing of our beloved board member, Dr. Noam Shudofsky. His unparalleled passion & commitment to Zionism and the state of Israel; his dedication to the power and promise of Jewish education; and his devotion to the cause of music and the arts are measures of an extraordinary life and accomplishment. His guidance, wisdom and leadership are irreplaceable--and even more his friendship. Our love and hearts go out to Nechi, Binny, Rachel and Leora in this difficult time. His memory will truly be a blessing to us all. Matthew Lazar Founder and Director Alan Septimus, President SHUDOFSKY--Noam. Noam was an outstanding leader and mentor, whose tireless effort and commitment to Israel and the Parade will forever continue to inspire us. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GASH, JAMES ALAN
description: GASH--James Alan. North Chatham, NY, March 3, 2005, James Alan Gash, better known as Jim, died after living several years with cancer. Only child of the late Etta (Press) Gash and Arthur Gash, he was born in Brooklyn on July 15, 1930. A graduate of Poly Prep and Cornell University, he majored in English and began his avocation for journalism while working on the Cornell Sun. One of his post graduate jobs was with the NBC affiliate in Buffalo. From there he went to WNEW in New York City when that station was at it's peak, with well known on air personalities William B. Williams and Gene Klavan. Jim joined the large news staff and worked there for fifteen years covering city hall, disasters, politicians, and celebrities of the day from Jackie K. to Marilyn M. His talent was to get to the nub of the story and interpret it clearly. He left in 1974 during the city's financial crisis when news operations were cutting back, and moved upstate to work in the press office of the Speaker of the Assembly. Since being a little boy cheering the Dodgers at Ebbets Field, he was more than a fan and knew everything about every player, trade and game. The 2005 Baseball Register is on his desk. He also loved travel, beach sitting, ethnic food and animals. He leaves his wife of forty four years, Wendy, his shaggy dog Muszka, and many friends who relied on his counsel and the rare ability to just listen.

title: Unintelligent Design
description: True believers will say that what look like imperfections are not really imperfections. Skeptics will reply that what looks like design may not be design. More interesting, however, is the notion inherent in intelligent design that there is only one designer. Experience tells us that the more complex an artifact is, the greater the number of people involved in its design and implementation. The proponents of intelligent design need to be aware that even though they make no claims about who or what the designer might be, they lay the groundwork for multiple designers, in essence for polytheism. So biology students can be forgiven for wondering if perhaps the design team might be made up of Aphrodite, Apollo, Ares and Zeus.

title: Inside the List
description: DEVIL IN THE DETAILS: There are new No. 1 books on both the hardcover fiction and nonfiction lists this week. James Patterson's 28th novel, "Honeymoon," written with Howard Roughan, bumps down "The Broker," by John Grisham, which had a five-week run in the top spot. On the nonfiction side, Jose Canseco's memoir "Juiced" pushes aside Malcolm Gladwell's "Blink," which was No. 1 for four weeks. One title that is conspicuously absent from the hardcover nonfiction list is M. Scott Peck's 19th book, "Glimpses of the Devil: A Psychiatrist's Personal Accounts of Possession, Exorcism, and Redemption," published in January. It is No. 55 on the extended list. There was a time when Peck seemed to rule this list. His personal-growth classic, "The Road Less Traveled," with its famously succinct first sentence ("Life is difficult"), is arguably the most successful paperback in the history of the Times list. Published in 1978, "The Road Less Traveled" hung on the list for more than 13 years. Peck, who is now 68 and suffers from Parkinson's disease, has said that his new book, an account of two exorcisms he says he performed more than 25 years ago, will be his last. In recent interviews, Peck has been outspoken about how evil has made itself manifest in the world. Exhibit A, Peck told Salon, was the decision in the Bush v. Gore Supreme Court case. "I wonder how that could happen," Peck said, sounding a bit like Dana Carvey's Church Lady, "without Satan hanging around."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHISOLM, BARBARA BOWEN
description: CHISOLM--Barbara Bowen Of Asheville, NC, died on March 1, 2005 from endometrial cancer. In Asheville, Barbara had been President of the Asheville Symphony Guild and a Board Director of the Asheville Symphony, among many other activities. Previously, Barbara lived in Greenwich, CT, where she married O. Beirne Chisolm in 1991 and was Executive Director of the World Affairs Forum of Stamford, CT, from 1989 to 2000. In addition, Barbara served as Chairman and President of the World Affairs Councils of America. Barbara had been married to Roland Frank Wille from 1969 until his death in 1988. Prior to moving to Greenwich, CT, in 1982, Barbara and her family lived in Washington, DC. She was born on December 8, 1936 in Albany, NY and received a B.A. in music from Smith College in 1958 and a M.A in Art History from the University of London (The Courtauld Institute) in 1961. In addition to her husband Beirne and his children, Barbara is survived by her two daughters, Serena Wille, an intelligence analyst in Washington, DC, and Alison Wille, a management consultant in New York City; and her sister Linda Bowen Sorenson of Newtonville, NY. Also seven grandchildren: Madeline, Emily, Tyler, Charles, Eric, Gaia and Carlo, and two brothers: Frank of Tenafly and Arthur Pastore of Cape Cod. title: Comings and Goings
description: In January, more than a dozen Canadian tourists fell sick after vacationing in the Dominican Republic, and by late February, 512 tourists in all had come down with norovirus, a stomach-flu-like illness, according to Rafael Schiffino, the Dominican health vice-minister. Norovirus is spread through interpersonal contact; its symptoms include vomiting and diarrhea for one or two days. But on Feb. 17, the tourism minster, Flix Jimnez, said that no new cases had been reported since Feb. 11, adding, "norovirus is now under control in the Dominican Republic." . . . The Transportation Security Administration on Monday announced that all lighters will be prohibited from sterile areas of airports and on aircraft. Passengers will be prohibited from carrying all lighters, even in carry-on luggage, beyond security checkpoints. The policy will be fully enforced beginning April 14. This includes, for example, butane, absorbed-fuel (Zippo-type), electric/battery-powered and novelty lighters. The T.S.A. will dispose of confiscated lighters. . . . Getting or renewing a passport will cost $12 more starting March 8 because of a surcharge that is to help pay for increased security, including the eventual addition of a computer chip to passports. That brings the total cost of a new passport to $97, and $82 for children under 16; renewals will cost $67. Ultimately, the government plans to store electronic data and a digitized photo of the passport holder on the chip, enabling a computer to verify the photo. "It will look the same on the outside," said Kelly Shannon, a spokeswoman for the Bureau of Consular Affairs, and it won't change the application process. Applicants will still submit photos, which will be digitized by the government.

title: Upstaged

But the real star of "K," at the MGM Grand Hotel Casino in Las Vegas, is the theater itself. This "Metropolis"-meets-"Blade Runner" showroom, custom built for the production, features a byzantine network of brass spires, planks and catwalks above and around the audience and a pair of "performance platforms" that fly through the air, changing shape, color and texture. The show's human performers are literally upstaged. "Cirque does like it when human performance transcends all the nonhuman elements in the show, but I can understand the person who says the theater is as epic as the story being told," said Lyn Heward, Cirque's president and chief operating officer.

description: MANY New Yorkers think they can do better than "The World's Second Home," the phrase that the Bloomberg administration wants to trademark as New York's official slogan. When the City section invited readers to suggest alternatives, hundreds of ideas arrived; here are some of the ones we especially liked.

title: Keren Backer, Ian Schindelman
description: Keren Golda Backer, the daughter of Sary and Edward Backer of Stamford, Conn., was married last evening to Ian Marc Schindelman, a son of Joan Schindelman and Dr. Harvey Schindelman of Long Beach, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph H. Ehrenkranz officiated at Amuse, a restaurant in New York.

title: A Woman's Journey Toward Herself
description: LIKE many of her 40ish contemporaries, the playwright Suzan-Lori Parks was in college when she discovered Zora Neale Hurston and her 1937 novel "Their Eyes Were Watching God." Hurston, a Harlem Renaissance-era writer, was plucked from decades of obscurity in the 1970's and her novels embraced as rediscovered classics because of her rich depictions of black life and the struggles of women.

title: Changing Tactics On Montauk Beach
description: MONTAUK - IN a move away from blanket prohibitions on seawalls and revetments on its ocean beaches, the Town of East Hampton is backing the use of shoreline armoring along a 3,000-foot stretch of oceanfront in low-lying downtown Montauk.

title: Black Churches Struggle Over Their Role in Politics
description: A tug of war is under way inside black churches over who speaks for African-Americans and what role to play in politics, spurred by conservative black clergy members who are looking to align themselves more closely with President Bush.

title: The Land Where Hope Springs Eternal
description: THE Radisson Bay Harbor in Tampa is not exactly a modern hotel. And it is definitely not trendy. Square rooms are stacked on top of one another, each overlooking the rippling currents of Tampa Bay. Two miles from the airport, in a neighborhood of chain restaurants and other chain hotels, the Radisson feels businesslike, almost sterile.

title: Shop in Your Backyard
description: THIS month, Whole Foods, the natural and organic supermarket that was founded more than two decades ago in Austin, Texas, will open its fifth store in New York in Manhattan's Union Square. Understandably, many folks are concerned that this new store will signal the beginning of the end for the fabled Greenmarket that now commands the square.

description: Move over Barbie. Harriet Tubman, Amelia Earhart and Mary Cassatt are the new dolls in town.

description: Antiques in Hartford

title: They Spy
description: In their efforts to stop pirates armed with camcorders -- who cost Hollywood $3.5 billion last year, the Motion Picture Association of America estimates -- film studios and theater owners have begun policing preview screenings, with security guards checking for recording devices at the door and then monitoring the audience using handheld infrared scanners like the one shown here. But with new, less conspicuous antipiracy technologies on the way -- including a wall-mounted device that pinpoints the location of camcorders in the theater -- these sentries may soon go the way of the projectionist. At a recent preview of "Constantine" at a Midtown theater, Joel Topcik spoke with Bob R., one of five men present from Noble Inc., a New York-based entertainment security company, about the dying art of watching the watchers. (Noble, which has caught three would-be pirates in the act in the last two years and delivered them to the authorities, asked that Bob's last name not be printed.)

title: Corrections
description: A credit last Sunday for pictures of a water filtration plant in Connecticut, with an article about public works projects by well-known architects, misspelled the given name of the architect whose firm supplied the photographs. He is Steven Holl, not Stephen.

title: Poster Gal
description: The posters and ads for the current Broadway revival of "Steel Magnolias" list a series of familiar television, film and stage names: Delta Burke, Marsha Mason, Frances Sternhagen, Christine Ebersole, Rebecca Gayheart. So who is the unfamiliar woman in jeans and blue sneakers who's actually pictured, grinning self-consciously from beneath a beehive hair dryer?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENFORADO, SALLY BOWEN
description: BENFORADO--Sally Bowen. Born August 12, 1924 in Syracuse, died March 2, 2005 at her Madison, WI home. In 1948 after graduation from Syracuse University, she married Dr. Joseph Benforado with whom she had six children. A writer and teacher, her most recent publication is "Bring Me More Stories: Tales of the Sephardim" (Floricanto Press, 2005) based on her mother-in-law's memories of Turkey. Preceded in death by her husband (2002) and a daughter, Kathryn (1999), Sally is loved and remembered by her children, Susan Benforado Bakewell of Texas, Jay Benforado of Virginia, Caroline Aksoy of New York, David J. Benforado and Marianne Benforado, both of Wisconsin; by sons - and daughters-in-law, Peter Bakewell, Elizabeth Coberly Benforado, Servet Aksoy, Carolyn Pieper Benforado, and David Lawrence; by grandchildren, Max Gunther, Nicholas Bakewell, Adam Benforado, Nate Benforado, Charlie Benforado, Sarah Benforado; by her brother, Dr. Willet Bowen of Connecticut; and by a host of other relatives, friends, neighbors. There will be no funeral. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Friends Service Committee, 1501 Cherry St., Phila., PA 19102.

title: A Day for Derby Hopefuls to Stretch Thundering Legs
description: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla., March 5 - Lost in the Fog improved his legitimacy as a Kentucky Derby candidate on Saturday, in the process stealing the spotlight from the Fountain of Youth Stakes later in the day at Gulfstream Park.

title: Changes of Heart, With Explanations
description: IT is relatively easy for most of us to change our minds. You said you wanted Chinese food, but now Italian sounds better? No big deal. A week in the Caribbean seemed a good idea, but now you'd rather go skiing. A couple of phone calls, and it is done.

title: Britain's Mainstream Muslims Find Voice
description: LONDON, March 5 - Inayat Bunglawala had just finished his talk on "Islamophobia and the Media" at the London Muslim Center when a man stood and berated him. "Where is your beard and your thobe?" Mr. Bunglawala said the man shouted, referring to the long garment worn by some Muslim men. "How dare you come to the mosque without them. How dare you preach about the new Koran."

description: PERHAPS merlot producers will breathe easier now that "Sideways" has won only one Oscar -- for best adapted screenplay -- after being nominated for five.

title: The 'Ready to Work' Test
description: New York vaulted to the head of the national school reform movement, when, after bolstering curriculum and teaching standards, it required aspiring high school graduates to pass five rigorous state examinations. The exams cover English, math, science, United States history and government, and global history and geography.

title: Next, the Shrills?
description: The Kills have a new album out this week. Or is it the Stills? Wait, it might be the Thrills . Even dedicated followers of indie rock can be excused for confusing those semi-homonymous bands, which has each recently ascended into at least cult favor. (And let's not even get into the Killers. Or the Little Killers.) Alison Mosshart of the Kills once ran into problems with someone who should have known better; a video treatment for the Kills song "The Good Ones" was sent to the band with "The Thrills/'The Good Ones"' written on the DVD label. "So we just threw it away," she said. "It was, like, 'Nope, not this guy."' She said that while "kids that are really into music don't get confused," she and her bandmate, Jamie Hince, had joked about the pileup of names: "We started making up other names that are probably going to start happening, like the Spills. That's probably a real band, we just don't know yet." Before we find out, here's a quick guide to telling the current "ill" bands apart.

title: The Paths Couples Travel When They Stray (or at Least Consider It)
description: HUNCHED over a hamburger and fries in Park City, Utah, six weeks ago, Mike Binder looked worried. His new movie, "The Upside of Anger," starring Joan Allen and Kevin Costner, had wowed a large audience at the Sundance Film Festival the night before, and early reviews in Rolling Stone and The Hollywood Reporter were laudatory. Mr. Binder's spaniel eyes brightened at the memory. Then he started worrying again. Would New Line, the studio releasing this independently financed film, give it a good send-off? "They're not that heavily invested," he fretted, descending deeper into paranoia. "They could make money just releasing the DVD!"

Geese swam in the unfrozen parts, and a few people trudged down snowy paths devoid of orange, except for the odd traffic cone marking a row of naked steel bases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRAFLET, ROBERT F., SR.
description: TRAFLET--Robert F., Sr., passed away on Monday, February 14, 2005 after a brief battle with cancer. Mr. Traflet founded Neumann Advisors, Inc, an equity management firm, where he worked until his recent illness. Mr. Traflet spent most of his career at Allied Signal Corporation. He joined the company in 1958 and continued there for more than thirty years, holding a variety of management positions including the office of president of three divisions: Plastics and Functional Chemicals, Fibers, and Fluorine Products. In 1989, he testified on behalf of Allied Signal before a US Senate Committee on the subject of ozone depletion. While at Allied Signal, Mr. Traflet was also appointed to serve as a member of New Jersey Governor Brendan T. Byrne's Capital Needs Commission. For many years, Mr. Traflet was active in St. Anne's Parish, Fair Lawn, New Jersey and had served as president of their Board of Education. He also served as President of the Board of Education of the Archdiocese of Newark. More recently, he was a member of the board of directors of the Picatinny Technical Innovation Center. Mr. Traflet held a Bachelor of Science degree in Chemical Engineering from Villanova University and a Master's of Business Administration from Fairleigh Dickinson University. The funeral was held at Mt. Carmel RC Church on February 18. In lieu of flowers, donations in Robert Traflet's memory may be sent to St. Vincent's Hospital, NY, NY

description: IN Buenos Aires, Porteos, as the city's inhabitants are called, do sleep (this is siesta territory after all) -- they just don't do it at night.

title: TAKING THE MORAL HIGH GROUND
description: After years of dispute, the New Jersey Senate has agreed to impose restrictions on political contributions by those who do business with the state and sent the measure to Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey for his signature. The 34-to-0 vote capped a long and contentious effort to curb the state's notorious "pay to play" politics and, campaign finance experts said, will give New Jersey the strongest law in the nation to limit the influence of campaign cash on the awarding of government contracts. As the flow of money into political campaigns was swelling in the last few years along with the list of public officials prosecuted for corruption, pressure to act had reached the point where some legislators were simply embarrassed into voting for anything bearing the rubric of reform, they conceded. Laura Mansnerus

title: Pop-Up

I would cry out, "Let down your hair!" and turn the cardboard page to see if she did that to trick the cruel enchantress and help the prince climb up the tower to her chamber.

"The heat off these movies is huge," Lucas said as he drank a glass of red wine at Mayrose diner in Manhattan. "Everyone in L.A. is saying, 'What do you want?' " His smile suggested a kind of sexy willfulness. "And that's why I'm doing Broadway. Why not run from all this pressure and be on the stage in 'The Glass Menagerie' for the next five months?"

My concern is that this may be viewed as a change in ownership that will result in the loss of my right to sell the apartment without the need for board approval, as is the right of the original owners. . . . G. Katona, Manhattan.

There was that neighbor who redid his bathrooms and knocked out a wall in the living room, and also a house around the corner that seemed to grow a whole new wing.

title: Breaking Away
description: I was on an errand worthy of Hermes, messenger of Zeus. It was also the best boondoggle available to copy boys at The New York Times, where I worked for several months in the spring of 1960, little suspecting that I was making what is now called a life choice. The errand, as barked out by Sammy Solovitz, the tiny insomniac who supervised the copy boys, was to "go get the weather." That meant riding the subway all the way down to Rector Street -- I always took the local train so as to have more time with whatever novel I was reading -- and then walking over to the Weather Bureau on Battery Park Place, where I was instructed to say: "I'm from The Times. I've come for the weather." This was after the age of gaslight, it may be noted, but well before the advent of the Internet or fax machine. The weather came in the form of a mimeographed map, which was handed over in a plain brown envelope. On this particular evening, which abruptly ended my first term of employment at the paper, the Weather Bureau clerk said I needed to call home immediately. There was an emergency. My bride of 10 months then informed me that my mother was being taken by ambulance to Mount Sinai Hospital following an overdose of pills in her hotel room on the East Side. It was not clear that the hospital would be able to save her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNEIDER, LEON D.
description: SCHNEIDER--Leon D. Died on March 2, 2005 at the age of 71. A passionate New Yorker, Mr. Schneider was a graduate of Tilden High School, Columbia University and N.Y.U. Law School. A practicing member of the New York bar for more than 47 years, Mr. Schneider began his legal career with the Waterfront Commission and then with the N.Y.C. Housing and Redevelopment Board. He authored "A Guide to the Court System" under the aegis of the Institute for Judicial Administration. He was a long term President of the Gustave Hartman Y in Rockaway Beach, Queens. Mr. Schneider is survived by his children Daniel, William and Elizabeth and by his grandchildren, Taryn, Dean, Max, Tyler, Cole and Preston. Graveside services Sunday March 7th, 11:00 A.M. at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale. Donations in his memory may be made to "Roy Reuther Senior Center" 718-471-3110, in lieu of flowers.

title: Halfway House and Garden
description: NOTHING like five months of canned peas, white potatoes instead of freshly dug fingerlings, iceberg lettuce and rock-hard tomatoes from the hothouse served up in the Big House to make one pine for the backyard garden again, eh? As a gardener in the Hudson Valley, I have to confess that no garden writing I've read in the last 10 years has touched me as much as something Martha Stewart said last fall. About to enter the slammer -- staring at five months of intimate contact with drug felons, hardened guards and a miserable cot -- what was on her mind? She hoped she would be released in time to start her spring garden. Gardeners everywhere, rejoice. Ms. Stewart is one of us. And once again among us, well, almost -- for the next five months she's confined to her estate in Bedford.

All the elements of his past -- growing up with an embarrassing last name in a rough part of Brooklyn, learning to be funny to ward off schoolyard bullies, running a strip club for five years and doing standup for eight -- everything had been leading up to this.

title: Real ID's, Real Dangers
description: Have you ever wondered what good it does when they look at your driver's license at the airport? Let me assure you, as a former bureaucrat partly responsible for the 1996 decision to create a photo-ID requirement, it no longer does any good whatsoever. The ID check is not done by federal officers but by the same kind of minimum-wage rent-a-cops who were doing the inspection of carry-on luggage before 9/11. They do nothing to verify that your license is real. For $48 you can buy a phony license on the Internet (ask any 18-year-old) and fool most airport ID checkers. Airport personnel could be equipped with scanners to look for the hidden security features incorporated into most states' driver's licenses, but although some bars use this technology to spot under-age drinkers, airports do not. The photo-ID requirement provides only a false sense of security.

title: Something Lurks in the Attic: A Metaphor
