But the attic in "Sister Week," at Centenary Stage here, isn't quite so accommodating. It's so crammed with junk that when one character makes the mistake of opening its door, she is practically killed by the avalanche that spills out.

title: Is a Cinema Studies Degree the New M.B.A.?
description: RICK HERBST, now attending Yale Law School, may yet turn out to be the current decade's archetypal film major. Twenty-three years old, he graduated last year from the University of Notre Dame, where he studied filmmaking with no intention of becoming a filmmaker. Rather, he saw his major as a way to learn about power structures and how individuals influence each other.

title: The Accidental Princess
description: Sherie Rene Scott, actress Broadway divas these days -- to the extent the category even survives -- are too often humorless, leather-lunged Valkyries impervious to emotion. But Sherie Rene Scott, who can belt with the best of them, is a new kind of musical star, or perhaps a throwback: voluptuously vulnerable yet deeply funny. As Christine Colgate, the apparently clueless mark of the titular con men in the just-opened "Dirty Rotten Scoundrels," she's continuing her investigation -- which began in earnest with a winning turn as the fashionista princess Amneris in Broadway's "Aida" -- into an almost aerodynamic question: How much serious acting can you smuggle into a broad comic role in a featherweight genre and still have it lift off?

title: Congo Tribal Killings Create a New Wave of Refugees
description: BUNIA, Congo, March 4 - Louise Dhikpala has run for her life so many times in recent years that she has lost track of her escapes from death. The first was in 1999, when violence erupted here in the lawless Ituri region in northeastern Congo. The most recent was in January. In the intervening years, she has run and run and run.

title: Welcome to Sherwood Forest, Er, Wal-Mart
description: THE recent bankruptcy filing of Winn-Dixie Stores, the supermarket chain, would seem to be the latest evidence that Wal-Mart, dreaded by competitors as retailing's 24-hour-a-day death star, has lost none of its price-cutting potency. The company's apparent invincibility is part of what galls its critics, whose opposition led to the cancellation of a proposed Wal-Mart in Queens.

title: As Clinton Wins G.O.P. Friends, Her Rivals' Task Toughens
description: The intimate gathering at a private home in Corning, N.Y., was pretty typical for an upstate fund-raiser featuring Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton: dozens of donors clustered in the terrace, listening to her speak, as they sipped wine and nibbled on hors d'oeuvres.

title: Amy Miller, Brian Friedman
description: Amy Lynn Miller, the daughter of Nancy and Fred Miller of Fort Lee, N.J., was married last evening to Brian Lawrence Friedman, a son of Francine and Michael Friedman of Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi David Holtz officiated at the Pierre in New York. Cantor Margot E.B. Goldberg took part in the ceremony.

title: Care To Brush Up On Dickens?
description: PRINCETON - YOU can never tell what will prompt a person to make a sudden and wild career move. Wars have often done it. Winning the lottery can lift many a nose from the grindstone. And so, of course, can divorce. For George Christian Newlin, it was divorce.

title: QUICK BITE/Westwood; Soup, Salad and Sunshine
description: Step into the Rolling Pin Cafe in Westwood, and you might think you've wandered into a 19th-century Midwestern tearoom. Sunshine slants through large windows into a narrow whitewashed room that holds eight small tables. Country antiques spice up the walls, but this kitchen has come a long way from the days of Betty Crocker. Rolling Pin's chef, Matt Foley, is a blue ribbon student of the Institute for Culinary Education, and his menu reflects contemporary taste.

title: Prize Fight
description: TWO weeks ago, 18 finalists were announced for the first Man Booker International Prize, a lifetime achievement award for fiction published in English. The biennial accolade is open to writers of any nationality, and the winner will be named in June. The finalists include four Americans: Saul Bellow, Philip Roth, John Updike and Cynthia Ozick; and three British writers: Ian McEwan, Doris Lessing and Muriel Spark.

title: Punta del Este Sparkles Once More, Day and Night
description: IT was shortly after midnight on a warm summer night at the harbor in Punta del Este, Uruguay, and tanned young couples were streaming out of restaurants, wondering what to do next. Walk down the block to one of those well-appointed bars that would remain open until dawn? Or head over to a discothque on the beach? And what about that all-night electronic music festival at the old airfield?

title: Shelby Brown and Cy Coleman
description: BEFORE she met Cy Coleman, the Broadway composer and jazz pianist, Shelby Brown Coleman was, in her words, a "flannel shirt girl." She had surveyed roads in Idaho, worked as a baby sitter for a community of feminists in Iowa and run a store, Video Rodeo, in Bozeman, Mont.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOOTNICK, LOUIS
description: GOOTNICK--Louis, 94 years old, died on February 26, 2005 in Boca Raton, FL, and is survived by his cherished son, Dr. David Gootnick, and beloved daughter-in-law, Margaret Mary Gootnick. Louis' wife, Esther, a beautiful, intelligent, and loving woman, passed away in 1999. His daughter, Luba Lisa, a renowned Broadway and television star, passed away in 1972. Louis' son and daughterin-law are the authors of several books and are nationally recognized authorities and seminar leaders in the areas of management, communication, and team building. Their current book is Action Tools for Effective Managers, used by managers worldwide. Louis Gootnick was a man of exemplary character and achievement and a "role model" to all who knew him. During his working career, he was a highly respected New York City Police Officer, New York City science and math teacher, and grievance representative for the United Federation of Teachers. Funeral services were held at Sinai Chapels in Fresh Meadows, New York. At the funeral, Louis Gootnick received the greatest honor of a full scale "honor guard" from his brothers and sisters of the New York City Police Department. In the Eulogy, Dr. David Gootnick proudly shared his father's Hebrew name, revealing the essence of this special man: "And to all who knew him, my father had the strength and courage of a lion and the heart of an angel. In fact, his Hebrew name encompasses his character and spirit, Arye Leb Ben Yisrael--which means 'Lion Heart, Son of Israel."'

title: Walking? In the Suburbs? How Weird
description: To the Editor:

title: Homes Without Addresses
description: Face Fines in Rocky Hill Faced with emergency personnel who were having difficulty finding addresses, Rocky Hill officials are considering fining residents who do not have numbers on their houses, or have numbers that are not visible from the street.

title: 'Cast of Shadows': Copycat Killer
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: The Refresh Button article on this page last Sunday, about Philippe Kahn, the founder of LightSurf Technologies, misidentified the first company he founded. It was Borland International, not Starfish Software.

title: Of Taxation and Inhalation
description: RESPONDING to the surge in cigarettes sales via the Internet, New York State's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, recently observed that online purchases "present a significant threat to public health because they provide easy access to cheap cigarettes, which increases smoking rates, particularly among children." That's right, but the statement implies that Internet businesses are to blame for this problem. In fact, government -- including New Jersey's -- is the culprit. High cigarette taxes have spawned and spurred the online sales market. Worse, those taxes have also created a cigarette black market.

title: Corrections
description: An entry on the Residential Sales page on Jan. 23 for a one-bedroom, one-bath co-op at 500A Grand Street on the Lower East Side of Manhattan that sold for $470,000 included an incorrect description of the building's amenities. And a correction on Jan. 30 attributed the description incompletely. The incorrect information -- that the building has a doorman and an attended elevator -- was provided by Eychner Associates, one of two brokers involved in the sale, not by "the broker." This correction was delayed by a miscommunication at The Times.

title: Goodbye Too Soon
description: What we saw on the monitor looked more like a cinematic alien than a 20-week-old fetus. Instead of arms, there were truncated flippers, and it looked like those drawings I've seen demonstrating how close man and dolphin are on the evolutionary scale. The legs were gnocchi-shaped buds that barely protruded from the pelvis. The chest cavity was deformed as well, although we wouldn't know that until later.

title: A Texan Stumbles in King Arthur's Court
description: Correction Appended

title: A Tax Net That Catches Only Minnows
description: EARLY each year, as the annual chore of filling out tax forms begins, the federal government announces indictments of tax evaders, hoping to deter anyone who may be tempted to cut a few corners.

title: Where the Buffalo Roam
description: JOSH TOWNSEND, a spike-haired city slicker, is relocating to the boondocks. "We're moving somewhere beyond cellphone service," he says with a groan from the back seat of his parents' car in the opening scene of "Buffalo Dreams," a Disney Channel movie that has its premiere Friday night at 8.

description: WASHINGTON - Arabs put their women in veils. We put ours in the stocks.

title: Stamping Out Steroids Takes Time
description: Commissioner Bud Selig and Major League Baseball have taken a lot of heat over the last several months for their supposed failure to grapple forthrightly with the sport's steroid problem. Some have even suggested that people in the commissioner's office have been winking at one another while they make public pronouncements against steroid use.

title: Uncaptive Minds
description: Buruma's article echoed my experience at Great Meadow, a maximum-security prison in Comstock, N.Y., where Skidmore College for years ran a similar program -- one of those shut down in the mid-90's in part because of the cessation of Pell Grants for inmates. One graduate, who was still facing many years in prison, delivered baccalaureate remarks to his fellow inmates. I'll never forget his opening words: "When I'm in the classroom here, the walls come down."

title: Sticking Up for Shea, Mets Fans Take Aim at the Mayor
description: The Mets of 2005, as any shred of their recent promotional material will tell you, are the New Mets. As they proceed with spring training in Florida, the long-derided Quixotes of Queens are fielding expensive new players that could very well lift the team into contention for something other than insults.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TEPFER, NAOMI FLAX
description: TEPFER--Naomi Flax. Age 102. Wife of the late Professor John J. Tepfer, mother of Ruth Watkins and Nina Bakstansky and the last of her 13 brothers and sisters. Service at the Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at West 90th Street, NYC, on Monday, March 7, at 1 PM.

title: Hotel Indigo in Atlanta
description: THE BASICS -- A former Days Inn stripped of its stain-resistant carpets and fire-resistant bedspreads, the Hotel Indigo in Atlanta, is the first of a new line of affordable yet stylish hotels from the InterContinental Hotels Group, which owns Holiday Inn and other chains. The idea is to give travelers some of the elegance -- but not the frills or the price tag -- of a W or a Delano. A second Hotel Indigo will open in Chicago in June, and a third is under construction in Sarasota, Fla.

title: DataBank; Jobs Report Starts a Rally on Wall Street
description: The stock market powered ahead last week, propelling both the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Dow Jones industrial average to their highest levels since 2001.

title: As Sex-Offender Notices Rise, Some Say Even More Is Better
description: EVER since New York's version of Megan's Law was passed in 1996, local authorities on Long Island have been notifying communities about the presence of sex offenders, many of whom had just gotten out of prison. But a court ruling last summer has resulted in a considerable spike in the number of new notifications on Long Island, some of them naming people who had lived with the secret for years.

title: Here Comes The Class of 2005. Can It Pay the Rent?
description: At first, looking into that room is a jolt. One day, it's a reverberating mound of teenage chaos; the next, with its occupant off to college, it's a gaping, eerily silent hole -- a bed, a desk, a stray sock or a T-shirt on the floor.

title: If He Wanted a Stadium, There Would Be One
description: IN the 1850's, when Boss Tweed was a young politician, voters in his Lower East Side district sent him to Washington as a congressman. Though surrounded by national celebrities and political figures, Tweed chafed with boredom, having, as he complained to a reporter years later, "to spend my time in hearing a lot of snoozers discuss the tariff and the particulars of a contract to carry the mails from Paducah to Schoharie."

title: Affirming Inaction
description: I am a minority student who opposes affirmative action. Thus I decided not to reveal my color in my law-school application. It is extremely hard, however, to omit race from my personal statement: race has had a large impact on my decision to go to law school and on my experience volunteering in the community. What is the more ethical course -- to disclose my race and be an honest hypocrite or omit mentioning it and feel dishonest? Anonymous, San Francisco

title: The Sorry, and Dangerous, State of Infant Health Care
description: The Lancet, the British medical journal, has published four reports, called the "Neonatal Survival Series," about health care for babies in the first four weeks of life. All four can be found at www.thelancet.com/journal/journal.isaacr.

title: Will the Real Thug Please Stand Up
description: For a bad guy, the Thug certainly has a lot of people eager to claim him as their very own.

title: The Man Who Made California Dreams Look the Way They Do
description: LOS ANGELES - "THE key to my work is that I stopped, physically, to observe something," said Julius Shulman, the 94-year-old architectural photographer. "I raised my camera and recorded my observations." As he spoke of that slow, hypnotic process, he was in the midst of some frenetic multitasking: laughing and telling stories, interrupting himself to answer his incessantly ringing phone, smiling as his photo was snapped.

description: PAYNE-HYNES--Vernona C. The officers & brokers of Brown Harris Stevens are deeply saddened by the passing of our longtime & valued Residential broker, Vernona Payne on February 26, 2005.

description: Correction Appended

title: Capturing Local Jocks for Posterity
description: RICK SPIDALIERI and Chris DiFalco started playing football together in the fifth grade, and didn't part ways until they graduated from Scarsdale High School almost five years ago. Last fall they returned to the local ball fields, this time as partners in a business, RC Photo Works.

title: A Debate Filled With Faith
description: AFTER the 74th General Convention of the Episcopal Church elected an openly gay bishop and left decisions about same-sex unions to each diocese in 2003, the leaders of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Darien sent a letter to their congregation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHACTER, RALPH
description: SCHACTER--Ralph. March 5. Survived by adoring wife Helen Jankoski, devoted children John (Mary) Schacter and Alan (Durelle) Schacter, and loving grandchildren Philip, Michael, William and Paul, Emma and Jonah. Ralph lives on through his aesthetic vision, uncompromising integrity and boundless generosity. Graveside funeral March 7, 2 PM, Willowbrook Cemetery, Westport, CT. SCHACTER -- Ralph. Fawn Associates and Mill Management mourn the passing of Ralph Schacter. Together with partner, Seymour Schwartz, Ralph was responsible for creating Putnam Green, Weaver's Hill, Greenwich Office Park and The Mill in Greenwich, CT. Ralph never allowed his concern for people and causes to take a backseat to the financial bottom line. His compassion and integrity, together with his noncomformity, will remain in our hearts and minds forever.

title: At MoMA, White Hats and Cold Feet
description: WHEN the renovated Museum of Modern Art opened on West 53rd Street last fall, its expanses of glass stunned some and awed others, while its $20 ticket price prompted a few to complain they'd have to skip lunch. While the transplanted Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden offers a taste of the familiar, with works like "St. John the Baptist Preaching," by Rodin, above; "Moonbird," by Joan Mir, foreground right; and "She-Goat," by Picasso, below, the recent snowfall gave them a jaunty new look.

title: The Land Where Hope Springs Eternal
description: THE Radisson Bay Harbor in Tampa is not exactly a modern hotel. And it is definitely not trendy. Square rooms are stacked on top of one another, each overlooking the rippling currents of Tampa Bay. Two miles from the airport, in a neighborhood of chain restaurants and other chain hotels, the Radisson feels businesslike, almost sterile.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SUDACK, LILLIAN
description: SUDACK--Lillian. Never forgotten, always loved. Wonderful wife, mother, aunt, friend. Lynda & A

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL
description: Louisville Marches To Title Continuing their late-season surge, the No. 9 Cardinals (26-4, 14-2) beat DePaul, 66-62, to clinch the Conference USA regular-season title. Louisville has won 15 of 16 games.

title: A Destabilizing Bit of Research
description: The Bush administration's regressive plan to develop powerful "bunker busting" nuclear weapons was held in check last year only after Congress failed to come up with research money. Ominously, lawmakers from both parties see a strong chance the money will be found this year because of concern over rogue nuclear states like North Korea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EWIG, THELMA
description: EWIG -- Thelma. Devoted aunt, mentor and friend passed away February 8, 2005, at age 89, and is survived by her niece Laura, nephew Russell, sister-in-law Lillian and longtime friend and associate Anita O'Gara. Born in Vienna, Austria, in 1915, she was the only woman to graduate from NYU Law School in 1941, when women lawyers were a rarity. For 60 years Thelma served as a successful corporate attorney and trusted partner. She will be missed by all her friends, family and associates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'CONNOR, MARCELLA BER NADETTE (HOGAN)
description: O'CONNOR -- Marcella Ber nadette (Hogan). 85, died of pulmonary fibrosis at Winter Haven Hospital, Winter Haven, FL Tuesday, March 1, 2005. She was born to Martin and Marcella (Mullins) Hogan in NYC November 16, 1919 and graduated with the first class of Queens College of the City of New York. She married Robert Emmet O'Connor in Miami, FL on December 30, 1942. From 1954 until 1969 she resided in Greenwich, CT. During that time she was instrumental in establishing the Foundation School in Orange, CT in 1965 for children with special education needs. In the years that followed she served on the Boards of Trustees of the Pine Point School in Camden, ME and Riverview School in Sandwich, MA. In the 1960's she was president of the Catholic Women's Club of Greenwich and president of the Marian Book Club. In 1970 she moved to Amenia, NY where she was a communicant at St. Joseph's Church in Millbrook, NY and an instructor in the Confraternity of Christian Doctrine. In more recent years she had been a member of Holy Spirit Church in Lake Wales, FL where she made her principal residence. She was an active and sustaining member of the Chesterton Society. She is survived by her loving husband of 62 years, Robert Emmet O'Connor; a daughter, Kathleen of Lakeland, FL; four sons, Robert, Jr. of Rhinebeck, NY, Dennis of Longmeadow, MA, Brian of Atlanta, GA, Christopher of Housatonic, MA; seven grandchildren, Thomas Tormey of Bronxville, NY, Sheila Tormey of London, England and Caitlin, Rory, Jane, Margery and Jack O'Connor of Longmeadow and Westfield, MA; and two great-grandchildren, William and Caroline Tormey of Bronxville, NY. Visiting hours will be from 2 to 4 p.m. and 7 to 9 p.m. on Monday, March 7 at the Allen Funeral Home, 3270 Franklin Avenue, Millbrook, NY. A Funeral Mass will be held 11 a.m. on Tuesday, March 8 at St. Joseph's Church in Millbrook, NY followed by burial in St. Joseph's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation, 1440 West Washington Blvd., Chicago, IL 60607.

title: Benefits
description: Families in Toyland TODAY -- A family party at Cipriani in the International Toy Center, 200 Fifth Avenue (23rd Street), will benefit leukemia, cancer and AIDS research supported by the T.J. Martell Foundation. The event begins at 1 p.m. with a buffet lunch, carnival booths, arcade games, miniature golf, face painting and other activities, and ends at 5. Tickets, $75 for adults and $25 for children under 18, from (212)833-5444.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTH, ANNETTE
description: ROTH--Annette. Died March 4, 2005. Beloved wife of Irwin, cherished mother of Marilyn, Ilene and Sharon, devoted sister of Gloria and Bernice, adored grandmother of Joshua, Lauren and Naomi, loving mother-in-law to Michael and Stephen and brother-in-law of David, beloved aunt of Diane, Susan, June and David. She will be sorely missed. Graveside services, 10:30 AM, Monday, March 7, Mount Eden Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Donations may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, or Alzheimer's research.

title: Education Law Finds Few Fans in Utah
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 4 - Utah was poised to deliver a rebuke to President Bush's No Child Left Behind law this week when the state's Republican governor stepped off the plane after a visit to Washington.

title: The Sound of Construction
description: WHEN Paul Newman starred as John Murphy, a police officer, in "Fort Apache, the Bronx" in 1981, he patrolled a burned-out wasteland, a hostile landscape inhabited by junkies, winos, pimps, hookers, cop killers and killer cops.

title: Museum Paves Way For Sale of Painting
description: EXECUTIVES at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington took two steps in the past week to move forward with their plan to sell George Grosz's painting "Eclipse of the Sun" to a private collector for $19 million, and to use some of that money for a proposed museum expansion.

title: The Supermarket in Your Backyard
description: THIS month, Whole Foods, the natural and organic supermarket that was founded more than two decades ago in Austin, Texas, will open its fifth store in New York in Manhattan's Union Square. Understandably, many folks are concerned that this new store will signal the beginning of the end for the fabled Greenmarket that now commands the square.

title: Corrections
description: An essay in the Book Review last Sunday about Winston Churchill and neoconservatives misspelled the given name of the author of "The Age of Reagan." He is Steven F. Hayward, not Stephen.

title: A Welfare System for Low-Spending N.B.A. Owners
description: The N.B.A. has embarked on a grand and peculiar experiment to alter the league's financial structure through a luxury tax. The system has changed the league, but perhaps not in the manner envisioned by its architects.

title: LOOKING AHEAD
description: When Intel's chief executive, Craig R. Barrett, spoke at the company's most recent developers conference -- probably his last, because he reached Intel's mandatory retirement age of 65 in August -- he took time from outlining the company's future to discuss his own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINBERG, BARBARA D.
description: FINBERG--Barbara D. Born February 26, 1929 in Pueblo, CO. Died Saturday, March 5, 2005 in New York City. Married to the late Alan R. Finberg on June 21, 1953, in Boston, MA. Retired from the Carnegie Corp. of New York where she was Executive Vice President. Board member of serveral foundations and not-for-profit organizations. She is survived by her brother Bob Denning and his wife Kate, and brother-in-law Donald Finberg, and his wife Hela and their children, Karen and Dana. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to The Barbara D. and Alan R. Finberg Scholarship Fund, Stanford University, Office of Development, Francis C. Arrillaga Alumni Center, 326 Galvez St, Stanford, CA 94305-6105. Memorial service will be held at a time to be determined.

While many companies have toned down anti-shareholder practices, investors must remain vigilant for executives and boards that are still in the Stone Age.

title: Wall Street Loves Tobacco. Well, for Now.
description: SMOKING is frowned upon at work, in restaurants and in courtrooms and legislatures. But there is one place where tobacco has been not only accepted but also preferred: Wall Street. Shares of tobacco companies have been stellar performers: those in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index were up 8.6 percent this year , though the index over all gained only 0.8 percent.

title: In the Balance
description: Nir Rosen (Feb. 20) notes that in 1918 the Kurds pinned their hopes on Woodrow Wilson's 14 points, with the call for autonomy for nationalities in the collapsing Ottoman Empire. Beyond autonomy, the 1920 Treaty of Svres, between the victorious Allies and Turkey, foresaw the possibility of a fully independent Kurdish state. That did not come to pass, and the Kurds have never forgotten Svres, although today they are pressing for a federalist Iraq, which will guarantee them autonomy and not independence.

description: TIGER WOODS had smashed a big drive into the 18th fairway at Doral. He had a one-stroke lead on Phil Mickelson after draining a 28-foot putt on the 17th green, and now his caddie, Steve Williams, turned and said something to him. As Woods smiled, his eyes twinkled.

Vice President Dick Cheney can do the job, as evidenced by White House transcripts, which faithfully note his comedic genius. description: ARONSON--Marilyn R. On March 5, 2005. Darling sister of Geraldine and the late Albert Aronson. Devoted daughter of the late Stella and Max Aronson. Services Monday, 12 noon, at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROMBERG, ARON A.
description: BROMBERG--Aron A. On March 1, 2005. At home at the age of 77. A former partner, his career spanned more than 50 years with Stern Metals. Aron was a member of the 24-KT Club and sat on the boards of American ORT and NCCJ. A well-respected and much-loved member of the jewelry industry, Aron was gracious with his time and available when called upon. His many charities included ORT, NYU Tisch School of the Arts and Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS. Beloved friend to Dawn Levine, John Politi and Jeff and Joan Bernstein. Donations may be made in his name to the charities listed above. Memorial service Friday, March 18 at 11:15 A.M., at "The Riverside", 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Taiwan Police Say Who Shot President, but Suspect Is Dead
description: HONG KONG, Monday, March 7 - The Taiwan police announced late Monday morning that they had identified the man who shot and injured President Chen Shui-bian on the eve of national elections a year ago.

description: ADLER--Paul. 83, died on March 6, 2005. Beloved husband of Lucille. Devoted father of David. Dear brother of Harry. He was the "Honorable Gentleman" and world traveler. Respected and loved by all. He will be sorely missed. Services Wednesday, 11:45 am, at "The Riverside," 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: We Love Him So
description: After Morgan Freeman accepted his best supporting actor Oscar last Sunday, he was not ushered off the stage to the music of "Million Dollar Baby," the movie for which he won the statuette. The moody soundtrack, which was composed by Clint Eastwood, did not even make it to stores until Tuesday and could not benefit from an immediate sales increase driven by the film's nomination for best picture.

title: All Dressed Up and Stuck in a Dispiriting Underworld
description: Paul Taylor's "Dante Variations," which received its New York premiere Friday night at City Center, is set to music by Gyorgy Ligeti but takes its cue from a sentence in Dante's "Inferno": "These are the nearly soulless whose lives concluded neither blame nor praise." In other words, it is a vision of a literally dispiriting corner of hell.

U.S. Killing of Italian Officer Stokes Anger Against War
description: ROME, March 6 - Most Italians have never supported the war in Iraq, nor liked having their troops there. But their misgivings found a physical form on Sunday, in the shape of a coffin lying in state and holding the body of an Italian intelligence officer killed in Iraq -- by an American bullet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAISEL, MELVIN L.
description: MAISEL--Melvin L. Died March 6, 2005. Devoted husband of 59 years to Selma. Beloved father of Naomi Goldis (Stanley), Marc and David (Tamara) Chernow. Cherished grandfather of Eli Duker (Ruchy), Joshua Duker (Shayna), Jonathan Duker (Susan) and Ezra. A source of great joy to Melvin was that he was able to fulfill David Ben Gurion's dream of Israel being a homeland for future generations. His eight treasured great - grandchildren were all born there. Melvin was born May 15, 1924. He was the President and CEO of Stabilization Plans for Business, Inc. in White Plains, NY. Melvin was a financial, estate and business planner specializing in planning with qualified pension and profit sharing plans and life insurance. He was associated with the Guardian Life Insurance Company for almost 40 years, and led the company in sales for 16 years. He was a lifetime member of the Guardian's President's Council and was active with the American Association of Life Underwriters, and many other national insurance groups. He lectured and wrote extensively for accounting, insurance and bar groups. He was a contributing editor for the New York State CPA Journal and many of his articles appeared in that publication. He was a founding member of the Estate Planning Council of Westchester County and the Professional Planners Forum, and served both organizations in all executive capacities. He was a founding director and Chairman of the Board of the Cornerstone Bank in Connecticut. As Chairman of the State of Israel Bonds Pension Division, he developed the Variable Rate Interest Bond. The funeral will be held at 2 pm, Monday, March 7, at Temple Sholom at 300 East Putnam Ave, Greenwich, CT. Shiva will be held at the Maisel home. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the WestchesterFairfield Hebrew Academy or UJA-Federation of Greenwich would be appreciated.

description: BARBASCH--Mark L., M.D. Beloved husband, father, grandfather. Died March 5, 2005, in New York due to complications following a fall. He was born on June 17, 1912, in Lvov, Poland. After graduating medical school in 1939, he served as a physician in the Soviet Army. After the war, he married Elsa Eckstein in Paris and immigrated to Israel where their children Avi and Annette were born. After immigrating to America, he opened a medical practice in the Bronx, practicing until his retirement. He loved being a doctor and was devoted to his patients and to his family. Following his wife's death, he met and married Esther Ancoli. He is survived by his wife Esther; his children Avi, Annette, Annie and Gary Gilbar, and Sonia and Andy Israel; and his grandchildren Sophie, Nadine, Emily, Lisa, Marc, Sarah and David. Memorial services were held at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Please make gifts in his memory to Magen David Adom (MDA).

The sum raised in the online auction, which ended Feb. 28, was slightly higher than the total of suggested opening bids, $7,459, but was only a fraction of the total estimated retail value of the items, $37,295. title: Hope in the Land of Dashed Hopes
description: For more than 40 years, the epitome of wasted potential and squandered opportunity in Africa has been Nigeria. From the time it gained independence from Britain in 1960, that behemoth of 137 million people has seemed to do its level best to fritter away every natural advantage. Given the second-highest proven oil reserves in Africa, Nigerian officials spent oil income on lavish estates in Europe instead of decent schools and water systems back home. The country that produced the Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka and arguably Africa's best author, Chinua Achebe, was better known for the cruel, thieving dictator Sani Abacha.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOOTNICK, LOUIS
description: GOOTNICK--Louis, 94 years old, died on February 26, 2005 in Boca Raton, FL, and is survived by his cherished son, Dr. David Gootnick, and beloved daughter-in-law, Margaret Mary Gootnick. Louis' wife, Esther, a beautiful, intelligent, and loving woman, passed away in 1999. His daughter, Luba Lisa, a renowned Broadway and television star, passed away in 1972. Louis' son and daughterin-law are the authors of several books and are nationally recognized authorities and seminar leaders in the areas of management, communication, and team building. Their current book is Action Tools for Effective Managers, used by managers worldwide. Louis Gootnick was a man of exemplary character and achievement and a "role model" to all who knew him. During his working career, he was a highly respected New York City Police Officer, New York City science and math teacher, and grievance representative for the United Federation of Teachers. Funeral services were held at Sinai Chapels in Fresh Meadows, New York. At the funeral, Louis Gootnick received the greatest honor of a full scale "honor guard" from his brothers and sisters of the New York City Police Department. In the Eulogy, Dr. David Gootnick proudly shared his father's Hebrew name, revealing the essence of this special man: "And to all who knew him, my father had the strength and courage of a lion and the heart of an angel. In fact, his Hebrew name encompasses his character and spirit, Arye Leb Ben Yisrael--which means 'Lion Heart, Son of Israel."'

Plans for a new permanent home for the festival were announced in 2003, but the project has been slow attracting the necessary financing. The new center is to be built in Toronto's downtown entertainment district on a parking lot now owned by the Hollywood producer Ivan Reitman, one of the developers of the project, and will include five floors of screening and conference rooms and office space. The man, Ervin Caspi, who had been staying at a residential hotel in Whitestone, Queens, was arrested at the Aqueduct Race Track, one of several tracks where authorities said he had carried out the fraud. According to a statement from prosecutors, Mr. Caspi withdrew cash advances from other people's credit card accounts and funneled the money into betting accounts at several race tracks. Mr. Caspi then withdrew cash from those accounts, officials said. When Mr. Caspi was arrested, he was carrying $171,000 in cash, as well as dozens of credit card account numbers and other people's Social Security numbers, the authorities said. description: CUTLER--Jay. Former Director of Government Relations for the American Psychiatric Association, passed away on March 4, 2005. Born in Brooklyn, NY, September 7, 1940, Mr. Cutler graduated from New York University and Brooklyn Law School, and served in the Korean War in Army Intelligence. He came to Washington, DC, where he worked in Public Service Television production and for the former Senator Jacob Javits as Staff Director of the Senate's Human Resources Committee. He then went to the APA as Director of Government Relations for 25 years and had a direct impact on such legislation as the landmark Employee Retirement income Security Act (ERISA) and the 1996 Federal Mental Health Parity Act. Mr. Cutler is survived by Randy, his wife of 53 years, daughters Hollie and Perri, son-in-law Eric Lipsetts and his cherished granddaughter Mikayla. title: Arts, Briefly; Russian Officials Say Looted War Art Can Stay
description: Russia is not obligated to return any World War II trophy art to Germany, the country's culture minister and the director of St. Petersburg's Hermitage Museum said in interviews last week. Both couched the issue in terms of the rule of law and good will. "We're not obligated to return anything to anyone," Mikhail Piotrovsky, the museum director, told the newspaper Vremya Novostei, noting a linguistic distinction: "We can hand things over." Aleksandr Sokolov, the culture minister, told the newspaper Trud that "special orders of the Ministry of Culture, injunctions of the Russian government or special laws will have to be enacted for this purpose." He criticized as arbitrary previous announcements that the controversial Baldin collection of hundreds of drawings and two paintings would be returned to Germany. The art, by Drer, Degas, Rembrandt, van Gogh, Rubens and other masters, was taken from Germany in 1945 by Viktor Baldin, an art restorer who died in 1997. However, Mr. Sokolov said Russia would be handing over silver that had belonged to the German Duke of Anhalt, who saved Soviet prisoners of war from the Nazis but perished in Soviet hands. Sergei Mironov, the speaker of the upper house of Russia's parliament, said that a decision on the Baldin collection "most likely will be made at the highest level." SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

title: The Unkindest Cut

As I walked through the place with the farmer's wife, I noticed that the cows' tails had been cut off and I asked her why. "Well, it's just easier to milk them without their tails," she explained, adding, "My husband didn't like the idea, so I did it while he was away fishing for the weekend." I felt a warm rush of affection for her husband.

World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Investor For Retailer Selected
description: A consortium led by the Marubeni Corporation trading company will buy a one-third stake in the ailing Japanese supermarket chain Daiei for nearly $600 million, the companies said. A state-backed corporate turnaround body chose Marubeni and its financial backer, the domestic buyout firm, Advantage Partners, to help overhaul Daiei. "We take our responsibility as the winning group very seriously," Marubeni's president, Nobuo Katsumata, left, told reporters at a news conference, adding that he hoped to increase his company's stake and make Daiei an affiliated firm. Under the deal, Marubeni will invest 18.6 billion yen ($177.6 million) in Daiei in return for a 10.9 percent equity share. Mr. Katsumata said that he would like to increase that figure to more than 15 percent over the next several years. Advantage Partners will provide 43.4 billion yen in return for an initial 23.4 percent stake. The combined 62 billion yen ($591.9 million) outlay will give the group more than a one-third stake in Daiei.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Broadcom To Buy Zeevo For $32 Million
description: The Broadcom Corporation, a maker of microchips for consumer electronics and computer networks, has agreed to buy Zeevo for $32 million in cash and shares to expand its wireless headset business. The price includes $29.4 million in cash and $2.6 million in restricted shares, Broadcom said yesterday. The closely held Zeevo, based in Santa Clara, Calif., makes chips and software for wireless headsets. Broadcom wants to increase sales of its products using the Bluetooth wireless technology, which allows cellular telephone headsets to work without being connected by wires to a cellphone. The market for Bluetooth headsets is expected to grow to 90 million units a year by 2008, according to the market research company In-Stat/MDR. The sale is expected to close during Broadcom's current quarter, which ends March 31, the company said. Shares of Broadcom, which is based in Irvine, Calif., rose 80 cents, to $32.11.

So it was for two aspiring "It" girls on Sunday when the premiere of the WB's new talent-search show, "The Starlet," barely mustered 1.6 million viewers to watch Faye Dunaway and the other judges dash their hopes of being the next Halle Berry. Meanwhile, the real Ms. Berry, below, eased the pain of a night without "Desperate Housewives," delivering a decisive ratings victory for ABC with "Their Eyes Were Watching God," the latest installment in Oprah Winfrey's books-on-television-club series. (CBS trailed ABC by an estimated average of 6.9 million with a night of new and recycled crime.) Coaxing an estimated 24.6 million viewers to stay up well past 11 p.m., "Their Eyes" was the best-performing of the six made-for-television movies produced under the "Oprah Winfrey Presents" shingle since the first production, "Before Women Had Wings," drew an estimated 27.9 million viewers in November 1997. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINBERG, BARBARA D.
description: FINBERG--Barbara D. A national figure in the non-profit world, an authority on children's needs, serving at the prestigious Carnegie Corporation, for some thirty-eight years, beginning as a program officer, later to become Executive Vice President. From that base, she became nationally respected for her role as a foundation executive who inspired generations of young people in their careers, tutored unskilled professionals seeking funds, nurtured fledgling new organizations, and restructured those older ones needing redirection. Her seminal work with Carnegie has led to new evidence that the earlier the intervention, the better the child's chances to be a fully functioning adult. She kept that focus throughout her career, and retiring from Carnegie, became a founding member, as Vice President, of MEM Associates, Inc., a non-profit consulting group concerned with the health and welfare of children and adults. In private and public life, Barbara Finberg was a model of what to be, by setting standards of measure of what a good life should be. Margaret E. Mahoney, President, MEM Associates Inc.

description: The presidents of Lithuania and Estonia, two former Soviet republics, announced that they would not attend ceremonies in Moscow on May 9 commemorating the 60th anniversary of the defeat of Nazi Germany, according to news reports. President Vladimir V. Putin has invited dozens of world leaders to the ceremonies on what is known in Russia as Victory Day. The Allies celebrate V-E, or Victory in Europe, Day on May 8. In the Baltic states, however, the end of World War II began what was widely viewed as the start of 46 years of renewed occupation by the Soviet Union. President Vaira Vike-Freiberga of Latvia, the third Baltic state, agreed to attend last month, but infuriated Russian officialdom by saying that on May 9, Russians would celebrate with vodka and dried fish while recalling "how they heroically conquered the Baltics." title: Arts, Briefly; New York Press Editor Quits Over Article
description: Jeff Koyen, the editor of New York Press, the pugnacious free weekly, resigned yesterday over a cover article last week that ridiculed the failing health of Pope John Paul II. The article, a column by Matt Taibbi, had the headline "The 52 Funniest Things About the Upcoming Death of the Pope." It also ran with a parody of a New York Post cover page printed inside the newspaper. Many politicians and public figures spoke out against the article, and in The Daily News on Friday, Representative Anthony D. Weiner, a Democratic candidate for mayor, said: "Everyone has a right to free speech, but I hope New Yorkers exercise their right to take as many of these rags as they can and put them in the trash." Mr. Koyen, who had been the editor of New York Press for two years, said he had been told by the publisher, Chris Rohland, that he was being suspended for two weeks without pay. He quit instead, and had harsh words for Mr. Rohland and the owner of the paper, Avalon Equity Group. "They refused to stand up against Rep. Weiner," he said in a statement. "They refused to condemn his call-to-action as immoral (and illegal)." Mr. Rohland said that Mr. Koyen defied a request to not run the New York Post cover parody and his suspension was due to insubordination. BEN SISARIO

Bombardier said the new model, to be available early next year, would have a range of 2,516 miles, about 275 miles more than the current version of the plane, which seats 70 to 78 passengers. The new model will carry "greater payloads over greater distances," said Rod Williams, the vice president for aircraft programs at Bombardier's regional aircraft division. In recent years, domestic airlines have shifted larger shares of their capacity to small regional jets, which are usually configured only with coach seats. SeatGuru.com, a Web site that displays seating diagrams for jets in the fleets of various airlines, says of the CRJ700 models that "many fliers find them to be generally uncomfortable" because of narrow seats and cramped space.

Sales will be 1.62 billion euros ($2.1 billion) to 1.65 billion euros, down from 1.69 billion euros in 2004, the company said. Consumers are spending less amid rising unemployment, and sentiment will remain "very, very negative," the chief executive, Silvano Cassano, said. title: LUFTHANSA AND NETJETS WILL COLLABORATE ON CHARTER JETS
description: Deutsche Lufthansa and NetJets, owned by Berkshire Hathaway, will cooperate on chartered business-jet services, starting midyear, the companies said yesterday. Lufthansa's chief executive, Wolfgang Mayrhuber, and the chief executive of NetJets, Richard Santulli, will give details about the new venture, Lufthansa Private Jet, in Munich tomorrow. Lufthansa said in October that it was talking with potential partners about providing business-jet services for companies and individuals willing to pay higher fares for direct flights at short notice. NetJets operates a fleet of 550 planes and has more than 4,000 customers. It is based in Woodbridge, N.J.; Lufthansa's headquarters are in Cologne, Germany.

title: Arts, Briefly; New Leader for SAG
description: The Screen Actors Guild board has elected Greg Hessinger as its new national executive director. Mr. Hessinger, a lawyer who is currently the national executive director of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, will succeed Bob Pisano, who has held the title since September 2001. Members of both unions overwhelmingly ratified a new three-year contract on Feb. 28. Mr. Hessinger said, "If SAG is to successfully confront the challenges before it, the guild must create an internal culture where the values of unity and consensus are adopted as pillars in the foundation of this great, tradition-rich institution." He will take over on May 2. CATHERINE BILLEY

She was a member of the Colony Club, The Mayflower Society, and a past national president of The National Society of The Colonial Dames of America. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDENSON, ISABELLE
description: GOLDENSON--Isabelle. The Board and staff of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City note with great sorrow the passing of our founder and benefactor, Isabelle Goldenson. Isabelle and her late husband, Leonard H. Goldenson, together with Ethel and Jack Hausman, Irving Sloan and other parents, founded UCP/NYC in 1947. It is still the flagship affiliate of a nationwide movement, which they also founded in 1949. Hers is a remarkable legacy. Today, UCP/NYC serves over 11,000 individuals each year, and more than 2400 of them receive year-round ongoing services through 80 adult, children, family support, health care, recreational and residential programs. Isabelle was active in UCP/NYC's Women's Division for nearly 50 years. Her daughter, Loreen Arbus, continues that tradition as a Co-Chair of our Women Who Care Luncheon, which celebrates the accomplishments of women as caregivers, volunteers and professionals. We extend our deepest sympathy to Loreen and her sister Maxine Goldenson, to Isabelle's grandson and her entire family. Martin Hausman, President Edward R. Matthews, Executive Director, Ronald J.H. Napal Chief Development Officer

The festival, the 10th, will run from July 12 to July 31 with performers from 25 countries. With music by Stephin Merritt, below, and book by Erik Ehn, "My Life as a Fairy Tale," the Andersen music-theater piece, will be directed by Chen Shi-Zheng in its world premiere. "Shadowtime," based on the life of Walter Benjamin, receives its American premiere. The writings of James Joyce inspired "Ocean," the Cunningham-Cage piece, which played at the festival in 1996. Mr. Wilson will direct "I La Galigo," which tells the Indonesian creation myth through music, dance, poetry and theater. Ms. Mnouchkine and Le Thtre du Soleil of Paris present "Le Dernier Caravansrail," which tells the story of Middle Eastern refugees seeking asylum in the West. title: World Briefing | Asia: Steps To A Tsunami Warning System
description: Officials in charge of the existing international tsunami warning system have a schedule for extending it to the Indian Ocean. The Intergovernmental Oceanographic Commission, a United Nations agency based in Paris, also said it had made progress in providing an alert network for the Caribbean region, the Atlantic and the Mediterranean. Beginning next month, Indian Ocean countries will receive seismic data from earthquake monitoring stations in Japan and Hawaii. They will then install tide gauges at 6 sites in the eastern ocean and upgrade 15 others to create a rudimentary alert system to be operative by the fall. A final, more sophisticated system that will be in place by the end of 2006 will include a regional warning system and seabed sensors. John Tagliabue (NYT)

description: ONE of the most fascinating stories of late 20th-century winemaking was the rebirth of the Priorat region in northeastern Spain. In the last 25 years, it has been completely transformed from a moribund area to one that makes intense, concentrated, expensive wines that manage the difficult trick of appealing to modern, globalized tastes without sacrificing their own distinctive character.

Arts, Briefly; The Royal Show
description: Camilla Parker Bowles dressed in jodhpurs brandishing her riding crop over Prince Charles. Diana, Princess of Wales, dancing romantically with Dodi al-Fayed. If Charles's impending marriage to Mrs. Parker Bowles hasn't given Britain's royal family enough to worry about, it now can contend with moments like those in a new show created by the Danish choreographer Peter Schaufuss and based on the life of Charles's first wife, which opened last night in Manchester, England. The show, "Diana the Princess," depicts Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip turning their backs on the proceedings and a corps de ballet of paparazzi, as well as music by Elgar and the Cure and sound bites from Diana's revealing television interview with Martin Bashir, Tony Blair referring to the "people's princess" after her death and her brother Earl Spencer's eulogy at her funeral. Mr. Schaufuss, who knew Diana in the 1980's when he was artistic director of the English National Ballet and she was its patron, conceived and choreographed the show. His partner, the British ballerina Zara Deakin, above, dances the role of Diana, while their son, Luke Schaufuss, 11, plays Prince William. "It's not so much a ballet as a 'musical without words,"' Mr. Schaufuss said, "a celebration definitely, and my personal take on this very special person and her short but telling life. I would never have faced this tremendous challenge had I not known the person behind Princess Diana to the extent that I did." "Diana the Princess" runs through Saturday at the Palace Theater. A transfer to London is planned for May. PAM KENT

But now a new movie is encouraging them to get rid of their postwar anxieties and join in for a good laugh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELLARD, JUSTICE WILLIAM T
description: BELLARD--Justice William T On March 7, 2005. Beloved husband of Eileen for the past 56 years. Father of William, Joseph, and James. Brother of Margaret Wilson. Grandfather of Joanne, Lorraine, Peter, Paul, Douglas, Timothy, and Mary. Great Grandfather of Ryan. Graduate of Brooklyn College and Brooklyn Law School. He fought with the Eighth Armored Division at the Battles of the Bulge, Rhine, and Roar; where he was awarded a battlefield commission to 2nd Lt. Member of the NYC Fire Department. Member of the NY State Bar and served as Justice in both Civil and Supreme Court for over 27 years. Former Kings County Commander and lifetime member of the American Legion. Founding member of the Catholic Lawyers Guild of Kings County. Lifetime member of the Ancient Order of Hibernians, the Lions Club, the Emerald Society, and the Catholic Lawyers Association. Family will receive friends Wednesday and Thursday 2-5PM; 79PM at the Marine Park Funeral Home, Inc. 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn, NY. Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial Friday 9:30AM at Mary Queen of Heaven RC Church, Brooklyn, New York. Interment US Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, NY. BELLARD--William T., Justice. The members of the Brooklyn Manhattan Trial Lawyers Association express their deepest sympathies at the passing of Justice William T. Bellard. He was a member of the Association and a retired jurist, who passed away on March 7, 2005. He was a distinguished and dedicated judge who served the Brooklyn community for the past 29 years. Our deepest sympathy to his family and loved ones. God bless him and eternal be his memory. Christina Vassilas, First Vice President Brooklyn, Manhattan Trial Lawyers Association

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Pretoria Renames Itself Tshwane
description: A metropolitan legislative council voted to rename South Africa's capital Tshwane, relegating the historic name, Pretoria, to a comparatively tiny part of the city's downtown that does not contain any major government offices. The long-debated and contentious change must still be approved by the national Geographic Names Council in October, but most consider that a foregone conclusion. Pretoria was named after Andreas Pretorius, an Afrikaner best known for the 1838 Battle of Blood River, so named because the river ran red with the blood of 3,000 Zulus killed by Voortrekkersettlers. Tshwane (pronounced t'SHWAN-ay) is the African name for another local river and for an Ndebele chief who ruled there before the arrival of whites. The city says the word means "we are all together." Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; A Glimpse of Harry Potter
description: The slow striptease that has come to characterize the publication of the next Harry Potter novel continued yesterday with the release of the cover art, below, for "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince," the sixth book in the series, due on July 16. The cover for United States edition, to be published by Scholastic, was created by Mary GrandPr, who also illustrated the covers of the five previous Harry Potter books for sale in the United States. The cover shows Harry with Dumbledore, the headmaster of the Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, whom many Potter fans and some bookies have predicted to be the character most likely to die in the new story. The last Potter novel, "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix," sold about five million copies in the United States on its first day in 2003. EDWARD WYATT

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: A Tut Mystery Is Solved
description: Young King Tut was not murdered, at least not from a blow to the back of his head. The first CT scan of the pharaoh's mummy showed no signs of damage to the skull or other evidence of foul play, Dr. Zahi Hawass, Egypt's chief archaeologist, announced. Researchers took more than 1,700 detailed three-dimensional images of the mummy two months ago, seeking answers to the unsolved mystery of how Tutankhamen died more than 3,000 years ago, at the age of 17. The research team, including scientists from Italy and Switzerland, did not complete its investigation until last week. The examination showed that the pharaoh may have suffered a broken leg shortly before his death, but this was not thought to be life threatening and may even have been caused by the embalmers. Though there was the possibility that Tut was poisoned, Dr. Hawass told The Associated Press that "these results will close the case of Tutankhamen, and the king will not need to be examined again." John Noble Wilford (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Prince Cleared For Civil Ceremony
description: Len Cook, the registrar general for England and Wales, dismissed 11 legal objections to the civil marriage of Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles, set for April 8. The complaints were made in Chippenham and Cirencester, west of London, where the prince and Mrs. Parker Bowles have homes. Most related to Victorian legislation denying members of the royal family a civil wedding. Later legislation, some argued, had not changed the fact that members of the royal family are in a "special category." But Mr. Cook said the couple is protected by British human rights legislation and the European Convention on Human Rights. The objectors can now take their case to the High Court. The Royal Mail will begin selling commemorative postage stamps of the couple on April 8. The photographs on the stamps -- A 30-pence stamp, above, and a 68-pence stamp -- were approved by Queen Elizabeth II. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: MAKER OF CAR SEATS FORECASTS 12% INCREASE IN EARNINGS
description: Johnson Controls, an automotive-seat maker, said yesterday that fiscal second-quarter earnings from continuing operations would probably rise 12 percent from a year earlier, helped by higher sales and cost-cutting. The company forecast income from continuing operations of 85 cents a share in the quarter ending March 31, up from 76 cents a share a year earlier. Johnson Controls also confirmed its previous fiscal 2005 forecast of a 10 percent to 12 percent increase in operating income from continuing operations. Johnson Controls' fiscal year ends Sept. 30. Shares of Johnson Controls, which is based in Milwaukee, rose $1.80, or 3.2 percent, to $58.80.

But when officers arrived at the school, at 965 Longwood Avenue, near Beck Street, with the fight still in progress, Ms. Woltson and another teacher, Quinn Kronen, 38, blocked a doorway and tried to stop the police from arresting the girls, the police said. One girl was treated for a minor injury at Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center and released. All eight were issued summonses for disorderly conduct. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOKIEDA, GEORGE Z.
description: TOKIEDA--George Z. The Brearley School community deeply mourns the passing on March 5, 2005 of George Z. Tokieda, a treasured member of our science faculty, who served as department head from 1977-1983 and was department co-head from 1983-1986; he was also the holder of a Chair for Excellence in Teaching from 1994-1997. Born in Clewiston, FL, he graduated from Princeton University in 1963 and began teaching science at Philadelphia's William Penn Charter School and the Buckley School in Manhattan. In 1975, Mr. Tokieda joined the Brearley Science Department, where for almost 30 years he rejoiced in the opportunity to inspire students with a love of science, teaching them to ask the right questions and lighting up the classroom with his knowledge, warmth, optimism and flair. A founder of the Brearley Employees of Color discussion group, he volunteered at the Children's Storefront School and consulted for the Children's Museum in Phoenix. He was a model of courage in fighting serious health problems over the last 20 years. We send our sincere condolences to his wife, Margaret Quigley Tokieda; his children, Kathryn J. Tokieda '98, and Charles P. Tokieda; his mother, Anna Imperial; and his brother and sister. A memorial gathering will take place at Brearley on April 8th; the family suggests that contributions in his memory be made to the Heifer Project, St. Jude's Children's Society or the Brearley School.

The work stoppage formally ended on March 1, before the concert could be arranged, but the outside musicians are coming anyway, the St. Louis players' committee said yesterday, this time to thank the community for its support. World Briefing | United Nations: Cloning Ban Victory For U.S.
description: In a symbolic victory for the Bush Administration, a divided General Assembly passed a nonbinding declaration banning all human cloning, including that for medical research. Reflecting the deep division over the issue, the vote was 84 to 34 with 37 abstentions. Britain said it would ignore the measure. The United States abandoned a four-year campaign to obtain a treaty banning all cloning in November when too many countries resisted broadening a ban on cloning to reproduce humans to include therapeutic cloning, which creates stem cells for research into diseases. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Teterboro: Airport Buffer Planned
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is contributing $500,000 toward the design of a buffer to stop runaway planes at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey, where a corporate jet skidded across a highway and crashed into a warehouse last month. The money will go toward engineering work on beds of concrete blocks at each end of the shorter runway that would give way under a plane, said a spokesman for Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, who has pushed for safety improvements since the crash. The runway ends 340 feet from Route 46, a busy highway, far short of the federal standard of 1,000 feet. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOWEN, JEANNE M.
description: BOWEN -- Jeanne M. On March 5, 2005 at age 84 after complications from open heart surgery. She had lived for many years with her late husband, Stephen, in Greenwich, CT where she was a wonderful mother and a successful real estate broker. They had retired together in 1972 to live in Sharon, CT where they together built several country home communities. title: Arts, Briefly; Literary Laurels
description: For a decade, the International Impac Dublin Literary Award has brought together the best of contemporary world literature in a city that likes to think of itself as the art form's capital, and the award's 10th anniversary seems set to be no different. The Impac Award, named for its sponsor, a Florida-based consulting firm concern, still retains its status as the richest prize for a single work of fiction, with a 100,000-euro ($133,000) purse, and the most international, judging by the shortlist announced yesterday. The 10 nominated titles are by authors from seven countries on four continents and written in four languages. (All are translated into English.) No American writer has yet won the prize, but Jonathan Lethem's Brooklyn-based "Fortress of Solitude," as well as "Known World" by Edward P. Jones, above, which won last year's Pulitzer Prize for fiction, are on this year's shortlist, along with two books by South African writers, two from Canada, and one each from Australia, Norway, the Netherlands and Germany. The winner will be announced on June 15 in Dublin's City Hall. BRIAN LAVERY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAINE, ELLEN (SIS) LEA
description: PAINE--Ellen (Sis) Lea, 93, died peacefully at home in Hobe Sound, FL on March 3rd after a brief illness. She was recently predeceased by her husband of 71 years, Peter S. Paine. The Paines also maintained a seasonal residence in Willsboro, NY on Lake Champlain and, at one time, a town house in Manhattan. She is survived by her son, Peter S. Paine, Jr. and his wife, Patty, of Willsboro, NY, three grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. A welcoming and elegant hostess, she was a formidable organizer and was respectfully (but affectionately) known as "La Generale". She maintained a life-long interest in health care and served for years as Board Member of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York City. In addition, she and her husband played a vital role in building and supporting the Smith House Health Care Center in Willsboro. An avid gardener, she took great pride in the gardens of her family properties and was an active member of the Essex County-Adirondack Garden Club. There will be a joint celebration of the Paine's lives in Willsboro next summer for family and friends. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory to: Visiting Nurse Service of NY; Smith House Health Care Center, Willsboro, NY; Essex County-Adirondack Garden Club, Essex, NY; or the Nature Conservancy of Florida, Altamonte Springs, FL.

It was the best performance for a cable series this year. While Fox dominated Monday night with "American Idol" and Hour 12 of "24," NBC strove to put the best face on the disappointing performance of the hour-and-a-half preview of its boxing reality show, "The Contender." Against two ABC reality shows, "Boss Swap" (a special workplace edition of "Wife Swap") and "Supernanny," "The Contender" won the 18-to-49 demographic, but with an estimated 8.4 million average total viewers, it fell behind the average audience of "Supernanny" and drew little more than a third of the estimated 21.3 million who watched "CSI: Miami." Another preview of "Contender" is set for tomorrow before the show settles into its 8 p.m. slot next Sunday opposite ABC's "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition." JOEL TOPCIK

She was the loving wife of the late Daniel; cherished mother of Wendy Katz, Meredith Gantcher, and Gary Katz; adored grandmother of Danielle Gantscher and Yaira, Gidon, and Matan Katz. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TUCKER, WILLIAM D., JR.
description: TUCKER--William D., Jr. Age 87, of Scituate, MA passed away on March 7, 2005. Son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William D. Tucker of Rye, NY. Mr. Tucker, formerly of Pelham, NY, was a retired senior partner in the New York Law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, and former director of the Chubb Corporation and Manville Corporation. His many charitable interests included higher education, the environment, and social services. A graduate of Holy Cross College (1939) and Harvard Law School (1942), he is survived by his beloved wife Mary Elizabeth Hayes; seven devoted children, W. Duane III of Hamilton, Ontario, Mary Evelyn (Grim) of Lewisburg, PA, Paul Hayes of Charlestown, MA, Anne (Roberts) of Scituate, MA, Carlton Hayes of Pennington, NJ, Libby of Melrose, MA, Peter James of Westport, CT; four adoring grandchildren, Jonathan, Jennie, Michael and Caitlin; and his sisters Virginia Kaufmann and Leonore Mahowald. A funeral mass will be held at St. Christine's Church in Marshfield, MA Friday, March 11 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his memory to Holy Cross College, Worcester, MA 01610 or to Hospice of the South Shore, 100 Bay State Drive, Braintree, MA 02185.

description: Many of the 500 people who attended a party on Tuesday celebrating the first issue of Absolute, a lifestyle magazine for Manhattan elites, felt tipsy. Some attributed their state to the waiters stationed seemingly every six feet with bottles of Macallan single-malt Scotch, but then even some of those who were not partaking found themselves wobbling. Partygoers who had made their way through 45-mile-per-hour gusts to the event, held on the 79th floor of the condo portion of Time Warner Center, gradually began to realize that the building was swaying. Nothing wrong with that -- many modern tall buildings give into the wind a bit -- and the gentle sway added a bit of romance. "When I noticed that I was moving back and forth a bit, I felt a twinge of horror that I had imbibed enough to get sloppy in the first half-hour of the party," said Caroline Miller, editorial director of the magazine. "But then I realized I had been very well behaved and that left the building." DAVID CARR

Thomas Fitzgerald was named chairman of the Riggs Bank N.A. unit. The three positions were previously held by Robert Allbritton, whose family owns about 40 percent of Riggs stock. Mr. Allbritton resigned last week, citing the pending acquisition. Riggs, based in Washington, agreed in July to be bought by PNC, though the deal almost unraveled over Riggs's role in helping the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet and leaders of Equatorial Guinea hide funds. The marble or glass tables, upholstered seats and iron shelves are mostly French. A sinuous 1940's sofa (above, estimated at $6,000 to $8,000), from the women's restroom, was once Karl Lagerfeld's. Metal vines wind around a 1940's tagre ($3,000 to $4,000) that was a partition at the club. "It was a very seductive, short-lived environment," said Steven Greenberg, a former owner of the hotel. The hotel, with Ian Schrager as an owner, is being gutted for condos and a smaller hotel, with minimalist interiors by John Pawson. EVE M. KAHN

The third, Hadas Thier, 28, faced the same charges except for assault. A college spokeswoman, Mary Lou Edmondson, said that the students were escorted from the job fair because their chanting was disruptive, and that they had been told that any further protest had to be on the sidewalk outside. title: Arts, Briefly; Pop Charts: 50 Cent's Big Splash
description: The music industry survives on hits, and last week it got its first genuine blockbuster of the year. "The Massacre" (Interscope), below, by 50 Cent, released half a week early to beat bootlegging, sold an astonishing 1.14 million copies in four days. That is the biggest sales figure for an album with a shortened debut week -- an increasingly common occurrence over the last few years -- and the sixth-best opening week since SoundScan (now Nielsen SoundScan) began tracking sales 14 years ago, according to Billboard. 50 Cent beat his own record: his "Get Rich or Die Tryin'," two years ago, sold 872,000 copies in its own abbreviated first sales week. The early release of "The Massacre" kept the new Jennifer Lopez album, "Rebirth" (Epic), at No. 2, with 267,000 sales. Two more new releases round out the top positions on the Billboard album chart. Jack Johnson's "In Between Dreams" (Brushfire) is at No. 3, selling 228,000 copies, and in the surprise of the week, the Mars Volta reached No. 4 with its latest brainy progressive-metal-punk album, "Frances the Mute" (Universal), which sold 123,000; its last, "De-Loused in the Comatorium," has been a steady-selling cult hit, with 315,000 sales to date, though its highest chart position was No. 34. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BETHE, HANS ALBRECHT
description: BETHE--Hans Albrecht. Cornell University mourns the loss of one of science's most universally admired figures and a giant of 20th-century physics, Nobel laureate Hans Bethe, emeritus professor at Cornell University. A devoted instructor, Bethe joined Cornell in 1935 after fleeing Nazi Germany. During World War II he was a key figure in the building of the first atomic bomb as head of the theoretical physics division at Los Alamos. Later, Professor Bethe became a persistent champion of nuclear arms control, helping to persuade the White House to ban atmospheric nuclear tests in 1963 and antiballistic missile systems in 1972. In 1967, Bethe won the Nobel Prize for his theory on the production of energy in stars. Although he retired from active teaching in 1975, Bethe continued to arrive regularly at his office at the Newman Laboratory on the Cornell campus. We express our sincere condolences to his wife, Rose Ewald Bethe, a 1941 graduate of Cornell University, his son Henry Bethe, his daughter Monica Bethe, and his three grandchildren. Peter Meinig, Chairman of the Board of Trustees, Cornell University Jeffrey S. Lehman, President, Cornell University

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Worker Hurt At Ferry Terminal
description: A Staten Island ferry worker was hospitalized yesterday after he was struck by falling debris at the St. George terminal. The man was walking from the lower level of the ferry Guy V. Molinari, which recently entered service, when a piece of an upper-level railing hit him at 1:30 p.m. The man, who was conscious and alert, was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital Staten Island, according to a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Transportation, which operates the ferry. Crews repaired the railing and began to inspect all other slips and railings at the terminal, said the spokeswoman, Molly Watkins. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Part-Time Pay for Full-Time Service
description: If life is unfair, as President John Kennedy bluntly said, then military life can be doubly unfair, as the sacrifices and extended war-zone assignments of American troops are exemplifying in Iraq. But there is one inequity that the federal government should address: the pay disparities for the reservists and National Guard members who have been serving so long and with such sacrifice.

description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it planned to increase spending on refinery expansions and chemical plants in the next five years to raise profit from sources other than oil and natural gas wells.

Pillow? In Your Dreams
description: In the unlikely event you need a pillow, passengers, bring your own. That's already part of travel basics for domestic flights on American and Northwest Airlines, and now Delta Air Lines, in its struggle against bankruptcy, is following suit. Small as they are, those lozenge-like pillows are being eliminated to cut costs. Planners claim that the change will be no great inconvenience -- they say passengers have been toting their own personal pillows onboard for some time now. (Surely you've noticed that rumpled business executive curled up, all a-drool, with his eiderdown favorite near the emergency exit?) So far those thin, doily-like blankets are staying -- the airlines drew the line at making passengers tote their frayed Linus blankets through security.

title: Italy's Premier Again Insists U.S. Explain Agent's Death
description: ROME, March 9 - Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on Wednesday repeated his strong demand that the United States fully explain the shooting death of an Italian intelligence agent in Iraq, even as he himself categorized it as a tragic case of "friendly fire."

title: Wood Stains With Summer And Its Fresh Colors in Mind
description: If you're thinking about finishing unpainted furniture for the summer, and want something livelier than the usual clear varnish or brown stain, Minwax's 68 custom-mixed colors of water-based stain may be the answer. The colors run the gamut from pale pink to intense reds and yellows, and all let the wood's grain show through. The stains are applied with a cloth or brush and cleaned up with water. Porch or patio furniture must be top-coated with a weatherproof finish, like Minwax's clear Helmsman Spar Urethane.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Auto Concern To Be Acquired
description: A British insurance company, Aviva, said it would buy RAC, a company that aids stranded motorists, for 1.1 billion pounds ($2.1 billion). Aviva, based in London, hopes to sell insurance policies to more of RAC's seven million customers. The roadside assistance service was once a branch of the 100-year-old Royal Automobile Club. Aviva's offer price is a 27 percent premium over RAC's stock price before it announced on March 7 that it had received a takeover offer. RAC is based in Buckinghamshire, England. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: German jobless summit
Backed by Bach and Sinatra, a Repertoire Rich in Allusions and Emotions
description: The Aspen Santa Fe Ballet can tell a happy tale of two cities: it thrives with dual headquarters in Aspen, Colo., and Santa Fe, N.M. On Tuesday night, it brought a lively program to the Joyce Theater that featured a New York premiere by Nicolo Fonte, a Brooklyn-born choreographer who has worked for European and American regional groups but whose ballets are little known in this region.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profit Rises At EADS
description: The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company reported that profit in the fourth quarter increased 8 percent, to 433 million euros ($578 million), from 402 million euros a year earlier. But EADS, whose biggest asset is an 80 percent stake in Airbus, the aircraft manufacturer, said that revenue for the quarter fell 11 percent, to 10.3 billion ($13.7 billion), largely as a result of a strong contribution from Airbus in the quarter a year earlier. EADS, which is based in Paris, raised its forecast for this year, saying it expected an operating profit of 2.5 billion euros ($3.6 billion), up from its previous forecast of 2.4 billion euros. With the market for commercial airliners improving, the company said that it expected Airbus to deliver as many as 360 airplanes this year, up from 320 in 2004. That would be the third consecutive year that Airbus has delivered more airliners than Boeing, its archrival in the United States. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Transit Bill May Reduce State's Aid
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 - New York State could lose up to $1 billion in federal money if Congress passes a transportation bill being debated in the House this week, lawmakers say.

title: Transit Chief Bets Ridership Won't Suffer if Fares Rise
description: As they try to push through a hefty fare increase, officials of New Jersey Transit made it clear yesterday that they were operating from a position of strength.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Industrial Output Drops
description: Industrial production in Brazil fell only slightly in January from the previous month, suggesting that a recent string of interest rate increases has yet to curb economic activity seriously. The government's statistics agency said output dropped 0.5 percent in January from December, a decline that was expected after a strong 2004, when Brazil's economy grew at its fastest pace in a decade. Compared with the same period a year earlier, however, output rose 6 percent in January. In the 12 months ended in January, industrial production climbed 8.5 percent, the highest rate since 1995. Todd Benson (NYT)
