description: TUCKER--William D., Jr. Age 87, of Scituate, MA passed away on March 7, 2005. Son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William D. Tucker of Rye, NY. Mr. Tucker, formerly of Pelham, NY, was a retired senior partner in the New York Law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, and former director of the Chubb Corporation and Manville Corporation. His many charitable interests included higher education, the environment, and social services. A graduate of Holy Cross College (1939) and Harvard Law School (1942), he is survived by his beloved wife Mary Elizabeth Hayes; seven devoted children, W. Duane III of Hamilton, Ontario, Mary Evelyn (Grim) of Lewisburg, PA, Paul Hayes of Charlestown, MA, Anne (Roberts) of Scituate, MA, Carlton Hayes of Pennington, NJ, Libby of Melrose, MA, Peter James of Westport, CT; four adoring grandchildren, Jonathan, Jennie, Michael and Caitlin; and his sisters Virginia Kaufmann and Leonore Mahowald. A funeral mass will be held at St. Christine's Church in Marshfield, MA Friday, March 11 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in his memory to Holy Cross College, Worcester, MA 01610 or to Hospice of the South Shore, 100 Bay State Drive, Braintree, MA 02185.

description: ALBANY, March 9 - Gov. George E. Pataki and his fellow Republicans in the State Senate said on Wednesday that they were trying to forge a compromise that would enable the Senate to pass budget bills next week. Such a move could put pressure on the Democrat-led Assembly, forcing it either to accept their deals or to take the blame for delaying the budget.

title: A Study of What Works in French Ballet
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 5 - Two milestones of French ballet, one filtered through a Dane and the other through an Englishman, were on display Saturday in Boston and Philadelphia, and both can be seen again this weekend. Each was charming, but unlike the Super Bowl, won by the New England Patriots, in this particular dance competition the Philadelphia Eagles (or was it the chickens?) prevailed.

title: Physicist Is Awarded the Templeton Prize in Spiritual Matters
description: Dr. Charles Townes, a physicist who shared the Nobel Prize for helping to invent the laser, added another and most unusual prize to a lifelong storehouse of honors yesterday. In a news conference at the United Nations, he was announced as the winner of the $1.5 million Templeton Prize, awarded annually for progress or research in spiritual matters.

title: CROMPTON TO BUY GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL FOR $1.55 BILLION
description: The Crompton Corporation, a maker of additives for plastics and rubber, agreed to buy Great Lakes Chemical for $1.55 billion in stock. Great Lakes investors will exchange each share for 2.2232 shares of Crompton, the companies said yesterday. The offer was valued at $29.92 a share, 10 percent above the Great Lakes closing price Tuesday. Crompton, based in Middlebury, Conn., said it would also assume $250 million of debt. The combined company will have sales of more than $4.1 billion. Great Lakes, based in Indianapolis, is the world's biggest maker of pool chemicals and also produces cleaners and fire suppressants. Crompton shareholders will own 51 percent of the new company, which will be based in Middlebury.

description: LONDON, March 9 - In a bitter political duel over new antiterrorism legislation, Prime Minister Tony Blair said Wednesday that he would make no further concessions to opposition demands for milder laws to control terrorist suspects.

title: System Follows the Paperless Trail to Reduce Outdated Documents
description: E-mail and word-processing programs have made collaborating on long documents much easier than it used to be, but getting everyone onto the same page -- or even into the right revision of the document -- can feel like herding cats. NextPage 1.5, a document-tracking system for Microsoft Office files, provides a way to lasso multiple copies of a document and make sure no one is working on an outdated version.

description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Last Things First
description: This week, there was more evidence that the world has begun edging away from the dollar. International data showed that several more nations who have been big customers for American debt -- including China and India -- have diversified their portfolios away from the American greenback. To us, that sounds like a serious threat to the long-term soundness of the national currency. But the Bush administration hasn't come close to addressing any of the economic fundamentals that have helped spawn the dollar's decline (the budget deficit comes to mind). Instead, the White House has been busy lobbying for new tax cuts that will make the situation worse.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: U.S. Suspect Arrested
description: The police have arrested an American man wanted by the F.B.I. in connection with a high-profile kidnapping and murder of a 15-year-old boy in Southern California five years ago. The suspect, Jesse James Hollywood, left, was detained on Tuesday in Saquarema, a beach resort town north of Rio de Janeiro, and is expected to be deported to the United States this week. Mr. Hollywood faces charges for his suspected role in the abduction and killing of Nicholas Samuel Markowitz, whose body was found in Santa Barbara on Aug. 12, 2000. The police said Mr. Hollywood, 25, had been living in Brazil for four years, where he used a fake name and taught English to make a living. Todd Benson (NYT)

description: A special war crimes court, intended to take over cases from the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague and to initiate possibly hundreds of cases of its own, opened in Sarajevo. The Bosnian state court was created with money from the United States and Europe and set up with expertise from The Hague tribunal. The court has jurisdiction over crimes linked to the 1990's Balkans wars, committed by either Croats, Muslims or Serbs and, unlike the temporary Hague tribunal, will have no closing date. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, SYLVIA
description: SCHWARTZ -- Sylvia. Artist and educator, who during World War II began her career as an illustrator for Vogue Magazine and drew portraits of soldiers and sailors at the Stagedoor Canteen, inspired thousands of students, ages 6-96. She was district coordinator of art for Lawrence Public Schools, and in her retirement was a docent at Tucson Museum of Art and an instructor at Pima Community College. She was a member of the National League of American Pen Women and past president of the New York State Council of the Arts. Wife of Solomon; mother of Marla and George Coleman, Siri Mills; sister of Florence Solnick and Herbert Gopstein; and grandmother of Jordan and Jessica Coleman, Ross Coleman, and Alexandra Beierlein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELLARD, JUSTICE WILLIAM T
description: BELLARD--Justice William T On March 7, 2005. Beloved husband of Eileen for the past 56 years. Father of William, Joseph, and James. Brother of Margaret Wilson. Grandfather of Joanne, Lorraine, Peter, Paul, Douglas, Timothy, and Mary. Great Grandfather of Ryan. Graduate of Brooklyn College and Brooklyn Law School. He fought with the Eighth Armored Division at the Battles of the Bulge, Rhine, and Roar; where he was awarded a battlefield commission to 2nd Lt. Member of the NYC Fire Department. Member of the NY State Bar and served as Justice in both Civil and Supreme Court for over 27 years. Former Kings County Commander and lifetime member of the American Legion. Founding member of the Catholic Lawyers Guild of Kings County. Lifetime member of the Ancient Order of Hibernians, the Lions Club, the Emerald Society, and the Catholic Lawyers Association. Family will receive friends Wednesday and Thursday 2-5PM; 79PM at the Marine Park Funeral Home, Inc. 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn, NY. title: Arts, Briefly; The Met Opera's New Web
description: The Metropolitan Opera has revamped its Web site, www.metopera.org, to allow online ticket-buyers to pinpoint the seats they are buying. Beyond that, the new site provides acres of archival information, including details of what the Met said is every performance in its 122-year history. The archival sections include 200 audio clips dating to 1903, newspaper accounts of performances, photographs and statistics that would warm a baseball fan's heart. Most performed opera? "La Bohme," 1,152 performances. First performance? Gounod's "Faust," on Oct. 22, 1883. First performance conducted by Toscanini? "Aida," on Nov. 16, 1908. On the more commercial side, the new site provides shopping carts for a browser to buy tickets, recordings and bric-a-brac all at once. Kinks are still being worked out, but the full site should be up and running tomorrow, a spokesman said. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: The Beirut Tea Party
description: The massive pro-Syrian demonstration that the Hezbollah militia mounted on the streets of Beirut on Tuesday underscored just how much all the old slogans and sentiments -- anti-Israeli, anti-American, pro-Islamist, sectarian -- can be exploited by Syria, Iran and their local proxies to still mobilize popular forces against change. It is also another reminder that the Berlin Wall is falling in the Arab world, but Vaclav Havel, Lech Walesa and the Solidarity trade movement are not on the other side, just waiting to jump into the arms of the West. It is a much more divided, complex, confused and, at times, angry group.

title: MARSH & MCLENNAN REDUCES ITS STAKE IN AXIS CAPITAL
description: Marsh & McLennan, the insurance brokerage firm, reduced its stake in Axis Capital Holdings, a Bermuda-based commercial insurer it helped to create after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. title: Arts, Briefly; Munch Theft Confessions
description: Three young Oslo men have admitted taking part in the theft on Sunday of a painting and two lithographs by Edvard Munch, but a police spokesman said the case did not immediately appear to lead investigators any closer to Munch's missing masterpiece "The Scream," taken from a museum in an armed robbery last August. The three men, age 17 to 22, were among nine people arrested on Monday in the previous night's theft of three pictures from the Restaurant Munch in the Hotel Refsnes Gods, in Moss, 37 miles south of the capital. The police recovered the works, including Munch's 1915 watercolor "Blue Dress," though one of the lithographs had sustained an eight-inch scratch. Four of the original nine suspects have been released, police said, while two face charges of receiving stolen property. Of the three (one of whom is above wearing a hat and consulting with his lawyer) said to have been ringleaders, two pleaded guilty to grand theft in Moss District Court yesterday and were remanded to custody, Rolf Nissen, the prosecutor, said. The two were also charged with assault, accused of spraying a Mace-like substance at a hotel employee who walked into the closed restaurant while the theft was in progress. The third man, said to have been their driver, acknowledged taking part in the theft but did not enter a plea. WALTER GIBBS

title: The Listings; ROBERT MORRIS: 'SMALL FIRES AND MNEMONIC NIGHTS'
description: Since helping to discover Minimalism in the early 1960's, Robert Morris has churned through many different styles and modes of art-making. Some critics have seen his chameleonism as the symptom of an inauthentic sensibility; others as the sign of a strategic independence from the market-ordained law of one style per artist. Mr. Morris's new easel-size, encaustic paintings prove that he can still surprise both fans and detractors. It is surprising that he would make paintings that suggest Edward Hopper under the influence of de Chirico and Magritte; and more surprising still are the genuinely touching feelings of nostalgia, loneliness and sadness. Some of the nocturnal, moonlit images are like dreams of actual places from the artist's past: an elementary school "Boys Room"; "Indiana Street," a neighborhood with bungalows silhouetted against the setting sun; a New York cafe; and New York's old "Union Station." Some refer to art: a canvas leaning face to the wall in an empty room, above; and the American flag attached to the wall in another evoking Jasper Johns, another encaustic painter and an important early influence on Mr. Morris. Distant fires and explosions can be seen through windows in some paintings, and the antique radio featured in "War News" implies that the artist is thinking less about Iraq than about the war that was going on during his boyhood in the 1940's. Clocks are prominently displayed in the rooms in some of the paintings. It is getting late, they hint; time to take stock. (Leo Castelli, 18 East 77th Street, Manhattan, (212)249-4470, through March 19; free.) KEN JOHNSON

title: Middleburg, Va.
description: JUST 40 miles from the halls of Congress, Middleburg leaves Washington's blue suits and red ties behind for jodhpurs and riding helmets -- though on its narrow streets, lined with historic buildings, an 18th-century powdered wig wouldn't look out of place. Olympic equestrians, country squires and political power brokers mingle in the brick and stone downtown while out in the surrounding green hills, thousands of equine residents luxuriate at well-tended stables. Middleburg has long been a retreat from the limelight for public figures. John F. Kennedy spent weekends there during his presidency, and Jackie rode in the local fox hunts. Elizabeth Taylor and Senator John Warner had their low-key wedding at his Middleburg estate (he sold it after the divorce). Linda Tripp fled to Middleburg from her worst-best-friend notoriety and now designs Christmas ornaments for her husband's East Washington Street shop. Like most old-money retreats, Middleburg is a guarded, private place, but visitors can get a glimpse of the horsey life in garden walks and estate tours in spring or at Christmas, at polo games on summer Sundays, and especially at the steeplechase races that draw thousands of spectators in spring and fall. title: The Listings; KIMSOOJA
description: Long before "The Gates" arrived and departed, the city was a treasure trove of found art as unexpected as the first crocuses that push up against all odds each spring. Thrust an umbrella into the air in one Manhattan subway station and music plays from a nearby motion-cued installation. Slashes of wild color suddenly appear and disappear, painted high above pedestrian sightlines, on the brick wall of a Midtown building before demolition. And this weekend through June 10, passersby who happen to look up at the NBC Astrovision sign in Times Square will see flashes of video of a meditative woman, motionless in desolate and teeming environments, in the last minute of every hour, 14 hours a day from 6 a.m. to 1 a.m. The images for "The 59th Minute," produced by Creative Time, are taken from three videos by Kimsooja, a young Korean-born artist who combines video, performance and sculpture. One is "The Beggar Woman," in which the artist stands in an identical pose with her back to the camera, watched by crowds in Cairo, New Delhi, Shanghai and Tokyo. Ms. Kim lies on her side on a windy ledge in "A Needle Woman" and stands facing the Yamuna River in India as life moves by in "A Laundry Woman," above. The lily will be gilded today by "Conditions of Anonymity," a free hourlong group performance choreographed by Ms. Kim and presented in Times Square. Both the 40 dancers and the audience will range about the performance space. The performers will re-enact "The Beggar Woman" as a one-hour screening of the videos plays on the Astrovision screen. ("Conditions of Anonymity" will be performed today from 2 to 3 p.m. in Times Square at Broadway and 44th Street. "The 59th Minute" may be seen daily at 6:59 a.m., from 10:59 a.m. to 5:59 p.m., and from 7:59 p.m. to 12:59 a.m. on the NBC Astrovision by Panasonic screen at 45th Street and the intersection of Broadway and Seventh Avenue in Times Square. For information, call Creative Time at (212)206-6674.) JENNIFER DUNNING

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Fall
description: Orders for machinery unexpectedly declined for the second consecutive month in January in a sign that Japan's economy may not be emerging as quickly as hoped from a recession that began last year. His lawyer said Mr. Patel, who obtained French citizenship through marriage, had been in Afghanistan for business purposes. The other two men, Redouane Khalid and Khaled Ben Mustapha, are being detained and investigated for "criminal association with a terrorist organization," officials said. John Tagliabue (NYT)

The audience fell just short of the 936,000 viewers who tuned in for last year's premiere of the Showtime series "The L Word," but a replay that followed immediately at 11 p.m. pushed the combined number of viewers to 1.5 million. Though a Showtime spokeswoman would not confirm the numbers, she said the performance of "Fat Actress" was the network's highest rated series debut in five years, since "Queer as Folk" in 2000. title: FORD TO GIVE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO VISTEON
description: The Ford Motor Company agreed to provide some assistance to the Visteon Corporation, its biggest supplier and a former subsidiary, while continuing to negotiate broader changes in their spinoff agreement made in 2000, Ford said yesterday in a regulatory filing. Ford has about 17,700 employees at Visteon plants, and Visteon reimburses Ford for those costs. Ford said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had agreed to reduce those payments by $25 million a month at least through the end of 2005. Ford, based in Dearborn, Mich., will also buy about $150 million worth of equipment for Visteon to make parts for Ford, the filing said. Ford will pay Visteon faster for parts, too. Visteon's chief executive, Michael F. Johnson, said in a statement that the agreement "will improve Visteon's operating results and cash flow." Visteon, based in Van Buren Township, Mich., makes auto electronics, interiors, steering parts and chassis components.

Nintendo's decision solidifies I.B.M.'s control of the market to supply the brains that power the new versions of games consoles released in the next two years. title: NEW YORK TIMES CO. COMPLETES PURCHASE OF FREE DAILY
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its subsidiary, the Globe Newspaper Company, had acquired a 49 percent stake in Metro Boston, a free daily newspaper aimed primarily at commuters, from the Metro USA division of Metro International for $16.5 million. The deal, which was announced in January, was completed after the Department of Justice closed an investigation into the potential effects on newspaper competition in the Boston area. Metro International is based in London. Nat Ives (NYT)

title: Jackson, Tardy and Unkempt, Hears Boy's Testimony
description: SANTA MARIA, Calif., March 10 - Michael Jackson, dressed in blue print pajama bottoms and looking more spectral than ever, listened on Thursday in obvious distress to more than four hours of damaging testimony from the boy who has accused Mr. Jackson of sexually molesting him.

Arts, Briefly; British Ratings Board Says Yes to Sex
description: Preceded by scores of letters of complaint, a film depicting explicit sexual activity opens today in Britain. The film, "9 Songs," from the British director Michael Winterbottom ("Jude," "Welcome to Sarajevo"), was given an 18 rating by the British Board of Film Classification, restricting it to audiences 18 or older. The 69-minute film tells the story of two lovers, Matt and Lisa, played by Kieran O'Brien and Margot Stilley, meeting for a succession of intense sexual encounters when they are not attending rock concerts. Sue Clark, a spokeswoman for the board described the number of letters as unprecedented and said yesterday that she expected to receive many more complaints once the film went into general release. She added: "The rating was given within the B.B.F.C.'s guidelines. There is nothing illegal or harmful in the film. If people don't want to watch it, they don't have to go to the cinema to see it." PAM KENT

title: Taiwan 'delegates' in Beijing spotlight
World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: New Zealand: Interest Rate Rises
description: Saying it needed to head off inflation as the economy continued to gallop ahead, New Zealand's central bank raised its key interest rate for the first time in four months, to its highest level since 1999. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand raised its official cash rate a quarter of a percentage point, to 6.75 percent. The bank's move mirrors a rate increase last week by the central bank of Australia. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Advanced Micro Introduces Turion 64 Chip
description: Advanced Micro Devices yesterday introduced its long-awaited chip for ultralight portable computers, called the Turion 64, which the company hopes will help it compete with Intel's widely successful Centrino mobile chip. The new chip, which uses more advanced processing technology than earlier 32-bit versions, offers better security and longer battery life, as well as support for the latest wireless technology, the company said. A.M.D., which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said systems based on the Turion 64 are scheduled to arrive in stores this month. Acer and Packard Bell are among the computer makers committed to using the new chip. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Official Declines to Pin Blame for Blunders in Interrogations
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 - A senior military investigator told Congress on Thursday that high-level American officials failed to establish clear procedures for interrogating prisoners in Iraq and Afghanistan, but said it was not his job to hold anyone responsible.

title: Pataki Presents Bill to Tighten Lobbying and Ethics Laws
description: ALBANY, March 10 - Gov. George E. Pataki introduced legislation on Thursday that he said would "strengthen public confidence in state government" by banning gifts from lobbyists, curtailing lobbying for state contracts and closing a loophole that allows former state employees to avoid punishment for ethics violations by leaving state service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARBER, SARAH LANIER
description: BARBER--Sarah Lanier, 67, educator and social activist, Wednesday at her Santa Fe home. She worked at LOOK, taught in Harlem, and LaGuardia Community College immigrants. Volunteered at Santa Fe Animal Shelter and founded the Lesbian & Gay Partnership at Santa Fe Community Foundation, with a focus on needs of elderly LGBT. Daughter of the late Red Barber, the "voice of the Brooklyn Dodgers" and Lylah Barber. Survived by partner, Pat Bailey, and companion, Gloria Donadello.

title: Citigroup Ousts Manager of Investments in Brazil
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, March 10 - Citigroup said Thursday that it fired its investment manager in Brazil, Daniel Dantas, a controversial figure who had become enmeshed in a string of legal battles as well as a corporate espionage scandal.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 - Ray Ozzie, whose popular Lotus Notes software helped demonstrate the power of office PC networks in the early 1990's, has gone to work for the PC software king, Bill Gates of Microsoft.

description: A 5-year-old girl and a Brooklyn woman were killed in separate house fires early yesterday, the police said.

description: BROWN--Mildred. Devoted wife of Martin, loving mother of Diane and Jayne. Adored grandmother of Ethan and Evan. Services at 10:30AM Sunday, Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn (Ave M).

title: An Enigmatic Author Who Can Be Addictive
description: When Gregory Rabassa talks about Clarice Lispector, it is evident that his infatuation with her isn't purely literary. "Those blue eyes, right out of Thomas Mann, 'The Magic Mountain,"' he sighed, during a recent interview. "She was so beautiful."

title: World Briefing | Asia: Debt Suspended For Tsunami-Hit Countries
description: The Paris Club, made up of 19 of the world's wealthiest nations, agreed to freeze debt payments of countries hit by the Asian tsunami until the end of the year, with the deferred amounts repaid over five years. The group said it agreed to the moratorium after an analysis of the situation in Asia by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Russia Fights For Yukos Extradition
description: Russia opened an extradition fight in a London court for the return of two former employees of the Russian oil company Yukos who have asked for political asylum rather than go home to face charges of falsifying contracts and cheating a regional government out of $2.8 billion. The two, Dmitry Maruev and Natalia Chernysheva, are the first of a group of Yukos employees who fled Russia for Britain after a Kremlin-driven crackdown on the company to seek political asylum there. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SWINT, ANN
description: SWINT--Ann. The Board and Administration of Southampton Hospital and the Southampton Hospital Foundation mourn the passing of Ann Swint, whose affection, kindness and generosity have forever left a lasting imprint. Much beloved for her dedication and integrity, she shall be dearly missed. We offer our most sincere condolences to her husband, Sam Swint, and to her daughter Amy.

title: Abu Ghraib, Whitewashed Again
description: It was good to learn yesterday that the military commander in Iraq has issued definitive rules about how to treat captives in American prison camps. Unfortunately, that was about the only good news in the newest Pentagon report on prisoner abuse, actually a 21-page summary of a larger, classified study by the Navy inspector general of interrogation rules in Guantnamo Bay, Afghanistan and Iraq.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Promotes Executive
description: The president of Japan Airlines, Toshiyuki Shinmachi, 62, left, was named chief executive, succeeding Isao Kaneko, as the airline warned that it expected profit to fall more than a third next year because of high fuel costs. The company forecast that net profit would decline 37 percent, to 17 billion yen ($164 million), for the fiscal year ending March 31, 2006, from an expected 27 billion yen for the year ending this March 31. The company said it expected high fuel costs to continue and to more than offset the effects of cost-cutting. The company also said it would cut 1,500 additional workers. With the new cuts, JAL plans to have eliminated 5,900 jobs by March 2008 from the April 2002 level. The airline said Mr. Kaneko would remain chairman. Todd Zaun (NYT)

description: Opens today in Manhattan Directed by John Irvin Not rated, 90 minutes

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Voting Machine Problems Seen
description: A mayoral advisory group said the city faces a catastrophe during elections in 2006 if the State Legislature does not quickly pass legislation allowing New York to qualify for federal money to buy new voting machines. The money was provided as part of a law passed in 2002 to overhaul the nation's election system after the 2000 presidential election. The mayor's Election Modernization Task Force said that under that law, municipalities must modernize their voting machines by 2006. Unless state legislation is passed soon, the panel said, the state risks losing its federal money, and the city will not have enough time to buy new machines, make sure they work properly and train thousands of polling workers to use them. State lawmakers have convened a conference committee to try to draft the necessary legislation. Michael Slackman (NYT)

Ski Biking

Bellavitae
description: Few restaurants reflect their origins as tidily as Bellavitae. It evolved from Rolando Ruiz Beramendi's import business, which gathers and peddles artisanal oils, vinegars, pastes, pasta and rice from Italy, a country with a larder that's the envy of most others. And in many ways Bellavitae seems less like a fully formed trattoria than a sit-down showcase for Italian condiments, cheeses, fruits and greens.

title: How Long Can G.M. Tread Water?
description: DETROIT, March 10 - Since the Depression, General Motors has reigned as the world's largest automaker and a pillar of American economic might. But now the company is broadly struggling and facing the humbling possibility that it will be displaced by Toyota at the top of the auto industry within a few years.

title: Trying for the Mayoralty With Dr Pepper and Twang
description: DOUBLE doggone it. Chad Clanton left his signature Tony Lama cowboy boots back at his bachelor pad near Union Square, so the only proof that he's a terminal Texan toiling as a temporary New York City political operative for the mayoral candidate Fernando Ferrer hails from his barbed-wire body -- he's a tad bowlegged inside those broken-in blue jeans -- and hard-wired twang. Yep, he says git for get. Repeatedly. Endearingly. As in, "We need a mayor who gits it, and Mayor Bloomberg just doesn't git it."

title: Hapless Bank Robber Foiled. Hapless Bank Patron Grilled.
description: Wednesday was an unlucky day for a would-be bank robber. Unarmed, he tried to rob two Manhattan banks, the police said. Both times, stubborn tellers refused to hand over any money.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Stabbing, Not Fire, Killed Woman
description: A woman found dead in an apartment fire in the Eastchester Heights houses on Wednesday morning had been stabbed to death, and was not killed in the blaze, the medical examiner's office said yesterday. The woman, Althea Brown, 33, died when someone stabbed her repeatedly in the torso and neck, according to the autopsy yesterday. Detectives said they were questioning her husband. The couple's three sons, ages 11, 7 and 5, escaped the fire, which occurred at 3:15 a.m. at 3437 Corsa Avenue. They later told the police their parents had been fighting. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Bon Voyage With French Cinema
description: THE great French director Claire Denis, whose film "The Intruder" looms as the pinnacle of this year's "Rendez-Vous With French Cinema 2005" series at Lincoln Center, has described its spellbinding sweep across the globe as a journey that follows "the curve of the Earth as I imagine it."

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Parliament Strips Sinn Fein Of Funds
description: British lawmakers decided to strip the four Sinn Fein members of the House of Commons, including the party's leader, Gerry Adams, of almost $850,000 for travel, staffing and other expenses for a year. The action was in response to allegations that the Irish Republican Army, for which Sinn Fein, the biggest nationalist party in Northern Ireland, is the political wing, masterminded the $50 million robbery of a Belfast bank in December. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Deportation Case Focuses on Definition of Torture
description: A New Jersey case before a federal court of appeals has linked the Bush administration's methods of interrogating prisoners in anti-terrorism efforts to a sharp change in the standards of humanitarian law at home, possibly affecting the chances of hundreds of immigrants to win protection from deportation under the Convention Against Torture.

title: An Affair to Remember, Self-Pityingly
description: The brilliant Italian actor Sergio Castellitto is especially good at playing highly civilized men who struggle to control, or at least to comprehend, their own savagery. In Marco Bellocchio's "My Mother's Smile," which opened in New York a few weeks ago, he was a literature professor tormented by lust, family history and rebellious urges left over from his youth. As a theater director and actor in Jacques Rivette's "Va Savoir" (2001), he was not so much tormented as exasperated, but it was his impatience and volatility -- a characteristic blend of intellectual quickness and reckless physical potency -- that gave that otherwise polite comedy of manners a vivifying jolt of rudeness.

title: On a Journey to Adulthood, Accompanied by Buffaloes
description: Set in the haunting watery wilds of Vietnam shortly before north and south were violently parted, when the country was still part of the French imperialist dream and known to the larger world as Indochina, "Buffalo Boy" tells a deceptively simple tale in a deceptively simple fashion. Ostensibly a coming-of-age story, this languorous, beautifully shot feature debut from Minh Nguyen-Vo, a writer and director, centers on a teenager whose journey from innocence to knowledge is also a twinned meditation on both the natural and very unnatural state of things.

description: A Yemeni cleric who once said that Osama bin Laden had called him his sheik was convicted of financing terrorism yesterday in a federal court in New York City.

title: Strike Slows Paris, but I.O.C. Steers Clear of Chaos
description: PARIS, March 10 - Two police officers, imposing figures in futuristic white helmets and old-school black boots, rode motorcycles ahead of the buses ferrying the International Olympic Committee's evaluation commission through the streets Thursday. The officers were ready to clear a path to the city's proposed Olympic sites through whatever chaos overflowed from a national strike by trade unions.

title: ICAHN CRITICIZES KERR-MCGEE'S EXPLORATION PROGRAM
description: Carl C. Icahn, the financier, said the Kerr-McGee Corporation, the oil company he bought a stake in this year, was destroying shareholder value with its high-risk exploration program. In a letter to the company dated yesterday and put in a public filing, Mr. Icahn again urged the company to sell some of its oil and natural gas production. The letter was written with Barry Rosenstein, one of the investors who, along with Mr. Icahn, acquired 7.6 percent of Kerr-McGee's stock. Mr. Icahn and Mr. Rosenstein said that if Kerr-McGee continued to ignore their suggestions, they would seek election as directors. The company has rejected their requests to be given board seats. Mr. Icahn's analysis of the company is "deeply flawed," a Kerr-McGee spokeswoman, Debbie Schramm, said. Kerr-McGee is based in Oklahoma City.

title: Rescission Time in Congress
description: Washington - PRESIDENT BUSH regularly calls on Congress to restrain spending. But he has yet to put his pen where his mouth is by using his veto -- a blunt instrument, to be sure, but one that very few American presidents have failed to wield, especially during times of high deficits. Mr. Bush says he prefers a sharper veto power: the ability to cut spending programs within larger bills. He called for line-item veto power in his first press conference after his re-election and in his 2006 budget.

Paid Notice: Deaths   NEWMAN, ANNE MARGULIES
description: NEWMAN--Anne Margulies. Died peacefully at home in West Palm Beach March 6, 2005, at age 91. Beloved wife of 56 years of the late Dr. Herbert Newman. Devoted mother of Robert, Donald and Carol, cherished motherin-law of Vivien, and loving friend of long-term caregiver Delores Waite. A child of immigrants, Anne was first in her family to attend college and served as a role model for her younger female cousins. She graduated cum laude in one of the first classes at Brooklyn College. Voted "Most Energetic" by her classmates, her life proved them correct--in education, public service and the arts. Anne obtained a Masters Degree in Health Education from Columbia University and joined the Brooklyn College faculty where she inspired generations of students, ultimately retiring as Professor Emerita. During her distinguished career, she was active in the leadership of municipal health organizations in New York City and of the Kadimah chapter of Hadassah at the East Midwood Jewish Center in Brooklyn. In retirement in West Palm Beach, FL, she was instrumental in installing and leading a Brooklyn College Alumni Association chapter and remained active in professional and synagogue activities. She was an awardwinning weaver and creative in many art forms throughout her life. A graveside service will be held at Knollwood Cemetery, Ridgewood, NY, Sunday, March 13 at 1 PM. Contributions may be made to the Anne & Herbert Newman Scholarship at the Brooklyn College Foundation, 718951-5074.

title: DANA FORMS VENTURE WITH DONGFENG MOTOR OF CHINA
description: The Dana Corporation, a maker of axles for light trucks, will form a joint venture with the Dongfeng Motor Company to produce axles in China and reduce its dependence on North American vehicle manufacturers. Dana said that it would invest $60 million in the 50-50 venture. The company, which would be called the Dongfeng Dana Axle Company and would be based in Xiangfan, China, is expected to have annual sales of $400 million this year. Dongfeng Dana Axle would supply Dongfeng Motor, a Chinese vehicle maker, and seek other customers in China. Dana is based in Toledo, Ohio. Dongfeng is based in Wuhan, China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLEMING, SHIRLEY
description: FLEMING -- Shirley. New York City Opera joins the entire classical music world in mourning the passing of our colleague and very dear friend, Shirley Fleming. As a longtime writer, critic, and the editor of Musical America, she has been a respected member of our community for over 25 years. It is difficult to imagine future seasons without her. Her kindness, her integrity, and her support for our company has been stalwart throughout the years. We will miss her gracious friendship. We extend our deepest sympathies to her family and her many friends around the world. Paul Kellogg General Director

title: She's All Angles, He's Got Curves
description: "The Upside of Anger," written and directed by Mike Binder, is a seriously flawed movie wrapped around two nearly perfect performances. Joan Allen and Kevin Costner play a pair of drifting suburban neighbors whose last-resort companionship blossoms into an unlikely love affair, and though the movie's premise is shaky, its story thin and its surprise-twist ending an utter catastrophe, the two stars bring such ease, wit and conviction to their roles that this awkward, underwritten attempt to blend midlife romantic comedy with domestic melodrama almost works in spite of itself.

title: Carrefour profit dips despite price strategy
Arts, Briefly; French Court Bans 'Last Supper' Ad
description: The Roman Catholic Church in France won its lawsuit yesterday to ban a fashion-house advertisement, above, built around Leonardo da Vinci's "Last Supper" and showing a female Jesus, women in designer clothes in place of the apostles, and a half-naked man. The order against the fashion house, Marith & Franois Girbaud, bans the advertisement from billboards, but the designers may continue to publish it in print. The church sued the Girbauds' advertising agency on the grounds that it had misused a religious image and offended a group of people because of their religious affiliation, its lawyer said. "Justice does not evolve anymore than the church in this country," Mr. Girbaud's lawyer, Bernard Cahen, reported that he said in response to the ruling. Mr. Cahen said the decision would be appealed. He added, "This isn't a loss, but this unwanted publicity will lead people to talk more about the Girbauds." HLNE FOUQUET

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Miller At A Financing Threshold
description: City Council Speaker Gifford Miller said yesterday that his mayoral campaign is the first to have raised or qualified for more than the maximum amount, $5.7 million, that it can spend in the Democratic primary. Candidates taking part in the city's campaign finance system are entitled to receive matching money for some of what they raise, but must abide by spending limits. They must file fund-raising disclosure statements by next Tuesday for the period that ends today. Mr. Miller's aides say he has raised about $4.5 million, of which about half should qualify for matching money. If the campaign's figures are verified by the Campaign Finance Board, Mr. Miller's campaign will have raised or qualified for a combined total of about $7 million, the campaign said. Michael Slackman (NYT)

title: Competitive Balance for Nextel Cup Leans Roush's Way
description: LAS VEGAS, March 10 - Jack Roush figures he is due. He put 18 years of time, sweat and money into racing in Nascar's elite Cup series. He stood resolute for years even when he thought Nascar was out to get him.

title: Before Soaring Imagination Is Grounded by Convention
description: When it comes to making movies, the English director Danny Boyle is usually up to no good, which is something this visual stylist does with great ostentatious flair. Best known for "Trainspotting," a grungy entertainment about the gleefully down and out, memorable for its E-is-for Ecstasy flourishes and the hallucinatory vision of a creepily crawling dead baby, and, more recently, for the shiver-filled zombie flick "28 Days Later," Mr. Boyle is the sort of creative type in whom the milk of human kindness often seems to curdle rather than flow.

title: Sign of Growth as Inventories Surge Higher
description: Wholesale inventories rose 1.1 percent in January, almost twice as much as expected, led by increased supplies of metals and cars, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

title: Board Faulted for Plans to Let Eisner Attend Job Interviews
description: LOS ANGELES, March 10 - Two former Walt Disney board directors have sent a letter to current board members asking them to reconsider plans to let the chief executive, Michael D. Eisner, sit in on interviews of candidates for his job.

title: Interpublic Agencies Win Intel Accounts
description: In a coup for the struggling Interpublic Group of Companies, the Intel Corporation yesterday named agencies that are part of the largest Interpublic division, the McCann Worldgroup, to handle its $300 million global brand marketing account.

title: Roundup: Second referee seized in Germany
World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Ex-President Questioned In Murder
description: Former President Leonid D. Kuchma was questioned by investigators for the first time about the abduction and murder of Georgy Gongadze, an investigative journalist, in 2000. Yuri V. Boychenko, a spokesman for Ukraine's prosecutor general, said Mr. Kuchma agreed to appear as a witness and spoke with investigators for a couple of hours. He would not elaborate on the line of questions or Mr. Kuchma's answers. Technology Briefing | Hardware: National Semiconductor Posts Profit Decline
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation, whose chips increase battery life in mobile phones and notebook computers, said yesterday that third-quarter profit fell 17 percent, to $77.4 million, as customers worked off excess inventory. Net income dropped to 21 cents a share in the period ended Feb. 27 from $93.1 million, or 24 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Sales declined 13 percent, to $449.2 million. The chief executive, Brian L. Halla, cut 550 jobs to pare costs and slowed production in the quarter after customers cut orders to reduce stockpiles of National Semiconductor's chips. Profit exceeded the average estimate of 16 cents from analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Analysts had expected sales of $444.4 million. Shares of National Semiconductor, based in Santa Clara, Calif., rose $1.13, to $21.12.

No one was injured, and Jadakiss left the scene, perhaps never realizing there had been a gun or a threat, the police said. The incident followed a party at the nightclub Roxy, sponsored by the radio station WQHT-FM, Hot 97. Last week, associates of two other rappers exchanged gunfire at the station's studios. Yesterday, Jadakiss and a crew filming him were walking on 10th Avenue near 21st Street around 3:15 a.m. when the truck slowed and the men inside shouted insults, the police said. A police officer, part of a detail assigned outside the party, saw a passenger raise a semiautomatic pistol and ordered the truck to stop. The driver, identified as Lonnie Jennette, 28, of Brooklyn, tried to flee, hitting a patrol car, the police said. All four men were charged with weapons possession. Mr. Jennette was also charged with reckless endangerment. Michael Wilson (NYT)

description: The architects David Marks and Julia Barfield, who reinvented the Ferris wheel and changed the London skyline with their 450-foot observation wheel, the London Eye, have responded to requests from around the world for a counterpart by designing an observation tower they call the i-360, left. Introduced this week in London, plans for the structure call for a 492-foot tower with a slowly ascending, doughnut-shaped, air-conditioned capsule offering 360-degree views for as many as 120 passengers. The architects say the i-360 has a number of commercial advantages over the observation wheel, which cost $125.45 million to build. With lower construction costs of $19.3 million, as well as lower operating costs, it is suitable for smaller cities that couldn't attract the 3 million to 4 million visitors a year needed to sustain the wheel. The London Eye, which has attracted 18 million visitors, celebrated its fifth birthday this week and has permission to remain at least until 2027. PAM KENT

description: Since 1965, jazz and religion have formed a literal crossroads at the Jazz Ministry of St. Peter's Lutheran Church, in Midtown Manhattan. The Rev. John Garcia Gensel, a great friend to musicians including Duke Ellington, started the ministry; at his death in 1998, he was succeeded by the Rev. Dale Lind. The jazz ministry serves its Samaritan function, but it is also a sort of social hub, and one of the hidden forces that holds the large community of jazz musicians together in New York. Aside from Sunday-evening jazz vespers, memorial services for departed jazz musicians and other regular events, the jazz ministry holds an annual fund-raiser centering on the legacy of Lester Young, above, a musician who will never pass out of favor. The 21st edition of "To Prez With Love" happens on Sunday evening, with an impressive lineup of musicians (and storytellers) spanning three generations, including Don Byron, Lou Donaldson, Junior Mance, Connie Crothers, Ron Blake, Gene Bertoncini, the radio host Phil Schaap and many others. description: Blond, bland, bubbly: the cute young thing who makes her entrance in the second act of "Brooklyn Boy," Donald Margulies's account of a novelist who finds fame at 50, would seem to have about as much substance as the junk food she appropriates from the minibar of the hero's hotel room. Yet as embodied by Ari Graynor, above, Alison the Valley Girl packs more than empty calories. In an increasingly revealing face-off with the play's title character, Eric Weiss (the excellent Adam Arkin), who has picked her up at a book reading in Los Angeles, Alison morphs before our eyes into a smart, self-sabotaging neurotic of the first order. Ms. Graynor's performance suggests that this barbed variation on the Britney Spears-era nymphet feels trapped in a predetermined future she knows she is powerless to escape. Though "Brooklyn Boy" is principally a study in that familiar bugaboo, the midlife crisis, Ms. Graynor (best known as Meadow's suicidal college roommate on "The Sopranos") makes it clear that being 20 is no piece of cake either. title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: New Curbs On Neo-Nazis
description: Parliament, alarmed at a new public boldness being shown by far-right groups, approved new legislation that would ban demonstrations at World War II memorials if the demonstrations threatened to "harm the dignity" of victims of Nazism. Germany already has laws that sharply restrict neo-Nazi activity, including bans on the display of Nazi slogans and insignia or denying the Holocaust, but efforts two years ago to ban the largest far-right group, the National Democratic Party, were rejected by the courts. The new legislation was specifically aimed at blocking a plan by the party to march past the Holocaust memorial in Berlin on May 8, the 60th anniversary of Germany's defeat in World War II. The text of the new law cited an increase in far-right gatherings that "resemble ever more the character of the Nazi regime's marches." The vote in Parliament came a day after the Supreme Court upheld a lower court's conviction of a far-right rock bank known as Landser, or Foot Soldiers, whose songs were deemed to spread hatred against Jews and foreigners. title: Arts, Briefly; Fox News References Are Cut From 'Boston Legal' Episode
description: Viewers who tune in to "Boston Legal" on ABC tomorrow night will see an episode that includes none of the references to Fox News that the show's creator, David E. Kelley, originally proposed. The draft script by Mr. Kelley revolves around censorship charges that follow a principal's decision to block Fox News from appearing on school televisions, saying its programming "almost rises to the level of hate speech." In the rewritten script, the principal blocks an unspecified channel, described by a student only as "the most fair and balanced one." Other references to Fox News hosts, including Bill O'Reilly, right, and Brit Hume, were also removed. One of the show's producers is 20th Century Fox Television, a division of News Corporation, which owns Fox News. ABC asked Mr. Kelley for the changes, said Susan L. Sewell, a spokeswoman at the network, which is part of the Walt Disney Company. "While real-life situations are often used as original inspiration for fictionalized programming story lines," she said, "it is a longstanding industry-wide practice not to use real people or actual events." The draft script's mention of "Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism," a documentary that criticizes Fox News, did survive into the final version, although ABC refused to accept a commercial for the DVD release of "Outfoxed" that the movie's distributors wanted to appear during the episode. Ms. Sewell said ABC does not accept commercials about other media companies. The revisions to Mr. Kelley's draft script were posted by Rory O'Connor on his Weblog, www.roryoconnor.org, and on www.alternet.org. A spokeswoman for Fox News declined to comment. NAT IVES

title: Arts, Briefly; Leno's License to Mock
description: A California judge yesterday affirmed Jay Leno's right to make fun of Michael Jackson. Mr. Leno, below, the host of the "Tonight" show on NBC, has been identified as a potential witness in Mr. Jackson's trial on child molestation charges and was thus subject to restrictions on talking about the trial laid down by the trial judge, Rodney S. Melville of Santa Barbara County Superior Court. But Judge Melville said from the bench that the order left Mr. Leno latitude to lampoon the trial in his monologue, as long as he steers clear of the part of the case that pertains to him. In recent days, Mr. Leno mocked his own legal predicament by turning to surrogate comedians -- including Drew Carey, on Thursday's show -- to tell his Jackson jokes. An NBC official said earlier in the week that no one at the network had sought the arrangement on legal grounds -- Mr. Leno was apparently taking his cues from Jerry Lewis, rather than the late Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr.-- but Mr. Leno's lawyers were concerned enough that they had sought a clarification from the judge. "It's not the court's intent to stop him from commenting on or telling jokes about the case," Judge Melville said yesterday, "except those parts he's a witness to, and he knows what those are." JACQUES STEINBERG

description: Dan Rather's final broadcast as the anchor of "CBS Evening News" on Wednesday drew more viewers than "NBC Nightly News" and "ABC World News Tonight," marking the first time in five years that the news program has beaten its competitors. Citing Nielsen Media Research, CBS said that "Evening News" had finished first in Nielsen's 56 metered markets -- a sampling that accounts for more than two-thirds of the nation's television-watching households -- averaging 7.3 percent of households, an increase of nearly half over its average. Unlike NBC, which announced the day after Tom Brokaw's Dec. 3 farewell that 15.36 million viewers had tuned in, CBS did not release more detailed ratings information, saying it had not ordered "fast national" ratings data from Nielsen. Full ratings information for the signoff by Mr. Rather, above, is to be released Tuesday, a CBS spokeswoman said. JOEL TOPCIK

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Inflation Picks Up
description: China's inflation rate rose to 2.9 percent in the first two months of the year, gathering pace for the first time since July as prices of food and fuel rose, the National Bureau of Statistics said. The pickup followed a 2.4 percent increase in the consumer price index in December. Fuel costs in the two months rose 9.6 percent from a year earlier, the bureau said. The cost of food, which accounts for about a third of the index, rose 8.8 percent in February after climbing 4 percent in January and 2.4 percent in December, the statistics bureau said. Figures for January and February are combined to eliminate distortions caused by changes in the timing of the weeklong Lunar New Year holiday.

title: Arts, Briefly; Barnes Collection Appeal
description: The Superior Court of Pennsylvania has asked a student at the Barnes Foundation to file a brief by mid-April on why the foundation should be blocked from moving its notable collection of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art from Merion, Pa., to downtown Philadelphia. The student, Jay Raymond, is appealing a ruling in December by a Montgomery County Orphans' Court judge that in order to salvage its finances the foundation can violate the wishes of its founder, Albert C. Barnes, and move to a site where more people could see the collection. Barnes stipulated that no picture could be lent, sold or even moved on the walls of the neo-Classical galleries that he had built for it in the 1920's. A three-member panel of the Superior Court will receive briefs from both sides and hear oral arguments on the appeal. After Mr. Raymond's brief is filed, the Barnes will have 30 days to file its own. Oral arguments are expected in midsummer. CAROL VOGEL

Earlier, a center official said that Dr. Fuks (pronounced FEWKS), would remain as chairman and that the institution had no comment because his arrest was a private matter. Dr. Fuks, 68, who has won top awards for cancer research and treatment, helped make ImClone successful, arranging a meeting that led to ImClone's licensing of the cancer drug Erbitux, its first and so far only successful drug. Christine P. Hickey, a spokeswoman for Memorial, said that Dr. Fuks would continue his clinical and research work. Dr. Beryl McCormick, an expert in the treatment of breast cancer and eye tumors, will serve as acting chairwoman, said Dr. Robert E. Wittes, the hospital's physician in chief. Lawrence K. title: A TV Sports Show That's More About Chuckles Than Cheers
description: Aside from the occasional gaffe or clever halftime commercial, televised sports are rarely laugh-out-loud events. But the twin brothers Randy and Jason Sklar have made it their mission to change that. Their show, "Cheap Seats," which will broadcast the first original episode of its second season on ESPN Classic on Monday night, features the brothers as tour guides to some of the most ridiculous sports ever captured on camera. Picture Beavis and Butt-head as sarcastic twins riffing on competitive lumberjacking, and you have "Cheap Seats." Culling from ESPN's vaults and those of "ABC's Wide World of Sports," the Sklars, 33-year-old identical twins, highlight the sports that time (thankfully) forgot. Some segments -- like "Creative Breaking Championships," featured on Monday night, in which men use karate chops and kicks to break cinderblocks, wood and other materials, competitively -- provide obvious invitation for ridicule. "It's like karate with choreography," Jason Sklar said. "We like to say that if the high school from 'Fame' had a martial arts program, this would be the result."

description: KOCH--Elizabeth and Dr. Lynn H. The Horace Mann Community mourns with profound sorrow the tragic passing of Elizabeth Koch, class of 2005 and her beloved mother, Dr. Lynn H. Koch. Lizzie was an inspirational student leader, a gifted student and a treasured friend to all. An advocate for human rights causes, she was Chapter President of the Junior State of America; a compassionate pragmatist, she was a strong advocate of Horace Mann student charitable fundraising events; an articulate social critic, she made her life a quest to repair the world. She was a licensed EMT and volunteered many hours at the Englewood General Hospital. Her lively intelligence, her keen insights, her warm personality, her unforgettable smile and her boundless optimism will be greatly missed but not forgotten. "The world has lost a ray of its own sunshine," commented her academic advisor. Her mother, Lynn Koch, in her passionate desire to contribute and to serve, embodied the best values of humanity and the HM community. She was our dearest friend, avid supporter and tireless worker. Devoted to and supportive of Horace Mann's vision and mission, she was an active leader in the Parents Association. Her culinary talents were legendary as was her generosity to the school. She left an indelible mark on all of us who worked alongside of her. We extend heartfelt condolences to Paul and L.J. Koch and grieve with them in their tragic loss. Dr. Eileen Mullady, Head of School Robert J. Katz '65, Chair, HM Board of Trustees The Horace Mann Parents Association
