Artist and educator, who during World War II began her career as an illustrator for Vogue Magazine and drew portraits of soldiers and sailors at the Stagedoor Canteen, inspired thousands of students, ages 6-96. She was district coordinator of art for Lawrence Public Schools, and in her retirement was a docent at Tucson Museum of Art and an instructor at Pima Community College. She was a member of the National League of American Pen Women and past president of the New York State Council of the Arts. Wife of Solomon; mother of Marla and George Coleman, Siri Mills; sister of Florence Solnick and Herbert Gopstein; and grandmother of Jordan and Jessica Coleman, Ross Coleman, and Alexandra Beierlein. The American Camp Association has established an art campership memorial fund in Sylvia Schwartz' memory. Donations can be sent to the American Camp Association, 5000 State Rd. 67 North Martinsville, IN 46151-7902.

title: 'Perfect Madness'
description: To the Editor:

title: Joanna Winslade, Ben Trachtenberg
description: Joanna Lang Winslade, a daughter of Dr. Joan A. Lang of University City, Mo., and Dr. William J. Winslade of Friendswood, Tex., is to be married today to Ben Lev Trachtenberg, a son of Francine Zorn Trachtenberg and Stephen J. Trachtenberg of Washington. Rabbi Gerald Zelermyer is to officiate at the Dorothy Betts Marvin Theater at George Washington University. Cantor Gideon Zelermyer, a son of the rabbi, will take part in the ceremony.

title: Macy's Is a Punk Rocker
Sticky Success
description: Splenda Sugar is one of those commodities that seem so commonplace that it is hard to imagine their absence. This was not always so: it was once a rare luxury, but a few hundred years of globalization and industrialization, plus some colonization and slavery, helped change that. Not that there weren't always critics, of course. "Sugar hath now succeeded honie," the author of one quasi-medical book wrote in 1633, "and is become of farre higher esteem, and is far more pleasing to the palat" -- before questioning the view, not uncommon at the time, that sugar had medicinal properties and charging that it "heateth the blood" and "rotteth the teeth," among other things. Several centuries on, of course, sugar is something that many people try to cut back on, or eliminate from their diets altogether. But sweetness is something few can do without, which means that there has been a vigorous market for sugar substitutes, from Sweet 'N Low to Equal to, more recently, Splenda.

title: On Further Review, Get Me Rewrite
description: NEW BRUNSWICK - JOURNALISM has often been described as history in a hurry for the relative speed with which it is done and the inevitable errors, oversights and failures of perspective that can result. It is the rare journalism education program whose students get a chance to experience this element of the discipline firsthand.

title: Softer Words for Harder Times?
description: IS Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, trying to send a reassuring message on the nation's record current-account deficit?

title: 'Lipstick Jihad'
description: It was so cool and quiet up in the toot (mulberry) tree that I never wanted to come down. I didn't have to; the orchard was so dense that I could scramble from the limb of one tree to another, plucking the plump, red berries as I went along. The sweet juice made my fingers stick together, but I couldn't stop climbing. The trees stretched out as far as I could see, a glorious forest of mulberries, ripe for my picking. I loved mulberries, but until that summer in Tehran, I had only tasted them dried, from little plastic packets sold in the Iranian grocery story in San Jose. Riveted by the abundance, and the squishy texture of the berry in its fresh form-a whole new delight-I had spent the better part of the afternoon perched in the shady canopy of the orchard. "Azadeh jan, I am going to count to three, and you had better come down," came Maman's glaring voice from somewhere far below. I gave in, but only because of the preliminary pangs of the hideous stomachache to come. Sedigheh Khanoum, one of the farmers who took care of the orchards at Farahzad and who had tended Maman's stomach when she was little, made me tea with sugar crystals, to soothe the cramps. And I lay content on my back on the Persian rug outside, as Maman chatted with Sedigheh about our life in America, debating whether tomorrow I should go after the delicate white toot, or the dark red.

title: Bookshelf
description: WILD ABOUT BOOKS. By Judy Sierra. Illustrated by Marc Brown. Knopf. $16.95. (Ages 4 to 8) The author and illustrator dedicate the story of Molly McGrew -- a librarian who drives her bookmobile into the zoo -- to their "favorite doctor," Dr. Seuss. His influence is clear in the witty illustrations and the tricky verse: "Raccoons read alone and baboons read in bunches. And llamas read dramas while eating their llunches."

title: BEST SELLERS: March 13, 2005
description: Weeks

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the possibility of a Fox News challenge to CNBC misstated the age of Roger E. Ailes, chairman of Fox News, and misidentified one of the United States presidents for whom he worked. Mr. Ailes is 64, not 54, and was on the staff of George H.W. Bush, not the current president.

title: Y.W.C.A.'s Sale Costs Longtime Crafts League Its Home
description: Nancy Sureck signed up for a ceramics class at the Y.W.C.A. on the East Side of Manhattan two years ago because she needed a distraction from cancer. The Craft Students League, which has been teaching people to work with wood, glass, metal, clay and cloth through branches of the Y since 1932, soon became her extended family, a more soothing force than medicine.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Plum TV, the cable channel that presents the model Sophie Dahl reading children's stories, misstated the relationship between her grandparents Roald Dahl and Patricia Neal. They were divorced; Ms. Neal is not Dahl's widow. The article also misidentified the island were Ms. Neal has a house; it is Martha's Vineyard, not Nantucket.

title: If Federal Transit Bill Is a Smorgasbord, the City Is in Line
description: The federal transportation bill passed by the House of Representatives last week included more than $230 million for an assortment of New York City projects, including a parking garage in Harlem, a waterfront trail in Brooklyn and street repairs in Queens.

title: The Remix; Teddy Boys
description: Dorm-room hedonism, homoerotic crushes and upper-class mores all make for a great sense of style, at least according to the English writer Evelyn Waugh. "Brideshead Revisited," Waugh's classic about a declining aristocratic family in the 1920's and 30's, has been a bedside companion for wan teenagers and sensitive aesthetes since it was published in 1945. Now designers like Helmut Lang and Christopher Bailey at Burberry are tapping into Waugh's town-and-country characters for inspiration.

title: How and Where to Be Heard
description: Re "When Readers Speak Out, Can Anyone Hear Them?" (Feb. 20): You quote the letters editor, Thomas Feyer, saying that "a news article is the product not only of the reporter whose name is on it, but The Times as a whole: the senior management and the desk editors, the copy editors and the headline writers."

title: A Very Ripe State Government
description: If there is a lush, green valley for lobbyists, it must look a lot like Albany. In every state building, in every agency in New York's state capital, there are easy pickings for those peddling the wares of the rich, the powerful, the big special interests.

title: How Bedford Got Its Good Thing Back
'Lighting Up': Smoking Ban
description: LIGHTING UP How I Stopped Smoking, Drinking and Everything Else I Loved in Life Except Sex. By Susan Shapiro. 309 pp. Delacorte Press. $22.

title: ...But Can Sex Talk Be the Bride of Chastity?
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. - LAUREN F. WINNER comes off not unlike a lot of liberal arts graduate students strolling the campuses of the country's elite universities. She wears retro cat's-eye glasses, has four tattoos, weaves references to the French sociologist Pierre Bourdieu into casual conversation and sips Ctes du Rhne over lunch.

title: There's a New Cart in Town, and It Looks a Bit Familiar
description: Aleem Rafiqi, a smooth-talking 32-year-old, moved to New York City from Afghanistan 10 years ago and built a mini-empire of lunch carts scattered in Midtown. Mr. Rafiqi and his five brothers own four carts -- all called Rafiqi's -- offering cheap Middle Eastern fare to the city's harried, hungry work force. In a borough famous for its hot dog vendors, Rafiqi's carts satisfy a different craving in the office-worker palate, serving heaping plates of pungent, shredded chicken, savory lamb and kabobs.

title: Why We Won't Let Woody Allen Grow Up
description: ON Friday, Fox Searchlight will release "Melinda and Melinda," the 34th feature film written and directed by Woody Allen. These days, the opening of a new Woody Allen movie is hardly an earth-shattering event in the motion picture world; they come around every 15 months or so, with their familiar white-on-black opening titles presenting the cast in alphabetical order accompanied by the scratchy, lilting sounds of old-time jazz. The reactions are often as ritualized, as predictable, as those titles. A few die-hards proclaim that the new picture is, if not quite a return to form, then at least a sign that Mr. Allen -- not that anyone ever calls him that outside the pages of this newspaper -- still has some comic brio and intellectual fire left in him. Others grumble, once again, that he is not what he used to be, and wonder why he still bothers making movies or why they still bother going.

title: Open-Air Pumas
description: Puma's Impulse Cat sandals, a new breed of women's sport shoe, cleverly crosses a ballet flat with a slingback sneaker. Available in pale blush with a raspberry stripe (shown), cream with a blue stripe or alabaster with an apple green stripe, the shoes have suede uppers and sturdy motocross-inspired tire-tread soles. They arrived in stores last week and have flown off shelves across the city, at stores like Orva and Lady Foot Locker. Well matched with jeans, khakis, miniskirts or even yoga pants, the Impulse Cats are also available at www.puma.com for $60.

title: Martha's Privacy Seems to Be Everyone's Business
description: TELEVISION news crews called the local police asking for permission to park, and residents braced themselves for what they were certain would be nonstop commotion. The woman who was sparking it all grabbed her hand-knit poncho from her cell in a West Virginia prison and boarded a private plane to the Westchester County Airport.

title: DATEBOOK
description: SEVILLE From April 12 to 17, this city's annual Feria de Abril, a flamenco music festival, is expected to draw around a million people to enjoy music, and to drink and dance until dawn. After the lighting of the gateway to the festival (below), most of the festivities take place in tents and stands set up on the west bank of the Guadalquivir River. Expect to see much of the city dressed in traditional garb -- particularly colorful flamenco- and gypsy-style dresses. Parades showcasing Seville's high society on horseback and in carriages run daily from around 1 to 5 pm. and are followed by bullfights starting around 5:30 p.m. In early March, round-trip fares from Kennedy Airport for departures to make the opening of the festivities started at $448. The Tourist Office of Spain, (212) 265-8822 and www.spain.info, can provide more information.

title: On the Whole, They'd Rather Fly From Philadelphia
description: Correction Appended

title: When Yellow Means Stop, Not Go
description: CATHY HUGHES remembered the day about two years ago when she stood at her front door in Glastonbury, watching her daughter, Emily, who was 9 at the time, run down the steep driveway of their home to catch the school bus. It was waiting across the street, as it always did, lights flashing, stop sign out.

title: From Young Artists, Work That Reverberates
description: SOMETIMES, late at night, after a hard day, I fantasize about being at the controls of a tank and casually lobbying mortars into a remote desert city. I don't know what it all means (paging Dr. Freud), but the sight of little twisters of smoke spiraling up from the bombed-out wreckage makes me feel calm and peaceful.

title: Just Do What We Tell You, or the Fictitious Bird Gets It
description: Last September, a crudely drawn flier appeared by the hundreds on lampposts and bus shelters along a three-mile stretch of the East Side of Manhattan. Full of scratch-outs and misspellings, it pleaded: "LOST PIGEON in Madison Squer Park. If found, please call. 212-613-6324." The kicker was the accompanying photograph: a hazy Polaroid image of pigeons in a park, indistinguishable from one another. A Magic Marker arrow pointed not to the pigeon in the foreground but to a bird behind it that was half out of the frame.

title: Katherine Shaio, Vickramajit Sandhu
description: Dr. Katherine Shaio, a daughter of Linda and Alberto Shaio of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Vickramajit Singh Sandhu, the son of Dr. Harjit Sekhon and the stepson of Baldev Sekhon of San Martin, Calif. The Rev. Robert H. Thompson, an African Methodist Episcopal minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York.

title: More to Do on the Queen Mary 2
description: As the Cunard Line doubles the number of trans-Atlantic crossings for the Queen Mary 2 in 2005 to 26, it is also expanding its onboard enrichment programs. In addition to continuing the Chefs at Sea partnership with Gourmet magazine and its association with Architectural Digest, selected crossings will feature lectures sponsored by House & Garden and The New Yorker.

title: In Europe's Capitals, Great Meals For the Budget-Conscious Traveler; MADRID: LA SANABRESA
description: Whether you're in the mood for good pasta in Rome or hot potato salad in Moscow, you can eat well while you're traveling around Europe and not have to count your euros (or rubles) too closely.

title: A Pint-Size Superhero Takes a Borough by Storm
description: Bronx schoolchildren are going Harry-Potter-nuts over a series of books about a new kind of hero, "Paperboy." Not only can they identify with the title character, an 11-year-old who gets back at bullies using weapons that give them paper cuts, but they can relate to the author, too. Omari Jeremiah, now 14, was a Bronx middle-schooler himself when he wrote the first book.

title: Tasty Matches and Screw Tops
description: Oz Clarke, the eminent British critic, prefers Australian rieslings with screw caps, which keep wine exceptionally fresh. "I'd like screw tops on pretty well all my whites," he says in his indispensable 2005 "Pocket Wine Guide" (Harcourt). His wine-and-food matches are inviting: Beaujolais (red) with bacon or sausages, Burgundy aligot (white) and smoked fish.

title: Union Labor, Squeezed From All Directions
description: TOM BRYANT of Bay Shore, a member of the Steamfitters Local 638, says he dreads having to leave Long Island again to find work. His last stint out of town -- in 1998 in California -- lasted seven months. Although the job put food on the table, it also put a strain on his marriage, he said.

title: The Remix
description: It's all about . . . PETER BEARD . . . 'brideshead' re-revisited . . . maori hip-hop . . . top cellars . . . rip-off artists . . . bespoke stationery . . . Rocker wear.

title: Other Voices: No Cease-Fire in the War of the Words
description: You call terrorism "an act of political violence committed against purely civilian targets." By this definition the British and American bombing of Dresden was terrorism, as was the fire-bombing of Tokyo and the nuclear attacks on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. (Almost no one argues there was military value to these targets.) These were attacks meant to change people's minds by invoking fear. The same can be said for the German attacks on London, which were clearly aimed at the will of the British people. And, if you accept the argument that these attacks were military because they forced the diversion of military forces to stop them, then any civilian attack becomes a military one.

title: All Suspects Are Charged In Hebron Arson Case
description: The investigation into vandalism and arson that caused more than $500,000 worth of damages in January to the site of the Hebron Harvest Fair, one of the state's largest agricultural fairs, was completed March 4 when the last of four suspects surrendered to the state police.

title: Stay Gold
description: I've always wanted a hideaway right on the beach, and after owning Blancaneaux Lodge in western Belize for a number of years, I knew our guests wanted one, too. I started looking at properties up and down the coast and finally found the ideal spot on the Placencia peninsula, near a charming little fishing village. The place was modest and rustic and was called Turtle Inn. At first, we just renovated it, with grander plans on the drawing board. But Hurricane Iris came along and swept it into the ocean. I remember the phone call to this day. "So you're telling me there was significant damage?" I said, and the answer was, "No, the entire resort is gone; there's nothing there but beach!" So there I was with a beautiful blank slate. FRANCIS FORD COPPOLA, Dec. 23, 2004

title: The Remix; First Watch - Greige is the Rage
description: Old World craftsmanship returns with the Greige Manufacturing Company, a label whose clothes would be right at home in a Walker Evans photograph. The company, which is a year old and was founded by the longtime friends Cory Gomberg and Christopher Rosen, offers men a nostalgic yet timeless alternative to rock 'n' roll T-shirts. The company's sturdy indigo denim is woven in Japan on vintage looms, and garments like the three-button Migrant blazer (left) have tape seams, hand-stitched hems and buttons that are handmade in Tibet. Such quality doesn't come at Depression-era prices, but these clothes -- making their debut this spring at Barneys New York and Odin -- are built to last. "If we ever have a shirt that costs $400," Rosen says, "you'll be able to drive a truck over it, and then pick it up and wear it." STEFFIE NELSON

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Feb. 13 with an article about new housing in the Rockaways misstated the year the first structure was built on the Rockaway Peninsula. It was not 1856; an early settler, Richard Cornell, built a home in Far Rockaway in 1690.

title: Kimberly Kubie, Edward Harrison IV
description: Kimberly Ann Kubie, a daughter of Audrey and David Kubie of New York, was married last evening to Edward Tucker Harrison IV, the son of Cherie Harrison and Mr. Harrison III of Vero Beach, Fla. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin officiated at the W Hotel in New York.

title: ProTour Beginning Its Pursuit Of Revenue
Contributors
description: David Bradshaw "I have to say I'm more excited to be back in front of the house than backstage," says the London stylist David Bradshaw, who until November was a creative consultant at Prada, where his responsibilities included Prada men's, Miu Miu men's and Prada Sport. "It was an incredible experience being in close proximity to the phenomenon of Prada," he says, though he's busy with his newest venture, starting the magazine GQ Style in Britain in September. "I see the business personally as an ongoing conversation, and I've always tried to be a part of that, whether in magazines or a fashion house." Bradshaw, whose efforts appear on Page 154, has worked for designers like Katharine Hamnett ("where I really cut my teeth on shows"), Calvin Klein and Jil Sander. He has also styled videos for Michael Jackson and Madonna. In magazines, he has worked as the creative director at Arena and fashion director at Arena Homme Plus.

title: The Remix; WEST - SPRAYED IN JAPAN
description: In the East, everyone knows West, a 36-year-old graffiti artist turned sportswear pioneer whose high-end street-wear collection is called And Suns. Widely considered to be the king of the graffiti T-shirt in Japan, West and his partner, Shin Ono, are now ready for the American market, with a rollout that began in stores like Union and the Reed Space in New York.

title: What U.S.F. Is
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Gourmet's Minimalist Flat
description: Mireille Guiliano, 58, author of 'French Women Don't Get Fat' and C.E.O. and president of Clicquot Inc., and her husband, Edward, 54, have lived in a 2,500-square-foot apartment in the West Village for 15 years.

title: Dublin's La Stampa
description: THE BASICS -- La Stampa, a French brasserie, was a Dublin landmark for a decade even before its owners added a cozy 22-bedroom boutique hotel in the Victorian buildings above and beside the restaurant in 2000. Since then, the institution has grown into a dining and drinking complex with an upscale Thai restaurant and a popular bar, Samsara, decked out in lush Moroccan dcor with palm trees and warm orange lights kept low. The hotel plans to expand upward, nearly doubling the number of rooms by adding penthouse suites. The sound of thumping dance music reverberates through the hallways -- and many of the rooms -- until 3 a.m. on weekends.

title: Hollywood Reporters
description: THE CHRYSANTHEMUM PALACE By Bruce Wagner. 210 pp. Simon & Schuster. $23.

title: Letters to the Editor
Paid Notice: Deaths   UNGEMACH, EVERETT
description: UNGEMACH--Everett. Age 87, died on March 10, 2005, Albuquerque, NM. Rare such a valiant gentleman. Loving husband of the late Winifred Farrell Ungemach. He will be deeply missed.

title: How to Put the Family Back in Farm
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RABSON, HERMAN N. (HON.)
description: RABSON--Herman N. (Hon.), 95. Died February 22, 2005, Forest Hills, New York. Beloved husband of the late Helen, loving father of Edward & wife Gloria, adoring grandfather of Lauren and triplets Lindsay, Jaclyn and Jaimee. Attended Columbia University and Brooklyn Law School. Distinguished Maritime Law Attorney and U.S. Administrative Law Judge-US Coast Guard.

title: 'Every Man a Speculator': Follow the Money
description: Correction Appended

title: Manning the Barricades
description: Cambridge, Mass. - ON March 4, a car carrying several Italians including the journalist Giuliana Sgrena and a military intelligence officer, Nicola Calipari -- raced along the notoriously dangerous highway leading to Baghdad International Airport. A plane was waiting to carry Ms. Sgrena home to Italy following her release after a month as a hostage. They never made it. American soldiers opened fire on the Italians' Toyota Corolla, killing Mr. Calipari and wounding Ms. Sgrena.

title: For Young Artists, All Roads Now Lead to a Happening Berlin
description: THE Galerie Max Hetzler II in Berlin was empty, so the young man behind the desk seemed happy to stop reading his paperback and suggest a few contemporary art exhibitions worth seeing in the German capital. Drawing his finger over the map in Index, Berlin's nifty folding gallery guide, he noted more than 20 openings scheduled for that week, most of which he would be attending himself. Like so many young Berliners and foreigners, he had come to the city to revel in its thriving art scene. Even if each stop offered nothing more than pretzels and cheap wine, and a chance to cadge cigarettes from friends, this revolving and continuous set of parties seemed to be the foundation of his social life.

title: A Bordeaux Connection
description: AS California-oriented "Sideways" moves to the sidelines, another wine film, "Mondovino," is scheduled to open in Manhattan on March 23. It touches Long Island tangentially.

title: On Style, Spiritualism and an Artists' Retreat
description: FRONT ROW: ANNA WINTOUR, the Cool Life and Hot Times of Vogue's Editor in Chief By Jerry Oppenheimer St. Martin's Press ($24.95, hardcover)

title: Iger Is Said to Be Choice for New Chief at Disney
description: LOS ANGELES, March 12 - The board of The Walt Disney Company is expected to announce on Sunday that Robert A. Iger, Disney's president, will replace Michael D. Eisner, the chief executive who is departing next year, according to a person apprised of the board meeting.

title: All Madison Is a Stage, Like It or Not
description: Madison these days has been acting like a ditzy dame in one of Shakespeare's comedies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARTER, J. MICHAEL
description: CARTER--J. Michael. The Executive committee, Foundation Board of Directors and staff of the Metropolitan Golf Association mourn the passing of their Vice President, Michael Carter on March 10. His dedication to the game of golf, to his club, the Association and our charitable Foundation's junior golf programs will be missed. We offer our deepest sympathies to his wife, Mary Lou, his daughters, Kelly and Aly, and the entire Carter family. Donald J. Hendler, President Jay Mottola, Exec. Director

title: Eat, Memory: The Absolutely No-Anything Diet
description: I was, of course, honored to be asked to write this essay on food, but also somewhat puzzled, since I completely ceased eating four years ago. Although the total cessation of eating has not always been easy -- it's especially awkward, for example, when I'm invited to "go out to eat" -- still, I believe I made the right choice.

title: Summer of Culture, From London to Venice
description: Correction Appended

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: DAN YACCARINO'S MOTHER GOOSE Illustrated by Dan Yaccarino. Unpaged. Golden Books. $14.95. (Ages 2 to 5)

title: The Quality Cure?
description: David Cutler hit what seemed to be the peak of his career at 28, when as a junior faculty member at Harvard he was whisked down to Washington to help draft a health-care bill under the tutelage of Ira Magaziner and, of course, Hillary Clinton. The project produced a dispiriting result: nothing.

title: Pope to be discharged from hospital
Blowing Kisses Across the Sound
description: RELATIONS between Long Island and Connecticut, at a low last year because of a number of intertwining disputes, have greatly improved but still show lingering strains, officials and groups on both sides of Long Island Sound say.

title: Fallen Angelo
description: The last time we heard from the Yonkers school superintendent, Angelo Petrone, and his minions about the angry buzz over the questionable hiring of a 24-year-old accountant to a top-level job at an inflated salary, they assured us that the nepotism rumors were false. They insisted that the young man, Pietro Barberi, had no personal connection with anyone in the school administration. He had just shown up one day, bless him, quickly taken charge of the books and was earning every penny of his $90,100 salary.

title: With Mayhem at Home, They Call a Parent Coach
description: WOBURN, Mass. - What tripped Lisa D'Annolfo Levey's maternal tolerance meter on a recent Tuesday afternoon was not just the toy football her 7-year-old son, Skylar, zinged across the living room, nearly toppling her teacup. Or the karate kick sprung by her 4-year-old, Forrest, which Ms. Levey ducked, barely.

title: Other Voices: No Cease-Fire in the War of the Words
description: Supporters of Israel's policies have long dominated this war of words in the American news media. Otherwise, you and your colleagues might be debating whether to use "settlers" or "colonists" for the inhabitants of Israeli enclaves in the occupied territories: the former implies that they moved into uninhabited territory; the latter that someone else might already have been living there. Use of "colonists" brings charges of anti-Semitism, however, while "settlers," which is at least equally partisan, is widely treated as a neutral descriptive term.

title: Other Voices: No Cease-Fire in the War of the Words
description: Regarding the Social Security debate, you write: "Republicans tout 'personal accounts'; Democrats trash 'private accounts.' In this atmosphere, I don't think reporters have much choice other than to use 'private' and 'personal' interchangeably, and to interchange them often."

title: Battle Splits Conservative Magazine
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLF, LYDIA BREWSTER HUBBARD
description: WOLF--Lydia Brewster Hubbard. Of Cornwall, CT, died March 8th, 2005, aged 92, at Sharon (CT) Hospital (where she was born in 1913). Survived by a son, Thomas Gordon Wolf, two grandsons, Matthew and Stefan Wolf, all of Cornwall, three brothers, William of Wilmington, Gordon of Tuscon and Thomas of Bronxville and Cornwall, and numerous nephews and nieces. Her sister, Elizabeth Hubbard Lansing, predeceased her. A memorial service will be held in Cornwall in the Spring. She was a woman of great compassion.

title: Names of the Dead
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 6 about an Apache-run ski resort near Ruidoso, N.M., misstated the location of the San Carlos Agency in the 1870's. The agency, a unit of the Bureau of Indian Affairs that provides services to the White Mountain Apaches, was in the Arizona Territory, not New Mexico.

title: Desiree Kilbourn, Andrew Trister
description: Desiree Kalani Kilbourn, the daughter of Lourdes M. Kilbourn and William R. Kilbourn of Tampa, Fla., and Andrew Daniel Trister, the son of Oana D. Trister of Chatham, N.J., and Jack I. Trister of Park Ridge, N.J., were married last evening at the Palma Ceia Golf and Country Club in Tampa. Rabbi Arthur I. Baseman officiated with the Rev. Robert Schneider, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: American Doctors Helped Identify Ukraine Leader's Poisoning
description: A team of American doctors flew secretly to Vienna in mid-December to assist in the care of the poisoned Ukrainian presidential candidate, Viktor A. Yushchenko, who later triumphed in a contentious election and became Ukraine's president, doctors involved in the case said last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILMAN, ALAN
description: MILMAN--Alan. Died March 8, 2005. Beloved husband of Marcella. Loving father of Dr. James (Martina) and Rebecca Thompson (Rony). Dearly beloved grandfather of Philip Barnet. Admired uncle and great uncle. Beloved brother of Miriam, Doris and Anne. Alumnus of M.I.T., B.S. 1943, M.S. 1947. Veteran (First Lt., Coast Artillery) of W.W. II and Korean War. Funeral private.

title: Playing for Keeps
description: You haven't lived until you've seen Sir Paul McCartney twirl his wife around the dance floor to the music of Peter Duchin and his band. Other partygoers, the lucky ones at ringside tables, feign disinterest while trying to decide which is more remarkable: the sight of the former mop-top McCartney fox-trotting to Peter Duchin, or the fact that Lady McCartney, who wears a prosthetic leg, dances so beautifully that it seems almost rude not to stare.

title: Torture Warrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Introduction
description: Our essay on Howard Dean drew an enthusiastic response for the new party chairman; readers said he was just the ticket for the Democrats. Others hailed Jonathan Safran Foer as novelist -- and e-mailer -- extraordinaire, while some weighed in on the way the golden years play out on the silver screen.

title: Brecht in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Think Outside the Box Spring
description: The Samurai Shopper swears on a stack of pillow shams that there's nothing as deadly dull as shopping for bed linen, except talking about shopping for bed linen. This comes as a surprise, but there it is; sheets are a huge snooze, even for shopping compulsives and the fools who support them. The good news is that sheet shopping is so boringly brainless that deep, R.E.M.-rich sleep invariably follows. After days of eyeing linens in a slack-jawed continuum of ivory and beige, the Samurai Shopper was ready to nose-dive onto a mat of dried seaweed and buckwheat chaff rather than face another faceless fagoted cotton rectangle.

We eat well -- too well, bien sr -- and can't come close to finishing what's set before us, three-plus courses and no stinting in sight. I finish with a gorgeous Paris-Brest -- cream-filled puff pastry with almonds; she, with a quince claufoutis. It is a meal any chef would be proud of, and one that would immensely please most diners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUSSMAN, HERBERT
description: GUSSMAN--Herbert. Of Tulsa, Oklahoma, on March 12, 2005, at the age of 93. Loving father of Ellen G. Adelson and Barbara G. Heyman. Loving grandfather of David Adelson, Robert Adelson, James Adelson, Thomas Adelson, Alexandra Nash and the late Claudia Heyman, and 17 great-grandchildren, and sons-in-law Dr. Stephen Adelson and Stephen Heyman. He was preceded in death by his beloved wife of 60 years, Roseline Nadel Gussman. A graduate of Cornell University, he worked at Lehman Brothers before he entered the oil business in the 1930's. He was amongst the pioneers of the modern oil industry and was amongst the first to employ and perfect the method of oil well acidization which today is standard procedure in the industry for oil and gas well stimulation. At one time, Nadel and Gussman was the largest independent oil producer in Kansas, and for many years was the largest independent oil producer in Osage County, Oklahoma's largest producing county. Today, from five regional offices the company is a significant producer of oil and gas. For many years Herbert Gussman was the chairman of the executive committee of the Missouri Pacific Railroad and was instrumental in the merging with the Union Pacific Railroad. A great lover of music, he was a founder of the Tulsa Philharmonic, and although his first musical love was classical, for many years he studied jazz piano with his friend, the late Teddy Wilson. His friendships in the world of music stretched from Isaac Stern, Leonard Bernstein, Eugene Istomin, Jan Pierce to Vladimer Golschmann, all who would stay and practice at his home when they came to Tulsa. He leaves a collection of French Impressionist paintings that is considered one of the finest private collections in the country. Under the tutelage of his late brother Lawrence Gussman, he built a large personal collection of African art, and along with his brother, endowed and donated many works to the Gussman Collection at the Philbrook Museum of Art. A lover and a student of the game of golf, he played to a low single digit handicap through most of his life. Beyond all of his interests, his family came first. He was always there for them. His love for them and their own achievements were so evident to all. GUSSMAN--Herbert. The employees of Nadel and Gussman mourn our founder Herbert Gussman, a visionary amongst oil men who boldly lead us into new areas and new technologies. He enriched us both as a human being and by making us participants in the company's successes while always stressing the highest ethics in all of our transactions. He so loved his family, his business, Cornell, the piano, art, an afternoon of golf, and he loved us.

title: The Remix; Hot Copy
description: While John Currin's paintings command whopping prices (his "Homemade Pasta" went for $847,500 at a recent Christie's auction), art enthusiasts on macaroni-and-cheese budgets can pick up a "John Currin" (pictured), an acrylic-and-collage copy by Eric Doeringer for $100. Doeringer, a 30-year-old graduate of Brown University who knocks off works by art stars like Elizabeth Peyton, Lisa Yuskavage and Julian Schnabel, started hawking his pieces in front of Chelsea galleries four years ago. "Most artists are flattered and have a sense of humor about it," Doeringer says. Richard Prince is a fan, and Schnabel lightly chastised Doeringer's rendition of one of his "Big Girl" paintings, claiming, "Your blues are all wrong!" Other artists, however, aren't laughing. Takashi Murakami put a halt to Doeringer's "homage." "They're not intended to be direct copies," says Doeringer, who can do up to 30 in a weekend. "They are my own work. There is a right to parody." (For your own art-star bootleg, visit www.ericdoeringer.com.) MAURA EGAN

title: The Heights Beyond Rome's Hills

What surprised me most about the view, though, was the snow-covered mountains in the distance. I had never thought of Rome as a mountain town, and yet there they were, dwarfing the hills of Rome - shocking in their height, grandness and proximity to the city center.

title: Our Currency, Your Problem
description: Every congressman knows that the United States currently runs large "twin deficits" on its budget and current accounts. Deficit 1, as we well know, is just the difference between federal tax revenues and expenditures. Deficit 2 is generally less well understood: it's the difference between all that Americans earn from foreigners (mainly from exports, services and investments abroad) and all that they pay out to foreigners (for imports, services and loans). When a government runs a deficit, it can tap public savings by selling bonds. But when the economy as a whole is running a deficit -- when American households are saving next to nothing of their disposable income -- there is no option but to borrow abroad.

title: Three-on-Three
description: It's clear that the "CSI" shows (ranked No. 3, 7 and 21 for the television season so far) have overtaken the "Law & Order" shows (No. 23, 24 and 28, not including the new "Law & Order: Trial by Jury") as the top-ranked crime-solving franchise in prime time. But there's at least one measurement by which "Law & Order" still wins: the total number of viewers who watch any "Law & Order" broadcast in the course of a week is well ahead of the combined "CSI" figure, given the older series's myriad syndicated repeats. The numbers above, from Nielsen Media Research, are for the week of Feb. 21-27, the last one before "Trial by Jury" upped the "Law & Order" ante to four shows. Of course, "CSI" still wins on average: there were 47 broadcasts of "Law & Order" shows on NBC, TNT and USA for an average of 1.96 million viewers per episode, and just 15 broadcasts of "CSI" shows on CBS, A&E and Spike, for an average of 4.37 million. Still, it's a sobering thought: in an age when Americans are divided by politics, and distributed among hundreds of cable channels, the equivalent of one-third of the nation's population spent an hour watching "Law & Order" that week. MIKE HALE

title: The Remix; POP EYE
description: The British painter Antony Micallef likes to subvert pop culture in his work, which is then collected by pop-culture fixtures like Michael Stipe. "In order to make it yours, you've almost got to drag it down and change it," Micallef says, "degrade it in a sense." Micallef's dreamlike images, which the artist calls visual diaries, are culled from the works of old masters, fashion magazines, graffiti and Japanese cartoons alike. One sketch, "Freaks, My Self and a Sex Object," in which Micallef wears a Puma T-shirt, caught the attention of the president of apparel for Puma. "We put a lot of effort into our stage shows," Simon says. "They're so big that in some sense we are like the dark side of the Polyphonic Spree." American audiences have yet to experience the full Menlo-mayhem blast, but that should change with the imminent release of its second album, which the group's frontman, Chris Taylor, center, humbly describes as "typically Menlo Park: exciting, grandiose, ambitious, symphonic and utterly brilliant -- and likely to alienate 98.6 percent of the record-buying public." description: VIEBRANZ--Alfred C. The St. Lawrence University Board of Trustees, in official action, has honored late University benefactor and volunteer leader Alfred C. Viebranz '42. Mr. Viebranz was president of the Alumni Executive Council, chair of the Board of Trustees and at the time of his death on February 18, chairman emeritus of the Board. He received the honorary degree Doctor of Laws from St. Lawrence for his service and in recognition of his career in corporate communications. The personification of the liberal arts, Mr. Viebranz earned a degree in physics, served as a US Naval officer; worked as an engineer, business executive and historian; and claimed writing as his passion. Volumes 1 and 2, in stores now, escort the reader from turn-of-the-century Parisian erotica to the birth of Playboy in 1953. Available in May, Volumes 3 and 4 will zoom in on the swinging 60's. "The best games don't just exploit rap music by throwing in some celebrities to make it sexy," says Marc Ecko, the fashion designer and creator of the new graffiti adventure game Getting Up. They "help players feel closer to the culture." Thanks to advances in character customization and "sandbox play" (game-geek-speak for continuous action with a malleable arsenal and mise-en-scne), you can develop a fully realized alter ego in an increasingly believable world (Heidegger would love it). Playing Midway's new games Narc and L.A. Rush is like co-starring in "Training Day." The producers of L.A. Rush asked West Coast Customs, the home shop of MTV's hit "Pimp My Ride," to trick out its fleet. Rockstar's new Midnight Club 3: Dub Edition brought in Dub Magazine, the hip-hop nation's Car and Driver, to style its fleet (anyone for an Escalade with 26-inch gold rims?). In Def Jam Fight for NY, you can design your guy with a range of tattoos and muscle sizes -- even brow shapes -- and spend his points on Jumpman gear and diamonds by Jacob the Jeweler. Some new titles even have real-world applications: Eidos's Get on Da Mic, a rap-along karaoke "competition," has been followed by Get on Da Floor, the hip-hop version of the Japanese hit Dance Dance Revolution. The game comes complete with a sensor-filled carpet to judge your dance-floor skills -- so you can realize your hip-hop alter ego to its fullest. ALEXANDRA MARSHALL

How the iPod Ran Circles Around the Walkman

Then Sir Howard should recognize that the Sony he inherits is constitutionally incapable of making one (electronics) plus one (entertainment) equal three.

title: Corrections

It was about $200,000, not $55,000, according to John R.H. Blum, the seller at that time. The miscalculation occurred when a formula using the current state real estate transfer tax rate was used to determine the sale price for transactions in the 1960's and 1970's, when a lower tax rate was in effect.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the increasing number of seals seen in Long Island Sound misidentified a power plant in the distance. It was the KeySpan Northport Power Station on Long Island, not the Manresa Power Plant in South Norwalk.

title: 9/11 Is Sneaking Onto a Screen Near You
description: LOS ANGELES - AT least another year will pass before Hollywood, notoriously wary of films based on "current events," is ready to face the trauma of 9/11 head-on. Universal Pictures is developing a script about the last two Port Authority officers pulled from the World Trade Center rubble, and Columbia Pictures only recently acquired rights to "102 Minutes," a book about the terrorist attacks by Jim Dwyer and Kevin Flynn, reporters for The New York Times.

title: Deaths at Rail Crossings, After Decline, Go Back Up
description: Deaths at railroad grade crossings rose 11 percent last year, according to new federal figures, and the government failed to meet its 10-year goal of no more than 300 crossing deaths by 2004.

title: Saratoga Springs Keeps Rolling
description: Saratoga Springs (N.Y.) High School continued its pre-eminence in girls' distance running yesterday by breaking the national high school record for the 4x1-mile relay at the Nike indoor nationals scholastic championships in Landover, Md.

title: A Call to Reform Program For Traffic Offenders
description: Officials with the two providers contracted by the state's Department of Motor Vehicles to run driving schools for traffic offenders said Connecticut must makes changes to lower the number of people forced to repeat the program because of additional violations.

title: Money Quote
description: 'At the outset of every sweep phoner," wrote Lisa de Moraes in The Washington Post in December about the calls placed by network officials to influence interpretation of the latest ratings, "one NBC exec begins with a money quote -- one the press is sure to jump on."

title: Summer of Culture, From London to Venice; OPERA: A RARE PERFORMANCE
description: What's worth getting on a plane to see this summer? Whether it's Ewan McGregor finding his inner Sky Masterson in a London revival of "Guys and Dolls" or a highly anticipated production of "Tristan and Isolde" at Bayreuth, the stages of Europe offer plenty of enticements for the cultural-minded traveler.

title: In Europe's Capitals, Great Meals For the Budget-Conscious Traveler; LONDON: AFGHAN KITCHEN
description: Whether you're in the mood for good pasta in Rome or hot potato salad in Moscow, you can eat well while you're traveling around Europe and not have to count your euros (or rubles) too closely.

title: Let Them Wear Perfume
description: Marie Let-Them-Eat-Cake Antoinette, wife of Louis XVI, has always had a bad rap as the queen whose spending sprees fueled the rage that fired the French Revolution. But every age has its villains and heroes, and to our luxury-loving, budget-deficient society, the pretty little reine is looking less like a spoiled doll and more like a style-setting celebrity. She has attracted the attention of Sofia Coppola, who is making a movie based on her life. And she was the subject of much discussion at a recent party at Versailles, where about 80 invitees gathered to celebrate the publication of the biography of her perfumer, Jean-Louis Fargeon, one in a series of books about tradesmen who supplied the court.

description: Correction Appended

title: Blowing Kisses Across the Sound
description: RELATIONS between Long Island and Connecticut, at a low last year because of a number of intertwining disputes, have greatly improved but still show lingering strains, officials and groups on both sides of Long Island Sound say.

title: Dangerous Intersection
description: To the Editor:

title: Are Parking Lots an Endangered Species?
description: THE parking lot may well be on its way to extinction if the frenzied search for land on which to plant luxury residential buildings continues unabated.

title: Does the Affordable Paris Bistro Still Exist? Oui.
description: INSIDE Chez Michel, a cozy neighborhood bistro beyond the Gare du Nord, the atmosphere is a tad nautical, the menu dotted with specialties of Brittany. My companion and I share brouillade d'oeufs, the creamy stew of scrambled eggs and cream, a stew of wild boar and a fantastic brandade de morue, the elegant and classic salt cod mousse - this one served in a little jam jar, beautifully browned on top and accompanied by broiled tomato, tapenade and salad. We eat well - too well, bien sr - and can't come close to finishing what's set before us, three-plus courses and no stinting in sight. I finish with a gorgeous Paris-Brest - cream-filled puff pastry with almonds; she, with a quince claufoutis. It is a meal any chef would be proud of, and one that would immensely please most diners.

title: Rates in Athens Fall From Olympian Heights
description: THIS time last year, much of the sporting world was wringing its hands over the coming Summer Olympics in Athens, wondering whether the Greeks would ever get their act together in time. Ultimately, the Games came off without a hitch, even to widespread praise. But the hoped-for boom in tourism for the host city -- which underwent a thorough makeover for its moment in the international spotlight -- never materialized.

description: LUCAS--Marcia Ann (nee Martin). Of Ringwood, on March 11, 2005. Born in New Haven, CT, and formerly of Tenafly. Beloved wife of Roy Lucas. Devoted mother of Alison Lucas-Kunert of Ringwood; Nicole Lucas Haimes of Venice, CA; Craig M. Lucas of Ridgewood; and Evan T. Lucas of Phoenix, AZ. Funeral Mass, Tuesday, 10 AM, St. Mary's Church, 17 Pompton Avenue, Pompton Lakes, NJ. Interment Christ The King Cemetery. Donations to Saint Mary's Church Capital Fund.

title: An SAT Without Analogies Is Like: (A) A Confused Citizenry...
description: When Grover Norquist, a leading conservative activist, was on the NPR program "Fresh Air" a while back, he casually made a comparison that left the host, Terry Gross, sputtering in disbelief. "Excuse me," she said. "Did you just compare the estate tax with the Holocaust?" Yes, he did.

title: In Sicily, a Winery Tour With Lunch Included
description: ABOUT halfway between Palermo, on the north coast of Sicily, and Agrigento, on the south, lies one of the island's premier wineries and cooking schools -- Regaleali, which has been in the family of Count Lucio Tasca since 1830.

title: When Shabby Isn't Chic
description: Q. I have been living in a rent-stabilized apartment for 35 years. The apartment is maintained in adequate condition by the landlord -- appliances are repaired or replaced as needed. But with normal wear and tear, certain things have become quite shabby. Countertops are worn and discolored, and one has a crack caused by the heat from a dishwasher below. Baseboards are cracked, the enamel is wearing off the stove, and the wooden cabinets underneath the sink are cracked and discolored. Is the landlord obligated for cosmetic maintenance? . . . Barbara Petroske.

title: AARP's Antagonist
description: Q: USA Next engineered the recent controversial ad that branded AARP pro-gay marriage and included a photograph of two men kissing. What else are you planning?

title: The One Who Got Away
description: On a July afternoon in 1974, when she was four years deep into breast cancer, my mother executed her will. She sealed the document inside an envelope from the local cultural arts commission, one of her favorite causes, and added several notes on the back. "If I die before Bubbe and there are services," she wrote, referring to her mother by the Yiddish term for a grandmother, "I would prefer that she not attend."

title: Mayor's Woes Reflect a City's Concern Over Gambling
description: Correction Appended

title: What Happened After the Ceiling Fell In
description: IN December, the ceiling of Mike Albo's closet office collapsed. It was inevitable, he said: the droppings from pigeons roosting above it, tempered with the rain that blew in from under the eaves, had cooked into a soft, odorous and ultimately corrosive stew that finally overwhelmed the plaster below.

title: DataBank; Rising Oil Prices Leave Stock Indexes in the Red
description: Rising oil prices and climbing bond yields set back the stock market last week. All three major stock indexes lost ground, and they ended the week in negative territory for the year.

Smuggling Trial in Texas Focuses on Trucker's Role

Paid Notice: Deaths   LOWENSTEIN, KATHERINE (NEE GOLDSMITH)
description: LOWENSTEIN -- Katherine (nee Goldsmith) on March 10, 2005 at her home in New York City at the age of 103. She was predeceased by her husband Melvyn, a long-time member of the New York Bar to whom she had been married in 1925. She is survived by her sons James, Hugh and Peter; her sister Bertha Bernstein; seven grandchildren; eight great grandchildren; a niece and a nephew. A 1923 graduate of Bryn Mawr College, she maintained a life long interest in the college and in a variety of charitable activities and devoted herself throughout her long life to the happiness and welfare of her family who could always count on her for advice and support. Interment will be private. Donations in her memory may be made to Bryn Mawr College, 101 North Merion Ave, Bryn Mawr, PA 19010 for the Katherine G. Lowenstein Library Fund.

title: Once Again, Marines Walk on Iwo Jima
description: IWO JIMA, Japan, March 12 - Pointing to a sandstone cliff pockmarked with World War II bullet holes, the Marine historian was describing a honeycomb of Japanese tunnels on Saturday when a somber voice piped up from the back of the Humvee.

title: Basic Instinct
description: Mike Mills has all the credentials of cool. A member of California's skate-punk scene, the graphic designer, artist, movie director and fabric designer is both big in Japan and part of the Sofia Coppola clan. The French group Air even named a song after him.

title: A Feast of the Mind
description: LONG before the world was mapped as bipolar and cross-addicted, human oddities were classified by affixing the suffix "mania" to any old Greek root, giving us now romantic terms like metromania (the compulsion to write verse) or clinomania (the overwhelming desire to stay in bed, also known by the English term "common sense"). Just as people today profess to be addicted to Prada or "Desperate Housewives," so manias and phobias found their way into the cultural world of balletomanes and Francophobes. The exercise even infiltrated the decorative arts, where the words decalcomania and potichomania were coined to refer to the fads of decoupage and of painting objects to resemble porcelain.

title: The Remix; What Would Jesus Wear?
description: Pascal Hardy was a professional windsurfer before he found God and created a popular line of faith-based T-shirts and sweatshirts for the extreme-sports lifestyle. "We're a company, but to Christians we're a ministry," says Hardy, 35, who started the Eternal Riders label in spring 2001. "Everything we do is based around the fact that Christ died for you, he loves you and you need to ride for him." One T-shirt called Committed pairs a graphic of a snowboarder with a passage from One Corinthians that reads, "Ride in such a way that you may win the race." Another model, a sleeveless shirt, is described as a Thank Top. A stylized cross acts as the T in the brand's logo. "Before, I was glorifying the name of brands that didn't lead anywhere," says Hardy, who is the director of a congregation in Maui, Hawaii. "The products were good, but I realized above all my sponsor was God." Available at www.eternalriders.com. MARK JACOBS

description: WALKING through Hoboken recently, I noticed that one of the many vacant storefronts along Washington Street would soon be home to a Cold Stone Creamery, the fast-growing national ice-cream chain.

title: The Remix; PICKUP ARTISTS
description: An Aston Martin DB5 is a classic-car coup, but it won't haul more than a blonde and a briefcase. That's why collectors are now parking vintage pickup trucks next to their Bentleys. Cooper Classics Collection, the 25-year-old Manhattan company that recently drove up the market for Jaguar XKE's, is now betting on the farm staple. "It's understated, not in your face," explains Elliot Cuker, Cooper's owner. "And you can actually put stuff in it!" Cuker sells about 10 restored Fords and Chevys a year, including a $25,000 1965 Chevy C10 that went to a real estate magnate's home in Bedford, N.Y. Of course, young L.A. actors and Williamsburg artists looking for a cool ride started hitting truckfinder.com years ago. Marc Blucas, the star of "First Daughter," drives a 1966 Ford F100 4x4. "People of all ages, races and sexes love old trucks," he says. "I get honks -- at least I think it's for my truck, not my driving." The downside?"Whenever a friend moves, I get the first phone call." CHRISTINE MUHLKE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOHLMAN, ROBERT F.

He is survived by his loving wife of 61 years, Vivian Wohlman, his son Gary and his daughter Leslie Wohlman Himmel and son-in-law Jeffrey Himmel, and his grandchildren Andrea and David. Services to be held at 12:00 Noon on Sunday, March 13th at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC. The family will receive friends at 125 E. 72nd Street on Sunday evening from 6:008:30 and Monday evening from 5:00-8:00. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in memory of Robert Wohlman to the Mount Sinai Department of Dermatology, The Development Office, One Gustave L. Levy Place, Box 1049, New York NY 10029.

title: Indecent Exposure
description: The idea that they need our paternalistic protection is all part of the prejudice against the old. For those in assisted-living and nursing homes, control of their lives is given up bit by bit. It starts with their physical beings and, if they become ill, eventually extends to every aspect of their lives. But everyone tries to hold onto some sense of self to the very end. It seems that Elliot Greenebaum gave the people in his movie some control back, separate from the regulations they must live with in assisted living.

title: In Niagara Falls, The City's Fortunes Finally Begin to Rise
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. - ALTHOUGH this city is famous as the honeymoon capital of the nation, its fortunes, in reality, were long tied not to kissing couples but to chugging smokestacks. When manufacturing moved to other regions, it suffered the all-too-familiar Rust Belt fate of a nearly deserted downtown, shuttered factories and rows of neglected and abandoned houses.

title: Hezbollah Leader's New Fray: Lebanese Politics
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 12 - When Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Lebanon's militant Hezbollah organization, addressed the hundreds of thousands of party faithful who gathered in the largest rally in Lebanon's modern history on Tuesday, his usual theme of liberating Jerusalem went unmentioned.

title: Other Voices: No Cease-Fire in the War of the Words
description: Terrorism is the intentional harming of innocent civilians for political purposes. The Times should have the courage to use this term correctly, consistently and as often (or seldom) as the facts require. Let the political chips fall where they may.

title: Other Voices: No Cease-Fire in the War of the Words
description: Neither The Times, nor any news source, should play along with the use of the term "Patriot Act." Rather, it should be referred to by its full name: Uniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism Act of 2001 (Public Law 107-56). Readers can then determine for themselves whether "Patriot Act" is an Orwellian euphemism or an accurate expression of patriotism.

title: Bankruptcy, the American Morality Tale
description: WHAT could be more American than the idea of a second chance, a fresh start, Act Two? It is embedded in the culture, the notion that you can reinvent yourself in every way, by moving to a new city, buying a new car, getting a face lift -- or by filing for bankruptcy.

title: Fred G. Burke, 79, Official Who Promoted Changes in Public School Financing, Dies
description: Fred G. Burke, who oversaw sweeping changes in the financing and accountability of public schools as the commissioner of education for Rhode Island and then New Jersey in the 1970's and early 1980's, died Friday at Newton Memorial Hospital in Newton, N.J. He was 79 and lived in Milford, Pa.

title: What She Earns Is Respect
description: A FORMER principal told me that during a recent trip to Italy, he was reminded of the high regard with which the rest of the world views his occupation.

title: Goodbye Doesn't Need to Mean Forever
description: A FEW weeks ago, in response to the musings of Harvard's president, Lawrence H. Summers, on women and science, I wrote about the need to reimagine the workplace. Women are in fact different from men, I said, not in their abilities, but in the timing, and breadth, of their parental responsibilities. Careers, therefore, should allow for stopping and starting, leaving and re-entering.

title: Somewhat West of Tuscany
description: FOR years South Shore diners flocked to Amato's, an Amityville restaurant known for its big portions and generous attitude. Bellissimo has taken over the building and is displaying a similar largesse.

title: The Get; Schlag Party
description: Vienna is not all faded Hapsburg palaces, Art Nouveau filigree and schlag. The city is fast becoming a destination for fans of high fashion, art and design. The hometown of the minimalist master Helmut Lang, it is also the spot where the T columnist Tyler Brl produced the first issue of his high-style bible, Wallpaper, back in 1996 -- with the help of a local Viennese art director, Herbert Winkler. The University of Applied Arts has attracted guest professors as celebrated as Vivienne Westwood and Raf Simons. In fact, from bespoke brogues to the Lang shop, this is an aesthete's paradise. MARKUS EBNER

title: Portraits of the Gay Literary Life
description: Amagansett - INDIVIDUALLY, Robert Giard's photographs of gay and lesbian writers offer a glimpse into the personalities of these writers -- some famous, others not -- living and working in disparate parts of the country. Collectively, his portraits capture an era in gay history: the emergence, from the mid-1980's on, of authors, poets and historians proud to declare themselves homosexuals, both in their lives and in their work.

description: SHANGHAI, March 12 - Local statutes for Hong Kong will be rewritten so that its next leader will serve only a two-year term, the Chinese territory's top officials announced late Saturday night, in a step that democracy advocates warned could set off a constitutional crisis.

title: What Dean Means
description: It is virtually impossible to yowl through gritted teeth, as Matt Bai characterized the uttering of that infamous "scream," which was, in fact, a full-throated, open-mouthed rallying of the troops, a roar of encouragement to a raucous, cheering crowd. Had Dean prevailed in subsequent primaries, it would probably have been described in retrospect as the opening salvo of a triumphant comeback.

title: In Retro Specs
description: I got my first pair of Ray-Ban Wayfarers in 1977, a gift from Kate Simon, an intrepid, gorgeous and hilarious photographer. Kate -- who hung out with Bob Marley, the Clash, Johnny Rotten and William Burroughs -- epitomized bohemian glamour. Kate got her first pair from the rock writer Lester Bangs in 1976, while she was touring Britain with the Who. I don't know who gave Lester his. Maybe Roy Orbison back in 1954. "It was a real shift, a transformative moment I have never come back from," recalls Kate, who has just published "Rebel Music" (Genesis Publications), an epic book of Bob Marley photographs. Wayfarers transformed me, too. Those shades instantly became a part of my face. I wore tortoise frames by day, black by night. In the late 70's, we all wore sunglasses around the clock. Some people thought it was about drugs, but it was really about cool: people couldn't read your eyes. In 1978, the Blues Brothers wore Wayfarers on "Saturday Night Live," and the glasses began their ascent as a mainstream fashion accessory. They probably peaked shortly after 1983, when Tom Cruise wore them in "Risky Business," and they were widely knocked off. Clich-phobic, I switched to Persols, but after some years I realized they were more Marcello Mastroianni than me, so I went back to my Wayfarers. They feel right and look right, and there's something about the name that strikes a chord: they're so "on the road." GLENN O'BRIEN

title: The Last Days of Enron
description: It has become the icon for an era of excess: the precipitate collapse of Enron, played out over the final weeks of 2001. Now, Kenneth L. Lay, Enron's former chairman, faces federal charges that he lied about the company's financial state in those weeks; his criminal trial is scheduled to begin next January.

description: MITCHELL--Sally, 91, peacefully at home December 28, 2004. Loving wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister, aunt and great-aunt. Sally was a kind, gentle woman whose first priority was love of family. She was a loyal and lifelong friend. She leaves behind her wonderful nurse's aide, Christiana. Graveside services were held at Mt. Ararat, Farmingdale, NY. Rest in peace.

title: A Changing of the Guard at the Barn
description: ON the notoriously bruising cop drama "The Shield," the command center of the Farmington police district is a testosterone hothouse. For its first three seasons, the snarling Vic Mackey (Michael Chiklis) ran roughshod over his fellow officers and his former captain, David Aceveda (Benito Martinez). At the outset of Season 4, Aceveda trades in the Barn, as the command center is called, for a city council seat, handing the reins over to Capt. Monica Rawling. It is a momentous change, and not only because it is Glenn Close's first regular TV role.

title: Still Turning Provocations Into Classics
description: SINCE the late 1940's, Robert Craft has been, among other things, a freelance boutique conductor. Without an orchestra of his own and concentrating on the works of a handful of composers, he has nevertheless influenced musical taste more than most traditional maestros have.

description: Correction Appended

title: Police Start Piecing Together Gunman's Path
description: DULUTH, Ga., March 12 - When Brian Nichols walked out of his hostage's suburban Atlanta apartment at 11:24 a.m. on Saturday, waving a white piece of cloth in surrender, he ended just over 24 hours of bloodshed, fear and furious police activity.

title: Visiting Gladys's Kitchen
description: EDUARDO MACHADO's 2003 play "The Cook," now at Hartford Stage, is about the difficult task of rooting out a personal identity in Cuba, both before and during the Castro years. The play revolves around Gladys, a cook, and her comrades, who struggle with three principal forces: Class Society, Fidel Castro and a problematic script.

title: Turning Back a Page
description: AFTER 60 years, the Oak Bar at the Plaza is closing on April 30, and not a minute too soon. The hotel is being converted to apartments, and the retail spaces renovated. Whether the Oak Bar, with its hansom-cab murals and carved paneling and celebrity as a place for the powerful to meet and drink, will return is unclear.

title: Teenage Drinkers, Permissive Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: The Heights Beyond Rome's Hills
description: LAST year, soon after moving to Rome, I stood atop the Janiculum Hill, which has a stunning view of the city, and looked out at the magnificent tile roofs, church domes and the great masses of starlings that form changing shapes in the sky. What surprised me most about the view, though, was the snow-covered mountains in the distance. I had never thought of Rome as a mountain town, and yet there they were, dwarfing the hills of Rome -- shocking in their height, grandness and proximity to the city center.

title: Corrections
description: A contents entry in this section last Sunday, referring to the Habitats column, about a group of friends who bought a building in the East Village, misstated the price. It was $2.3 million, not $2.1 million.

title: 3 Iraqi Police Officers Killed in Attack by Gunmen in Mosul
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 12 - Gunmen shot and killed three Iraqi police officers on Saturday in the northern city of Mosul as they drove to a colleague's funeral, witnesses said.

title: Matthew Bourne Does the Horizontal Ballet
description: HOWEVER many times you may have admired nearly naked dancers at the ballet, they are -- emotionally speaking -- rarely very naked at all. But in "Play Without Words," Matthew Bourne's latest piece of dance theater, being undressed is just the beginning. In the course of the action, a manservant literally undoes his young master, whose fiance gets feather-dusted by the maid and proceeds to have an affair with a household hanger-on. Gropings, tumblings and couplings are seamlessly woven into the fabric of moving bodies and limbs. Indeed, the show is half horizontal; it's as if all the things usually nailed frustratingly beneath the floorboards of ballet had exploded to the surface.

title: Great Performers
description: Psssst! Your photographic portfolio was absent an acknowledgment of James Caviezel's stunning performance in "The Passion of the Christ." The fog surrounding Clint Eastwood's photo must have temporarily enveloped those selecting the honorees as well.

title: Bishops of Opposite Colors? Bacrot Can Handle It, Thanks
description: It was once rare to name a tournament after a living player. The Havana International Tournament of 1913, though, was held to celebrate Jos Raul Capablanca's great career, even though he played in the event. It was perhaps the only time he lost to Frank Marshall, who proceeded to win the competition.

title: P.S. 8's Comeback Spurs Higher Hopes
description: Three years ago, word spread that Public School 8 in Brooklyn might shut down. Located in a century-old building on Hicks Street, the school serves Dumbo, Vinegar Hill, Fulton Ferry and parts of Brooklyn Heights and Fort Greene. Years of declining enrollment -- largely because neighborhood children were being sent to private schools -- had cast a shadow of doubt over its future.

description: To the Editor:

title: Women Are Writing a Lot More of Those Paychecks
description: A common injustice in the workplace is that women are often paid less than men for comparable work. The unspoken assumption seems to be that it's men -- those omnipotent corporate bullies -- who are doling out the paychecks and that women are humbly beseeching them, on bended knee, for their fair share.

title: The Zone; Genius in a Bottle
description: Christopher Brosius, the proprietor of the CB I Hate Perfume Gallery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, doesn't do copies. So don't bother bringing in your grandfather's discontinued cologne. However, if you find yourself pining for a whiff of your salad days, he does have lettuce, tomato and cucumber notes on hand. The company stocks more than 1,000 essences, and for a price (starting at $125), Brosius will custom-blend your own memory-triggering madeleine. One aging client, who wanted to be reminded of Little League baseball, received a cologne containing essences of dandelion, dirt, grass and leather -- for that special top note of baseball mitt. Proust would be proud. 93 Wythe Avenue; (718) 384-6890. STEFFIE NELSON

description: PASTERNAK--Sandi. "A woman of valor who can find? For her price is far above rubies...Strength and dignity are her clothing...Give her the fruits of her hands: and let her works praise her in the gates." Pat and Marty Pincus PASTERNAK--Sandra (nee Friedman), 51, on March 10 Beloved wife of Gavril, devoted mother of Katie, David and Anna Rose. Sister of Ricki Goldstein. Daughter of Flora and the late Eugene Friedman. Daughter-in-law of Laura and Richard Pasternak. Beloved sister-in-law, aunt and friend. A dedicated educator and Assistant Director of the Gateway School. Service on Sunday, 10AM, March 13 at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. PASTERNAK--Sandra. The Department of Neurology at Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center mourns the untimely passing of Sandra Pasternak, beloved wife of Dr. Gavril Pasternak, our colleague and friend. Sandra died at Memorial Sloan-Kettering on March 10, 2005, seventeen months following her diagnosis of pancreatic cancer. We extend our deepest sympathies to Gavril, her children Katie Rachael, David Avram, Anna Rose, and her extended family. PASTERNAK--Sandra. Our dearest friend Sandi, who inspired us with her strength, courage, kindness, generosity and love. She will be in our hearts always. Trinity Moms Diane, Nancy, Sue, Phyllis, Claudie

title: Editors' Choice
The Remix; LADY KILLERS
description: If you look at today's professional female wrestlers, with their plus-size pecs and spandex silhouettes, the word "lady" isn't the first thing that comes to mind. But according to the "golden gals of wrestling," like Ella Waldek, pictured here, the early stars of the sport were ladies first, wrestlers second. In "Lipstick and Dynamite," a forthcoming documentary, it is also clear that they were killing their opponents with more than kindness. And loving it. "Drop-kicking was my forte," says Ida May Martinez, now an avid yodeler. The Fabulous Moolah, a world champion who was famously defeated by Wendi Richter and then managed by Cyndi Lauper, in a match broadcast by MTV in 1984 (she reclaimed the title a year later), recalls, "I was mean." She still is. Now in the ring at the age of 80, Moolah proves that in the end, girls really do just wanna have fun. STEFFIE NELSON

title: Great Performers
description: No one is more deserving of success than Clint Eastwood. It was a delight to see him on the cover of your magazine (Feb. 27). In the 1980's, my husband and I were skiing in Sun Valley. On our last day, we were resting in the mountain cafeteria, which was empty except for us and our two friends -- and Clint Eastwood. My friend so wanted her picture taken with Eastwood, but she felt it was an imposition to ask. I braced myself to ask him, and he obliged. His manner was one of easy confidence and graciousness. He made my day.

title: Inside the list
description: CRYSTAL LITE: Every so often a best seller comes along that, as Michael Korda put it in his book "Making the List," makes us "question our sanity, or at least that of the American reading public." One of those head-scratchers has got to be Masaru Emoto's spectacularly eccentric book "The Hidden Messages in Water," which argues that water has feelings, too -- and that the crystals that form in frozen water change shape when an onlooker shows the water words, or beams thoughts in its direction. Emoto's book is filled with photographs of the shiny, happy crystals that form when water is shown phrases like "You're cute" or "Thank you," and also of the deformed, sorry-looking crystals that result when you show it "You fool!" or "Satan." Emoto's book has sold some 400,000 copies internationally, and it has lingered on the upper reaches of the Times extended paperback advice list for months, rising this week to No. 13. Emoto, who has studied alternative medicine in Japan, also notes that water is picky about the music it likes. Mozart and the Beatles' song "Yesterday" made it perk up, while heavy metal music freaked it out, making its crystals look malignant. All of this has broad implications for personal happiness and world peace, Emoto suggests, when you consider that our bodies are 70 percent water. "When you have become the embodiment of gratitude," Emoto writes, "think about how pure the water that fills your body will be. When this happens, you yourself will be a beautiful, shining crystal of light."

title: Has Anybody Here Seen My Old Friend Martin?
description: Some would argue that Martin Margiela is the coolest man in fashion. He's certainly the most elusive. Since the Belgian wunderkind set up shop in Paris in 1988, no one has seen a picture of him, and no face-to-face interviews have been granted. Margiela sees his role as a philosopher, rethinking the basic premise of clothing -- how it is sized and sold, how it interacts with the body -- with his team of white-coated assistants. Over the years, this has resulted in frayed ball gowns, reversed seams, cloven-toed boots and, when he was designing for Hermes, the most perfectly cut pants and jackets on the planet. Now, with his high-flying partner, Renzo Rosso of Diesel, and a new, industrial-strength business plan, Margiela is hotter than ever. How to scale the ramparts and dispel the mystery? We figured that if anybody could do it, it would be that fashion and music provocateur, Malcolm McLaren. Herewith, the beginning of a correspondence. Dec. 15, 2004 Dear Martin, We know each other, I believe, but have never met. I certainly don't know what you look like and have even contemplated the thought that you may be a ghost! Do you exist? Sometimes I think not. But with that in mind, I am writing to you to find out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLANK, MYRON N. (MIKE)
description: BLANK--Myron N. (Mike) of Des Moines, Iowa. Mike's family, friends and community celebrate the life and mourn the passing of this fine gentleman who made such a difference in so many lives. As president of Central States Theatre Corp. Mike operated an influential theater circuit in Iowa and Nebraska for 72 years. During the 1950's he was the largest operator of drive-in theaters in the country at which time he traveled the world as the president and representative of the National Association of Theatre Owners (NATO). After the circuit was sold in 2002, Mike continued to work daily until two weeks prior to his death at the age of 93. During World War II Mike was a commissioned officer in the Navy where he headed the production unit for foreign language training films. His greatest contribution to the people of Iowa was his lifetime of philanthropy. In central Iowa he founded Blank Children's Hospital, the Blank Park Zoo, the IMAX at the new Science Center of Iowa, the Jacqueline N. Blank Bookworks of Planned Parenthood of Greater Iowa, the children's wing at the new Des Moines library, the Steven N. Blank Youth Center of Youth Emergency and Shelter Services, the A.H. Blank Public Golf Course, the Blank Performing Arts Center at Simpson College and the Belin-Blank International Center for Gifted Education and Talent Development at the University of Iowa. Mike was preceded in death by his wife of 66 years, Jacqueline N. Blank. He is survived by his daughter, Beverly Perry of New York City, eight grandchildren and 13 great grandchildren. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Blank Children's Hospital, the Blank Park Zoo, or the Belin-Blank Center. Checks may be sent to the "Blank Family Office, 414 Insurance Exchange Building, Des Moines, Iowa 50309."

title: THE RHODE ISLAND GIANTS?
description: The New York Giants said that their deal to build a privately financed $700 million Meadowlands stadium collapsed last Wednesday when New Jersey officials added two last-minute conditions that the team insisted were unacceptable. "I thought we'd be here to announce a deal, but it blew apart today," Joe Shenker, an outside lawyer for the team, said during a meeting with reporters. The team thought until early in the day that a final issue raised by Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey -- a $3 million payment to the state if the Jets did not build a stadium on the Far West Side of Manhattan and were cotenants in a new Giants facility -- had been settled and that it would announce a final agreement with the state. But the talks fell apart over the state's refusal to guarantee that there would be no special taxes imposed in the future on stadium revenues and its insistence on a separate agreement clearing the way for Meadowlands Xanadu, an entertainment and retail park that is to be built near the stadium. Richard Sandomir
