title: LOOK BOTH WAYS
description: If history is a guide, 153 pedestrians will be killed by cars in New Jersey this year, give or take about nine. That may seem an impossibly precise prediction, but judging by a report released last Tuesday by the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, it is a good guess. According to statistics the group compiled, between 144 and 162 pedestrians have died in traffic accidents in the state in 7 of the past 10 years. Last year's total was 153, one shy of the 10-year average. The leaders of the group, which advocates for the rights and safety of cyclists and pedestrians, can't explain the constancy of the carnage in the crosswalks. But they say the number is too high and the state government is not doing enough to bring it down. "It has stayed steady over the past 10 years despite the fact that walking has actually declined in New Jersey," said Michelle Ernst, author of the report. By one measure, New Jersey is one of the most dangerous states for pedestrians. It was one of only three states in which more than one of every five people killed in traffic accidents was on foot, Ms. Ernst said. The solution, she said, is more and better sidewalks and speed humps to slow traffic. "The faster the car is going, the more likely a pedestrian who is struck is to die," Ms. Ernst added. Patrick McGeehan

title: 'Metropolis'
The Lost Soldiers Of Stalag IX-B
description: William J. Shapiro describes how "the buddy system, all that broke down." That certainly happened at Berga, where each man was just trying to survive another day. But there were examples of heroism and caring for others. My father, Alexander Weisberg, survived to live another 59 years because a fellow prisoner, Julius Morrison, carried him down the hill in the morning to the work site and back up the hill at night. He would have been shot by the Nazis if he couldn't report to work. Berga showed human nature at its base evil (the Nazis) and its ultimate good (Julius Morrison).

title: WorldCom Teaches a Pricey Lesson
description: ENGINEERING the earth's largest accounting fraud and filing the planet's biggest bankruptcy evidently wasn't enough for WorldCom. Last week, the company earned its third Dubious Achievement Award. With 13 of its former banks coughing up $4 billion to settle with investors who lost money when the company failed, WorldCom is now responsible for the largest payout in history for a securities class-action suit.

title: Corrections

Moore, who said he left eBay last June and moved his online store to a smaller rival because it offered a better deal. EBay says it earlier suspended Mr. Moore from selling on its site. He was suspended after rival sellers accused him of bidding on their products to drive up prices and of failing to pay in auctions he won -- accusations that he denies. He says he was already intending to switch sites.

title: VOLUNTEER TOURISM
description: To the Editor: "More Vacationers Answer the Call to Help" (Feb. 20) deeply troubled me. To take largely untrained vacationers and place them at schools, farms and building sites for two weeks serves no greater purpose than to stroke the volunteers' egos.

title: The Remix; Natty Threads
description: Years before Run D.M.C. rapped about their Adidas, Rastasfarians were sporting those kicks on the streets of Kingston, Jamaica. In fact, the roots of many of the early hip-hop looks -- striped tracksuits, Sta-Prest jeans, leather porkpie hats -- can be seen in the cult reggae film "Rockers," which celebrates the 25th anniversary of its American release with a special DVD edition in spring. The actors in the film have their own take on cool: one flaunts gold shades and a Dynomite logo T; another layers a sweater vest and tie over a warm-up jacket. The star, Leroy Wallace, known as Horsemouth (a session drummer at the time, at the legendary Studio One), rocks a red-and-black bowler hat and tight, colorful T-shirts that the folks at Resurrection would kill for.

title: Career in a Box
description: Philippe Caland's Hollywood journey has been short and steadily downhill. He produced Jennifer Lynch's much-reviled 1993 film "Boxing Helena." He cemented his credentials in what his publicists call the "'girl-in-a-box' genre" with "Dead Girl," which stars Val Kilmer as an adviser to a man in love with a corpse; made in 1996, it will finally be released on Wednesday -- as a one-day download at www.netmusic.com. Both those films' directors have since dropped out of sight, and Mr. Caland himself nearly skulked off to wherever Hollywood hides its washouts.

title: Big Guns
description: In football-ese, a two-way player isn't a sexual designation. A.F.L. -- not to be confused with the risible X.F.L. -- games feature eight-on-eight teams, with most players doubling up on offense and defense. This means that Greg Hopkins, the wide receiver and linebacker for the Los Angeles Avengers, averages 50 minutes of field time a game. (N.F.L. slugs, in comparison, average half that.) To make this physically possible, Hopkins, who at 33 is 6 foot 2 inches and 205 pounds, lifts, runs and does speed footwork and agility drills. He credits a childhood spent wrestling for his current balance and flexibility. But his "man strength," which he defines as the ability to open pickle jars for little kids, can't be achieved at the gym. That comes only from manual labor; off-seasons he works at his family cattle farm in southwest Pennsylvania. "Baling hay," Hopkins says, "that's a good workout." We smell a Crunch class. ALEXANDRA ZISSU

title: How and Where to Be Heard
description: You point out two fundamental limitations of news delivered on newsprint. Lack of editorial resources and column space limit a newspaper's ability to analyze, publish and respond to reader comments and corrections. As a remedy, The Times should allow readers to post unedited comments on each online story. The online edition should then publish updates and corrections, posit alternative analyses and respond to criticisms. The Times should be more like a blog -- engaged in an online dialogue with its readers -- that also has vast newsgathering resources.

title: Distress Test: Earning an A
description: Leather, a material associated with luxury, is getting down and dirty. A processing technique that involves washing the hide is taking away its pristine appearance, leaving it creased and slightly misshapen. For men, Rick Owens's burnt orange shrunken leather motorcycle jacket ($1,990 at Barneys) and Jil Sander's pea green leather jacket ($2,650 at Jeffrey) bear all the wrinkles of a garment after a spin cycle. Even men's shoes look kicked about, like Sciapo's faded black washed leather lace-ups (right, $250 at Barneys). For women, the washed leather handbags by Prada (below), which come in sage green and light blue in two sizes ($1,495 and $1,530), and Sissi Rossi's green, oval handbag with outside cargo pockets ($765 at Barneys Co-op) alleviate any worries about getting that first scratch. Women's washed leather jackets, like Duarte's teal motorcycle version (above, $665 at Bloomingdale's), are as casual and comfortable as washed jeans -- which is where the taste for distressed clothing started, said Kal Ruttenstein, the fashion director at Bloomingdale's. These days, he said, "well-worn has a certain cachet." ELIZABETH HAYT

title: 2005 Toyota Tundra: A Taste of Toyota's Big Ambitions
description: TESTED: Toyota Tundra Double Cab SR5 WHAT IS IT? Toyota's first full-size pickup with four real doors. HOW MUCH? 2005 prices: SR5 V-8 4x2, $26,785; SR5 V-8 4x4, $30,115; Limited V-8 4x2, $30,410; Limited V-8 4x4, $33,740. Tested SR5 V-8 was $31,070 with keyless entry, running boards, foglights, styled steel wheels, towing package and a few other options. REBATES? Combined $1,650 until March 31. WHAT MOVES IT? 4.7-liter V-8 (282 horsepower); five-speed automatic transmission; rear- or four-wheel drive. WILL IT HAUL MY HOUSE? Maximum payload is 1,835 pounds and towing capacity is 6,800 pounds. The Double Cab seats five or six. HOW THIRSTY? E.P.A. ratings are 16 m.p.g. in town, 18 on the highway (4x2) and 15/18 m.p.g. (4x4). My average was 15 m.p.g. SAFETY? Standard dual-stage front air bags and antilock brakes. Optional stability/traction control, side air bags and side curtains. ALTERNATIVES: Chevrolet Silverado 1500 Crew Cab; Dodge Ram 1500 Crew Cab; Ford F-150 SuperCrew; GMC Sierra 1500 Crew Cab; Nissan Titan Crew Cab.

title: New Signs on the Arab Street
description: From Baghdad to Beirut, the Middle East has seen a series of unprecedented popular demonstrations for democracy. There were, however, two street protests in December that got virtually no coverage, but were just as important, if not more. One took place in the Egyptian Nile Delta town of Mahalla and the other in the Suez Canal city of Ismailiya. Both of these raucous Egyptian demonstrations, which involved marches, strikes, denunciations of the government and appeals to Parliament, were triggered by President Hosni Mubarak's decision to sign the first substantial trade agreement with Israel since Camp David. That decision brought Egyptian workers from both areas into the streets. They were furious. They were enraged. Why?

title: The Collectors
description: ABOUT 2 o'clock on a Saturday morning this month, I was driving along East 20th Street with Larry Pugh, a well-mannered supervisor in the Sanitation Department, when the honking started. In front of us, two sanitation workers were scrambling to dismantle a tower of trash on the sidewalk -- standard black bags, long "sausage" bags, a soiled king-size mattress and assorted detritus. Behind us, traffic had backed up all the way down the block and into the intersection, and it seemed as if every horn in a 10-block radius had been punched.

title: What Did They Take and When Did They Take It?
description: LIKE most Americans, I was initially surprised when Congress announced it would hold hearings on the use of steroids in baseball. If there's one thing I know about members of Congress, it's that they prefer toiling in anonymity to grandstanding before the cameras. But the more I thought about it, the more the hearings began to make sense. Disappointed with the anemic lineup of the Washington Nationals, Congress has found a way to attract baseball superstars to Washington: subpoena them. Here is a preview of what we can expect at this week's hearings before the House Committee on Government Reform.

title: What Dean Means
description: Matt Bai's essay should give all "fire in the belly" Democrats reason to take heart (The Way We Live Now, Feb. 27). title: The Calvinist Manifesto
description: THIS year is the 100th anniversary of the most famous sociological tract ever written, "The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism," by Max Weber. It was a book that stood Karl Marx on his head. Religion, according to Weber, was not an ideology produced by economic interests (the "opiate of the masses," as Marx had put it); rather, it was what had made the modern capitalist world possible. In the present decade, when cultures seem to be clashing and religion is frequently blamed for the failures of modernization and democracy in the Muslim world, Weber's book and ideas deserve a fresh look.

title: Mr. Yamamoto's Blue Period
description: Veiled and distant and dour, Yohji Yamamoto is the cockeyed pessimist of fashion. Hunched over his dinner plate one winter evening in Florence, he is an enigmatic outsider surveying a roomful of strangers who, as it happens, have come to celebrate this man whom hardly anyone knows much about.

title: The New Bridge and Tunnel Crowd
description: THIS is a killer weekend for new art in New York City. Three contemporary fairs -- the Armory Show, Scope New York and the DiVa Digital and Video Art Fair -- are in town for a few cash-crazed days. A show of sculptures called Art Rock is parked in Rockefeller Plaza. And "Greater New York 2005," a survey of some 150 young artists living in and around the city, opens at P.S. 1 in Long Island City on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YANOWITCH, MURRAY (MIKE)
description: YANOWITCH -- Murray (Mike). The M.E. Sharpe publishing family mourns the loss of our longtime colleague and dear friend Mike Yanowitch, economist, editor, and author, who died on March 2, 2005, in New York. Born in Harbin, Manchuria, in 1923, he emigrated to the United States with his family in the early 1930s. After service as a radio gunner in World War II, he earned a doctorate at Columbia University, where he studied under Abram Bergson, and served as professor of economics at Hofstra University until his retirement. Mike's long association with M.E. Sharpe began in 1960, as an editor of translation journals and later as editor of Challenge: The Magazine of Economic Affairs. His most recent book (with Bertram Silverman) was New Rich, New Poor, New Russia: Winners and Losers on the Russian Road to Capitalism. All who had the opportunity to work with Mike, both here and in Russia, will remember him as a wise and generous man, devoted to the true and just, but never unkind or without humor. We extend our condolences to his wife Rose, his son Phillip, and daughters Nina and Lee.

Paid Notice: Deaths   KIMCHE, IDA
description: KIMCHE--Ida. Born 1913 StGallen, Switzerland, de ceased March 11, 2005 Tel Aviv, Israel. Participated in The Zionist Congress in Basel, Switzerland. Immigrated to Israel in 1952. Shortly thereafter in 1965 she opened a prestigious art gallery in the Tel Aviv Hilton. Her long and prosperous professional career dealing in 20th century masters, spanned 40 years and became a landmark in the Tel Aviv Hilton during that period. She is survived by her two daughters, Varda Gill of Tel Aviv and Raja Fuchs of Manhattan; also her five grandchildren, Roy, Era, Dana, John, and Nina and six great-grandchildren. It was our great fortune to know her. Her unique spirit will live on forever. May she rest in peace. We love her. Susan and Jeffrey Allen Alex, Bara and Lacey Tisch

title: The Interregnum
description: The day they buried Yasir Arafat in the Ramallah fort that had become his prison, the most remarkable sight was not the thousands who brushed aside Palestinian security to swarm over the walls and bid him an impassioned farewell, some with semiautomatic gunfire. It was not Uri Avnery, the dogged Israeli dove, comparing Arafat to Moses for leading his people from bondage to die within sight of his promised land; it was not the delegation of Moonies from Rockville, Md., who sat primly amid the mob. One grows accustomed to such things. This was Palestine after all, and Palestine is really a state of mind, or a state of being, but not, in any event, a state. Its rules are its own rules, those of a place that is not wholly real, that is dreamlike and a little scary -- an Oz at once remembered and mythic with a small number, yet more than its share, of flying monkeys.

title: Keeping the Motion in Poetry
description: WHOEVER said there's no money in poetry perhaps never rode the No. 4 train.

Maybe Not the Last Time I.O.C. Sees Paris
description: PARIS, March 12 - The International Olympic Committee's evaluation commission sat in a room under a huge dome; the walls were covered with paintings, windows framed with statues, and the light from a giant crystal chandelier overhead glimmered off the gold-colored walls.

title: A View to a Killing Field
description: "Sometimes in April," HBO's film about the Rwandan genocide, is the first large-scale movie ever shot in that country. ("Hotel Rwanda" was shot in South Africa -- at a nicer hotel than the decrepit Mille Collines.) And it's certainly the first one to have its premiere there. The director Raoul Peck pledged to show the film first in Kigali, Rwanda's capital, which is why on Jan. 22 an enormous screen was erected at the Amhoro Stadium, one of the few places of successful refuge for thousands of Tutsis during the genocide. The film was screened for President Paul Kagame, government ministers and much of the city's elite. On the following night HBO opened it to the public and provided live, simultaneous translation of the English soundtrack into Kinyarwanda, the national language. (The movie will be shown in the United States on March 19. )

title: Desperate Times, a Helping Hand
description: JERSEY CITY - KRUNAL THAKORE, a 19-year-old freshman at St. Peter's College, had heard a great deal about the beauty of southern India from his family. But he had never visited that part of the subcontinent until several weeks ago.

title: Disputed 9/11 Monument, at Sea for a Bit, Gets a Home Nearby
description: Bayonne, N.J. - THERE he was, Zurab Tsereteli himself, wearing an immaculate black leather coat with a black fur collar, carrying an ornate gold fountain pen as imposing as a small scepter, and striding into the frigid wind on the desolate edge of the peninsula jutting into Bayonne Harbor, the new home of his latest monument.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUNSHINE, MARGARET
description: SUNSHINE--Margaret, 89, on January 26, 2005. Well known make up designer for Broadway, movies, TV. Personal make up designer for Lauren Bacall, Ann Reinking, Joanne Woodward, Meryl Streep, Swoozie Kurtz, Barbara Harris, Bette Davis, etc. Everyone she touched became more beautiful. She will always be loved & missed. Survived by son, Paul; daughter, Carol, and grandchildren, Angela, Peter, Susan & Michael.

title: Can a Virus Hitch a Ride in Your Car?
description: A VIRUS can wreak havoc on computer files, hard drives and networks, but its malicious effects tend to be measured in wasted time, lost sales and the occasional unfinished novel that evaporates into the digital ozone. But what if viruses, worms or other forms of malware penetrated the computers that control ever more crucial functions in the car?

title: Oscar vs. Oscar
description: In the blue corner, Oscar de la Renta, the fashion-world heavyweight and philanthropist from the Dominican Republic, who, at 73, still packs a punch. Is it true that he once decked a journalist who had written something nasty about him? "I mean, I didn't knock him out," De la Renta says, "and I have never, ever been upset by anyone writing a bad critique about my collections. But he said something rude about my wife. And that upset me very, very much, so there was an altercation, let's say. When I get angry, I can walk through a wall, but I very seldom get angry."

title: A Midtown Crib for P. Diddy
description: SEAN COMBS, the rap music and fashion impresario, bought a three-bedroom apartment last month for $3.82 million in the Park Imperial, a condominium tower at 230 West 56th Street, according to a deed filed with the city and two people close to the deal.

description: There are days when it seems that trucks were put on this earth to frustrate the citizens of New York. They clog the streets, making north-south traffic difficult, east-west roads impassable, and traversing the boroughs a headache.

Preservationists at the 1920's Sunnyside Gardens in Queens want landmark designation for their inventive and charming model housing. But the builders of Sunnyside produced a memorable experience rather than memorable buildings.

description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif., March 12 - Two players who have been having recurring nightmares over Davis Cup defeats ended up facing each other on the stadium court in the second round of the Pacific Life Open on Saturday. This time, Andy Roddick was a winner.

We have visited Dominica many times and can confirm that it is an island of unsurpassed natural beauty with warm and friendly people.

title: Power Line
description: Margins aren't the only thing narrowing on Wall Street these days: Ralph Lauren has made the slim-cut European suit safe for the boardroom. For those young Polo players not quite ready to step up to the fashion plate in Dior Homme or Costume National's razor-thin pants and shrunken jackets (which are more band member than junior broker), there is now Lauren's new Black Label collection. The line achieves a more modern -- even sexy -- silhouette in classic fabrics like cotton twill and charcoal black pinstripe wool. "The fabrics and tailoring are of the highest quality, like Purple Label," Lauren explains, "but with slimmer, sleeker cuts, giving it a cooler, edgier attitude." The edginess continues with trim, stiff-collared shirts with subtle pinstripes paired with skinny ties -- a fresh look that goes from meeting to meatpacking district without a stop at the loft. CHRISTINE MUHLKE

description: Cars with dealer plates have been speeding by John R. Zeeve's house on Glenville Road in Greenwich, and recently, Mr. Zeeve decided he had had enough.

title: Good in the Paint
description: Alonzo Adams's evocative genre paintings of urban black life have long had a following among African-American cultural figures like Maya Angelou, Eddie Murphy and Bill Cosby (who helped start Mr. Adams's career by offering him a fellowship at the University of Pennsylvania and putting his work on the walls of the Huxtable home in "The Cosby Show"). Recently he has become popular with another group: the budding collectors of the professional sports world, especially the National Basketball Association. A list of clients on his Web site (www.theadamsgallery.com) includes current and former stars like Ray Allen, Kenny Anderson, Tim Hardaway, Juwan Howard and Alonzo Mourning. Mr. Adams sells his work (like "Let the Rhythm Hit 'Em," below) both online and through Sienna Visions, his Plainfield, N.J., gallery; Greg Allen spoke with him about being the No. 1 pick in the painters' draft.

Michael Smith, wants to tackle the tribe's problems with drug and alcohol abuse because they result in higher-than-average unemployment, below-average life expectancy, and unbearable medical bills. But there is another reason: he has been there himself.

He is the managing director of the Renault Formula One racing team, not a race car driver.

title: Rates Soaring at Big-City Hotels
description: Travelers headed to cities frequented by business travelers are going to find it more expensive to get a room this spring. According to research conducted by analysts at J.P. Morgan Chase, hotel rates will be at least 24 percent higher this April compared to a year earlier in New York, Atlanta and Los Angeles, and 16 to 19 percent higher in Chicago, Dallas and San Francisco.

description: CONFERENCE USA The freshman Darius Washington, left, with an N.C.A.A. tournament berth in his hands, made only the first of three free throws with no time left to hand No. 6 LOUISVILLE a 75-74 victory over MEMPHIS in the Conference USA title game. The outcome sent the Cardinals (29-4) into the N.C.A.A. tournament as a possible top-seeded team and left Memphis (19-15) most likely on the outside when the N.C.A.A. field is announced today.

Services are March 27, 1-3, in Westfield, NJ, at home of Gail Winbury. Donations to the American Heart Association.

title: Sorry, I'm Keeping the Bonus Anyway
description: WILLIAM A. WISE hit the jackpot when his company hit its number. After the El Paso Corporation, the energy company in Houston, reported a profit of $93 million in 2001, Mr. Wise, its chief executive, was rewarded with a $3.4 million bonus, 768,250 stock options, $1.7 million of restricted stock and $3.7 million in "other compensation." And that was on top of his regular salary of $1.3 million.

description: FLYNN--Robert Hugh. Mutual of America and its Board of Directors, together with all of its officers and employees, mourn with great sadness the loss of Robert Hugh Flynn-beloved son of our friend and Chairman William J. Flynn and his wife Peg, and brother of our colleague Jim. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Karen; their children Carris, Michael and Billy; his siblings Maureen and Bill; and to his entire family. Moran President and Chief Executive Officer Mutual of America Life Insurance Company FLYNN -- Robert Hugh. title: Cape Fear
description: On the other side of Superman's Metropolis is an altogether different kind of comic-book town. In Frank Miller's "Sin City," soon to be released as a feature film starring Bruce Willis and Benicio Del Toro, the heroes are assassins and thugs who shoot first, dismember second and rarely find the moment to ask questions.

title: Destroying Television, Toon by Toon
description: AT 11 o'clock each night, after the Powerpuff Girls have been put to bed and Scooby-Doo has curled up in a corner, the Cartoon Network becomes a strange place. From this hour until the early morning, a red-eyed viewer will not see combative cats and mice or rascally rabbits, but rather an anthropomorphic milk shake that argues with space aliens, a high-tech underwater lab where no one can find the fuse box, and a small-town mayor who protects his city's streets by littering them with bear traps.

title: Has Anybody Here Seen My Old Friend Martin?
description: Some would argue that Martin Margiela is the coolest man in fashion. He's certainly the most elusive. Since the Belgian wunderkind set up shop in Paris in 1988, no one has seen a picture of him, and no face-to-face interviews have been granted. Margiela sees his role as a philosopher, rethinking the basic premise of clothing -- how it is sized and sold, how it interacts with the body -- with his team of white-coated assistants. Over the years, this has resulted in frayed ball gowns, reversed seams, cloven-toed boots and, when he was designing for Herms, the most perfectly cut pants and jackets on the planet. Now, with his high-flying partner, Renzo Rosso of Diesel, and a new, industrial-strength business plan, Margiela is hotter than ever. How to scale the ramparts and dispel the mystery? We figured that if anybody could do it, it would be that fashion and music provocateur, Malcolm McLaren. Herewith, the beginning of a correspondence.

title: Lottery Numbers
Up Front
description: This week, we feature a wild tour of the publishing scene in China, "The World's Biggest Book Market." Our guide is Mike Meyer, a Minnesota native who has lived in China ever since the Peace Corps sent him there to teach English in a rural village in Sichuan Province 10 years ago. Meyer, who studied with Adam Hochschild and Maxine Hong Kingston at Berkeley, where he got a master's degree in education, now lives in Beijing and is writing a book about the destruction of the ancient neighborhood where he lives.

title: Judge Blocks the Transfer of 13 Detainees From Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 - A federal judge on Saturday prohibited the government from transferring 13 Yemeni prisoners from the military's detention facility at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, until a hearing could be held on their lawyers' fear that they might face torture if sent to another country.

title: Baffling Knicks Facing Big Games
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., March 12 - Efforts to make sense of the Knicks' late-season turnaround seem as futile as attempts to explain the secret of Donald Trump's gravity-defying hair.

title: Even Saviors Need a Living
description: DESPITE the budget cutting, the begging for volunteers and the fund-raising efforts at local fairs, Joe Bilotto, captain of the Harrison Volunteer Ambulance Corps, says it's all worth it. He felt the same way one day not long ago at headquarters, when he looked up from his chores and there standing in the doorway was a man recovered from an accident, smiling at him.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THESE days he's the host of a new reality television series about boxing ("The Contender"), but there was a time, of course, when Sylvester Stallone was doing the punching, and never with more metaphorical baggage on his back than in ROCKY IV (1985). After his friend Apollo Creed is killed in the ring by Drago, a Soviet fighter played by Dolph Lundgren, Rocky is compelled to challenge the gigantic fellow. In 1985, it was a match reflective of the cold war, but today the movie has a new timeliness: it feels like a commentary on baseball's steroid debate. Drago follows a high-tech training regimen that, as one of his handlers says, "makes a man a better man, a great athlete a super-athlete," and though he denies using steroids, later he is seen getting an injection of something -- Saturday at 10 p.m. on AMC.

title: The Remix; Rock the Note
description: Wise men send handwritten notes instead of e-mail. Even wiser ones write on bespoke stationery from the Printery in Oyster Bay, N.Y. "It's the best there is," says Larry Gordon, a senior vice president at Ralph Lauren. "I build my stationery wardrobe like I build my apparel wardrobe." Adds Gordon, who has more custom notecards and monograms than most men have ties, "You need casual attire and formal attire." Gordon likens the Printery, which has been around for 123 years, to something out of a Dickens novel. "It's located in this rickety old 19th-century building, complete with cobwebs and cracked windows," he says. Besides atmosphere, the business boasts an archive of vintage monograms, reams of unusual paper colors and clients like Calvin Klein, the event planner Robert Isabell and the decorator David Easton. By appointment; (516) 922-3250. SANDRA BALLENTINE

title: The Remix; Macy's Is A Punk Rocker
description: Hey, ho, let's go . . . shopping. Though three of the founding members of the Ramones have gone to the great needle exchange in the sky, their slim, grungy drag lives on. While a denim-and-accessories line produced by CBGB, with skinny-cut models named after Joey and Dee Dee, is now available at Macy's and Trash and Vaudeville, Vision Street Wear has produced sneakers with the Ramones' eagle and surfing-bird logos. And should pegged-jeans couture from Dior Homme strike you as more Beverly Hills than the Bowery, the band's original Schott jacket is still available to team with your vintage T-shirts and low-tech sneakers. Boasts the band's creative director, Arturo Vega, "The Ramones never lost their credibility as the ultimate outsiders." No, not even after the AT&T Wireless commercials (that was "Blitzkrieg Bop" selling low-cost plans). Make sure to keep a bloodshot eye peeled for the DVD release of the documentary "End of the Century: The Story of the Ramones," a string of box sets and a coming musical called "Gabba Gabba Hey!" And if that's not enough, there's even a Joey Ramone action figure -- sniffable glue not included. ALEXANDRA MARSHALL

description: AGING Brooklynites tend to don rose-colored glasses when recalling the quality of equipment used in stickball. They romanticize the game's pink rubber balls, known as Spaldeens, as paragons of durability and bounciness. So, on the rare occasions when a modern Spaldeen develops a crack, the complaint line lights up at Spalding, the balls' manufacturer.

For me, a veteran of Catholic schooling in the Bronx from kindergarten through the last stages of graduate study, the closings are a reminder of what I owe to these schools and how much they have shaped my life.

title: Hamas Will Take Part in Vote for a Palestinian Legislature

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABRAMSON, SHIRLEY (NEE TANSMAN). ''SUNNY''
description: ABRAMSON -- Shirley (nee Tansman). "Sunny" was the beloved mother of Leslie and Steven, loving grandmother of Lila and Geoffrey, motherin-law to Karen and devoted companion to Leon Lobel, died peacefully March 12, at the age of 84. Sunny will be remembered for her effervescent, sunny personality and its extraordinary effect on all those who knew her. Her kindness, generosity of spirit, passion for living and devotion for friends and family will be sorely missed, but cherished always by those who loved and cared for her. Contributions can be made in her memory to UJA--the organization that Sunny loved working for and was so good to her in return.

Many apartment-dwelling oenophiles store their posh plonk in free-standing fridges from companies like EuroCave and Chambrair, but once a collector's cache of Latour and La Tche reaches 1,000 bottles, it's time to rack it up. Enter Lee Zinser, of the New York-based firm Cellarworks, who has perfected the art of the miniature cave. "Believe it or not, you can fit 4,000 bottles and a tasting area into an 11-by-8-foot space," he says (about the size of a walk-in closet). But keeping things cool has its cost. She was surrounded by her loved ones, but most especially by her devoted fiance, Joe Diamante. Laurie accepted her fate with tremendous courage and a contagious sense of humor. Laurie drew strength and comfort from her close spiritual relationship with Rev. Ammon, Stephen Minister Sarlin and Elder McKenzie at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. Laurie is survived by her parents Ronald and Donna Holbrook of Freeport, ME and her dedicated fiance Joe Diamante of New York City, her sister Kathleen, and her brothers Marty, Peter and John, and grandparents, nieces and nephews, and her cats Vivi and Madison. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, Room H909, NY NY 10021, C/O Dr. Robert Maki. title: Odd Birds of a Feather
description: THE other day, with the last of Christo's "Gates" flapping stubbornly along a few east-side footpaths, I turned my back on Central Park and went to visit "Audubon's Aviary" at the New-York Historical Society. I imagined that the display of 40 bird watercolors by John James Audubon, the great 19th-century painter-naturalist, would be a sort of anti-Christo experience, but it turns out that the two installations are weirdly connected. This is not really because Christo and Audubon have much in common -- though both grew up in Europe, fell in love with the American landscape, embraced the relationship between art and commerce and ultimately settled in New York. It is because their works, taken together, are oddly complementary reminders of how intertwined the man-made and the natural are.

During the fall auctions at Christie's, "Memphis, c. 1970," by William Eggleston, sold for $253,900, and "Calla Lily, 1986," by Robert Mapplethorpe, for $242,700. For "brand name" photographers of later-20th century vintage, six-figure prices have ceased to be exceptional.

The Remix; Colombia Gold
description: Why fight crime the old-fashioned way when you can make a killing designing kingpin couture? Miguel Caballero, a Bogot native, has turned his country's violent reputation into a $3.5-million-a-year company by making security stylish. Practically every product from the eponymous label, from a leather jacket to a tropical shirt, is guaranteed to withstand ammunition from a nine-millimeter, .44 Magnum or .357 revolver (tested on new employees, who face a literal trial by fire). The range, worn by high-risk honchos and several South American presidents, comes in three collections. "The platinum line is for a V.I.P. person: raincoats or blazers," Caballero says. "The gold line offers casual wear, like a jean jacket or a tropical-print T-shirt. And the classic line features regular vests for the army and police." (He even makes knife-proof undershorts, popular with wardens.) The company has developed its own indestructible material, key to minimizing bulk and risk, he says. So when can we expect a bulletproof boutique at Barneys New York? Caballero says he's eyeing the Middle East before braving the United States or Russia. Aw, shoot. MARK ELLWOOD

"A New Zealand gangster would only roll up and smash you in the face." Scribe, 25, is at the forefront of the country's exploding hip-hop scene -- a posse that includes the artists Che-Fu, Con Psy and P-Money. With Americanlike production values and tattoos that improve on the standard "Brooklyn" rendered in olde English across a stomach, these Kiwi rappers mean business: it's suddenly possible that New Zealand could become known for more than just hobbits. title: Free Ranging
description: Otto, 'inoteca and al di l, all leading Italian restaurants in New York, offer the same dessert -- affogato -- on their menus. One step up from a scoop of ice cream, affogato, which means "drowned," is a ball of vanilla ice cream that is served by a waiter who then pours a shot of hot espresso or coffee over it. For this, New Yorkers, myself included, are willing to pay as much as $8. It's not the ingredients you pay for, but the taste of bitter against sweet, the way the espresso makes the ice cream foam on the edges and the tiny bit of fanfare as the waiter douses the pristine frozen orb with the muddy liquid.

description: KOCH--Elizabeth and Dr. Lynn H. The Horace Mann Community mourns with profound sorrow the tragic passing of Elizabeth Koch, class of 2005 and her beloved mother, Dr. Lynn H. Koch. Lizzie was an inspirational student leader, a gifted student and a treasured friend to all. An advocate for human rights causes, she was Chapter President of the Junior State of America; a compassionate pragmatist, she was a strong advocate of Horace Mann student charitable fundraising events; an articulate social critic, she made her life a quest to repair the world. She was a licensed EMT and volunteered many hours at the Englewood General Hospital. Her lively intelligence, her keen insights, her warm personality, her unforgettable smile and her boundless optimism will be greatly missed but not forgotten. "The world has lost a ray of its own sunshine," commented her academic advisor. Her mother, Lynn Koch, in her passionate desire to contribute and to serve, embodied the best values of humanity and the HM community. She was our dearest friend, avid supporter and tireless worker. Devoted to and supportive of Horace Mann's vision and mission, she was an active leader in the Parents Association. Her culinary talents were legendary as was her generosity to the school. She left an indelible mark on all of us who worked alongside of her. We extend heartfelt condolences to Paul and L.J. Koch and grieve with them in their tragic loss. Dr. Eileen Mullady, Head of School Robert J. Katz '65, Chair, HM Board of Trustees The Horace Mann Parents Association KOCH--Elizabeth. In loving memory of our friend Lizzie whose spirit, energy, giggle, and love will be with us forever. We miss you with all our hearts and we'll meet you around the corner. Love, Alix, Laura, Danielle Marissa, Vicky, Beka, Rachel Lexie, Babette, Ashley Amy, Rayna, Sarah, Ali Perry, Lauren, Jane, Morgan and Sam KOCH--Lizzie. Temple Sinai of Bergen County deeply mourns the passing of our member, Lizzie Koch, daughter of Lynn and Paul, sister of L.J. Heartfelt condolences are extended to the family. Dr. Bruce S. Block, Rabbi George Bean, Stuart Himmelfarb, Presidents KOCH--Lynn Hurwitz. title: The Remix; Howe Now
description: After sending legions of loud, baggy surfer shorts and T-shirts into the world as a designer for Quiksilver, Jade Howe felt so guilty about his role in the slobbing down of the American male that he decided to atone for his sartorial sins. He started his own brand, Howe, in 2001. Four years later, the line, based in Orange County, Calif., and backed by the skate legends Tony Hawk and Per Welinder, is regularly stocked alongside Theory and other trendy labels at chic boutiques and department stores. (In addition, it's available at Howe's loft cum retail outlet, Howe Homme.) Followers like Pharrell Williams appreciate details that say "California" without saying "dude": tailored shirts feature rodeo-style bat-wing collars; unstructured blazers are lined with a grinning skull and the motto "Dressed to kill." Yet it's the Skinny Puppy jeans that are Howe's hottest item. Their low rise and twisting inseam, which hugs the legs and makes them look longer, has earned them a female following as well. "We've made it palatable for men to express their feminine side," the designer says with pride. "And they don't even know it." STEFFIE NELSON

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUSSMAN, HERBERT
description: GUSSMAN--Herbert. Of Tulsa, Oklahoma, on March 12, 2005, at the age of 93. Loving father of Ellen G. Adelson and Barbara G. Heyman. Loving grandfather of David Adelson, Robert Adelson, James Adelson, Thomas Adelson, Alexandra Nash and the late Claudia Heyman, and 17 great-grandchildren, and sons-in-law Dr. Stephen Adelson and Stephen Heyman. He was preceded in death by his beloved wife of 60 years, Roseline Nadel Gussman. A graduate of Cornell University, he worked at Lehman Brothers before he entered the oil business in the 1930's. He was amongst the pioneers of the modern oil industry and was amongst the first to employ and perfect the method of oil well acidization which today is standard procedure in the industry for oil and gas well stimulation. At one time, Nadel and Gussman was the largest independent oil producer in Kansas, and for many years was the largest independent oil producer in Osage County, Oklahoma's largest producing county. Today, from five regional offices the company is a significant producer of oil and gas. For many years Herbert Gussman was the chairman of the executive committee of the Missouri Pacific Railroad and was instrumental in the merging with the Union Pacific Railroad. A great lover of music, he was a founder of the Tulsa Philharmonic, and although his first musical love was classical, for many years he studied jazz piano with his friend, the late Teddy Wilson. His friendships in the world of music stretched from Isaac Stern, Leonard Bernstein, Eugene Istomin, Jan Pierce to Vladimer Golschmann, all who would stay and practice at his home when they came to Tulsa. He leaves a collection of French Impressionist paintings that is considered one of the finest private collections in the country. Under the tutelage of his late brother Lawrence Gussman, he built a large personal collection of African art, and along with his brother, endowed and donated many works to the Gussman Collection at the Philbrook Museum of Art. A lover and a student of the game of golf, he played to a low single digit handicap through most of his life. Beyond all of his interests, his family came first. He was always there for them. His love for them and their own achievements were so evident to all.

title: Love Before Music
description: Bolstered by music lovers who are now paying for their tunes, spending on online entertainment increased 90 percent in 2004, according to a study released last week by the Online Publishers Association. Single-purchase music sales from services like Napster accounted for 15 percent of the $413.5 million spent by American consumers for online entertainment last year. The rise in entertainment spending helped drive up overall spending on online content to $1.8 billion in 2004, an increase of 14 percent. (The figures do not include money spent on pornographic or gambling sites.)

title: As Cars Become More Connected, Hiding the Antennas Gets Tougher

But with all the antennas in some new cars -- high-tech luxury sedans may carry 18 or more -- it takes a major engineering effort to design vehicles that do not bristle with metal quills.

title: Spotlight on Sacred Music and the Zenith That Wasn't
description: The Vox Vocal Ensemble, formed by George Steel in 1992, turns up occasionally in new-music concerts, and it contributed to the Miller Theater's small Bach in Context series a few seasons ago. But Mr. Steel and his singers seem most devoted to the music of the Renaissance, and within that fairly broad era (chorally speaking), Vox has made a specialty of English church music, which it sings with a good balance of scholarly fascination and interpretive warmth. The choir's program on Saturday evening at Riverside Church offered an overview of this repertory and built on the previous installments of its exploration.

title: The Angry Sound of Wounds Time Has Not Healed

As she performed it at Town Hall on Saturday night, the lines, "There is room at the top they are telling you still/But first you must learn how to smile as you kill," assumed a new, bitter edge for the age of corporate crime. And the song's prophetic vision of a society "doped with religion and sex and TV" rang as prophecy fulfilled.

description: Family comedies continued to rule the box office as "Robots" (Fox), right, directed by Chris Wedge and Carlos Saldanha, and featuring the voices of Robin Williams, Greg Kinnear, Ewan McGregor and Halle Berry, opened at No. 1 with $36.5 million in ticket sales, according to studio estimates. "The Pacifier" (Disney), last weekend's top movie, dropped to No. 2 with $18.1 million in ticket sales, bringing its two-week gross to $54.4 million. "Be Cool" (MGM), the sequel to "Get Shorty" starring John Travolta, Uma Thurman and a busload of other stars, was beaten for the second week by the family fare, sliding to No. 3 with $10.3 million in receipts. The only R-rated film in the Top 5 was "Hostage" (Miramax), starring Bruce Willis as a hostage negotiator brought out of retirement, which opened with an estimated $9.5 million. The romantic comedy "Hitch" (Sony), released on Valentine's Day weekend, continues to be a significant draw, with $8.7 million in receipts over the weekend, bringing its cumulative sales to just under $150 million. CATHERINE BILLEY

After coming to New York, he rose to a Professorship at the College of the City of New York and became the Director of the Center Against Anti-Semitism at the Free University of Berlin. His life was dedicated to his work, his family and his many friends. A kind, modest and warm scholar, a brilliant mind and a prolific and meticulous lecturer and writer, he leaves an unfillable void. Our deepest sympathy goes out to his widow, daughter and grandchildren. Fritz Weinschenk, Pres. American Federation of Jews from Central Europe

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLOGG, MARY LOUISE WEBSTER
description: KELLOGG -- Mary Louise Webster. Wife of Spencer Kellogg II, died on March 11. Besides her husband, she leaves five children, their spouses, 14 grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Her children and their spouses are Spencer Kellogg III and Winifred of Wilton, Connecticut, Jean K. Pettibone and Peter, of New York City, Richard Kellogg and Pamela of Huntington, Vermont, David Kellogg and Cynthia of Oyster Bay, New York, Mary Louise K. Lyman and Philip of Huntingdon Valley, Pennsylvania. Mrs. Kellogg was born in Buffalo in 1914, the daughter of Frank G. Webster and Jean Bissell Webster, and was a member of the Westover Class of 1933. Since 1940 she resided in Old Brookville, Long Island, and participated in many community activities, including the Red Cross during World War II. She went on to serve on the boards of the North Shore Community Hospital (now the North Shore University Hospital at Glen Cove) and Green Vale School. As a lifelong avid horticulturist, she served as the President of the North Country Garden Club, as Hospitality Chair for the Garden Club of America in New York, and on the flower committee of the Colony Club. She was a valuable early contributor and curator for the original Slide Library of Notable American Parks and Gardens for the Garden Club of America, now in the Smithsonian archives. She was an enthusiastic tennis player, playing competitively into her 80s. A memorial service will be held at Saint John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, on Wednesday, March 16, at 11:30 am. Honorary contributions may be made to Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind, 371 East Jericho Turnpike, Smithtown, NY 11787; or the North Country Garden Club Memorial Fund, PO Box 264, Jericho, NY 11753-0246.

description: KANEKO--Mamoru, M.D. It is with profound sorrow that the Mount Sinai Alumni mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague, one of Mount Sinai's greatest resources for over 40 years. He produced an enviable record of seminal and classic tomes which have become required reading by patholgists and clinicians. The cluster of eager residents around his demonstration table was a scene that has been commemorative of the best teachers in medicine for hundreds of years. The court ruled last Friday that six British Internet service providers need to turn over the names and addresses of the individuals, who are accused of uploading music to file-sharing networks without permission. The music trade group said it was focusing on networks with the highest amount of illegal files. "About 15 percent of individuals are uploading or making available 75 percent of the content," said the group's spokesman, Matt Phillips. "Unfortunately, we have to keep threatening to sue until this activity stops." The organization has already settled 23 of the 26 suits it filed against individuals in Britain last October. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FIELDS, HARRY W.
description: FIELDS--Harry W. Long-time resident of Chappaqua and Scarborough, N.Y., died March 13, 2005 at Westchester County Medical Center, nine days before his 90th birthday. He was born in Brooklyn, N.Y. on March 22, 1915. A veteran of WWII, he was a Sergeant in the U.S. Army Air Force. Mr. Fields is predeceased by his brothers Julian and David, and his sister Martha Laine. In 1946, he married Leona Miller with whom he had two daughters, Lynn A. Hanover and Emily J. Fields. After his divorce in 1969, he married a second time to Carol Perona, with whom he had two sons, Jordon W. Fields and Christopher J. Fields. Known for his quick wit and endless jokes, he was a great favorite on the Metro North from Scarborough, where he had many friends. Mr. Fields began his long career at Harry Winston, Inc., and at 82, he was still riding the train to 47th Street, where he was a partner at Samuel Schick, Inc. He was an avid horse racing fan and, for years, was well known at Yonkers Raceway. He will be missed by his children and grandchildren: Allison Hanover, Jodi Hanover, Joseph Kroetsch, Adam Kroetsch, Brandon Fields, Arieana Fields and Azelyn Fields; daughter - in - law Danielle Fields and son-in-law Ronald Hanover. A family funeral service will be held graveside on Tuesday morning. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to Clearview School, 550 Albany Post Rd., Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.10510 would be appreciated.

description: A man was arrested yesterday in the hit-and-run death of a 76-year-old retired bartender who was crossing the street with his coffee and newspaper on Sunday morning, the police said. The suspect, Royce Quigua, 30, of 61-05 39th Avenue, Woodside, was charged with manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide, as well as leaving the scene of a fatal accident, the police said. He turned himself in yesterday. A police officer stopped Mr. Quigua before the accident after noticing him talking on a cell phone while driving, but when the officer approached the car, Mr. Quigua sped away, the police said. The victim, Donald Hennessy, was killed instantly in the 7:30 a.m. accident at 56th Street and 31st Avenue in Woodside. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Fare Increases Stick
description: FARE INCREASES STICK -- For the second time in a month, Northwest Airlines has taken the lead in imposing fare increases that have been adopted by the other major carriers. The latest increases are as much as $20 round trip, depending on routes. In the past, Northwest has often been the spoiler when competitors sought to raise fares to offset the higher cost of fuel. "It's amazing because this is going to stick, and it's the second time in two weeks that Northwest has led the way," said Terry Trippler, an air fare researcher who is starting a Web site, FareFacts.com. "It shows you just how serious the airlines are about fuel costs."

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Newspaper Sales Decline
description: France's leading newspapers lost circulation last year, published figures show. The largest-selling daily, the regional paper Ouest France, remained stable at about 750,000 copies, but the biggest national daily, Le Monde, slumped 4.1 percent, to 330,768, while Le Figaro, a conservative newspaper that holds second place, declined 3.1 percent, to 329,721 copies. Those hardest hit were the leftist daily Libration, which slumped 7.8 percent, to 139,479, and France-Soir, which fell 11.6 percent, to 62,197. Les Echos, the financial daily, rose 2.1 percent, however, to 116,856 copies, and L'Equipe, the sports daily, rose 8.6 percent, to 355,135 copies. John Tagliabue (NYT)

description: A panel of legislators accused the armed forces of failing to shield young recruits from bullying. The report by the panel, the Commons Defense Committee, followed unexplained shooting incidents in which four young army recruits died at the Deepcut barracks in Surrey. The report said the army in particular had a "duty of care" toward teenage soldiers but had failed to take sufficient action against bullying. But it said that a public inquiry into the Deepcut deaths -- as demanded by the families of the dead soldiers -- would not "add substantially" to other investigations carried out by the civilian and military police. title: Arts, Briefly; Ukrainian Song Rewritten for Eurovision Contest
description: Eurovision, the annual pop-song contest that gave Abba its start three decades ago, has approved a Ukrainian group's entry that had been rejected earlier as too political now that its songwriters have changed the lyrics. The hip-hop-flavored song "Razom Nas Bagato!" ("Together We Are Many!"), by Greenjolly (right), was the anthem of Ukraine's recent Orange Revolution and was ubiquitous in the streets of Kiev during the demonstrations there. In its earlier version, it included the lyrics "Falsifications -- no! Machinations -- no!" and "Yushchenko, Yushchenko is our president. Yes, yes, yes!" Viktor Yushchenko won the new elections called in Ukraine after President Leonid Kuchma's administration was accused of rigging the first vote in favor of a hand-picked successor. Earlier this month, Eurovision's executive supervisor, Svante Stockselius, disqualified the song on the grounds that the contest is "nonpolitical." The BBC reported that last week the band submitted new lyrics at the request of the contest's organizers. Ukraine's Communist Party has accused the new Yushchenko administration of rigging the Eurovision vote to favor Greenjolly, a previously unknown group whose name, in its original Ukrainian, translates as "sleigh." SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: LSI Logic Raises Sales Forecast
description: The LSI Logic Corporation, a maker of chips for data-storage equipment and electronics, raised its forecast for first-quarter revenue to as much as $435 million on demand from digital audio product manufacturers that was higher than expected. First-quarter sales will be $420 million to $435 million, compared with a previous forecast of $400 million to $415 million, LSI said yesterday. LSI, based in Milpitas, Calif., had 2004 first-quarter sales of $452.4 million. LSI has had more than $480 million in net losses in the last two quarters as chip demand sank and customer inventory swelled. Intel, the world's largest maker of chips, surprised investors on March 10 by saying first-quarter sales would be at the high end of its forecast. LSI was expected to have first-quarter sales of $407.7 million, according to the average estimate of eight analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Shares of LSI, which plans to report first-quarter results on April 27, rose 21 cents, or about 3 percent, to $6.27.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Chorus' Girl Will Sue
description: A 14-year-old French girl who sang on the soundtrack to the Oscar-nominated film "Les Choristes" ("The Chorus") has said that she will sue the movie's producers and the soundtrack's record company for royalties from DVD and CD sales. Lucille Hartmann says that the performance of her private school's choir helped propel it to international success, although the singers were not properly compensated. More than 8.5 million people saw the movie (starring, right, Grard Jugnot), the DVD sold in excess of 1 million copies, and the soundtrack has sold 1.5 million, according to the movie and soundtrack producers. A contract with the record producers gave the amateur choir's association 1 percent royalties -- a low figure in France -- but no contracts were made with the members of the group. "The success of this movie has worn her out," said Ms. Hartmann's lawyer, Alain Jakubowicz. "Her parents think it would be fair that she receive a share of the royalties." Ms. Hartmann, who recently resigned from the choir, is the only member of the group to have announced plans for legal action. HLNE FOUQUET

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUSSMAN, HERBERT
description: GUSSMAN--Herbert. Of Tulsa, Oklahoma, on March 12, 2005, at the age of 93. Loving father of Ellen G. Adelson and Barbara G. Heyman. Loving grandfather of David Adelson, Robert Adelson, James Adelson, Thomas Adelson, Alexandra Nash and the late Claudia Heyman, and 17 great-grandchildren, and sons-in-law Dr. Stephen Adelson and Stephen Heyman. He was preceded in death by his beloved wife of 60 years, Roseline Nadel Gussman. A graduate of Cornell University, he worked at Lehman Brothers before he entered the oil business in the 1930's. He was amongst the pioneers of the modern oil industry and was amongst the first to employ and perfect the method of oil well acidization which today is standard procedure in the industry for oil and gas well stimulation. At one time, Nadel and Gussman was the largest independent oil producer in Kansas, and for many years was the largest independent oil producer in Osage County, Oklahoma's largest producing county. Today, from five regional offices the company is a significant producer of oil and gas. For many years Herbert Gussman was the chairman of the executive committee of the Missouri Pacific Railroad and was instrumental in the merging with the Union Pacific Railroad. A great lover of music, he was a founder of the Tulsa Philharmonic, and although his first musical love was classical, for many years he studied jazz piano with his friend, the late Teddy Wilson. His friendships in the world of music stretched from Isaac Stern, Leonard Bernstein, Eugene Istomin, Jan Pierce to Vladimer Golschmann, all who would stay and practice at his home when they came to Tulsa. He leaves a collection of French Impressionist paintings that is considered one of the finest private collections in the country. Under the tutelage of his late brother Lawrence Gussman, he built a large personal collection of African art, and along with his brother, endowed and donated many works to the Gussman Collection at the Philbrook Museum of Art. A lover and a student of the game of golf, he played to a low single digit handicap through most of his life. Beyond all of his interests, his family came first. He was always there for them. His love for them and their own achievements were so evident to all.

title: Technology Briefing | Services: Blackberry Introduces New Messaging Options
description: The BlackBerry maker Research in Motion is broadening its menu of instant-messaging options. New services for the hand-held communications device include instant messaging offerings from Yahoo and the America Online unit of Time Warner, the companies announced yesterday in conjunction with the CTIA Wireless show in New Orleans. Research in Motion also announced software deals with Sybase and High Tech Computer. The BlackBerry will be preloaded with Yahoo's software "in the coming months," the companies said, without being more specific. Yahoo Messenger users will have full wireless access to their contacts and be able to carry on multiple chat sessions. Currently, BlackBerry users can obtain access to Yahoo offerings like search, news and sports updates, depending on availability through phone carriers. Research in Motion is also working with America Online to include AOL Instant Messenger and ICQ services on the BlackBerry, besides offering AOL's mobile mail service. BlackBerry users will get access to their AOL Buddy List feature or ICQ contact list for chatting on both networks. No schedule was given for when the services would be available. Two years ago, AOL ended a deal with Research in Motion in which the two companies offered a co-branded wireless messaging device. Shortly after that, Research in Motion began equipping the BlackBerry with instant-messaging software from I.B.M.'s Lotus division.

Arts, Briefly; Forsythe's New Dance
description: William Forsythe, below, the American choreographer who won loud acclaim for his work with Ballett Frankfurt before that troupe lost its financing last year, has won the financial backing for a new dance company from an unusual consortium of two German states and two cities. In a public-private arrangement, the states of Hesse and Saxony and the cities of Frankfurt and Dresden will together provide 75 percent of the new Forsythe Company's annual budget of $5.4 million while corporate sponsors and patrons will finance the rest. "I am very glad that I can stay in Germany," Mr. Forsythe said at a news conference in Berlin yesterday. "An exceptional artistic situation was created here which is unique in the world." The new company will divide its time between Frankfurt's Bockenheimer Depot and the Festspielhaus in Dresden-Hellerau, and has financing secured through the 2009-10 season, he said. The troupe opens this season on April 21 with a still unnamed new piece in Frankfurt. Ballett Frankfurt closed last summer after 20 years when the city of Frankfurt canceled its nearly $6 million annual subsidy. VICTOR HOMOLA

In a letter to Italian newspapers, Mr. Muti wrote, "In view of the climate that has grown up around me and the insinuations, insults and lack of understanding, a climate to which certain musicians of the Philharmonic and theater orchestra of La Scala are no strangers, the conditions no longer exist to make music together." He said he was canceling rehearsals and the concert scheduled for Friday, Agence France-Presse reported. The row began when La Scala's general manager, Carlo Fontana, was fired, and replaced by Mauro Meli, the former manager of the Cagliari opera house in Sardinia.

title: Arts, Briefly; ABC Skit Not Indecent, F.C.C. Decides
description: The Federal Communications Commission has given ABC reason to breathe a little easier about combining sports and scantily clad women. The F.C.C. concluded yesterday that the network did not violate indecency regulations when it broadcast a controversial promotion, left, for a "Monday Night Football" game in November that had Nicollette Sheridan -- who portrays the serial divorce Edie Britt on ABC's hit "Desperate Housewives" -- wearing only a towel. "The episode is not sufficiently explicit or graphic to be deemed indecent," the commission said. In the scripted segment, Ms. Sheridan flirted in a locker room with the Philadelphia Eagles receiver Terrell Owens, dropping her towel for a shot that revealed her naked back. At the time, the National Football League called the sketch "inappropriate and unsuitable" for its audience and ABC Sports apologized. Earlier this month, the agency decided that the network had also acted within the bounds of its regulations when it broadcast the graphic war film "Saving Private Ryan" last year on Veterans Day. JOHN FILES

title: World Briefing | Europe: Moldova: Ex-Defense Minister Held In Sale Of MIG-29'S To U.S.
description: Relations between Russia and Moldova further soured, after the detention in Chisinau, Moldova's capital, of a former Moldovan intelligence official and defense minister, Valeriu Pasat. Mr. Pasat, a prominent adviser to Unified Energy Systems, Russia largest electricity company, was seized Friday, as he arrived in Moldova from Moscow, and accused of defrauding Moldova in the sale of 21 MIG-29 fighter jets to the United States in 1997, when he was defense minister, Russian news agencies reported. Moldovan officials also said he traveled to Chisinau to meet with a pro-Russian opposition bloc. Russia and Moldova have quarreled bitterly since 2003, and the Moldovan government has turned westward. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLOGG, MARY LOUISE WEBSTER
description: KELLOGG -- Mary Louise Webster. Wife of Spencer Kellogg II, died on March 11. Besides her husband, she leaves five children, their spouses, 14 grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Her children and their spouses are Spencer Kellogg III and Winifred of Wilton, Connecticut, Jean K. Pettibone and Peter, of New York City, Richard Kellogg and Pamela of Huntington, Vermont, David Kellogg and Cynthia of Oyster Bay, New York, Mary Louise K. Lyman and Philip of Huntingdon Valley, Pennsylvania. Mrs. Kellogg was born in Buffalo in 1914, the daughter of Frank G. Webster and Jean Bissell Webster, and was a member of the Westover Class of 1933. Since 1940 she resided in Old Brookville, Long Island, and participated in many community activities, including the Red Cross during World War II. She went on to serve on the boards of the North Shore Community Hospital (now the North Shore University Hospital at Glen Cove) and Green Vale School. As a lifelong avid horticulturist, she served as the President of the North Country Garden Club, as Hospitality Chair for the Garden Club of America in New York, and on the flower committee of the Colony Club. She was a valuable early contributor and curator for the original Slide Library of Notable American Parks and Gardens for the Garden Club of America, now in the Smithsonian archives. She was an enthusiastic tennis player, playing competitively into her 80s. A memorial service will be held at Saint John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, on Wednesday, March 16, at 11:30 am. Honorary contributions may be made to Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind, 371 East Jericho Turnpike, Smithtown, NY 11787; or the North Country Garden Club Memorial Fund, PO Box 264, Jericho, NY 11753-0246.

Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Conor and Novartis Plan Stent Trials
description: Conor Medsystems, based in Menlo Park, Calif., which has been developing a new form of drug-eluting stent, said yesterday that it had signed an agreement with Novartis Pharma, the Swiss drug company, to test three Novartis compounds on its stent. Stents are metal mesh cylinders inserted in blood vessels to prop them open after blockages have been cleared. The best-selling stents are coated with polymers impregnated with drugs that combat the tendency of vessel wall tissue to grow through and around the stent and form new blockages. Conor's CoStar stent, which stores drugs in tiny wells in the metal instead of using a coating, has performed well in European trials but the company is locked up in legal battles with Boston Scientific and Angiotech Pharmaceuticals over rights to use paclitaxel, the drug involved in those trials. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; An Insider Jab at ABC
description: David E. Kelley might not have been able to mention the Fox News Channel by name in last Sunday's episode of "Boston Legal" after running afoul of the ABC standards department, but he did manage to slip in a dig about ABC. Alan Shore, the lawyer played by James Spader, made a thinly veiled comment about halfway through the episode. "I don't know which newscast you've been watching recently, but the First Amendment is losing its luster lately," he said to a colleague. "Some networks are even censoring their scripted dramas." Mr. Kelley, above, the show's creator, appears to have inserted his rejoinder after ABC executives reacted unfavorably to some aspects of the original script's plotline revolving around media bias: a high school principal was to land in court after blocking the Fox News Channel from appearing on his school's televisions, saying that in promoting a political agenda it veered dangerously close to hate speech. ABC executives asked Mr. Kelley to cut all references to Fox News and the on-air personalities mentioned. On the episode, Fox News became an unnamed cable news channel with a conservative agenda. Spokesmen for the show and for ABC declined to comment. LORNE MANLY

World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: 4 Men Convicted In Gang Rape Released
description: A local judge freed four of five men acquitted this month of gang raping a woman in Punjab Province in 2002 on orders of their village council. It was yet another legal twist in a case that has caused outrage across Pakistan and abroad. The victim of the attack, Mukhtaran Bibi, who is also known as Mukhtar Mai, told The Associated Press that she was worried about the release. "I fear they might kill me," she said. The men's release (the fifth remained in jail on unrelated charges) came a day after the Supreme Court, Pakistan's highest court, said it would take over the case after conflicting rulings by different tiers of the judiciary, one that overturned the convictions and death sentences of the five men and commuted the death sentence of a sixth to life in prison and another that suspended that ruling. The local judge maintained that the Supreme Court's decision did not bar the men's release until they are to appear before that court. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Movie Costs Drop
description: The average cost of making and releasing an American film dropped slightly in 2004 because of a decrease in marketing costs, the president of the Motion Picture Association of America, Dan Glickman, said in Las Vegas yesterday at the annual ShoWest movie convention. The average cost of a production stayed the same, about $63.6 million, but marketing costs dropped by 12 percent, to $34.4 million, putting the average film cost at $98 million. Mr. Glickman, above, gave no reason for the decrease. With little increase in American ticket sales, the biggest area of growth in the industry was overseas, he said, where the box office has risen 44 percent since 2003, to total $15.7 billion in 2004, outstripping the domestic box office take, which was $9.54 billion last year. SHARON WAXMAN

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Doormen's Union Reaches Agreement
description: The union representing 1,700 doormen, superintendents and janitors who work at 750 apartment buildings in the Bronx said yesterday that it averted a strike by reaching a tentative three-year contract with the Bronx Realty Advisory Board. The union, Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, said the contract called for improved prescription, dental and hospital benefits, with employer health contributions rising 67 percent -- to $7,284 a worker per year from $4,368 -- over the life of the contract. Wages, which are $9 to $17 an hour, will rise on average by little more than 5 percent over the contract's span, the union said. A ratification vote is set for later this month. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

His selection brought enthusiastic comments from members of both parties in Congress, so he seems likely to sail into a job that will pose daunting challenges as the agency struggles to get its stricken shuttle fleet back into operation, complete the international space station and get on with the president's exploration initiative.

title: The Wrong Chechen
description: It was no surprise that Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, declared the recent killing of Aslan Maskhadov, who was elected president of Chechnya in 1997 and spent the past several years in hiding, as a major victory in the Chechen war. Russia has badly needed a success since the massacre at the Beslan schoolhouse last September, and the Foreign Ministry was indignant that the outside world did not entirely accept the "liquidation" of an "international terrorist" at face value. The fact is, the Russians killed the one Chechen leader with whom they might have begun a political process. If Mr. Putin really wants to end the war, he needs to find someone better to deal with than the man the Kremlin seems to prefer, Ramzan Kadyrov, the brutal son of the assassinated Russian stooge in Chechnya.

A pizza peel helps, because the pie is placed directly on the rack. The crust is better if it's not baked when cold. Choices are Pizza Romana, above, with a spicy sauce and smoked mozzarella; Margarita, with tomato sauce and good mozzarella; and Pizza Pantesca, with provolone and pesto. description: The Rayovac Corporation, the battery maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Tetra Holding of Germany for about $555.2 million to expand into the global pet-supply market. Tetra, which makes and sells food and supplies for fish and reptiles, operates in more than 90 countries with market-leading positions in Germany, Japan, Britain and the United States, Rayovac said. The purchase will allow Rayovac, which owns the United Pet Group in North America, to become a top global maker of pet supplies. The company, which is changing its name to Spectrum Brands, has made at least four acquisitions in the last two years to broaden its product lines as battery sales decline. Tetra, based in Melle, Germany, is being sold by Triton, an international private equity group in Frankfurt; AXA Private Equity, a subsidiary of AXA Investment Managers, based in London; and Tetra management.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: 2 Candidates Report Fund-Raising Figures
description: C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president, and Representative Anthony D. Weiner added their names yesterday to the Democratic mayoral candidates who reported their fund-raising for the last two months. Ms. Fields reported having raised $76,000 in the last two months, bringing her total for the race to $1.1 million. Mr. Weiner's aides said he raised $172,000 in the same period, bringing his total to $1.7 million. The two candidates are behind their rivals, Fernando Ferrer, the former Bronx borough president, and City Council Speaker Gifford Miller. Mr. Ferrer's aides said this week that he had raised about $600,000 in the last two months, bringing his total to about $3.1 million. And last week, Mr. Miller said that his campaign raised or qualified for more than the $5.7 million spending limit for the Democratic primary. Jonathan Hicks (NYT)

title: Facing a Dark New World, Voiceless and Nearly Alone
description: Filled with gasps, peeps, whirs and caws, plangent musical notes and not a single word of dialogue, the independent film "After the Apocalypse" tracks a handful of survivors struggling in the aftermath of World War III. All young, the five dystopian stragglers appear to have been left voiceless by a gas that may have wiped out the rest of the world. The truer reason may be that the first-time feature director Yasuaki Nakajima wanted to make a film as stripped down in form as the bare-bones world in which the story occurs (and probably didn't have enough dollars to make his concept fly any other way).

The suspect, Arshan Little, 19, of Jersey City, was arrested Monday night and charged with the felony murder of the bodega owner, Fausto V. Garcia, 54, said the Hudson County prosecutor, Edward J. De Fazio. The authorities are also looking for Anthony Darnell Hicks, 20, of Jersey City, in connection with the murder and for a separate armed robbery in Jersey City. Mr. De Fazio said that Mr. Little, Mr. Hicks, and a third suspect, Calvin McRae, 16, of Jersey City, who was also killed during the robbery, singled out the store because it opened early. title: Arts, Briefly; Cardinal Takes On 'Da Vinci Code'
description: Until now the Vatican has largely ignored "The Da Vinci Code," the blockbuster mystery novel that has sold more than 25 million copies worldwide. But in an interview on Vatican Radio yesterday, Cardinal Tarcisio Bertone, the Archbishop of Genoa, said that the popularity of the book, which he described as "a castle of lies," had persuaded him that it was time to have an "open and assertive public debate." He said he would hold a discussion in Genoa today to "shed light" on the book. Vatican Radio listeners heard some of Cardinal Bertone's ideas in advance. Saying that the real intrigue was not to be found in the book's plot but in its marketing, the cardinal pointed out that it was published in the wake of Jubilee 2000, a holy year for the Roman Catholic Church that brought millions of pilgrims and tourists to Rome. The church's impact during the jubilee year "disturbed many people," he said, calling the popularity of "The Da Vinci Code" a disturbing sign of anti-Catholic sentiment. ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

description: LESTER--William. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of William Lester of Westfield, N.J. and Delray Beach, FL. A founding member of the organization and a life trustee of the Board of Regents, Dr. Lester was a steadfast and inspiring friend for more than 50 years. He was a brilliant engineer and businessman who launched three successful plastics companies and was a moving force in the growth of the Technion since his first visit there in 1952. Together with his wife, Gloria, he became a Technion Guardian, representing the highest level of commitment to the ATS, the Technion and Israel. Their dedication of the William and Gloria Lester Wing for Optical Information Processing and Communications in the Irwin and Joan Jacobs Center for Communication and Information Technology has helped position the Technion and Israel as leaders in global communications. In recognition of his exemplary dedication, en gineering achievements and unique history, Dr. Lester was awarded a Technion honorary fellowship in 1991, followed by an honorary doctorate in 1999. We extend our condolences to his wife Gloria, and to his and his late first wife Betty's children Gay Freda Gertz, Kenneth Lester, and the entire Lester family.
