title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENE, HENRY GEORGE
description: GREENE--Henry George Architect and Developer for over 65 years. Died March 13, 2005 at the age of 93. Greene had a long and successful career. His many projects included industrial and office buildings, housing and apartment developments, shopping centers, hotels, and broadcasting, entertainment and theatrical facilities. He was the consulting architect for 20 years for The American Broadcasting Company, where he designed and constructed over 80 movie theatres throughout the US as well as the the ABC Entertainment Center Complex in Los Angeles. He was considered to be one of the foremost experts in theatre design and renovation, consulting frequently with the Shubert Theatre Organization. His design of the Cine Capri in Phoenix was considered to be the "Grand Old Lady of Cinema" in Arizona. He was one of the forerunners in the conversion of commercial buildings into residential apartments in NYC that was initiated by the J-51 tax abatement law. These buildings included 79 Pine St., 130 Water St., the Saint George Hotel and many more. He developed over 1800 units of housing in NYC and surrounds. He designed and built Weeki Wachi in Florida, the Club Med and airport at Punta Cana in the Dominican Republic. Greene was born in NYC and lived there until 1953 until he moved to Westchester. His interest in architecture was kindled by his father's lifelong involvement in the construction industry. When NYU opened its School of Architecture he was among its first group of students where he met his first wife Mae who died in 1975. He married again in 1984 to Margery Cohen who died in 1993. Greene was well known for his sense of humor and wit, which helped resolve many difficult negotiations. He traveled extensively about the world both for business and pleasure. He is survived by his son, Elliott Greene; daughter Karen Berkley, granddaughters Lara Berkley and Tamara Boback and great-grandchildren Calvin, Marissa and Eden.

description: CARPENTER--Vernon John (Jack). General Tax Counsel of Viacom Inc., died suddenly on March 12 at his home in West Harrison, NY. He was 51. Mr. Carpenter was Vice President and General Tax Counsel of Viacom Inc. and responsible for the worldwide tax affairs of the company. He previously held the position of Vice President and General Tax Counsel of CBS Corporation. Mr. Carpenter was born May 15, 1953 in Pittsburgh, PA. Paid Notice: Deaths   EMMER, MARTIN
description: EMMER -- Martin. Died March 13, 2005 in Seattle, Washington at the age of 86. He is survived by his loving wife, Ruth, son Fred, daughter, Hilary, grandson, Josh Gray-Emmer, granddaughters, Tamar Dunn & Natasha Dunn, and sisters, Ethel Jones & Florence Schachter. "Marty" was born, raised, and spent most of his life in Brooklyn, New York. He was in the Army for five years where he served in the Pacific. He made friendships during those years that lasted a lifetime. He continued to write to and visit his army buddies and attend reunions of his battalion. Marty and Ruth were married in 1946. They worked hard but also knew how to have a good time by driving around the United States, signing up for elderhostel classes and trips and taking cruises that ranged from cargo ships to South America to luxurious cruise ships to the Caribbean and Alaska. Marty worked for the same company for 40 years selling commercial thermometers and gauges throughout the City of New York and New Jersey. He was active in B'nai Brith and served as President of the Marine Park Lodge, as well as its Treasurer for many years. Marty was an avid bowler who won many individual and team trophies while serving as the Marine Park League's Treasurer for over 20 years. He also played in a weekly poker game. Marty was loved and respected by everyone who knew him. Wherever he was, friends and relatives knew that he could be counted on. He loved New York City and knew every street and its history. Many friends and relatives who came in from out of town were fascinated by his tours of Manhattan. Ruth and Marty loved the theater and spent many wonderful summer afternoons taking their children to Broadway and off-Broadway shows which were always followed by dinner at a different restaurant. They also enjoyed the opera. After leaving his long time employment, he started his own business which he sold 10 years later when he and Ruth retired to the Clearbrook community in Cranbury, New Jersey where they made many new friends. When their health started to fail, they moved to Seattle, Washington so that they could be closer to their daughter, Hilary who lives on Vashon Island, a short ferry ride away. Services will be at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York on Friday, March 18 at 10:45 A.M. under the direction of Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels (www.msmc.us), East Brunswick, NJ.

description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia visited the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow yesterday to discuss reconstruction plans for the country's premier opera and ballet stage, which is set to close on July 1 for work to modernize the building and keep it from collapsing. But the building's decrepit state is not the Bolshoi's only problem. Several dozen protesters from Moving Together, a pro-Putin youth group, picketed the Bolshoi on Monday over a new avant-garde opera with a libretto by Vladimir Sorokin, a postmodern writer. Holding banners reading "Pornographer Out of the Bolshoi," the protesters said that Mr. Sorokin's work was indecent and slandered Russian culture. The opera, "Children of Rosental," depicts scientifically bred clones of Tchaikovsky, Mussorgsky, Wagner and other composers as beggars after the collapse of the Soviet Union. description: Akamai Technologies, which provides services to speed data over the Internet, said yesterday that it would buy Speedera Networks for $130 million in stock to help it compete against larger rivals. Akamai, based in Cambridge, Mass., said it would issue about 12 million shares to acquire Speedera and its Indian subsidiary. Paul L. Sagan, the president and chief executive-elect of Akamai, said the deal would add to earnings in 2005. Speedera, based in Santa Clara, Calif., sells software and services to improve the performance and security of Web sites. Akamai said the acquisition would help it compete for contracts against larger managed-services vendors like AT&T. Akamai had filed a patent infringement case against Speedera in Federal District Court in Boston and a theft of trade secrets case in California state court, both of which were scheduled to go to trial this year. Mr. Sagan said all pending litigation between the companies would be dismissed when the deal closed. Shares of Akamai rose 68 cents, or 6.3 percent, to $11.47.

The inquiry builds on state inquiries into whether the company steered clients to insurers that paid hidden placement fees. Aon agreed this month to pay $190 million to settle accusations from New York's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, and prosecutors in Connecticut and Illinois. It did not admit or deny wrongdoing. Aon said it was cooperating with the Labor Department.

title: The Arts, Briefly; Museum Expansion

The project, which is budgeted at $130 million, is to begin this year, with completion scheduled for 2007. The museum says it has the largest collection of Korean art outside Asia, the foremost collection of old master paintings in the Western United States and one of the world's 10 most important collections of Islamic art. Mr. Piano is also working on designs for the High Museum of Art in Atlanta, the Pierpont Morgan Library in New York, the Art Institute of Chicago, the California Academy of Sciences in San Francisco, the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York and the new headquarters for the New York Times Company. Previews of the musical -- about a young boy who overcomes the prejudices of his mining family to become a successful ballet dancer -- are now set to begin at the Victoria Palace Theater on March 31, a week late, and will play a reduced weekly schedule until the official opening in May. Three boys, age 12 to 14, split the title role (played by Jamie Bell, above, in the film), and were said in a report in The Evening Standard to be exhausted by the rehearsals. "This is one of the most ambitious projects I have been involved with," said Mr. Daldry, who is also directing the musical. "The decision has been made to push back our preview performances in order to give our cast, including 45 children, a little extra time so they are as fully prepared as possible." The boys playing Billy, James Lomas, George McGuire and Liam Mower, are making their stage debuts in the production. PAM KENT

title: 2,000 Talmud Tapes, or One Loaded IPod
description: TWO weeks ago, about 26,000 Orthodox Jews crowded into Madison Square Garden to mark the completion of the Daf Yomi, a seven-and-a-half-year cycle of Talmud learning. Participants in the Daf Yomi -- who number, worldwide, in the hundreds of thousands -- study a page a day of the massive compendium of Jewish oral law, culminating in this celebration, known as the Siyum HaShas.

title: National Briefing
Big Board's Earnings Declined Last Year
description: The New York Stock Exchange said it earned $24.6 million in 2004, down from $49.6 million in 2003. Total expenses climbed 5.3 percent, the exchange said in its annual report. The steepest rise came in expenses for professional services, which includes costs from litigation related to Richard A. Grasso, the exchange's ousted chairman, and a lawsuit related to its specialist stock-trading firms.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer Accepts Buyout Bid
description: A British auto insurer, Cox Insurance Holdings, agreed to a buyout by Neil Utley, the company's former chief executive, valued at 288.7 million ($552 million). The company, based in Essex, sold its commercial business lines in 2002 and specializes in insurance for cars and motorcycles. Mr. Utley is backed by the London buyout firms Duke Street Capital and Englefield Capital. The offer is 13 percent above Cox's closing price on Tuesday; the company's stock rose 10 percent yesterday. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Return of an Injured Senior Gives St. Joseph's a Lift
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 16 - His nationally famous right arm tightly wrapped from wrist to midbiceps, the St. Joseph's senior forward John Bryant took the floor Wednesday at the Fieldhouse with the idea of staying there for a while.

title: The School Auction as Economic Indicator
description: There are many ways to gauge the economic recovery of New York's most lucrative professions, and everyone has a favorite indicator. The packed dining rooms of $250-a- plate-restaurants. title: Palestinians Gain Security Control of Jericho
description: JERICHO, West Bank, March 16 - Israeli troops on Wednesday transferred security control to the Palestinians in the sleepy desert town of Jericho. The move was largely symbolic but pointed to the prospect of a broader Israeli pullback in the West Bank.

title: Close Hospitals, Pataki Says in Medicaid Cost Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 - Concerned about New York's rapidly escalating Medicaid costs, Gov. George E. Pataki said Wednesday that it might be necessary to force some hospitals and nursing homes to close to trim the program's budget.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Resignation From Rights Panel
description: Russell G. Redenbaugh, who served on the United States Commission on Civil Rights for 15 years, has resigned, saying that the agency had become too partisan and that "chronic mismanagement" had caused severe financial problems. "The commission, once the nation's conscience, is now a national embarrassment beyond repair," Mr. Redenbaugh said in his resignation letter, adding that he was frustrated with his colleagues' resistance to an independent review. The departure of Mr. Redenbaugh, an independent, comes three months after President Bush declined to reappoint Mary Frances Berry, who had served on the commission for 25 years and was an outspoken critic of the president. The panel investigates civil rights complaints and reports its findings. John Files (NYT)

title: Opal Petty, 86, Patient Held 51 Years Involuntarily in Texas, Dies
description: Opal Petty, whose lawsuit over her 51-year involuntary commitment in Texas mental institutions led to changes in state policy, died on March 10 in San Angelo, Tex. She was 86 and lived in Christoval, Tex.

title: Tax Cut Plan Withstands a Challenge in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 - President Bush's tax cuts survived an important challenge in the Senate on Wednesday, when lawmakers voted by the narrowest of margins to defeat budget language that would have made it more difficult to extend the cuts for another five years.

title: FORTUNE BRANDS AGREES TO SPIN OFF A UNIT
description: Fortune Brands has agreed to spin off its ACCO World Corporation unit, which will merge with General Binding to create the world's largest supplier of branded office products. Fortune and General Binding expect the new company to have annual revenue of nearly $2 billion. The new company, to be called Acco Brands, will combine products including ACCO's Swingline staplers and Kensington computer accessories with General Binding's GBC binding equipment and Quartet presentation products. General Binding is based in Northbrook, Ill., and Fortune is based in Lincolnshire, Ill. After the spinoff, Fortune will focus on expanding its hardware, liquor and golf units.

Sham Self-Discipline in the Capitol
description: The Republican majorities in Congress have begun another of their deficit-deepening wrangles over the annual budget with a shameful rejection of the pay-as-you-go discipline that helped the nation achieve healthy surpluses in the 1990's. Instead, the two houses are busy invoking sham versions that make a show of mandating cuts in selective programs, while once again ignoring lost revenues and mounting debt on the other side of the ledger.

description: Cargo passing through the Port of New York and New Jersey set records, in both value and volume, in 2004, increasing the need for new facilities to store the incoming merchandise, government officials said on Wednesday.

title: JUDGE RULES AGAINST FORD IN DISCRIMINATION LAWSUIT
description: A federal judge in Tennessee ruled that Ford's Primus lending unit discriminated against African-American buyers by allowing dealers to mark up interest rates. Judge Aleta Trauger said she would issue an order stopping the practice unless Primus reached a settlement by April 18, said Michael Terry, an attorney for customers. The buyers claimed that dealers charged black customers an average of $450 a car more through higher interest rates. Seven cases, including lawsuits against the lending arms of General Motors and Nissan, have settled by agreeing to change policies, Mr. Terry said.

He has a sound and a presence, and everything he does is interesting, even moving and talking and introducing his band members.

Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Teenager Guilty In Murder Of Deliveryman
description: A Queens teenager was convicted yesterday of robbing and killing a Chinese food deliveryman last year to get money to buy Air Jordan sneakers. A jury in State Supreme Court in Queens found the teenager, Charles Bryant, 17, of Rosedale, guilty of two counts of second-degree murder in the killing of the deliveryman, Huang Chen, 18, on Feb. 13, 2004, making Mr. Bryant liable for a life sentence. During the trial, prosecutors told jurors that Mr. Bryant; his friend Nayquan Miller, 17, who is awaiting trial; and another friend who has not been charged, needed money to buy the sneakers and decided to order food and rob the deliveryman. Prosecutors charged that they took $49 from Mr. Chen and killed him with a baseball bat and a knife. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Children's Life Expectancy Being Cut Short by Obesity
description: BOSTON, March 16 - For the first time in two centuries, the current generation of children in America may have shorter life expectancies than their parents, according to a new report, which contends that the rapid rise in childhood obesity, if left unchecked, could shorten life spans by as much as five years.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: United Internet To Acquire Web.de Portal Unit
description: United Internet, a German Internet service provider, said yesterday that it planned to buy the Internet portal business of the German online company Web.de for about 333 million euros ($447 million) in cash and stock. United Internet agreed to pay 200 million euros in cash and 5.8 million of its own shares to buy the portal business, the companies said in statements to the Frankfurt exchange. The United Internet shares, which amount to a 10 percent stake in the company, were worth about 130 million euros based on yesterday's closing stock price of 22.44 euros. United Internet is buying Web.de's most profitable unit as it tries to overtake the Web portal of T-Online International, Europe's largest Internet service provider. Web.de, based in Karlsruhe, Germany, said it would use funds from the sale to market its new telecommunications products, which are still being developed.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighters Object To Beret Ban
description: A group of Bronx firefighters, banned by the Fire Department from wearing their signature green berets in today's St. Patrick's Day Parade, filed a formal complaint yesterday with the New York State Division of Human Rights. A lawyer for the firefighters charged that the department's policy amounted to "ethnic and religious discrimination" against the firefighters, many of whom are of Irish descent. Meanwhile, many firefighters from the Bronx will not march in the parade today. Instead, wearing green berets but not their uniforms, they plan to muster at Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, where they will be joined by the executive board of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, which has also objected to the decision. In a statement yesterday, Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta said, "When a member publicly represents this department in uniform, a proper dress code must be adhered to." Nicholas Confessore (NYT)

World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: U.N. Relocates Threatened Staff
description: The United Nations withdrew its staff from a portion of the troubled western region of Darfur, citing threats to attack aid convoys from militias aligned with the government. Radhia Achouri, a spokeswoman for the United Nations mission in Sudan, said that "credible, serious threats" of attacks led the organization to withdraw about 30 employees, most of them Sudanese workers, from isolated areas of West Darfur near the border with Chad to a regional capital. She said that local government officials had recently begun seizing vehicles of pro-government Arab militants and that attacks on aid workers were planned as retribution. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing
Paid Notice: Deaths   LOWELL, STANLEY H.
description: LOWELL--Stanley H., on March 16, beloved husband of Lee, cherished father of Jeff and wife Eleanor, Darcy and husband Jay, Lauri and husband Isaiah, adored stepfather of Barry and wife Jennifer Schaevitz, and Scott and wife Sue Schaevitz. He is also survived by eight grandsons. Stanley H. Lowell had a long and distinguished career as an attorney, in public service and as an advocate and champion for human rights. He was Deputy Mayor of New York City, served as the first Chairman of the Commission on Human Rights in NYC, and marched with the Rev. Martin Luther King, Jr. He was a US delegate to the Madrid Conference on Human Rights. He played a continuous leadership role at City College, his alma mater, and was an outspoken proponent of free tuition for students from families with no prior college experience. He received the distinguished Finley Medal from City College for outstanding contributions to the City of New York and was instrumental in the development of Shakespeare in the Park, serving as its President. He worked for decades on behalf of Jews in America, Israel and the former Soviet Union, serving as Chairman of the National Conference on Soviet Jewry. He was a Board member of the UJAFederation for forty years, and received the prestigious Proskauer Award. He was also President of the Citizen's Committee for Children of New York. We honor his unfailing integrity, generosity and sense of justice and fairness. Contributions can be sent to UJA-Federation of NY. Services Thursday, March 17, 11:30AM, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Avenue. LOWELL--Stanley. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Stanley Lowell, whose vision and impact helped strengthen the Jewish community in New York and around the world. Stanley's civic and Jewish conscience will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Lee, a treasured former colleague; to his daughter, Lauri Jan Lowell Cooper; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

According to a recent survey by the Pew Internet and American Life Project, of the 52 million adults who use instant messaging services, about a third, nearly 17 million, have received spim. Thirty-nine percent of IM users age 30 and younger report having received spim.

The union, whose contract expired in May 2003, had requested such a panel, saying talks with the city had reached an impasse. A spokesman for Mayor Michael R. title: INAMED IS UNDER FORMAL INVESTIGATION BY S.E.C.
description: The Inamed Corporation, which makes cosmetic surgery devices, said the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun a formal investigation into disclosures made by the company regarding a type of its silicone-gel breast implants. Inamed said it believed that the disclosures were in compliance with the law. Inamed is seeking to become the first company in about 12 years to sell silicone implants in the United States. A panel of Food and Drug Administration advisers is scheduled to review Inamed's application in April. The F.D.A. banned the silicone products in 1992 after concerns were raised that they cause immune-system disorders like rheumatoid arthritis.

World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Woman Arrested In Banker's Killing
description: A French woman has been arrested and charged with the killing of the French banker douard Stern, who was shot in his luxury Geneva apartment earlier this month. In a statement, the judge investigating the death, Michel Graber, identified the woman only as someone "with whom he had intimate relations for several years." He said that the woman had confessed to having shot Mr. Stern, 50, once the heir to one of France's oldest banking families, and that the motive might have been personal or financial, since she and Mr. Stern were known to be in a legal dispute over money. The judge confirmed details of the shooting that were disclosed earlier in Swiss newspapers, saying that Mr. Stern had been found "clad in a latex body suit, and was struck by four bullets from a handgun, two of them in the head, in the course of an encounter of a sexual nature." title: As Americans spend, U.S. deficit hits a record
Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Rural Limits Urged For Off-Road Vehicles
description: New York State would sharply restrict the use of off-road vehicles in the Adirondacks and the Catskills under a draft policy that environmental officials began circulating for public comment yesterday. Conservation groups hailed the proposal as a ban, contending that the all-terrain vehicles have destroyed wildlife, eroded the soil and polluted the water. But Michael Fraser, a spokesman for the State Department of Environmental Conservation, which prepared the draft policy, said the proposal was not a ban. Rather, he said, it would apply state vehicle and traffic laws to the use of such vehicles on public roads, land and easements in the Adirondacks and Catskills. The public must comment by May 27. Patrick D. Healy (NYT)

title: STEEL DYNAMICS SEES PROFIT BELOW ANALYST ESTIMATES
description: Steel Dynamics said yesterday that its profit for the first quarter would rise less than analysts had estimated as a result of lower prices and demand, setting off an 8.5 percent decline in its share price. Profit will rise to $1.10 to $1.20 a share from 58 cents a year earlier, the company said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial expected a profit of $1.43 a share. "Soft market conditions have persisted as service centers and end users of steel products have been working off excess inventory," Steel Dynamics said. Shares of Steel Dynamics, which is based in Fort Wayne, Ind., fell $3.42, to $36.94.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BRECKIR, ALBERT
description: BRECKIR -- Albert. Missing you every day, but especially on this your birthday. Judi

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Police Battle Protesters
description: The police used rubber bullets and water cannons to disperse hundreds of protesters demanding a referendum on a proposed new constitution. During his 2002 campaign, President Mwai Kibaki promised swift enactment of a new constitution that would limit the powers of the presidency. Infighting within his administration has bogged down any reform. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: One Bank of 42 Tiny Speakers Thinks It Has You Surrounded
description: If a ventriloquist were to design a surround-sound system, it might work something like the Yamaha YSP-1. Its single cabinet of speakers, which you place in front of a TV, throws sound to simulate speakers positioned behind and beside the listener.

title: French woman admits killing banker
Paid Notice: Deaths   CRONKITE, BETSY
description: CRONKITE--Betsy. On behalf of the Board of Trustees, staff and volunteers of Educational Broadcasting Corporation, licensee of Thirteen/WNET and WLIW21, we note the passing and mourn the loss of Betsy Cronkite, beloved wife of our Trustee and friend Walter Cronkite. Through Walter, we had the pleasure of knowing Betsy, who will be long remembered for her unfailing wit, grace and deep devotion to her husband. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to him and the rest of her family. Steven R. Rattner Chairman William F. Baker President

title: Paul Dundes Wolfowitz
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 - After surveying the tsunami-pummeled coast of Indonesia from a Navy helicopter in January, Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz appeared shaken at the devastation.

title: A Trusty Pocket Tool For the Great Indoors
description: The new line of Swiss Army tools from Victorinox takes the heavy lifting out of home improvement. The six-ounce, four-inch Spirit ($75), left, offers three sizes of screwdrivers, a wire cutter, a crate opener, a chisel, metal and wood saws, and -- the pice de rsistance -- needle-nose pliers.

title: Too Many Megapixels? Maybe Not.
Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Fire Captain Shot
description: An off-duty Fire Department captain was struck by random gunfire last night while driving to church, a department spokesman said. Capt. Jackie James was hit once in the shoulder by a large-caliber bullet around 6:30 p.m. near Springfield Ellis Avenues in Newark, said the spokesman, Thaddeus Kennedy. Captain James, 54, drove about 10 blocks to Engine Company 18, where firefighters called paramedics. She was taken to the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, where she was in good condition last night, Mr. Kennedy said. Jason George(NYT)

title: Bush Defends the Offering Of Videotaped News Releases
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 - President Bush on Wednesday defended his administration's practice of providing television stations with video news releases that resemble actual news reports, saying that the practice was legal and that it was up to broadcasters to make clear that any of the releases they used on the air were produced by the government.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Oil Drilling Plan In Africa
description: Petrleo Brasileiro, the Brazilian oil giant known as Petrobras, said it signed a contract with the National Oil Corporation of Libya to explore and possibly produce oil and gas off the country's Mediterranean coast. Petrobras, which is controlled by the Brazilian government, has a 70 percent stake in a consortium that won a bid in late January to explore for oil in a 4,020-square-mile block off Libya. Its partner in the consortium is Oil Search Ltd., a company listed in Australia with the bulk of its production in Papua New Guinea. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Purloined Lives
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 - The phone lines are seldom quiet for long at the nonprofit Identity Theft Resource Center. But lately they have been ringing almost continually.

title: Episcopal Bishops Suspend Naming Any New Ones
description: Bishops of the Episcopal Church U.S.A., under pressure from leaders of the international Anglican Communion not to approve any more openly gay bishops, have gone a step further and decided not to approve any new bishops at all for a year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Toddler Left At Bus Stop
description: A toddler was abandoned at a bus stop Tuesday evening, the police said yesterday. Police officials said that witnesses told them a woman wheeled the boy, who was in a blue stroller, to the bus stop in front of 961 Morris Park Avenue in Baychester about 6 p.m. and disappeared. The authorities released a photo of the boy, who they said was about 18 months old, and asked anyone who could help identify him to call 1-800-577-TIPS (1-800-577-8477). The child was wearing a white shirt, blue denim jumper, blue jacket, white socks, and he was wrapped in a light blue blanket. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

description: Jackman to Be Tonys Host Again

title: JEFFERSON PILOT VARIABLE AGREES TO PAY NASD FINE
description: The Jefferson Pilot Variable Corporation, a brokerage firm, agreed to pay $564,000 for failing to stop rapid trades in its variable universal life insurance policies, NASD said. The firm, part of the Jefferson Pilot Corporation, did not have a system to prevent the trading, known as market timing, NASD said. Jefferson Pilot, which did not admit or deny wrongdoing, will pay a $325,000 fine and $238,697 in restitution. Paul Mason, a spokesman for Jefferson Pilot, said it corrected deficiencies and made restitution when it discovered the problems before the NASD inquiry. Jefferson Pilot is based in Concord, N.H.

title: Architect of Russia's privatization survives assassination attempt
New Mexico Star Thinks Of a Friend Who's Gone
description: NASHVILLE, March 16 - Billy Feeney's headband hangs from the rearview mirror of Danny Granger's car. The dresser in Granger's room at the University of New Mexico has pictures of the two, who were teammates and best friends. Granger's scrapbook has the newspaper accounts of the night when the friends separated for good.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I don't want to get up in public and say the sky is falling if it's not falling. I'm going to try to be very realistic and sensible and serious about the kinds of tradeoffs that we have to consider when we're making decisions about protecting ourselves."

title: Corrections
description: A television review in Weekend on March 4 about "Deadwood," an HBO series created by David Milch, omitted the co-creator of "NYPD Blue," another series Mr. Milch developed. He is Steven Bochco.

title: Last Piece of Trade Center Puzzle May Not Be an Easy Fit
description: THE clock ran out last week for public comments on New York State's plan to condemn almost an entire block south of ground zero, the last parcel needed for the full redevelopment of the World Trade Center site.

description: WASHINGTON, March 16 - Continuing cuts in aviation research at NASA are endangering the country's leadership in aeronautics and the aerospace industry, several experts testified on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THEUNE, ADALBERT
description: THEUNE--Adalbert, 83, of Yaphank, NY on March 15, 2005. Recipient of the Officers Cross of the Federal Republic of Germany in recognition of his work for the German American Community, and Past National Chairman of the Steuben Society of America. Beloved husband of Christel (nee Schmitz). Loving father of Peter and Anne, Philipp, John and Amy, Eric and Julieanne, Walter and Edith, and the late Rudolph and William. Cherished brother of Hans, and Marie Hayes. Devoted grandfather of eight. For information the Ruland Funeral Home, Inc., 500 N. Ocean Ave. (South of LIE at Exit 63) in Patchogue, NY. Family to receive friends Friday from 2-4 and 7-9PM. Services will be held on Saturday, 10AM, at the Lutheran Church of Our Savior, Patchogue, NY. Interment to follow in Yaphank Cemetery.

title: Starved for Hits, Producer Finds Hard Times on Street of Dreams
description: The headquarters of Dodger Theatricals on West 41st Street are everything you might expect from a successful Broadway production company: a two-story complex of handsome offices and a roof garden set high above the bruising business below. But later this month, the Dodgers, as the company is informally known along Broadway, will move to a small former rehearsal studio in a nondescript building off Times Square, with four rooms, a view of a garage and a hand-scrawled note on an envelope -- "Dodger Theatricals, Ltd." -- taped to the door.

title: The Arts, Briefly; Indie Country
description: This week, for the first time in almost five years, a song on an independent record label has reached No.1 on the Billboard country singles charts. Craig Morgan, left, a former Army paratrooper, is at the top spot with "That's What I Love About Sunday" on Broken Bow Records, which uses RED Distribution, a division of Sony BMG Music. Wade Jessen, Billboard's director of country charts, said that the last indie country single to reach No.1 was Kenny Rogers's "Buy Me a Rose" (Dreamcatcher) in May 2000. Mr. Rogers himself is back on a major label, having signed with Capitol Nashville, at age 66. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: Iraqi Librarian Becomes Cultural Hero in 2 Children's Books
description: It is hard to imagine how startled Alia Muhammad Baker, the chief librarian of Basra, Iraq, has been to discover that she is the hero of two American children's books. Ms. Baker, who rescued 30,000 books just days before the city's main library was burned during the invasion of Iraq in 2003, has sent e-mail messages recently to thank the authors for "showing us Iraqis as an educated people" and says she was surprised but also happy that the books "describe the truth."

title: Saying Goodbye to New York in a Series of Intimate Portraits
description: Peter Boal's chamber ballet troupe is going out in style, in its final season in New York City, with an evening of dance that is intimate, thought-provoking and affecting. On Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, the program opened with Wendy Perron's "Finding," set to music by Philip Glass. Created for Mr. Boal, the solo looks like a window into the soul of one of the most elegant classicists dancing today.

description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, March 10 - At roughly $3 billion, the Emirates Palace in Abu Dhabi, which just opened to the public, is said to be the most expensive hotel ever built. A billion won't buy what it used to, of course, but three seems to do just fine.

description: A succession of three power failures shut down the Lexington Avenue subway line in Manhattan for much of yesterday, creating a day of confusion that stranded hundreds of thousands of commuters.

description: Raymond Simko, the former media director on a federal antidrug account at the New York office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, pleaded guilty yesterday in federal court to charges related to overbilling for advertising work on the account.

description: TAIC--David. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of David Taic, beloved father of Louis, father-in-law of Chantal, grandfather of Jason, Alexander and Stefania. We share the sorrow of this devoted Park East family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier

title: Giambi Showing Patience and Relief
description: BRADENTON, Fla., March 16 - Jason Giambi had his flight to Washington arranged, and his suit was ready. But the road trip Giambi took on Wednesday was to McKechnie Field, not to Washington. He wore a Yankees uniform and practiced hitting, not his responses to questions from the House Committee on Government Reform.

title: Surging Nets Stop the Bulls to Keep Pace
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 16 - A comfortable 17-point lead was whittled to 7 midway through the fourth quarter when the Nets looked to Vince Carter and Jason Kidd to bail them out again.

title: Three Firms Are Said to Buy Toys 'R' Us for $6 Billion
description: Toys "R" Us, once the most powerful toy seller in the country, will be sold to a team of two private equity firms and a real estate developer-- Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Bain Capital Partners, along with Vornado Realty Trust -- for about $6 billion, people involved in the negotiations said last night.

title: The Arts, Briefly; Larry King Renews at CNN
description: CNN has extended Larry King's contract by three years, ensuring that the brand-name talk-show host (and his famous suspenders) will remain at the cable channel through 2009, Variety reported. The deal, said to be close to $7 million a year, comes as Mr. King, left, approaches his 20th year as the host of "Larry King Live." A CNN spokeswoman would not confirm the duration or the value of the contract, saying only that it was a "multiyear deal." "Larry King Live" is CNN's highest-rated show and its only prime-time offering that competes with the ratings enjoyed by Fox News. While "The O'Reilly Factor" on Fox News outdrew CNN's "Paula Zahn Now" at 8 p.m. by an average of 1.8 million viewers last month, "Larry King" doubled the "Paula Zahn" audience at 9 p.m. with 1.02 million, according to Nielsen Media Research. JOEL TOPCIK

title: Canadian Sikhs Are Cleared in 1985 Air India Bombing
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, March 16 - Twenty years after a bomb on an airliner en route from Toronto to New Delhi blew up off the Irish coast, killing 329 people, a judge on Wednesday acquitted the two Indian-born Canadian Sikhs charged in the explosion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bush Will Name Wolfowitz To Head the World Bank President Bush said he planned to nominate Paul D. Wolfowitz, the deputy secretary of defense, to become the next president of the World Bank.

title: Iraqi Assembly Opens as Talks Over a Government Drag On
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 16 - The country's first freely elected parliament in a half-century met for the first time on Wednesday in the heart of the capital, just after a volley of mortar rounds rained down on the surrounding area.

title: Colors of Spring Bloom Underfoot
description: SISAL has long been the default choice for summer floors. This year's seasonal rugs, however, are anything but beige or bland.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: 4 Sentenced To Death For Bomb Attack
description: A Kabul court sentenced four men to death for organizing a car bomb attack outside an office of the American security concern DynCorp in August in which at least 10 people, including 3 Americans, died, the government news agency Bakhtar said. The court also sentenced a man from Tunisia to five years in prison for ordering a suicide bomb attack two months later at a popular tourist street. That attack killed an American woman and an Afghan girl and wounded eight other people. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Bush and Blair See Assurance by Berlusconi
description: ROME, March 16 - President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said Wednesday that the military coalition in Iraq was not fraying despite comments from one of the alliance's leaders, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy, that he aimed to begin bringing home his nation's 3,000 troops by September.

title: Translator Tools Are Within Reach
World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Mine Kills U.S. Soldier
description: An American soldier was killed and four others injured in a mine explosion near a former Soviet base in western Shindand, the United States military said. Five Afghan civilians were killed and six wounded when their vehicle hit a mine in the same area. The mines were apparently laid during one of the country's earlier wars. In a brief visit to Kabul, Gen. Richard B. Myers, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, described the security situation in Afghanistan as "exceptionally good." Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Vote on 2010 Super Bowl
description: The National Football League's decision on whether to award the 2010 Super Bowl to New York is expected to be made Tuesday.

title: BlackBerry Maker to Pay $450 Million to Settle Patent Fight
description: OTTAWA, March 16 - Research In Motion, maker of the popular BlackBerry messaging device, settled a three-year-old patent dispute Wednesday by agreeing to pay $450 million to NTP, a company that holds a patent on a primitive form of wireless e-mail.

title: Security Center Makes Sure You're Alerted
description: Q. In the last few weeks I have persistently received System Tray balloons with an icon that looks like a shield and a message saying, "Your computer might be at risk," along with other messages about viruses and spyware. What is this? I already use antivirus and antispyware programs. Do I still need to be concerned about these alerts?

title: A Rare Sighting of Audubon Prepares to Take Flight
description: One of the appeals of bird-watching must be the thrill of capturing a fleeting phenomenon, of seizing, at least in memory, an instant that will not soon come again: the rare bird rarely sighted. Notice the way the wings spread, the beak opens in flight, the tilt of the neck. Remember too the texture of the light, the movement of the air, the shape of the leaves. The experience can be cataloged but not captured: melancholy is mixed with the thrill.

title: Don't Parade, Just Go Vote
description: WHEN I was growing up in Jersey City, no one gave more than a passing thought to St. Patrick's Day. Ireland was a remote place where people sang weepers like "Mother Macree." Otherwise the country was seldom if ever mentioned. We did not even have a St. Patrick's Day Parade.

title: Americans Save So Little, but What Can Be Done to Change That?
description: THE single-cell paramecium is about the size of the period at the end of this sentence. In many species, mature cells divide daily into two daughter cells. In schools around the world, this feature has made the paramecium a favorite vehicle for illustrating the miracle of compound interest.

title: Corrections
description: A Small Business article in Business Day last Thursday about George Lichter and Rob Wrubel, who founded a nationwide chain of yoga studios, misstated the location of Knowledge Adventure, the educational software company where the two once worked. At the time, the company was in La Crescenta, Calif., and it is now in Torrance; it was never based in San Francisco.

title: What's in a Scrawled 'Namath'? A Minor Ethics Debate
description: ALBANY, March 16 - At a luncheon last week for lawmakers and other supporters of a new stadium in Manhattan, the New York Jets served food, gave a PowerPoint presentation, doled out plastic minihelmets, and even brought out a legendary quarterback to try to see the team through one more tight spot, Joe Namath.

description: In percent

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Terror Trial Delayed Until Next Month
description: The trial of a London businessman who prosecutors say agreed to provide weapons to a Federal Bureau of Investigation informer posing as a Somali terrorist has been delayed once again, until April 18. The defendant, Hemant Lakhani, 69, left, who runs an import-export business, was charged with providing material support to terrorists. His trial has been delayed by three operations he underwent. Mr. Lakhani told Judge Katharine Hayden of federal court he needed "three to four weeks" to regain his strength. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Iran Offers Europe 'Guarantees' on Its Nuclear Program
description: ISFAHAN, Iran, March 16 - President Mohammad Khatami said Wednesday that his country would not drop its uranium-enrichment program but was ready to provide "objective guarantees" that European negotiators were seeking about Iran's nuclear program.

title: Too Cold to Connect
Sometimes, new is improved
Mountaineers' Gansey Has Seen Worst and Best, and Best Is Better
description: Mike Gansey's college basketball journey started in an abyss, where St. Bonaventure, plagued by scandal, found itself at the end of the 2002-3 season. Six games were forfeited, the players boycotted two more and the coach, the athletic director and the president were all fired. The chairman of St. Bonaventure's board of trustees, Bill Swan, killed himself after leaving a note that said, in part, that he had let down his alma mater by failing to prevent the scandal.

title: Cathay rules out Air China merger
Big Screens to Come in Small Packages
description: THE shrinking bulk of cellphones and digital organizers makes them easy to carry, but the miniaturization comes at a cost: the screens are shrinking along with the electronics. You can read a short text message on them, for instance, but not a page of a newspaper.

title: Right Name, Wrong E-Mail In-Box
description: LAST fall, David A. Green was looking forward to his new job at a Manhattan real estate brokerage. Finally, he would be able to shed the e-mail confusion that plagued him because of the two other David Greens at his company.

title: Lottery Numbers
McDonald's Commands a Real Estate Empire in Russia
description: MOSCOW, March 16 - The busiest McDonald's restaurant in the world is not in America but thousands of miles away in Pushkin Square. The store serves 30,000 customers a day, as busy as on opening day, Jan. 31, 1990. The menu is essentially the same as in the United States, with the addition of cabbage pie among other traditional Russian food items.

title: From Grandstand, Panel Takes Look at Witness Lineup
description: JUPITER, Fla. - BUD SELIG has long observed that baseball is held to a higher standard than other sports. The Congressional hearing on steroids today is Exhibit A. When he has made that observation, the commissioner has usually made it as a complaint, as in why us, why me, but he has also recognized there is a positive side to the coin. People make a fuss about baseball because people care, whether they are fans or members of the news media or even members of Congress.

title: Taiwan Leader Criticizes China
description: HONG KONG, Thursday, March 17 - President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan on Wednesday night strongly criticized mainland China's adoption of an antisecession law, and urged residents to join an islandwide day of protest on March 26.

title: National Briefing

Wolfowitz Gets Bush Nomination for World Bank
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 - President Bush said Wednesday that he planned to nominate Paul D. Wolfowitz, the deputy secretary of defense and one of the administration's earliest and most outspoken advocates of using American influence to spread democracy around the globe, to become the next president of the World Bank.

title: Toddler-Proof and Party-Perfect
description: LAST Saturday the TriBeCa loft of Dominique Lvy and Dorothy Berwin was the scene of a rollicking dinner party capping off a week of art shows in New York. The guests -- artists, visiting Europeans and collectors-- caroused late into the night amid artworks by Cindy Sherman, Tom Sachs, and Tim Noble and Sue Webster, whose wall-mounted light sculpture in the front hall flashed the word "Forever" all night. Cheers erupted when the artist Lisa Yuskavage demonstrated her skill at fireman's lifts by hoisting Ms. Berwin over her shoulder not once but twice.

title: Labor Unions Enter Social Security Debate
description: Fearing that the business supporters of President Bush's proposed Social Security overhaul will greatly outspend opponents, the nation's unions are trying to even the sides by pressuring financial companies and trade associations to drop out of the coalition backing Mr. Bush's plan.

title: An enthusiasm for remaking Iraq
G.M. Sees a Loss Near $1 Billion; Stock Falls 14%
description: DETROIT, March 16 - General Motors' stock fell to its lowest level in more than a decade Wednesday after the company said it expected to post a loss of nearly $1 billion for the last six months. The news set off G.M.'s largest single-day share loss since the market collapse of 1987 and further darkened Wall Street assessments of the company, the world's largest automaker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BREAKSTONE, GLADYS
description: BREAKSTONE--Gladys, 78, of Atlanta, died Tuesday, March 15, 2005. She is survived by her sons and daughters-in-law, Ron & Gayle Breakstone; Steven and Elena Breakstone; sister and brother-in-law, Dorothy and Mortimer Malden; grandchildren, Nina, Dean and Matthew Breakstone. Mrs. Breakstone was predeceased by her husband, Myron Breakstone. Graveside services will be held 1:30PM Friday, March 18, 2005 at Mt. Ararat Cemetery. Dressler's FH 770-451-4999.

title: Senate Votes to Allow Drilling in Arctic Reserve
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 - President Bush's long-stalled plan to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling cleared a major hurdle on Capitol Hill on Wednesday, when the Senate voted to include the proposal in its budget, a maneuver that smoothes the way for Congress to approve drilling later this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILSON, CHRISTINE BAGALOFF
description: WILSON--Christine Bagaloff of Manhattan and Old Lyme, Connecticut died on Friday, February 18th at age 81 in Boston, MA. Born in Hammond, IN, she performed in Broadway musicals before marrying the late C. Philip Wilson, M.D., a psychoanalyst. She is survived by her son Marc N. Wilson of Old Lyme, her son Scott N. Wilson, MD of Newton, MA, nephew James Bagaloff of Empire, MI and Naples, FL, daughter-in-law Anne Allan, MD of Newton, MA, and grandchildren Eric Glenn Wilson, 17, and Julia Christine Wilson, 3, both of Newton, MA. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 A.M. on Saturday, March 26th at the First Congregational Church at 2 Ferry Road in Old Lyme. In lieu of flowers, donations made out to The Endowment for the Advancement of Psychotherapy may be sent to Anne Alonso, M.D., WACC Room 805, 15 Parkman Street, Boston, MA 02114.

title: Senate Votes to Restore $14 Billion in Medicaid Cuts
The Arts, Briefly; Digital Copying in France
description: In a French court case that is being closely watched by intellectual property experts and the entertainment industry, a judge at the Court of Appeals of Montpellier has ruled that it is legal for a person to make digital copies of music, video and other materials for friends and family members. But the public prosecutor's office has appealed the case again, to France's highest court, saying the decision broadens the idea of private use too far. "The judge extended the scope of the 'private' exception much beyond the limit set by the law itself," said Christian Souli, the lawyer for the prosecution, which is representing 17 major film studios. The case concerns a 22-year-old former student who owned 488 copies of movies, some downloaded from the Internet. Joelle Glock-Fossat, the defense lawyer, hailed the ruling, saying, "Before, downloading was called piracy; now it will just be called downloading." She noted that French consumers already paid copy taxes when buying computers and blank CD's. HELENE FOUQUET

title: Soccer: Remodeled Porto surrenders crown
Corrections
description: A chart in the sports pages on Monday about the individual teams in the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's basketball tournament misstated the University of Florida's performance since 2000, when it appeared in the championship game. Florida advanced to the second round before losing in 2001 and 2003; it has not lost in the first round every year since 2000.

title: You Are Not Paranoid: The Walls Are Watching
description: "Party Wall," right, is an interactive installation by Eric Bunge and Mimi Hoang, the principals of nArchitects in New York. The wall's two-inch-thick foam panels connect to a series of pulleys and cables that react when embedded sensors detect motion nearby. The resulting gaps in the wall, reminiscent of giant eyes or mouths opening and closing, offer ever-changing views of goings-on on the other side. (Sometimes the wall even triggers itself.) The designers also created the bamboo canopy that took over the courtyard of the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Queens last summer. Through April 23 at Artists Space, 38 Greene Street (Grand Street), New York; (212)226-3970. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

title: Herbert L. Seegal, Who Helped Take Macy's Upscale, Dies at 89
description: Herbert L. Seegal, whose analytical approach to courting shoppers at R.H. Macy & Company helped start the chain's move to a more upscale market in the 1970's and who trained several of its future leaders, died on Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 89.

Paid Notice: Deaths   LYNE, RUTH LALLY
description: LYNE--Ruth Lally. Late of Boston, MA, died at her winter home in Ocean Ridge, FL on March 16, 2005 after a long illness. She was 80 years old. Mrs. Lyne, the daughter of Grace and Frank Lally, grew up in Brookline, MA, attended Brookline High School and later Erskine Academy, before taking a job at Thomas Cook & Son. Mrs. Lyne was a tireless volunteer at numerous hospitals and hospices throughout her life. She was on the boards of Friends of Dana Farber and Home for Little Wanderers Thrift Shop of Boston, and was a student of the decorative arts throughout her life. She was a role model and confidant to numerous children, a number of whom lived at her home for extended periods of time. Mrs. Lyne is survived by her husband, Eugene, to whom she was married for 55 years; her five children, Susan, Barbara, Daniel, Diana, and Abigail; numerous grandchildren, nieces, and nephews; and many friends of all ages and walks of life. A Memorial Service will be held at 11:00 AM on Friday, March 18, 2005 at St. Marks Church, 643 N.E. 4th Avenue, Boynton Beach, FL. A second Memorial Service will be held in Boston at a future date. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in Mrs. Lyne's name to the Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407. For information: Quattlebaum Funeral Home, West Palm Beach, FL (561) 832-5171.

description: SAP, the world's largest maker of business management software, raised its offer to buy Retek by 29 percent, to $629 million, escalating a bidding war with its competitor, Oracle. SAP said it would pay $11 a share, topping its Feb. 28 offer of $8.50 and Oracle's $9 offer, announced March 8. Retek, which is based in Minneapolis, said yesterday that its board supported SAP's new offer. Retek shares surged nearly 11 percent, rising higher than the bid, signaling that investors expected the Oracle chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison, to increase his company's bid. Retek is a maker of software for retailers, including Best Buy. Buying Retek would be SAP's biggest acquisition. Retek shares rose $1.13, to $11.65. Oracle shares rose 14 cents, to $13.16.

title: Still Afraid of That Video and Fatal Career Missteps
description: "The Ring Two" is the inevitable sequel to "The Ring," which, in turn, was a remake of the wildly influential Japanese horror flick "Ringu." Released in 1998, "Ringu" spawned several other films and turned its director, Hideo Nakata, into an international brand. It was only a matter of time before Mr. Nakata went Hollywood, and so he has at last as the director of, yes, "The Ring Two," the sequel to the remake of his original hit. (Got that?) Such creative cannibalism is of course part of the pleasure of genre movies, especially horror, where directors like Wes Craven ("Scream") and Takashi Shimizu ("The Grudge") return to the scene of the crime to scare up new frights and profits.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: IPCS To Acquire Horizon For $213.3 Million
description: IPCS has agreed to buy Horizon PCS for $213.3 million in stock to become the nation's third-largest vendor of Sprint-brand mobile phone services and products. IPCS shares rose as much as 27 percent. Each Horizon share will be exchanged for 0.7725 share of iPCS, the companies said yesterday. The agreement valued Horizon at $23.18 a share based on iPCS's closing price Wednesday. IPCS shareholders will own about 57.5 percent of the combined company, which will be led by Timothy M. Yager, the chief executive officer of iPCS. The transaction is expected to close in the second or third quarter. Horizon, based in Chillicothe, Ohio, sells Sprint-brand phones in 11 states, including Ohio, Indiana, Pennsylvania, Tennessee and West Virginia. IPCS, based in Schaumburg, Ill., operates in Illinois, Michigan, Iowa and eastern Nebraska. Both companies exited bankruptcy in 2004. IPCS shares rose $3.05, or 10 percent, to $33.05. Horizon rose $1, to $26.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: U.S. Expands Some Stent Reimbursement Coverage
description: The federal government yesterday expanded its reimbursement coverage for Medicare patients who get blockages in their major neck arteries cleared intravenously rather than through surgery, but some doctors said that policy was still too restricted. The intravenous process is known as carotid stenting. After a catheter is inserted in a leg artery and threaded up to an obstruction in either of the two carotid arteries in the neck, a balloon is inflated to clear the vessel and a metal mesh stent is deployed to keep it propped open. Last September, the Guidant Corporation became the first company approved to sell such devices, but several competitors have been racing to enter the market. Until yesterday, Medicare only paid for stenting carotid patients involved in clinical trials. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: The Listings; VICKY SHICK
description: Ms. Shick belongs to a school of female choreographers -- among them Susan Rethorst and Wendy Perron -- who specialize in implied scenarios, unknowable and mysterious yet strangely clear. Ms. Shick's quiet authority encourages trust as she draws the viewer through dark thickets of possibilities into the still center -- the knowable heart -- of each new dance. A dancer bursts out extravagantly but is interrupted and exposed as vulnerable in Ms. Shick's latest piece, "Repair," set to a score by Elise Kermani, a sound designer, that is triggered by sound-producing light sensors on the costumes. Reassuringly, those costumes and the sculptural set are the work of Barbara Kilpatrick, a longtime collaborator whose delicately powerful designs create the perfect worlds for Ms. Shick's intimate, poetic distillations of time and place. "Repair" features Ms. Shick and Jodi Melnick (above), another frequent collaborator. Tall, slender and supple, with a wide-cheekboned face ringed by a fluff of hair, Ms. Shick looks like a cross between an angel and one of Walker Evans's paradoxically beautiful Dust Bowl farm wives. She is one of many choreographers active today who cut their dance-teeth with Trisha Brown. She has also danced with Ms. Rethorst and Ms. Perron. Vicky Shick's "Repair" will be presented tonight and tomorrow at 8:30 p.m. and Sunday at 7:30 p.m. Sunday's performance will be followed by an informal conversation with the artists. (Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, at Second Avenue, East Village, (212)674-8194 or www.danspaceproject.org. Tickets: $15; TDF vouchers accepted.) JENNIFER DUNNING

Credit rating companies have cut BearingPoint's rating to junk status, and the Securities and Exchange Commission subpoenaed the company over some transactions. BearingPoint, based in McLean, Va., said it probably would report a loss in the fourth quarter and for 2004. The company delayed filing its annual report while it revises its accounting. Oracle is based in Redwood City, Calif.

Mr. Erburu, 74, had been lead director since October, when Jeffrey W. Greenberg stepped down as chairman and chief executive. The chairman's post was left vacant when Michael G. Cherkasky, who joined the company in July when it acquired Kroll, a risk consulting company, replaced Mr. Greenberg as chief. A 'Buffy' Alumna on Ice, Living a Physics Lesson
description: As the figure-skating movie "Ice Princess" executes lazy triple loops on its way to its climactic but underwhelming competition, you can feel this niche-marketed tweener fantasy of athletic glory frantically trying to balance a decent sense of values against a market-savvy awareness. The movie's likable saucer-eyed heroine, Casey Carlyle (Michelle Trachtenberg from "Buffy the Vampire Slayer"), is a high school physics whiz on the fast track to a Harvard scholarship. When she is drawn into the world of competitive figure skating, she has to make a Hollywood choice between equations and eye shadow. The rule says that sports heroines must trump nerds for box office security.

title: The Listings; BEN STILLER
description: Neil LaBute has said that he didn't write the narrator of "This Is How It Goes" with Ben Stiller in mind, but anyone who reads the script might be excused for thinking otherwise. A likable writer with a weakness for bad jokes, the character (named simply Man) superficially resembles many of the nebbishy protagonists played by Mr. Stiller, above, in past films. Even his nervously staccato speech patterns will sound familiar to fans of "Meet the Parents" and "There's Something About Mary." For his long-awaited return to the stage, Mr. Stiller has chosen a part that he is perfectly suited for (much more so than the cocky salesman Richard Roma in "Glengarry Glen Ross," which he was to play on Broadway several years ago before dropping out of the revival, leading to the production's collapse). But if this seems like old hat, remember that no playwright is better at tweaking audience expectations about celebrities than Mr. LaBute, who usually casts his plays with movie and television stars (preferably good-looking ones). To take the most recent example, "Fat Pig," Jeremy Piven, best known as the oily agent in the television series "Entourage," played a sweet, indecisive hero and Keri Russell (the angelic title character from "Felicity") was his bitchy ex-girlfriend. In "This Is How It Goes," Mr. Stiller, who was last onstage almost two decades ago in a revival of "The House of Blue Leaves," is not only an unreliable narrator, but an inscrutable one. He has returned to his hometown, but it's not clear why. He seems to be flirting with an old crush from high school, played by Amanda Peet, but what are his real intentions? And then there are the racially insensitive jokes. We know that Neil LaBute is up to something -- he always is -- but what exactly is it? (This weekend's schedule: tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m. and Sunday at 2 and 7 p.m. Public Theater, Anspacher Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village; (212)239-6200. Tickets: $60.) JASON ZINOMAN

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Suspect In Dental Office Killing Is Dead
description: A man who was wanted in the fatal shooting of his former girlfriend at an orthodontist's office last week was found dead in a park in South Jamaica yesterday in an apparent suicide, the police said. The man, Michael Hicks, 51, had been sought by the police after he was identified as the man who ran into the waiting room at 42-31 Colden Street in Flushing on March 10 and shot Xian Quian Cheung, 41, in the chest and neck in front of her daughter. Yesterday, the police said that Mr. Hicks entered Baisley Pond Park in South Jamaica and shot himself in the head around 3:50 p.m. with a 9-millimeter gun, which they believe was the same gun used to kill Ms. Cheung. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

The S.E.C. upgraded the inquiry after the company told it that one or more former workers might have relevant information, Navistar said. A formal investigation requires a vote by the S.E.C.'s commissioners and gives subpoena power to investigators. Roy Wiley, a spokesman for Navistar, said that two or three former workers were involved, but did not say what information they might have. An S.E.C. spokesman declined to comment. Navistar is based in Warrenville, Ill.

"Prosecutors don't smile," she warns in mellifluous alto tones, then violates her own edict. title: COLLINS & AIKMAN DELAYS 2004 EARNINGS FOR SECOND TIME
description: The Collins & Aikman Corporation, a manufacturer of auto parts, has delayed its earnings report for 2004 for a second time, saying it found improper accounting that probably would force it to restate results for the first nine months. The announcement set off a 24 percent decline in the company's share price. Collins & Aikman said that it expected to reduce operating income for the nine-month period by as much as $12 million and that it also might have to restate results from 2003. The accounting problems involve rebates to suppliers totaling about $88 million from 2002 through 2004, the company said. Stock in Collins & Aikman, based in Troy, Mich., fell 39 cents, to $1.24 a share.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Bomb Scare Delays Ferry
description: A Staten Island ferry was evacuated yesterday and service between the island and Manhattan was suspended for nearly two hours because of a bomb scare. Shortly after the ferry Andrew J. Barberi left the Whitehall terminal in Lower Manhattan at 10:30 a.m., a bomb-sniffing dog reacted to a trash can, according to the city's Department of Transportation, which operates the ferry. The 750 passengers were directed to another deck of the ferry, which docked at the St. George terminal on Staten Island. There, a second bomb-sniffing dog also reacted to the trash can. The Coast Guard ordered ferry service suspended while the Barberi was searched by police officers and bomb specialists. No explosive was found and service resumed at 12:30 p.m. Sewell Chan (NYT)

Two Years Later
description: The invasion of Iraq, which began two years ago this weekend, was a world-changing event. We can see many of the consequences already. The good ones, so far, exist mainly as hopes and are fewer than the bad ones, some of which are all too concrete. One of the few positive domestic consequences of the war has been the nation's determination -- despite obstruction from the White House and its supporters -- to honor the memory of each American man and woman who has died in Iraq. description: For the second time in a month, the auction of Gorky Film, one of Russia's oldest movie studios, has been delayed to allow the Russian privatization agency to recalculate its assets to get a higher price. The sale of the studio, known for Soviet epics like "And Quiet Flows the Don," had been set for Feb. 16 and was moved to Wednesday, but has been postponed yet again, a spokesman for the Russian Federal Property Fund said. The initial asking price for the studio -- which needs a big technical overhaul but sits on valuable real estate -- was set at about $4.4 million, a bargain that the newspaper Izvestia reported had drawn many potential buyers, including Russian television channels and banks, and some suspect that Hollywood studios are interested and are using Russian front companies for a potential purchase. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: No Plan To Reduce Textile Exports
description: China's government said rising raw material and labor costs would slow the increase in its textile shipments, and it had no plans to reduce its $100 billion a year in exports from the industry in response to requests from the United States and the European Union. China's growth in textile imports this year will slow to last year's growth rate of about 20 percent, down from 29 percent in January, said Cao Xinyu, left, the vice chairman of the China Chamber of Commerce for Import and Export of Textiles, a trade organization. A decades-old system of textile quotas that limited trade in 2,400 items ended Jan. 1, prompting textile makers in the United States and Europe to push for measures that would restrict Chinese exports.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'The Wire' Renewed
description: HBO has renewed its crime drama "The Wire" for a fourth season, the president of HBO Entertainment, Carolyn Strauss, said in a telephone interview. Ms. Strauss acknowledged that the future of the series was uncertain: "The question we were presented with was, 'Should we just end on a great note or should we go further?"' The third season ended with the incarceration of the drug lord Avon Barksdale (Wood Harris, above) and the death of his lieutenant, Stringer Bell (Idris Elba), bringing to an end the story arc that linked the first three seasons. Reached at home in Baltimore, where the series is set, David Simon, the creator, explained that each season has been thematically distinct, focusing in turn on the drug war, unionized labor and local politics. The fourth season will address the public school system. Though Mr. Simon declined to reveal any plot lines, "some characters will continue, some will not," he acknowledged. A fifth season has been mapped out but not yet approved. HBO will begin shooting 12 episodes in late 2005 for broadcast sometime next year. JOEL TOPCIK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EISDORFER, SIMON
description: EISDORFER -- Simon. On March 16, 2005, of Cedarhurst, NY. Devoted husband of Beatrice (Feld), beloved father of Barbara Waitman and James Eisdorfer and his wife Rae, loving brother of Al Eisdorfer, adoring grandfather of Jennifer, Adam, the late Joshua, and Jonathan Waitman and his wife Rebecca, and Aliza, Jesse and his wife Jamie, and Talia Eisdorfer, and cherished great grandfather of Lyla and Joshua. Simon was born on the lower east side and graduated from Stuyvesant High School and CCNY. A World War II army veteran, Simon later joined the N.Y.P.D., in which he served for 38 years. He rose through the ranks to become a three-star Chief. He was the N.Y.P.D.'s first Chief of Organized Crime Control and retired as Chief of Personnel. In 1976, Simon was the first recipient of the N.Y.P.D Shomrim Society's Asser Levy Award to the person who best exemplifies the strong commitment of Jews to police service. He was a mentor and role model to many. As Director of the Special Operations Division of the N.Y.P.D., Simon developed a new technique for negotiations in hostage situations and successfully obtained the safe release of hostages held in a sporting goods store in 1973. He later testified before Congress regarding his innovative approach to hostage negotiations, a method which is still in use today. In addition to his professional career, Simon was actively involved with Jewish causes. He was a founder of the Chabad Center of the Five Towns, a Grand Marshall of the Israeli Day Parade, and a volunteer with the Israeli Defense Force. He lived by the motto "Do justly. Love mercy. And walk humbly with thy G-d." Contributions in his memory may be made to Chabad Center of the Five Towns.

title: The Listings; THE NO FUN FEST 2005
description: This annual music festival is devoted to the kinds of jagged, free-form, wildly demanding compositions that often are described as noise. Last year's No Fun Fest bore the influence of Sonic Youth -- at least one band member performed on each of the festival's three days. This year, the No Fun Fest headliners include the wild -- and, sometimes, wildly unsettling -- Swiss extremist Rudolf Eb.er, who terrorizes audiences under the name Runzelstirn & Gurgelstock, as well as the long-running British act Whitehouse, known for pairing volatile musical tantrums with sadistic rants. (Visit www.nofunfest.com/ for the complete lineup.) Perhaps the most exciting act on the bill is Fe-Mail, the Norwegian duo of Maja Ratkje (above right), a singer and composer, and Hild Sofie Tafjord. The two record together as half of the excellent all-female quartet Spunk, which specializes in sharp (or sometimes gentle) jazz-inspired collisions. But as Fe-Mail, the two make more of a racket: on "Syklubb fra Haelvete" (Important), the duo's startling debut CD, full of splintered, screaming sounds that hinted simultaneously at terror and joy; don't be surprised if the duo's headlining performance on Sunday night finds ways to split the difference, too. (Tonight and tomorrow night at 7, Sunday night at 6:30, the Hook, 18 Commerce Street, near Columbia Street, Red Hook, Brooklyn, (718) 797-3007; www.thehookmusic.com. Tickets are $13 per night.) KELEFA SANNEH

Arts, Briefly; Jerry Springer on British TV
description: The talk-show ringmaster Jerry Springer, right, will be the host of a new show on British television. ITV, Britain's largest commercial television network, has signed a one-month deal with Mr. Springer for a series of daytime shows in what has been called a "studio-based confessional format." A spokesman for the channel said there were no details of when or where the series would be recorded. Meanwhile, Christian Voice, a group that has been conducting protests against "Jerry Springer: The Opera," the award-winning musical satire, is attempting to halt a regional tour of the show that is scheduled to begin in the fall. The group, which calls the show blasphemous and obscene, announced earlier this month on its Web site, christianvoice.org.uk, that it would send a letter to 250 regional theaters in Britain warning them that they might face court action if they staged the show. The producer of the musical, Jon Thoday, said in a trade magazine, The Stage, that some theaters had pulled out of the tour but that "we have 25 who 100 percent want it to happen." PAM KENT

Venice, Calif.
description: VENICE is a rarity in Los Angeles, a neighborhood where you actually want to walk. In fact, assuming your flip-flops are sturdy, it's possible to spend a weekend in Venice without getting into a car. Since it was designed as a beachside resort in 1905 by Abbot Kinney, who became a real estate developer after he dropped out of the family tobacco business, the neighborhood has seemed removed from the rest of Los Angeles's flashy, auto-centric urban culture. Even in the early 1990's, it was authentically bohemian: a run-down beach community where real estate was cheap, skaters and surfers ruled the boardwalk, and hippies and artists populated dilapidated Craftsman bungalows. Times have changed. Although Venice still has an abundance of artists, writers, surfers and plain old eccentrics, it also attracts A-list celebrities (Julia Roberts bought property there in 2002), fine restaurants and chic boutiques. The popular annual garden tour (May 7) is increasingly a showcase for designer landscapers and prominent architects. On the lush residential streets near Abbot Kinney Boulevard, Frank Gehry is designing a home for himself, and the local designer Steven Ehrlich has already built one. But even with property values and celebrity cachet on the rise, Venice remains quirky and laid back, a place where you might see entire families on bikes or an artist walking to the shore with a canvas in one hand and a beach chair in the other. Feel free to leave the stilettos at home. JANELLE BROWN

title: The Listings; 'ZABRISKIE GALLERY, NEW YORK/PARIS: SEASON 1980'
description: When she set up shop in 1954, Virginia Zabriskie was said to be the youngest art dealer -- or gallerist, a preferred term in the trade -- in New York. Fifty years later, if no longer quite the youngest, she is certainly one of the best regarded, not only for her eye but for doing lively shows of what she believes in, regardless of art-world fashions or trends. In her New York and Paris divisions, she has mounted nearly 800 exhibitions of contemporary and modernist painters, sculptors and photographers, with emphasis on 20th-century American art, French and American photography, Dada and Surrealism. Her Paris gallery, which operated from 1976 to 1998, focused on the work of significant French and American photographers and created a rewarding exchange by bringing the former to New York and the latter to Paris. Her current show, "Zabriskie Gallery, New York/Paris: Season 1980," celebrates the gallery's 50th year by revisiting its 1980 season, with a display of works from exhibitions mounted at that midpoint of its existence. And it reveals its proprietor's wonderfully eclectic taste, with objects like a classical "Head" (about 1909) in white marble by Elie Nadelman; a finely executed charcoal drawing (1936) of three biomorphic forms in space by the British abstractionist Paule Vezlay (above); a rugged "Landscape for the Forties" (1946) by the out-of-mainstream painter Arnold Friedman; and two superb photographs of stately trees by the German Albert Renger-Patzsch. Bravo! to this very lively place and its vibrant proprietor. Would that it could be around for another half century. (Zabriskie Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, Manhattan, (212)752-1223, through April 16; free.) GRACE GLUECK
