title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHARP, BRUCE
description: SHARP--Bruce. Born August 9, 1941, Bruce Sharp was a man who was known for his big heart and dedication to family and friends as well as his pioneering entrepreneurship in the underground storage tank industry. A former Eagle Scout and Naval Reservist, Bruce Sharp started his own tank lining company in 1967 which specialized in lining underground storage tanks preventing leaks into the environment. By 1972, Bruce Sharp had developed his own tank lining material and process and began a national network of franchises that specialize in lining petroleum tanks. Bruce's revolutionary process became the industry leader by the early 1980's and shortly thereafter he began patenting ideas helping to improve underground storage tank designs. He then founded his National Leak Prevention Association, which became nationally recognized by the EPA, and by the 1990's Bruce successfully began licensing patents to various tank manufacturers on a national level. In addition to the over 100 patents and being recognized as a leader in the petroleum storage industry, Bruce Sharp held both commercial and instrument pilot licenses, was an avid scuba diver, enjoyed sailing, was a certified Dolphin Trainer, loved snow skiing and was a licensed and registered pyrotechnician. Bruce Sharp was best known as a man of true compassion by his close friends, neighbors and relatives. This was evident in Bruce's many acts of selflessness, loving heart, and his generosity to others in their time of need. Bruce R., beloved husband of Linda K. (nee Eck) for over 43 years, cherished father of Scott (Jan), Derick, Heather, Tobie, and Rebecca; dear brother of Brenda Klus, Elaine Bartlett, Lowell Sharp and Beth Hondorff. He is also survived by his grandchildren Victoria, Prairie, Jamie, and Jan-Michael. Bruce Sharp quietly passed on Tuesday, March 15th, 2005 amongst family and close friends. Friends may call on Saturday from 36PM and Sunday 3-6PM at the Jon Deitloff Funeral Centre, 4389 Spring Grove Avenue (45223). Funeral service will be at 6 PM on Sunday at the funeral home.

description: Despite long-running labor conflicts at the Montreal Symphony Orchestra, it will go ahead with the concerts in coming weeks featuring the conductor Kent Nagano, below, an orchestra spokeswoman said. The musicians, who have been working without a contract since August 2003, have been wearing red union T-shirts at performances since the summer, defying the dress code. Although negotiations this week failed to result in a contract, the musicians agreed not to wear the T-shirts during Mr. Nagano's four concerts at the Place des Arts, from March 30 to April 6. The labor issues concern recording, touring, schedules and personnel assignments. The spokeswoman, Marie-Jose Desrochers, said in a telephone interview that negotiations would resume in April, after the concerts. STEPHANIE ROSENBLOOM

title: False Data for Yucca Mountain?
description: Those who believe, as we do, that the best way to get rid of nuclear waste is to bury it deep underground have got to be discouraged by the latest revelation rocking the effort to create a burial site at Yucca Mountain in Nevada. Two federal agencies are investigating whether a government scientist falsified documents for a license to build the depository. It is unclear whether the falsification involves trivial issues that can easily be rectified or strikes a deeper blow at the validity of data designed to prove the site would be safe. Any falsification would throw yet another cloud over a project that has been repeatedly staggered by technical problems, political opposition and adverse court decisions.

title: Arts, Briefly; Mediator Named for La Scala Dispute
description: Gabriele Albertini, below right, the mayor of Milan and the chairman of La Scala, appointed a city official yesterday to mediate between the board of the foundation that manages the opera house and the unions representing its striking workers. A spokeswoman said that the official, Bruno Ferrante, would "explore whether common ground can be found between the various parties." He is expected to meet with union representatives on Monday morning. Musicians and other workers voted overwhelmingly this week to demand the resignation of La Scala's music director Riccardo Muti. They blame him for the dismissal of the general manager, Carlo Fontana, last month. Mr. Fontana was replaced by Mauro Meli, Mr. Muti's choice. On Friday night, the majority of La Scala's musicians performed a free concert at Milan's conservatory without Mr. Muti, "to let the city know about our problems," said Sandro Malatesta, a trumpeter and union representative for the orchestra. Italy's culture minister, Giuliano Urbani, visited Milan yesterday and pressed for the resolution of the dispute. He said that Mr. Muti's resignation was to be avoided "in every possible way." ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

title: The Sharp Clarity of a Romantic Obsession

With its sliding doors, clean lines and open spaces, this set, designed by Michael Yeargan, is the very picture of clarity. And for Butterfly, everything within it -- her life with Pinkerton, then the memory of that life and the promise of its resumption -- is entirely clear. It's the more complicated world outside that has turned murky, and by avoiding the clutter that often accrues to a "Butterfly" staging, Mr. Lamos has emphasized that tragic delusion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISHMAN, RABBI HERTZEL
description: FISHMAN -- Rabbi Hertzel. Passed away in his sleep on March 17 at age 84 in Jerusalem and will be buried there on March 20. Beloved father and grandfather. Intense lover and critic of the Jewish people. Pugnacious, incisive and articulate, influenced many in his writing and conversations and affected many more. Served as a Zionist youth leader, rabbi and educator in the US, and in the Foreign and Education Ministries and on the Executive of the Jewish Agency in Israel. Founded and headed Sciences and Arts Camps for gifted students, impressing on hundreds of campers the meaning of "freedom in responsibility". Wrote the first book in Hebrew on civics, and continued to develop the linked themes of belief, national purpose, high ethical aspirations and self-criticism in his many articles and books. His doctoral dissertation, published as American Protestantism and A Jewish State, continues to be cited as does his most recent book, Challenge to Jewish Survival. He leaves behind his children David and Mindy, Leora, and Talya & Max, grandchildren, Akiva, Eliana, Oren, Elisheva, Leah, Jessica and Mikey, Sam and Jennifer, as well as his brother Aryeh and sister Batsheva. His beloved wife of 50 years, Priscilla, predeceased him. Shiva will be held at his home in Jerusalem. A memorial service will be held in the US at a later date.

Arts, Briefly; Fresh Shakespeare?
description: A play that some scholars believe was partly written by Shakespeare is getting a major production at the Royal Shakespeare Company in Stratford, England. "Thomas More," now in previews, is a sympathetic portrayal of the man who became Henry VIII's lord chancellor but was beheaded because he would not support the king's effort to marry the second of his six wives, Anne Boleyn. Believed by some scholars to have been written around 1592 by Shakespeare, Anthony Munday and Henry Chettle -- and others, too, perhaps -- the play features a speech by More defending the rights of immigrants, delivered to quell an uprising by Londoners who feared that their jobs were at risk from Protestants fleeing persecution in Europe. No known performance of the play was recorded in Shakespeare's lifetime, perhaps because of comments written in the margin of a manuscript by the censor about the riot: "Perform this scene at your peril." PAM KENT

Arts, Briefly; 'Spamalot' Gives Broadway a Boost
description: "Spamalot" is selling a lot. The new musical, which opened to a round of mixed and positive reviews on Thursday night, had sold $1.6 million in tickets by 5 p.m. yesterday, one of Broadway's biggest single-day takes at the box office. The producers of the show, based on the 1975 film "Monty Python and the Holy Grail," released a new block of tickets just after midnight Thursday, even as the cast party at Roseland hit its stride. Directed by Mike Nichols, right, "Spamalot" also had advance ticket sales of around $20 million before it opened: also extremely impressive. Broadway records are somewhat fuzzy, but the show's day-after-opening sales put it in fairly rarefied company; "The Producers," the 2001 megahit, sold more than $3 million the day after it opened; "Hairspray," which opened in August 2002, sold about $1.5 million; and "The Lion King" sold $2.7 million the day after it opened on Broadway in November 1997. JESSE McKINLEY

title: A New Angle on the Inner Lives of Women
description: In dance, women are frequently reduced to stereotypes. Mercifully, Vicky Shick tempts her audiences with a more provocative look at their secret lives. In "Repair," her new duet, as performed Thursday night at Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church, Ms. Shick surrounds herself with female collaborators but steers clear of clichs. Her style -- beautiful, tough and even a bit perverse -- is reined in by a love of the absurd. It is feminism with a screw loose.

description: After a string of serious railroad accidents in southern Texas, Gov. Rick Perry said yesterday that he had signed an agreement with the nation's largest railroad, Union Pacific, to work toward moving freight lines out of congested urban areas.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: 5 Lawmakers Admit Fraud
description: Five lawmakers in the 450-member Parliament pleaded guilty in Cape Town to stealing public funds by converting government travel vouchers to cash, and more legislators' guilty pleas were anticipated in an estimated $2.8 million scheme widely dubbed Travelgate. The five, all members of the governing African National Congress, received fines and suspended prison sentences for converting as much as $12,600 in travel vouchers into cash, but critics noted that the fines barely matched the amount that was stolen. African National Congress leaders said in a statement that the members would face discipline, but did not mention stripping them of their seats, a move demanded by many opposition parties that called the thefts a breach of public trust. Twenty-four Parliament members are implicated in the scandal; three more may enter pleas next week. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: SIEMENS TO BUY CTI MOLECULAR FOR $967 MILLION
description: Siemens, the world's second-largest maker of medical equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy CTI Molecular Imaging for about $967 million. CTI shareholders will receive $20.50 a share in cash, or 17 percent more than CTI's closing stock price on Thursday. Siemens, based in Munich, and CTI, based in Knoxville, Tenn., have been allied since 1987 through a joint venture for equipment that helps doctors detect diseases like cancer or cardiac diseases. The companies last year also created a marketing agreement for their imaging devices. "We worked closely in a joint venture with CTI over the last 17 years now," said Michael Reitermann, president of the nuclear medicine division in Siemens Medical. "The importance of medical imaging led us to take this step now."

The score includes orchestral snippets and stretches meant to be interwoven with Shakespeare's spoken dialogue.

title: STANDARD & POOR'S RAISES HASBRO DEBT RATING
description: Standard & Poor's said yesterday that it had raised the unsecured debt rating of Hasbro, the toymaker, after changes were made in the company's credit agreement. S.&P. raised the rating to BBB- from BB+, saying the company's outlook was stable. An amendment to Hasbro's credit agreement ended a requirement that the debt be secured by assets, including inventory, in the event some financial ratios fell below a certain level, S.&P. said. Hasbro, which makes Monopoly and Trivial Pursuit, has taken steps to cut costs and those measures, along with a reduced reliance on entertainment licenses, have made earnings more consistent, S.&P. said. Hasbro is based in Pawtucket, R.I.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Business Urged To Help Fight Aids
description: Vice Premier Wu Yi urged domestic and international businesses to join the fight against AIDS, the latest step in the government's increasingly open and aggressive efforts to combat the disease. Ms. Wu, left, who also serves as health minister, said that the battle could not be won by the government alone and that companies should help their employees be tested and treated. Since she took command of China's health care system in 2003, Ms. Wu has sought to raise the alarm about AIDS. China says it has about 840,000 H.I.V./AIDS sufferers, but the true number is thought to be several times higher. The United Nations has warned that the number could rise to 10 million by 2010 unless China takes many more steps to educate the public and provide testing and comprehensive treatment. Ms. Wu made her comments at a Beijing conference organized by the New York-based Global Business Coalition on H.I.V./AIDS. Richard C. Holbrooke, the former American ambassador to the United Nations who serves as president of the coalition, said he was pleasantly surprised by Ms. Wu's candor. "Today I would remove China from the list of countries in denial," he said. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

description: The Ontario Securities Commission said yesterday that it might fine Conrad M. Black and bar him from acting as a director of a public company over claims that he diverted more than 100 million Canadian dollars ($83 million) from the publisher Hollinger International. The commission, Canada's main securities regulator, said it would hold hearings May 18 to consider staff allegations that Lord Black and his executives breached their fiduciary duties, diverted money to their holding company and lied to investors in financial statements. Hollinger International, the publisher of The Chicago Sun-Times, accused Lord Black and his associates of looting the company of more than $425 million. He has denied any wrongdoing.

title: BAUSCH & LOMB SETTLES PATENT LAWSUIT WITH ALCON
description: Bausch & Lomb, the maker of eye care products, said yesterday that it settled a patent infringement lawsuit against Alcon Inc. over a line of ocular vitamins. Under the agreement, Alcon will be allowed to continue sales of its ICaps eye vitamin product and Bausch & Lomb will get global rights to one or more Alcon patents. Bausch & Lomb filed the lawsuit in December 2003 in Federal Court in Rochester, where it is based, claiming ICaps infringed on its patent for the supplement Ocuvite PreserVision. Bausch & Lomb developed the supplement with the National Eye Institute, part of the National Institutes of Health and holds the worldwide patent rights. Alcon is based in Hunenberg, Switzerland.

Mr. Whedon, right, said he had planned to turn down the opportunity offered by the producer Joel Silver. "I wrote him a letter saying 'I'm passing and here are some thoughts,"' Mr. Whedon said. "Halfway through the letter, I really got into it." Asked what attracted him to the character, he said: "She has these extraordinary standards. She can't categorically contemplate the thought of giving up. I think it's as much a liability as it is a heroic element." Mr. Whedon's involvement was first reported in The Hollywood Reporter and Variety. The film, which does not have a release date, is to be produced by Mr. Silver and Leonard Goldberg and distributed by Warner Brothers. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHARP, BRUCE
description: SHARP--Bruce. Born August 9, 1941, Bruce Sharp was a man who was known for his big heart and dedication to family and friends as well as his pioneering entrepreneurship in the underground storage tank industry. A former Eagle Scout and Naval Reservist, Bruce Sharp started his own tank lining company in 1967 which specialized in lining underground storage tanks preventing leaks into the environment. By 1972, Bruce Sharp had developed his own tank lining material and process and began a national network of franchises that specialize in lining petroleum tanks. Bruce's revolutionary process became the industry leader by the early 1980's and shortly thereafter he began patenting ideas helping to improve underground storage tank designs. He then founded his National Leak Prevention Association, which became nationally recognized by the EPA, and by the 1990's Bruce successfully began licensing patents to various tank manufacturers on a national level. In addition to the over 100 patents and being recognized as a leader in the petroleum storage industry, Bruce Sharp held both commercial and instrument pilot licenses, was an avid scuba diver, enjoyed sailing, was a certified Dolphin Trainer, loved snow skiing and was a licensed and registered pyrotechnician. Bruce Sharp was best known as a man of true compassion by his close friends, neighbors and relatives. This was evident in Bruce's many acts of selflessness, loving heart, and his generosity to others in their time of need. Bruce R., beloved husband of Linda K. (nee Eck) for over 43 years, cherished father of Scott (Jan), Derick, Heather, Tobie, and Rebecca; dear brother of Brenda Klus, Elaine Bartlett, Lowell Sharp and Beth Hondorff. He is also survived by his grandchildren Victoria, Prairie, Jamie, and Jan-Michael. Bruce Sharp quietly passed on Tuesday, March 15th, 2005 amongst family and close friends. Friends may call on Saturday from 36PM and Sunday 3-6PM at the Jon Deitloff Funeral Centre, 4389 Spring Grove Avenue (45223). Funeral service will be at 6 PM on Sunday at the funeral home.

title: The Other Side of Paradise
description: Even the European jet-setters who have colonized the Kenyan island must be of a certain sensibility, one that's more in keeping with the backpackers who have been coming here since the 1960's. Not only is Lamu wildly inconvenient to get to, it also lacks many of the conveniences that today's boutique traveler has come to rely on. But it's a piddling sacrifice for what might be some of the world's most enchantingly empty beaches, in a place where the Islamic seafaring culture is on the brink of change after 700 years. No Swahili Disneyland this; you can rent a gorgeously renovated villa -- all plump floor cushions, carved limestone alcoves and sea views -- but you'll still step in donkey droppings while navigating the dirt alleyways on your way to one of the island's two bars, and be blasted awake with the first call to prayer before daylight. However much charm you find in that should determine whether Lamu is worth the 36 hours it takes to get there from New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAROTA, ELVIRA MARY, M.D.
description: CAROTA--Elvira Mary, M.D. Physician, passed away peacefully at the Community Hospital, Dobbs Ferry, on February 15, 2005 at the age of 91. She was born to Domenico & Immaculata (Piscitelli) Carota in New York City. She was a resident of Scarsdale, N.Y. since 1959. Elvira was extremely accomplished in her field and dedicated to her profession. She had advanced degrees in education, nursing and medicine and was a fellow in child psychiatry. She was one of only two women graduating from medical school at Long Island College in 1948. She had a lengthy work experience being affiliated with Lincoln Hall in Lincolndale, New York, Family Court, N.Y.C., St. Vincents Hospital in N.Y.C. and in Harrison, N.Y., Mercy College, Dobbs Ferry. She was chief psychiatrist at the Catholic Charities Guidance Center, N.Y.C., for ten years as well as maintaining a private practice. Elvira was well known for her good works among them she was founder of the Aged Women's Home in Ofena, Italy, where her father was born. She was, also, a member of the Dame of Malta and Lady of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem. Elvira was the recipient of many awards and accolades including a listing in Who's Who of American Women and the Italian Woman of the Year, under County Executive, Alfred DelBello. Although Elvira never married, she had a life long relationship with her sister, Ida Cavoli, who resides in Lakewood, Ohio, and her brother Dominick's children, Richard, of Eden, N.Y., Maryellen Phelan, of Chappaqua, N.Y., Patricia Endreny, of Providence, R.I., Susan Crosby, of Marlton, N.J., and Diane Bohanan, of Albany, CA. She is predeceased by her brothers, Dominick and Dante and her sisters, Bambina Whalen and Ann Carota and her grand niece, Isabel Phelan. Family and dear friends attended the funeral service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BORGESON, ROGER D.
description: BORGESON--Roger D., 76, died March 9 of complications following a fall at his home in Yarmouthport, MA. He is survived by his sister, Ruth Elliott of Harwich, MA, his daughters, Pamela Montgomery of New York, NY, Dawn Beaver of Darien, CT, and Kim Brosche of Nashville, TN, and his grandchildren, Jackson and Nicholas Beaver and Sasha Montgomery. He leaves behind his faithful canine companion, Eddie. Mr. Borgeson was a graduate of Bronxville High School, Princeton University, Columbia Law School and New York University. Mr. Borgeson had a distinguished career in human resource management for several prominent companies, in addition to founding and serving as President of Personnel Leadership Corporation, a management consultancy business. Mr. Borgeson helped establish and served as President of the Kansas City branch of the Executive Service Corps and was named Volunteer of the Year by the Center for Management Assistance of Kansas City in 1998 and 1999. A memorial service will be held at 3 PM on Saturday, March 26, 2005 at the First Parish Brewster Unitarian Universalist Church on Route 6A in Brewster, MA. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in his memory to the Sampson Fund for Veterinary Care, PO Box 1756, Orleans, MA 02653 (www.sampsonfund.org) or the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation (www.jdf.org).

My rationale is simple: I need the disorientation of someone else's property, furniture, sheets and gewgaws to escape from mundane reality, to make it easier to inhabit my characters' imaginary worlds.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Led by Northwest Airlines, major carriers raised ticket prices by $10 or more in the last few weeks, blaming the soaring price of jet fuel. Even Southwest Airlines, which limits its highest ticket price to $299 each way, said it was raising discount fares from many major cities, but only by $1 to $3 one way. American and Continental Airlines raised fares on most flights in the United States and Canada by as much as $20 round trip. The increase, matched by America West, is $5 each way on flights of 1,000 miles or less and $10 each way on longer flights. US Airways raised fares in "select markets." At the same time, these airlines have spring fare sales on thousands of domestic and international flights. United, US Airways, Northwest and American were among the airlines offering lower prices on tickets purchased for travel primarily between April and June. JetBlue Airways said this month that it was planning its own version of the East Coast shuttles run by US Airways and Delta. JetBlue said it planned regular service between Logan in Boston and LaGuardia in New York (but not to Washington), using new 100-seat regional jets. JetBlue has not set a starting date for the service, but it said a round-trip ticket would be about $100. That is lower than the walk-up prices charged by its competitors -- last week Delta quoted a shuttle price of $484.90 and US Airways $406.90 -- and it would be half the price of the high-speed Acela Express run by Amtrak. But Delta's chief marketing officer, Paul Matsen, said his company offered a price about that low to its corporate customers. In mid-March Delta joined American and Northwest in pulling pillows as a cost-saving move. It also raised the price of an alcoholic beverage by $1, to $5. But starting April 4, the airline is going to offer passengers free snacks, eliminating its food-for-sale program in coach. MICHELINE MAYNARD

title: Up Front

In his essay "Ghosts in the Machine," on Page 7, Joe Queenan rails against ghosted books, especially those supposedly written by politicians and public figures, and argues that readers (and voters) should care who wrote the words they're reading. And from London, Sarah Lyall writes on the unmasking of Jennie Erdal, whose forthcoming book, "Ghosting," documents how she wrote everything from newspaper columns to novels for the businessman and publisher Naim Attallah. For the article, Lyall interviewed both ghost and ghosted. "What struck me most in talking to them was that, like a couple in the aftermath of an emotional divorce, neither seems quite to have recovered from or resolved their lingering feelings about the other," she says.

title: Washington's Fiscal Meltdown
description: Before leaving town for a two-week spring break, Congress indulged in its own form of March Madness. The Republican majority in the House and the Senate passed budget blueprints for 2006 that slash domestic spending by upwards of $150 billion over the next five years. Yet they still managed to increase the projected deficit by more than $125 billion over the same period (and by more than $1 trillion through 2015). How is it possible to produce that much red ink while slashing spending? Easy. Just cut revenue by giving huge tax cuts to -- surprise, surprise -- high earners and wealthy investors. The lawmakers will not make any final decisions until they cobble their separate proposals into one official budget later in the year, but the early signs are all bad -- pointing to the least sensible tax cuts for the least needy recipients with no thought to the exploding deficit.

As I floated through the warren of rooms under the watchful eye of a real estate agent, I forgot to ask the hard questions about closets, plumbing, wells and septic systems. Sunlight streamed into the many-windowed living room, once a one-room schoolhouse, circa 1850. I was stirred by thoughts of alphabets recited, knuckles rapped, lessons learned. I later read that Eleanor Roosevelt had visited the school in 1937 and called it "awful," a pronouncement that humiliated local taxpayers and gave impetus to a new elementary school. Mrs. Roosevelt had stood on my threshold! That very fact made the monthly mortgage payments (not to mention the cost of replacing the roof, well pump and rotting windowsills) worth it.

description: KAPLAN--Anne. A Woman of Valor Died March 16th, 2005 of Natural Causes. No matter what she put her mind to, she succeeded. Raising a child on her own and managing to find the time to become one of the most outstanding Operating Nurses. She graduated first in her class and won numerous awards for outstanding practical, theoretical, and kindly nursing from Beth Israel Hospital School of Nursing in Brookline, MA. Although she lived here, her heart was in Israel. She received the Woman of Valor award from the State of Israel for her deep devotion and sale of Israel Bonds. She was a lifetime member of Hadassah and received the Myrtle Wreath Award. She was dedicated to her family but always made time to contribute to the community. She was a Member of Beth Israel Nurse's Alumni, Hebrew Rehabilitation for the Aged, Sisterhood Temple Tifereth Israel, Sisterhood Aqudas Achim, President Circle Justice Brandeis Society, Brandeis University Woman's Division Friends of Yeshiva, and Beth Israel Synagogue Sisterhood. She even awarded two scholarships for nurses in Israel. In 1990 when her only son passed away, she established an endowment at Brandeis University: The Richard Kaufman '58 Memorial Prize for Leadership and Academic Excellence. She leaves three grandchildren Shari Kaufman-Levins and husband Michael Levins of Westport, CT and Kenneth Kaufman of Manhattan NY and three great grandchildren, Richard, Zachary and Alexandra, two sisters Eva Sherman, and Pricilla Kublin, as well as several nieces and nephews. title: World Class
description: Had it not been for Eaton Hall, the Duke of Westminster's English estate, would a French convent girl named Coco Chanel have seen the luxe in mannish tweeds? Chanel's love affairs often involved travel, and both pursuits were to influence her imagination. She was not alone in this respect. The explorations that took place in the latter part of the 19th century, especially to Arabia, fed the romantic longings of a string of remarkable women, as Lesley Blanch's book "The Wilder Shores of Love" makes clear. By the time Paul Poiret conceived his Oriental robes, much of fashionable Europe felt the lure of the East. Nowadays, with three or four collections a year to produce, and shops to be filled in Beijing and Moscow, designers can't afford the luxury of a grand tour. They must keep their own trains running. Which doesn'tmean that travel doesn't figure into fashion. Miuccia Prada based last year's spring collection around a travel theme, using skirts printed with picture postcards to suggest that the best way to open one's mind is to see a new country. Travelis an integral part of John Galliano's research at Dior; a trip to Egypt in 2003 yielded beautiful dresses in bandages of black and white organdy that reasserted the connection between Pharonic elegance and the sphinxlike poses of 1950's fashion photography. At the most recent haute couture shows in Paris, Jean Paul Gaultier made a mental voyage to Africa, picking up the trail of Yves Saint Laurent and Azzedine Alaa; Valentino named each dress after a world-class destination, as if thinking of his jet-setting clientele. Indeed, behind the chinoiserie prints and "Viva Las Vegas" showstoppers is an awareness of how important it is today for a couturier to be perceived as an international brand.Some designers, like Karl Lagerfeld and Alexander McQueen, consciously avoid travel themes, mainly on the grounds that it seems too easy to throw some astrakhan on the collar of a coat and say, "Here we have Russia." They prefer to explore moods or periods. The 60's and 70's saw a lessening of travel's influence in fashion, as designers felt the social vibrations of youth, political protest and rock 'n' roll. With the emergence of global luxury groups like Gucci in the mid-90's, there was a renewed interest in fashion's looking exotic. Still, a designer can be genuinely moved by his wanderlust, few more so than Francisco Costa at Calvin Klein. After visiting Yellowstone, he returned to New York and created a series of jersey dresses that brilliantly captured the natural Technicolor of a Western hot spring. It was better than a View-Master. CATHY HORYN

The team from 100 miles to the northeast, Cincinnati, was scoring at will and gaining momentum with every rim-rattling dunk.

In the 1936 movie "The Garden of Allah," Dietrich (her hair as immaculately coiffed as her tent's perfectly art-directed drapes) basks in the most luxurious campsite imaginable, not to mention in the love of a renegade monk. Sadly for anyone who has ventured into the great outdoors in search of similar stylishness, luxury camping has proved to be an oxymoron. Until now.

title: THE FACE OF SHANGHAIA
description: Kentucky Fried Chicken, DVD's, cellphones, chinese.yahoo.com: the Westernization of Shanghai continues at a 21st-century pace. In this, the most dynamic city in Asia, the population is ambitious; the foreign investment is the highest in China; and the noise, traffic and construction are nonstop. Still, people take time to sing and do tai chi in the park, and the most frequent crime is bicycle theft. Clearly, this is a new Shanghai. Look now, or you'll miss it.

Those searching for a cure for diabetes or Parkinson's disease have now taken their case to state capitols, where legislators have started to listen.

title: The Politics of Ibrahim Parlak
description: This is a story about the trickery of time. Sometimes the world changes on a dime, as it did on Sept. 11, and with the transformation of the present, the past, too, can suddenly take on a different hue. This, it seems, is what happened to Ibrahim Parlak. Indeed, it's tough to choose the tense in which to tell his story. He runs -- or ran -- a Middle Eastern restaurant. It's in Harbert, Mich., a small summer resort town, an hour and a half by car from Chicago, along the Lake Michigan shoreline. Parlak is a Kurd from Turkey and had been in this country for 13 years when, on the morning of July 29 last year, he was arrested by officers with the Department of Homeland Security and taken into custody. He was charged with crimes relating to his time in Turkey, when he had been involved with a Kurdish separatist group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIZACK, MARTIN A. MD. PH.D.
description: RIZACK--Martin A. MD. Ph.D. The Medical Letter mourns the loss of Martin Rizack on March 7, 2005. Martin, who was a distinguished researcher at Rockefeller University, was an integral part of our publication, beginning in 1966 as a member of our editorial board. One of the first people in medicine to understand the importance of drug interactions, he was the author of "The Medical Letter Handbook of Adverse Drug Interactions", the first book on the subject to be widely read by physicians. His clear vision of new drugs and the place they would achieve in practice were invaluable to The Medical Letter and an inestimable service to the medical community.

description: FOREIGN ENTANGLEMENTS -- Opposition to Syria's military occupation and continued political domination of Lebanon brought out hundreds of thousands of protesters in downtown Beirut on Monday, where some spread a giant Lebanese flag, right. It was their largest mass rally to date. On the same day in Guatemala, the flashpoint was a new free trade agreement with the United States that critics said would be ruinous for local farmers; demonstrators threw rocks and bottles at riot police in the capital, below.

title: A Fairy Tale For Grown-Ups
description: Terms like "fairy tale" and "Cinderella story" are used so often that we lose sight of what they really mean. The structure of the fairy tale has always been one in which the heroine starts out in good shape (daughter of a king, for example), loses what she has and finally manages to triumph against all odds. Camilla fits the structure perfectly. She had Charles originally, lost him and experienced years of ridicule, isolation and scandal. Now, against all odds, Camilla has managed to regain him. That is just about as classically enchanting as it gets in real life.

title: Breaking Away
description: I was profoundly touched by Joseph Lelyveld's memoir of his parents' divorce and his early journalistic career (March 6). At the same time, I felt privy to some of those events, as I was a young congregant at Fairmount Temple in Beachwood, Ohio, in those days. Rabbi Lelyveld's beating in Mississippi informed many lives. Indeed, I remember the pride I took in the honor of his appearance in the chapel at my bar mitzvah ceremony, his head still bandaged from the assault. To this 13-year-old bar mitzvah, his presence that day was a powerful example of the meaning of the struggle for social justice and its connection to my community and life. I suspect that, sadly, there are few young people today who can honestly say that their rabbi or minister has ever been their role model in the way Rabbi Arthur Lelyveld was for me.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEDZWATER, WAYNE
description: PEDZWATER -- Wayne. 48. Passed away at home surrounded by family and friends after a long battle with stomach cancer. He leaves his wife, Patty ForbesPedzwater, his mother, a sister and countless family and friends. A memorial service will be held at The Little Church Around the Corner (1 East 29th Street) at 11 am, on Thursday, March 24, 2005.

title: The Things They Carried
description: Apparently, and reassuringly for those of us who have been known to splurge on them, there is a collective unconscious of handbags, a kind of archetypal shape memory that has existed throughout time and across continents. It seems that the impulse to carry just the right bag -- an Herms Birkin or a limited edition Murakami Vuitton or whatever currently seems to signify your personality and taste to the world -- is not just a recent, Western preoccupation. In the Sepik region of Papua New Guinea, mountain dwellers would announce their wealth and individuality by hanging ornamental seashells from their woven bags, while now we dangle expensive doodads from a Prada crocodile satchel. The effect is the same: in the choice of handbag, image and utility merge.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Before we cremate them, I want to find out who is right and who is wrong, who is a victim and who is a killer. What I need to know first is, who were the killers."

title: Williamsburg Reinvented
description: IN the last decade, Williamsburg in Brooklyn has been a first stop for young people new to the city, just out of college. As they have grown up, the neighborhood has too, evolving from dive bars and movie rental joints to chic sushi restaurants and designer furniture emporiums.

title: The Joys of Ear Cleaning
description: My 32-year-old stepson, Harper, has just broken up with his girlfriend, and my 12-year-old daughter is traveling with her father in Africa, so Harper and I both find ourselves at loose ends for the holidays. Why not travel together? We thus end up in Hong Kong on New Year's Day, looking for somewhere to go in mainland China. Our criteria: We want to find a place that neither of us has been to, that is off the beaten track and that has as many magical, spiritual properties as possible.

He was the man who proposed "containment," the cornerstone of the cold war, as a way to oppose the Soviet Union.

description: A 25-year-old Queens man who was coming home from work yesterday morning was stabbed and critically injured after he got into an quarrel with several young men on a street corner, the police said.

title: Memory of Activist Sister Is Now Brother's Mission
description: DENVER, March 19 - David Stang was retired and thought that the days ahead would be marked by the easy tread of his gardening and his books. But the killing last month of his sister Dorothy, a Roman Catholic nun in Brazil who had made powerful enemies in the Amazon Basin working on behalf of the homeless, turned that plan upside down.

title: The Talk
description: Real Re al / (real, rel) / adj. / true and actual; not imaginary, alleged or ideal: a reality television show based on the real-life experiences of an heiress working in a duty-free store; free of pretense, falsehood or affectation; more than ever, a part of the canon of travel connoisseurship, e.g., "Laos is so much more real than Bhutan!" or "Are those real Masai beaded flip-flops?"

title: The Traveler's Manifesto
description: The last time I had political ambitions was back in the eighth grade, when I decided to run for head boy at my quaint little private school in Winnipeg, Manitoba. With a bit of crafty lobbying, some outstanding graphic design and a solid five-point platform, I managed to knock out the competition in the course of an afternoon. My administration quickly came under fire because some half-wit consumed too much vodka at a fund-raising formal. But we managed to stay in office by coming up with an "improve the toilets" initiative, which pleased classmates and clergy alike. For the next 15 years, though I reported on politics and mastered some aspects of being an office politician, I never had much interest in public office proper. Recently, however, I've had a shift in aspirations.

title: Miami Refines Its Playoff Form, but the Knicks Can't Find Theirs
description: MIAMI, March 19 - There was a time not long ago when the Miami Heat would break New York hearts in rough-and-tumble postseason melees and grind-it-out series played in April and May.

title: Toward a Unified Theory of Black America
description: Roland G. Fryer Jr. is 27 years old and he is an assistant professor of economics at Harvard and he is black. Yes, 27 is young to be any kind of professor anywhere. But after what might charitably be called a slow start in the scholarly life, Fryer has been in a big hurry to catch up. He was in fact only 25 when he went on the job market, gaining offers from -- well, just about everywhere. He abruptly ended his job search by accepting an invitation to join the Society of Fellows at Harvard, one of academia's most prestigious research posts. This meant he wouldn't be teaching anywhere for three years. The Harvard economics department told Fryer to take its offer anyway; he could have an office and defer his teaching obligation until the fellowship was done.

title: The Remix; Mondovino/Globalization by the Glass
description: "A wine reveals the person who makes it and the place it comes from when it's true," says Jonathan Nossiter, the director of "Mondovino," the documentary-film equivalent of "Fast Food Nation," which opens this week in New York.Nossiter argues for preservingthe soul of wine against the growing trend of massproduction. To that end, he seeks out artisanal vineyardswhere, he says, the integrity ofthe wine is directly related to theland and the personality of the owner. Most viewers will leave determined to cancel their Wine Spectator subscription and drink only terroir bottles.To stock your cellar, the New York terroir-only importer Neil Rosenthal, who appears in the film, gives his current top five.

title: Kitchen Voyeur: Girl Meets Grill
description: Red-haired, slender and beaming, the daredevil Chelsea cook Kate Hirson braves wind, rain and whatever else God throws at her to get to her grilled lamb. On a recent gray and gusty afternoon, she fired a bungee cord over an arbor on her rooftop garden and strapped down a tarp to protect the grill underneath. "I never cook the same thing twice," she said. "I have lots of friends who are vegetarians, and the repetition of the vegetarian menu is depressing. I want the thrills!"

title: Corrections

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: The Remix; Never Neverland
description: With miles of empty beaches and an emerald green sea, the Gulf of Oman should be the next St.-Tropez. So how is it that P. Diddy and his entourage haven't dropped anchor yet? Location, location, location. Bordered by Saudi Arabia and Yemen, across the gulf from Iran, Oman is not exactly a draw for Americans. It's a shame, as the Al Bustan Palace hotel, on one of the only privately owned beaches in the country, is the ne plus ultra of high-end beach resorts. The hotel, a golden-domed, 250-room palace, was built for Sultan Qaboos bin Said. Everything from the lobby to the doorknobs is gilded. But don't expect to get your own golden glow: only the most intrepid bather will feel comfortable next to the shrouded Omani women. And then there are the sultan's rules. Tourists must register with the ministry, so it'll feel like your taxi driver knows your itinerary better than you do. And that Ers bikini? That's a lot of skin. For a hassle-free vacation, head inland to watch the camel races. ANN MARIE GARDNER

title: Suburbia, at Long Last, in Academia
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. - IN some ways, all academic conferences sound the same, so when Hofstra University staged a symposium on all things suburban on Friday and yesterday, the topics had a familiar ring of cheeky certitude.

title: Gander Airport: When the Going Was Good
description: Visitors to the island of Newfoundland, the easternmost part of Canada, are traditionally welcomed with a Screech In. This ancient ceremony, by which one attains honorary citizenship, involves kissing a cod on the lips -- or, absent that, a puffin's posterior -- and downing a shot of Screech Rum, Atlantic Canada's "golden elixir." Foreign dignitaries and heads of state are not excluded. His Royal Highness Prince Philip was treated to a variation of the ritual when he was the guest of honor alongside the queen at the inauguration of a new terminal at Gander International Airport in 1959.

title: A Fairy Tale For Grown-Ups
description: I appreciated Daphne Merkin's trenchant, funny and culturally counterintuitive assessment of the Charles-Camilla-Diana triangle in its current incarnation (The Way We Live Now, March 6). But in her effort to appreciate the unfashionably mature love of Charles for his "devoted old bag" Camilla, Merkin reduces Diana to a star-struck media hound. Instead, Merkin might have mentioned Diana's evolution from a nave 19-year-old into someone who devoted her own celebrity, despite royal-family resistance, to such human rights causes as the fight against land mines and the need for society to embrace those struck by AIDS. There may be some twits flitting about, royal and otherwise, but Diana wasn't one of them.

title: Awaiting a Smoking Ban? Don't Hold Your Breath
description: Applause -- real, un-ironic clapping -- broke out last week in Committee Room 6 of the State House when the Senate Health, Human Services and Senior Citizens committee approved a bill to ban smoking in restaurants and casinos.

title: Listen to Your Mother. And Everyone Else.
description: COUNTRY moms might send their kids out to find the nicest pine cones, but here in the city, it's words we collect. "Listen up," I instruct my daughters, Jane, 9 and Lena, 7. "Whoever overhears the best stuff wins."

title: Can a Parent Learn to Talk?
description: ONE school night this month I sidled up to Alexander, my 15-year-old son, and stroked his cheek in a manner I hoped would seem casual. Alex knew better, sensing by my touch, which lingered just a moment too long, that I was sneaking a touch of the stubble that had begun to sprout near his ears. A year ago he would have ignored this intrusion and returned my gesture with a squeeze. But now he recoiled, retreating stormily to his computer screen. That, and a peevish roll of his eyes, told me more forcefully than words, Mom, you are so busted!

title: 'Who the Hell's in It'
Suffolk Legislature Tables Measure on Gas Plant
description: After lengthy debate, the Suffolk County Legislature tabled a measure on Tuesday that would have put the county in opposition to a proposed $700 million floating liquefied natural gas plant in Long Island Sound.

Mitchell of Houston. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan.

title: Bad Connections
description: In the 16th century, Venetian and French glassmakers perfected a technique of coating glass with an alloy of silver to produce an effective mirror. Mirrors soon proliferated in public spaces and private homes, and owning a pocket or hand mirror became a marker of status. The mirror, you might say, was an early personal technology -- ingenious, portable, effective -- and like all such technologies, it changed its users. By giving us, for the first time, a readily available image of ourselves that matched what others saw, it encouraged self-consciousness and introspection and, as some worried, excesses of vanity.

title: A Life in Reruns: Watch Out, the Ending Goes Quickly
description: THANKS to television, the baby boomer life cycle is as well known to every American child as that of the monarch butterfly. The infant boomer toddles around shooting cap guns, while a well-coifed 1950's mom watches benevolently; soon afterward the organism's hair grows long, as he dons bell-bottoms and flashes a peace sign. A cocoon period involving key parties and shag rugs follows, and the boomer re-emerges, with thinning hair and a ponytail, to observe the rise of the Internet. It's always entertaining, coming as it does with a rock 'n' roll soundtrack, but we never see its terminus.

title: Blogged Down
description: Q: Should I call you Jim Guckert or Jeff Gannon?

title: Home Sweet Studio
description: THERE'S a tambourine in Adam Pierce's bedroom, two upright pianos and some Balinese gamelan instruments in his living room, a Celtic harp near his television set. Piled up next to the basement stairs are four drum kits in their cases. Take a left at the laundry room and there's the recording studio, a low-ceiling den where drums, a guitar and a vibraphone are set up and battered amplifiers and reverb units are stacked against a wall. The control room, where Mr. Pierce records nearly everything on an old 16-track reel-to-reel tape recorder -- 13 of the tracks still work -- is a few steps away. It smells a little dank, since bathroom pipes run behind the mixing board.

description: SURPRISES were absent from the agenda Thomas R. Suozzi described in his State of the County address on Monday. Not that he needed any. In most circles, fixing Nassau County, fixing Albany and reinventing the concept of suburbia would be considered a full plate.

title: Aren't Juries Grand?
description: I'm on a grand jury. We've been given cases involving someone who views pornography on his computer behind locked doors and someone caught in the presence of marijuana. The assistant D.A. indicates that I shouldn't abstain from voting, but my conscience won't let me sleep if I make felons out of such people. May I vote not to indict? L.D., Fountain Hills, Ariz.

title: Wanted: A New Cheerleader for Opera

The women got into a spat over who was whose best friend, then kidded the wholesome Ms. Shore about her current beau, the heartthrob actor Burt Reynolds.

title: VIEWING CHIMPANZEES IN KIBALE NATIONAL PARK, FEB. 1, 2005
description: Lynn Robinson, from San Rafael, Calif. After three months volunteering in South Africa, I decided I'd take a holiday to Uganda. At Kibale, we took an easy hike into the forest and within 10 minutes you could hear the chimps really loud. Our guide said, "They're greeting you." They sound as if they're screaming bloody murder, but they're not. There was a whole family in a huge fig tree. We were watching them jump from branch to branch, and also preen. They take the ticks out of each other, and they actually eat them for protein. It's a bit disgusting. The thing you think of is "The Jungle Book," the bare necessities of life. They're not going out to work every day and slogging through the traffic, but they do what they have to, preen and eat and defecate, so you have to watch out from underneath. As told to Seth Kugel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLAZER, WALTER
description: BLAZER--Walter, age 87, March 10, 2005. He was born January 8, 1918 to the late David and Anna Karper Blazer. He grew up in NYC, where his family settled after fleeing the persecution of Jews in Poland. He became a musician, studying classical voice at Juilliard, only to be interrupted by World War II. He was part of the African invasion. As an Army lieutenant in the 9th Infantry, he was wounded in North Africa. Later he was assigned to psychological warfare in Europe. In Italy he met his wife-to-be, Maria Vernole. They came to America in 1951 and etched out a life in music, supplemented by hard work in a print shop. They raised two children. Walter was a most generous and insightful man, with humor always ready. He followed world affairs closely. He sang with the highest musical standards in the great NY concert halls, and throughout the US and Europe. He was on the voice faculty of the Manhattan School of Music, and taught extensively in Florence, Italy and in the warmth of his home in Montclair, NJ. Walter is survived by his wife, Maria Vernole Blazer, Dickson, TN; his daughter, Judith Blazer, NY, NY; his son and daughter-in-law, Dr. David and Regina Blazer, Dickson, TN; his grandchildren Nikki and Ben Blazer; his sister and brother-in-law, Ruth and Stanley Rosenberg, NY, NY; his nephews and niece, Marnin, David, and Nina Rosenberg. He leaves us with a legacy to be reckoned with. He was a powerful presence and will be deeply missed. In keeping with his wishes, his memorial service will be held at a later date aboard a boat in NY Harbor and his cremains will be ceremoniously scattered in "his" beloved Hudson River.

title: Inside the List
description: GOD SQUAD: Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins, the authors of the apocalyptic thrillers in the "Left Behind" series, have had their winning streak snapped. The pair's previous six novels all entered the Times hardcover fiction list at No. 1; their new one, "The Rising," makes its debut this week at No. 2, behind James Patterson and Howard Roughan's "Honeymoon." LaHaye and Jenkins's new book tells the not-so-cheerful story of the birth of the Antichrist to a literature professor named Marilena; it's the first of three planned prequels to the events of the first book in the "Left Behind" series. "The Rising" may not have landed at No. 1, but LaHaye and Jenkins remain an outsize force in the publishing world. The previous 12 books in the "Left Behind" series have sold more than 40 million copies; these guys have even sponsored a truck on Nascar's Craftsman Truck Series circuit. (This was probably a doomed experiment; who wanted to drive a race truck with the words "left behind" stamped on it?) LaHaye and Jenkins have not been bothered by critics who find their books anti-Catholic, anti-Jewish and anti-United Nations, or by those who've pointed out that their prose does not exactly crackle and pop. "Pedestrian writing, thin characters -- I can handle the criticism," Jenkins told Newsweek's David Gates last year. "I write to pedestrians. And I am a pedestrian. I write the best I can. . . . The literary-type writers, I admire them. I wish I was smart enough to write a book that's hard to read."

title: Op-Chart; Two Years and Counting
description: Two years after the invasion of Iraq, the rising American death toll has prompted some commentators to suggest that poor and minority soldiers are bearing the brunt of the war's human cost. An analysis of casualties by the Center for American Progress in Washington suggests otherwise. The majority of the dead are Army and Marine enlisted personnel, white men in their mid-20's, who graduated from high schools in major cities and suburban areas. (Navy and Air Force personnel accounted for less than 3 percent.) Moreover, a look at the poverty rates in the high schools many of them attended suggests that these young men and women are from working-class communities that are neither disproportionately poor nor rich.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERN, HARRY
description: STERN--Harry. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Harry Stern of Media, PA, a long-time, ardent friend. Mr. Stern was a founding member of the Philadelphia Chapter in 1947. He served in various capacities on the regional and national board of directors, and was a life trustee of the Board of Regents and an honorary member of the Technion International Board of Governors. A mechanical engineer and businessman committed to developing Israel's technological edge, he established the Harry Stern Family Center for Continuing Education and External Studies to provide career-long training for industry professionals. A Technion Guardian who reached the highest level of commitment to the ATS, the Technion and Israel, Mr. Stern received the Albert Einstein Award, the highest ATS honor, and a Technion honorary fellowship. We extend our condolences to his children Sheva Mann Adler, Rebecca Herschkopf, Sareva Naor, Zelda Rosenzweig, Chayim Stern, Jerome Stern, and the entire Stern family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Stephen A. Laser, President Evelyn Berger, Chairman Melvyn H. title: Strange Lands

Not that he likes to wear socks with his sandals, but as the curator of "Universal Experience: Art, Life, and the Tourist's Eye," at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago, through June 5, he has assembled a rambling, nonlinear exhibition that's a departure from the predictable museum show. "The culture of complaint for art critics is similar to the culture of complaint for tourists," Bonami insists. "We are so used to the prepackaged experience, we get upset when we don't find what we are looking for."

title: The Right Stuff
description: Valextra, founded in 1937, is known for making streamlined luggage from exotic materials like crocodile hide and ostrich leg. Maria Callas traveled with Valextra trunks. Gianni Agnelli and Aristotle Onassis were clients as well. The company's most famous model -- the compasso d'oro of 1954, a "24-hour bag" made for air travel -- is included in the Museum of Modern Art's modern-design archives. All this was achieved without a visible label or logo -- remarkable in today's brand-mad world. Valextra's handmade quality and sleek lines spoke for themselves. They still do, thanks to Massimo Suppancig, the Italian fashion executive who saved the prestigious but fading company two years ago. Suppancig, who grew up in Trieste but traveled often to Milan with his family, has always loved both the beauty of the past and the excitement of the future -- the ideal sensibility for his current post. "The first thing I learned from my grandfather was a way of talking and moving and behaving," the elegant Suppancig says in his trademark immaculate white turtleneck. "I try to translate that spirit into a product that now belongs to me." JOSH PATNER

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Audio-Video Company Acquired
description: Avid Technology, a maker of editing systems for audio and video, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a rival, Pinnacle Systems, for $462 million in cash and stock. Under the terms of the agreement, Avid will exchange 0.0869 of one Avid share plus $1 cash for each Pinnacle share. That equates to 6.2 million Avid shares plus $71.3 million in cash, based on Avid's closing stock price on Friday. The offer represented a premium of 30 percent to the closing price of Pinnacle on Friday. Pinnacle shares climbed 77 cents, or 15 percent, to $5.74. Shareholders of Pinnacle, based in Mountain View, Calif., will own about 15 percent of Avid after the transaction. Pinnacle, based in Tewksbury, Mass., makes video-editing tools for professional and consumer markets.

The production is the first attempt at opera by Bernd Eichinger, the acclaimed German filmmaker who produced and wrote the screenplay for "Downfall," the Academy Award-nominated film about Hitler's last days. And without an original episode of ABC's hit "Desperate Housewives" in the mix, CBS was also No. 1 among adults 18 to 49, as the original movie "Spring Break Shark Attack" -- a cautionary tale about partying college students being eaten by schools of vicious tiger sharks -- brought in that younger demographic. NBC ranked third, behind CBS and ABC for the night, both in total viewers and among 18-to-49-year-olds. Its 8 p.m. offering, the reality boxing show "The Contender," featured Najai Turpin, below, the contestant who committed suicide last month, in a losing match. The show, which made its debut in its regular Sunday time period last week, attracted 7.8 million viewers, a stronger showing than the previous week's audience of 6.7 million. But it was still beaten by CBS's "Cold Case," a repeat of ABC's "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" and Fox's "Simpsons." KATE AURTHUR

description: In its eighth annual report on bicycling in New York City, Transportation Alternatives, an advocacy group for pedestrians and cyclists, gave the city a C-plus for its cycling environment, the same grade as a year ago, but it gave a B to the government's efforts, up from a B-minus last year. The group concluded that bicycling in the city became "a little safer and more convenient" in 2004. The number of city residents using bicycles every day rose to a record 113,000 last year, but 3,000 cyclists were injured and 15 were killed in traffic accidents, according to the group. Kay Sarlin, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Transportation, said the department had added 100 miles of bike routes and installed 2,800 bike racks and would make additional improvements a priority. title: Trading the Dangers of War for the Perils of Love
description: For the new production of Handel's remarkable opera "Orlando" that opened on Sunday afternoon, the New York City Opera has assembled a splendid cast, headed by the exciting countertenor Bejun Mehta in the title role. Still, if a Handel opera is not to seem like a stagy succession of da capo arias in which characters simply posture themselves and proclaim emotions, a production must help the singers penetrate the beguiling musical surface to tap the dramatic subtext. The director Chas Rader-Shieber's enchanting production, introduced two years ago at the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., does this and more.

title: Gas Money
description: GAS MONEY -- For weeks, airlines have been essentially asking passengers to chip in for gas by raising fares about $10 each way. Staggered by sharply rising fuel costs, the major airlines have managed to raise fares twice in the last month. And they are trying again. But it was not clear last night whether the latest attempt to add $10 to fares, begun last week by Continental Airlines and matched over the weekend by its competitors, was going to collapse. After Delta Air Lines retreated yesterday morning from the latest fare increase, Continental also abandoned it, according to The Associated Press. Competitors were assessing their positions last night. Still, with oil prices expected to remain at record levels, industry experts predict that fares will keep rising. "Some leisure fares are now $50 more round-trip than they were Feb. 1," said Terry Trippler, an online air-fare analyst. "I don't think this is the end of it. I think we're going to see more fare increases."

title: Germany Says That Citigroup Broke No Law in Its Trading
description: A spokeswoman for the Frankfurt prosecutor's office said yesterday that employees of Citigroup would not face criminal charges there from $16.4 billion in trades that roiled European bond markets in August.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Man Indicted In Banker's Death
description: A Queens man accused of impersonating a police officer and fatally shooting a bank manager in January has been indicted in the killing, the Nassau County district attorney said yesterday. A grand jury charged the defendant, Reginald Gousse, 31, with first-degree murder, second-degree murder, attempted robbery and criminal impersonation in the death of James Gottlieb, who managed an HSBC branch in Cedarhurst. Prosecutors have said that Mr. Gousse pulled over Mr. Gottlieb on Jan. 5 and shot him after demanding to see his official identification. Patrick O'Gilfoil Healy (NYT)

title: Researchers Toil With Genes on the Fringe of a Cure
description: In her laboratory at the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, Dr. Huda Y. Zoghbi and her research team has found the genetic roots of at least two crippling neurological diseases -- Rett syndrome and spinocerebellar ataxias.

title: A Nation Gripped by a Drama of Life and Death (11 Letters)
The Anniversary of World War II Is an Invitation to Continue Fighting
description: There was a lot of talk 10 years ago, when the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II was being celebrated, that the great war was finally over. Europe was one again, Germany and Japan (not to mention Italy) were fully back in the democratic fold, the "greatest generation" was having a grand last hurrah, a new century was about to dawn. Now here comes the 60th, and suddenly the old resentments are out again in force.

title: Spain's unity
Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Student Hurt When Gun Goes Off
description: A freshman at New Utrecht High School accidentally shot himself in the leg yesterday when a gun inside his book bag discharged in the middle of an English class, the authorities said. The student, whom classmates identified as Paul Henry, 15, was taken to Lutheran Medical Center in stable condition, the authorities said. The police said he was not immediately charged.. New Utrecht does not require that students pass through metal detectors. School officials said there were about 30 students in the room when the .45-caliber handgun went off. "Everyone was scared," said a classmate, Alexis Napolitano, 14. The police said another student, identified as Danny Rhames, 17, was charged with weapons possession after trying to dispose of the gun and book bag.

title: As Police Overtime Increases and Budgets Tighten, Hiring New Officers Is Not a Priority
description: The Police Department is spending more than $900,000 a week on overtime pay for counterterrorism measures, but with city agencies under orders to control costs, there are no plans to hire many more officers anytime soon, police officials said yesterday.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES WILL BUY SECURITY SOFTWARE VENDOR
description: The United Technologies Corporation, a conglomerate that serves the building systems and aerospace industries, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a security software developer, Lenel Systems International Inc., for $400 million. United Technologies said that the acquisition would add access-control and smart-card technology to the equipment, guards and monitoring offered by its Chubb unit.

Mr. Wagoner bought 50,000 shares at an average price of about $29.65, a G.M. spokesman said. G.M. stock rose $1.07, to $29.69 a share.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: U.S. Grades Annan Plan
description: The United States welcomed Secretary General Kofi Annan's new proposals for sweeping change at the United Nations but said it had doubts about his recommendation that the Security Council be the arbiter of when military action was justified. "We very much appreciate the serious effort that the secretary general's report represents," Adam Ereli, the deputy State Department spokesman, said, adding, "Frankly, we're skeptical that any kind of resolution on the use of force would be helpful." The Security Council angered Washington two years ago by refusing to back the invasion of Iraq. In a speech to the General Assembly, Mr. Annan recommended enlarging the 15-member Security Council, scrapping the discredited Human Rights Commission and redefining terrorism to end any defense of its use for political purposes. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOWELL, STANLEY H.
description: LOWELL--Stanley H. The City University of New York mourns the death of Stanley Lowell, a distinguished alumnus, civic leader, and longtime supporter of higher education. A graduate of City College, Stanley was a former Trustee and past President of the City College Alumni Association. Over the years he had lectured at City College and had been a visiting professor at the Graduate School. He received the John H. Finley medal from the CCNY Alumni Association in 1980. He was awarded an honorary degree from CUNY in 1981. A human rights advocate with enduring integrity, Stanley was Chairman of the New York City Commission on Human Rights in the early 1960s. He had a deep compassion for those in greatest need. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

title: STINGER INTRODUCES STUN GUN TO COMPETE WITH TASER
description: Stinger Systems, a maker of electric stun guns, said that it had begun producing a gun exclusively for law enforcement and military use to compete with Taser International. Its weapon, the Stinger, can reach targets as far as 31 feet and comes with video and audio functions that can document use, the company said. It will be sent to about 1,000 police and law enforcement agencies for evaluation, Stinger said. Stock in the company, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., rose $1.98, to $11.68.

title: BBC announces 2,050 more job cuts
The Return of Latin America's Left
description: Oakland, Calif. - THE left is in power in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, the Dominican Republic and Venezuela. With this month's inauguration of Tabar Vzquez as president of Uruguay, this trend will likely continue. The year 2006 could bring a similar leftward shift in Mexico and Peru, while in Bolivia the Socialist opposition has been setting much of the political agenda since the fall of President Gonzalo Snchez de Lozada in 2003. Although this movement is hardly homogeneous (there are major differences between Venezuela's Hugo Chvez, Chile's Ricardo Lagos and Brazil's Luiz Incio Lula da Silva), the continental pattern is clear.

description: For hunters, the most dangerous game may be turkeys, at least in Pennsylvania. An analysis of hunting accidents in that state has found that more turkey hunters are accidentally shot than hunters of deer, pheasant, grouse, rabbits or squirrels.

description: Simon Eisdorfer, a retired New York City police chief who developed the department's widely emulated hostage negotiation team, died on Wednesday in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 87 and lived in Cedarhurst, N.Y.

description: Rome Neal, the artistic director of the Nuyorican Poets Cafe theater program, is not working as an usher in the bio-play "Monk," about the life of the jazz musician Thelonious Monk. But that's about the only thing he isn't doing. According to the program, he is the star, the choreographer, the producer, the director (along with Laurence Holder), the lighting, set, sound and costume designer. And for good measure, he handled publicity.

But then these women just kind of walked onto the painting," said Leila Kubba, an artist who returned last year to her native Iraq for the first time in nearly two decades to take stock and seek inspiration.

description: YONKERS, March 21 - Mayor Philip A. Amicone recently ordered that all computers at Yonkers City Hall and at the Board of Education be blocked from connecting to a Web site he deemed particularly scurrilous.

description: WASHINGTON, March 21 - John B. Taylor, the Treasury Department's under secretary for international affairs, said Monday that he would resign on April 22, the latest in a series of top-level resignations at the department since the elections in November.

title: Time to Litigate Those Airbus Subsidies
description: Negotiations between the United States and Europe over Europe's subsidies to Airbus aren't going well -- to say the least. A contentious telephone session late last Friday between Peter Mandelson, the European Union's trade commissioner, and Robert Zoellick, the American deputy secretary of state, ended abruptly, with an irate Mr. Mandelson narrowly winning the race to hang up first. Mr. Zoellick then publicly derided the European Union for its refusal to eliminate key Airbus subsidies. A spokesman said the European trade minister was "completely surprised" by the outburst.

title: Goldman Sachs Buys Zilkha, Expanding Interest in Wind Power
description: Goldman Sachs said yesterday that it was strengthening its investment in wind energy with the acquisition of Zilkha Renewable Energy, one of the nation's largest developers of wind projects. The deal comes after several similar transactions since the start of the year, signaling robust commercial interest in wind-powered electricity generation.

He also leaves a twin brother Joel and adoring sister Elaine. A brief service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81st Street today, March 22 at 12PM. Interment to follow at Mount Hebron. A memorial service will be held in April. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Prostate Cancer Foundation, 1250 Fourth Street, Santa Monica, CA 90401. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Renault Joins Venture
description: Renault, the French carmaker, will form a 125 million euro ($165 million) venture with Mahindra & Mahindra to make Logan sedans in India. The venture will build as many as 50,000 cars a year beginning in 2007 for Indian buyers, Mahindra said. Mahindra, India's biggest maker of sport utility vehicles and tractors, will own 51 percent of the company, with Renault holding the remainder. The Logan accord was signed by Louis Schweitzer, Renault's chief executive, above, and Keshub Mahindra, chairman of Mahindra, in Mumbai, where the Indian company is based.

title: A Blow to the Rule of Law
description: If you are in a "persistent vegetative state" and there is a dispute about whether to keep you alive, your case will probably go no further than state court -- unless you are Terri Schiavo. President Bush signed legislation yesterday giving Ms. Schiavo's parents a personal right to sue in federal court. The new law tramples on the principle that this is "a nation of laws, not of men," and it guts the power of the states. When the commotion over this one tragic woman is over, Congress and the president will have done real damage to the founders' careful plan for American democracy.

title: Clear Channel Loses Case With Rival
description: A federal jury in Chicago ruled yesterday that the entertainment giant Clear Channel Communications had competed unfairly in fighting to win back a contract to hold Supercross motorcycle races and awarded a smaller Chicago promoter $90 million in damages.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Foundation For Islam
description: The government and Muslim leaders signed an agreement establishing a foundation to finance the development of Islam in France. Relying on private donations from France and abroad, the Foundation for Islam, as it will be known, will distribute money to build and renovate mosques and to train imams for the five million Muslims in the country. For years, Islam in France has been financed by foreign governments and donors, with little transparency or public oversight. The government has been seeking a greater degree of oversight without jeopardizing the country's separation of church and state. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Photo Gear Dealer Cuts Outlook
description: A British retailer of photographic equipment, Jessops, said annual earnings would be significantly below its expectations after demand for digital cameras faltered, setting off a 31 percent decline in its share price. The company, based in Leicester, England, will report slower sales growth for the fiscal first half, the chief executive, Derek Hine, said. A slowdown in consumer spending crimped revenue from digital cameras, he said. He did not give any earnings targets for the fiscal year, which ends on Sept. 30. Hanophy of State Supreme Court indicated he would sentence the defendant, Juan Batista, 28, to 22 years to life in prison on April 13. The Queens district attorney said Mr. Batista admitted in court that on July 26, 2003, he used an extension cord to hang his son, Omar Arias, from a shower curtain rod.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Hate Crimes Double
description: The number of hate crimes, most notably against Jews and against Arabs of North African origin, nearly doubled last year, to 1,565, from 833 a year earlier, according to a report to the government by the National Consultative Commission for Human Rights, an advisory body. It said 62 percent of the total were anti-Jewish acts. Acts against people of North African origin totaled 595 in 2004, up from 232 in 2003. "Previously, we saw a correlation between the increase in racist acts and international events, but that is not the case for 2004," the commission's secretary general, Gerard Fellous, told Agence France-Presse, adding that ethnic violence now appeared to be "a constant" in French society. title: ABB ADDS $232 MILLION TO ASBESTOS CASE PAYMENT
description: The Swiss engineering company ABB, facing more than 135,000 asbestos claims in the United States, said yesterday that it had reached a new agreement to settle the lawsuits, which had threatened the company with bankruptcy. ABB will pay an extra $232 million into a $1.3 billion fund to resolve claims against its ABB Lummus Global and Combustion Engineering Inc. units, the chief executive, Fred Kindle, said on a conference call. The plan addresses objections by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia, which had rejected an earlier settlement, he said. About 440,000 claims against Combustion Engineering have cost more than $1 billion since 1990. Combustion Engineering, based in Norwalk, Conn., used asbestos to insulate boilers made until the 1960's. ABB purchased the company in 1990.

Paid Notice: Deaths   CHEEL, HELEN SNELL
description: CHEEL--Helen Snell, passed away on March 18, 2005, at her home in Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ, at age 100, after a short illness. Mrs. Cheel was born on May 10, 1904 in Potsdam, NY. She was the daughter of Sara Merrick Snell and The Honorable Bertrand H. Snell, Minority Leader of the House of Representatives from 1931-1939 and Congressman for 24 years from the 31st District of New York. Mrs. Cheel was a remarkable, independent woman. Her friendships, keen intellect, sense of humor, infectious laugh, unwaving generosity and ability to live in the present served her well for 100 years. She graduated from the Emma Willard School in Troy, NY and the Crane School of Music in Potsdam, and she earned a B.S. in Music Education from Teachers College of Columbia University in 1928. That same year she married Harold W. Cheel, an engineer, successful architect and developer of Cheelcroft in HoHo-Kus, NJ. They had two children, Bertrand Snell Cheel, who died in 1985, and Barbara Anne Cheel, who died in her childhood. Helen was predeceased by a sister, Sara Snell Petersen. She is survived by a nephew, Hollis, a niece, Sara, a grandniece, Elizabeth, and grandnephew, Christopher. Mrs. Cheel was recognized on many occasions for her lifelong philanthropic endeavors and her community service for more than 75 years. She was a lifelong benefactor of Clarkson University and the major contributor to the Cheel Campus Center, Cheel Arena and the Bertrand H. Snell Hall. She was also a lifelong benefactor of Emma Willard School, where she contributed to the Snell Music Center and the Helen S. Cheel Aquatics Center. On the local level, Helen and Harold Cheel were major patrons of The Valley Hospital, where the Cheel Orthopedic Unit was dedicated in 1987 and the Harold W. and Helen S. Cheel Wing was dedicated in 1992 in their honor. Mrs. Cheel was also active in leadership roles in The Valley Hospital Auxiliary, Ridgewood Woman's Club, YWCA of Ridgewood, American Cancer Society, Community Meals, Hospital Auxiliary of Naples, Florida and the New Jersey Federation of Woman's Clubs. Mrs. Cheel was a member of the Ridgewood Country Club. Services will be private.
