title: NEWS CORPORATION GAINS FULL CONTROL OF FOX
description: The News Corporation, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, said yesterday that it had persuaded Fox Entertainment Group minority holders to accept $6.6 billion for their stock, giving the company full control of assets including the Fox News Channel and the 20th Century Fox film studio. Fox's investors will get $36.72 a share in News Corporation nonvoting shares for their stock, based on Friday's closing prices. Minority investors held 178.4 million shares, or 18 percent in Fox, and will get 2.04 News Corporation shares for each share of Fox.

title: Arts, Briefly; Queens Museum Architect
description: The Queens Museum of Art in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park has selected Grimshaw Architects to design its expansion, replacing the project's original architect, Eric Owen Moss, the museum announced yesterday. Grimshaw, with Ammann & Whitney as a prime consultant, was chosen from eight architectural firms selected to participate in New York City's Design and Construction Excellence Initiative. The firm has offices in London, New York and Melbourne, Australia. Its projects include the Fulton Street Transit Center in Lower Manhattan. The museum occupies the northern half of its Queens building, built for the 1939 World's Fair. The renovation and expansion will allow the museum to occupy the entire 105,000-square-foot structure. ROBIN POGREBIN

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Springer' Tour Postponed
description: The producers of "Jerry Springer: The Opera," the hit satirical musical that recently closed in London after nearly a year and a half in the West End, have postponed a British tour until 2006 after protests from a Christian group persuaded about a third of its scheduled theaters to cancel the show. Christian Voice, which operates the Web site www.repent.uk.com, wrote to 250 theaters asking them not to book the show and threatening legal action if they did. The group has called the show blasphemous and its Springer character "the Antichrist." The producers said they were determined to take it to a wider audience next year. HEATHER TIMMONS

title: RETEK ACCEPTS $643 MILLION OFFER FROM ORACLE

Oracle boosted its bid to $11.25 a share March 17, topping an $11 offer from SAP that Retek's board accepted earlier that day. The victory enables the Oracle chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison, to maintain Oracle's No. 1 rank in North American sales of programs that run business tasks such as payroll and human resources.

description: Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey yesterday signed into a law a bill requiring hospitals to provide rape victims with what are known as emergency contraceptives. The new law makes it mandatory for doctors to administer pregnancy tests to victims of sexual assault. If the tests show no pregnancy, the hospital would then be required, if the victim requests them, to provide the victims with prescriptions for the pills. They contain a higher dose of the hormone found in ordinary birth control pills and are most effective if taken within five days after sexual intercourse. Josh Benson (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Imprint at Simon & Schuster for Conservative Books
description: Mary Matalin, right, the political strategist, will oversee a new imprint of Simon & Schuster Inc.'s adult publishing group that will specialize in books about conservative politics and current events, executives said yesterday. The imprint, which has yet to be named, will publish 6 to 10 books a year and will be jointly managed by David Rosenthal, the publisher of Simon & Schuster, and Louise Burke, the publisher of Pocket Books. Ms. Matalin, 51, will work out of her Washington office and continue her political consulting business and public speaking career, she said. In a statement, she said the books she publishes would "provide a forum for the creative people, bedrock principles and innovative ideas of contemporary conservatism." title: Arts, Briefly; Eminem Drops Lawsuit
description: Eminem, below, has asked a federal judge to dismiss his lawsuit against the publisher of the hip-hop magazine The Source, saying that remaining issues in the case are moot. The rapper, whose real name is Marshall B. Mathers III, had contended in his suit, filed in December 2003, that the magazine had violated his copyright by publishing lyrics disparaging black women that were attributed to him. Eminem, who is white, acknowledged that the lyrics were his but described them as the product of adolescent heartbreak, written before he acquired his fame. The judge, Gerald E. Lynch of Federal District Court in Manhattan, has displayed a zeal for the case, writing at length on the role of race in popular music. He has made several rulings in Eminem's favor, including enjoining online publication of the lyrics and awarding monetary damages for violation of that injunction. A lawyer for Eminem, Donald N. David, said the time and expense of a trial were no longer worthwhile because the discovery of the lyrics was no longer newsworthy. Michael S. Elkin, a lawyer for the publisher, said Eminem's request for a dismissal was a victory. He said, "You can't stifle the press." MICHAEL BRICK

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: High-Level Bribery Scandal
description: Olusegun Obasanjo fired his education minister and accused the president of the Senate, Adolphus Wabara, of taking a bribe after an investigation disclosed that the minister had paid nearly $400,000 to persuade lawmakers to pass his department's bloated budget. In a televised speech, Mr. Obasanjo said the minister, Fabian Osuji, and several lawmakers would face criminal charges for their involvement in what he called "this sordid matter." Under the Constitution, the president of the Senate is the No.3 official in government. Mr. Obasanjo has said that tackling rampant government corruption is a top priority of his second term. Arts, Briefly; Thanks and Jokes From David Letterman
description: David Letterman, right, has publicly thanked law enforcement officials who thwarted what they said was a plot to kidnap his 16-month-old son, Harry. On "Late Show" on Monday night, Mr. Letterman did not explicitly mention the kidnapping but said, "Last week, my family and I were involved in a little legal activity, and fortunately everything turned out fine." He then briefly thanked two F.B.I. agents, as well as a sheriff and a lawyer from Teton County, Mont., where Mr. Letterman and his girlfriend, Regina Lasko, who is Harry's mother, own a ranch. Throughout the program, the first one taped since the news became public, Mr. Letterman also made joking references to the incident, saying he asked investigators for tips on interrogations, "because we have staff problems." Kelly A. Frank, 43, a painter who had worked at the ranch, which is near the town of Choteau, was arrested last week and charged with planning to kidnap the boy and his nanny from the house and then hold them for a $5 million ransom. He pleaded not guilty in a court hearing yesterday and remains in jail. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, PHILIP
description: LEVY--Philip. Age 90, on March 20, 2005. Loving husband of the late Jane Molinaro Levy. Beloved father of Paul S. Levy and his wife Karen and Dr. Linda Fagenholz and her husband Dr. Allen Fagenholz. Adored grandfather of Rebecca and Charlotte Levy and Peter, Andrew and Elizabeth Fagenholz. His life was an inspiration to those who knew him. He came of age in the Depression and made a wonderful life for himself and his family. From chopping trees in Colorado for the Civil Conservation Corps, to running a milk route for Sheffield Farms in the Bronx, to New York City Transit Officer, to New York City Fireman (rising to Inspector), to a private business career highlighted by founding and taking public a long-term healthcare company, his energy and capacity for reinventing himself was unusual. No challenge was too great for him, and he never forgot his roots. He was a man of honor who will be sorely missed by his entire family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHEEL, HELEN SNELL
description: CHEEL--Helen Snell, passed away on March 18, 2005, at her home in Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ, at age 100, after a short illness. Mrs. Cheel was born on May 10, 1904 in Potsdam, NY. She was the daughter of Sara Merrick Snell and The Honorable Bertrand H. Snell, Minority Leader of the House of Representatives from 1931-1939 and Congressman for 24 years from the 31st District of New York. Mrs. Cheel was a remarkable, independent woman. Her friendships, keen intellect, sense of humor, infectious laugh, unwaving generosity and ability to live in the present served her well for 100 years. She graduated from the Emma Willard School in Troy, NY and the Crane School of Music in Potsdam, and she earned a B.S. in Music Education from Teachers College of Columbia University in 1928. That same year she married Harold W. Cheel, an engineer, successful architect and developer of Cheelcroft in HoHo-Kus, NJ. They had two children, Bertrand Snell Cheel, who died in 1985, and Barbara Anne Cheel, who died in her childhood. Helen was predeceased by a sister, Sara Snell Petersen. She is survived by a nephew, Hollis, a niece, Sara, a grandniece, Elizabeth, and grandnephew, Christopher. Mrs. Cheel was recognized on many occasions for her lifelong philanthropic endeavors and her community service for more than 75 years. She was a lifelong benefactor of Clarkson University and the major contributor to the Cheel Campus Center, Cheel Arena and the Bertrand H. Snell Hall. She was also a lifelong benefactor of Emma Willard School, where she contributed to the Snell Music Center and the Helen S. Cheel Aquatics Center. On the local level, Helen and Harold Cheel were major patrons of The Valley Hospital, where the Cheel Orthopedic Unit was dedicated in 1987 and the Harold W. and Helen S. Cheel Wing was dedicated in 1992 in their honor. Mrs. Cheel was also active in leadership roles in The Valley Hospital Auxiliary, Ridgewood Woman's Club, YWCA of Ridgewood, American Cancer Society, Community Meals, Hospital Auxiliary of Naples, Florida and the New Jersey Federation of Woman's Clubs. Mrs. Cheel was a member of the Ridgewood Country Club. Services will be private.

title: MAKER OF CHILDREN'S FURNITURE IS FINED $4 MILLION
description: The Graco unit of Newell Rubbermaid Inc. was fined a record $4 million by the Consumer Products Safety Commission for failing to report defects promptly in more than 12 million items, some of which caused deaths and injuries to children. Under the settlement, Graco will recall 1.2 million toddler beds, sold from February 1994 to March 2001, because a child's limb can lodge in guardrails or footboards, the agency said. From 1991 through 2002, Graco and its Century brand failed to report defects that could pose risks of injury or death to young children, the agency said. A total of 919 incidents and injuries to children involved 16 different product lines, the agency said. Six deaths were associated with infant swings, the agency said.

Those schools, diocesan officials said, would be given a few weeks to come up with financial plans to save themselves.

title: Officer in Murder Case Got Benefit of Doubt in '85

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Postal Service's Profit To Rise
description: The European postal service Deutsche Post said that its earnings for 2005 would rise about 41 percent, to more than 2 billion euros ($2.63 billion), because of new accounting standards, a cut in the tax rate and smaller losses in the United States. Excluding the accounting changes and tax cut, net income will increase about 10 percent, the chief executive, Klaus Zumwinkel, said. Deutsche Post, which owns the express delivery service DHL and is based in Bonn, increased the share of international revenue to 48 percent last year from 43 percent in 2003.

title: Puppets as Ancient Greeks, Pulled by Gods and Men
description: Theodora Skipitares puts her large-scale puppetry to potent use in her adaptation of Euripides' "Iphigenia" at La MaMa E.T.C. Using five-foot bunraku-style puppets strapped to actors, Ms. Skipitares retells this familiar Greek tragedy of a father's sacrifice of his daughter. Her trademark mix of puppets and humans creates a moving miniature of the larger-than-life myth. And the innate theatricality of puppet spectacle is particularly well suited to this melodramatic material.

title: TV Chief at Fox Going to Paramount

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Boston Scientific To Exercise Purchase Right
description: Boston Scientific has told Cryovascular Systems it planned to exercise a right acquired in 2003 to buy the privately held company, which has developed a method for temporarily freezing the walls of blood vessels where blockages are being cleared. Cryovascular, based in Los Gatos, Calif., uses a variation on balloon angioplasty, a common procedure in which tiny balloons at the end of catheters are inserted into obstructed blood vessels and inflated to push plaque that restricts blood flow out of the way. Instead of using saline solution to inflate the balloon, Cryovascular uses chilled nitrous oxide, which tests have shown is less damaging. The acquisition is expected to close in May. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

The rights belong to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which runs the region's beleaguered mass transit system. The offer was only a fraction of the appraised value, and you'd have thought Mayor Michael Bloomberg and Gov. George Pataki -- who understand the M.T.A.'s problems but have not been particularly helpful about solutions -- would have been outraged. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KENNAN, GEORGE F.
description: KENNAN--George F. The Council on Foreign Relations and Foreign Affairs magazine mourn the passing of George Kennan, author of the doctrine of containment and one of the most important articles in the hstory of American foreign policy, "The Sources of Soviet Conduct." A member of the Council for 59 years, George Kennan exemplified the best of America's diplomatic tradition. His writing and analysis, like the man himself, were distinguished for grace of style, clarity of thought, and force of argument. The Council and Foreign Affairs have been honored by our long association with him. We offer our sincerest sympathy to nis wife, Annelise, his son Christopher, and the other members of his family.

title: Arts, Briefly; Another 'CSI: Miami' First
description: A new episode of CBS's "CSI: Miami" that featured a guest appearance by the skateboarding star Tony Hawk as a dead body was Monday night's most-watched show, with an estimated 18.68 million viewers. The show helped CBS win the night in the Nielsen overnight ratings both in total viewers and among 18-to-49-year-olds. Fox was second to CBS in those major audience measurements, but it was No. 1 for the night among adults 18 to 34. "Nanny 911," its babysitting reality show, is faring well in the new Monday slot it took over last week, having increased its ratings in total viewers as well as among 18-to-49-year-olds. The show, at 8 p.m., appears to be sating viewers' need for parenting advice before ABC's "Supernanny" can get to them at 10 p.m. That show attracted an estimated 7.54 million viewers (versus "Nanny 911's" 9.55 million), which was a season low for an original episode of that show. KATE AURTHUR

title: A 'Menagerie' Full of Stars, Silhouettes and Weird Sounds

As staged by David Leveaux, this revival suggests that to recollect the past is to see life as if it had occurred underwater, in some viscous sea through which people swim slowly and blindly.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Seal Hunt Starts Next Week
description: The Department of Fisheries and Oceans announced that Canada's annual seal hunt, the world's largest, would open Tuesday and that for the second year in a row it would have a quota raised to a near-record high, compared with past decades. Until May, the federal government will allow the killing of up to 320,000 baby harp seals, almost as many as the 350,000 last year, which was the biggest hunt in at least a half-century. Defending the hunt against animal rights advocates, the government says the harp seal herd is healthy and abundant, with a population of more than five million, close to the largest ever recorded. The animals are hunted largely for their fur, which has become more valuable as new markets have opened. Colin Campbell (NYT)

description: Fifteen people, including four doctors, a dentist and a psychologist, have been charged in a medical insurance fraud, the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday. Mr. Morgenthau said a mother and son team had engineered the scheme, using their control of a billing company and clinics to charge for services and tests that were never provided. The victims were insurance companies and New York City Transit, which insures its employees. Mr. Morgenthau did not specify the amount of the fraud, but said it added up to millions of dollars over a 10-year period. The accused pleaded not guilty to charges that included insurance fraud and grand larceny at State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Officer Slashed And Suspect Shot
description: A police officer was slashed in the face and neck last night in Saint Albans by a Queens man wielding a carpet knife, the police said. After the attack, which occurred just before 8 p.m. near the intersection of Dunkirk Street and Elmira Avenue, the officer's partner shot the suspect, whom the police identified as Radcliffe A. Meeks, 33. He was struck in the right elbow and was taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, where he was listed in stable condition. Charges against Mr. Meeks were pending last night, the authorities said. The suspect has two prior arrests for assaulting a police officer, a police official said, but the status of those cases could not be determined last night. In last night's attack, the police said, two plainclothes officers had identified themselves as officers and tried to stop Mr. Meeks, whom they suspected of threatening to shoot a man. The police said Mr. Meeks then attacked one officer, a five-year-veteran whom officials did not identify. The officer underwent surgery last night and was expected to make a full recovery. title: Arts, Briefly; Lost Novel by Dumas to Be Published
description: A forgotten novel by Alexandre Dumas, which he left nearly completed when he died in 1870, has been discovered by a scholar in the archives of the National Library of France and will be published in June, Le Figaro reported. The book, "Le Chevalier de St.-Hermine" ("The Knight of St.-Hermine"), set at the peak of the Napoleonic era with scenes of the battle of Trafalgar and the death of Horatio Nelson, was serialized in a newspaper in 1869 but never published as a book. The scholar, Claude Schopp, a French Dumas specialist, discovered the serialized work -- which completes the trilogy begun with "The Companions of Jehu" and "The Whites and the Blues" -- in 1988 on newspaper microfiche at the library. He has worked in secrecy since the discovery to edit the book and reconstruct the damaged clippings, and he added a brief conclusion. It is to be published at a length of 900 pages by Phbus of Paris, with plans to publish translations in English and Russian. HLNE FOUQUET

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GAINES, WILLIAM LOUIS
description: GAINES--William Louis, of Chicago, IL, died Tuesday, February 8, 2005, at the age of 82. Dr. Gaines studied at the University of London on a Fulbright Scholarship before earning his Ph.D from Yale University in 1951. He was named head of the Fulbright Program for the United Kingdom in 1956. In 1961, he became the Associate Director of the Commonwealth Fellowships in New York, and the following year was named Director of Education at the Africa-America Institute. He later served 18 years as President of the Institute for the International Education of Students in Chicago. He received numerous honorary degrees and was appointed Honorary Commander of the Order of the British Empire for his outstanding work in international education. He is survived by his sister, Mary Lou Nitzschke. Funeral services were held February 12, 2005, Church of the Ascension in Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINOWITZ, SOL M.
description: LINOWITZ--Sol M. Cornell University mourns the loss of devoted alumnus, trustee emeritus, and presidential councillor, Sol M. Linowitz. His ground-breaking business leadership, unwavering commitment to public service, and ardent dedication to Cornell will long be remembered. In 1938 Sol Linowitz received his J.D. from Cornell Law School, graduating first in his class. In 1966 he was appointed to the Cornell Board of Trustees by New York Governor Nelson Rockefeller serving until 1995. In 1996 he was named Presidential Councillor by Cornell President Hunter Rawlings. In 1998 the University was proud to see Sol Linowitz receive the nation's highest civilian honor, the Presidential Medal of Freedom, from President Clinton. Sol Linowitz's wife and two of his four children are Cornell alumnae, punctuating a great man's indelible mark on the University. He will be missed by the entire Cornell community. We express our sincere condolences to his wife Evelyn Zimmerman Linowitz '39 and daughters Anne Linowitz Mozersky '65, Ronni Linowitz Jolles '78, Jan Linowitz Wadden and June Linowitz Eisner. Peter Meinig, Chairman Board of Trustees Jeffrey S. Lehman, President Cornell University

description: TOMLINSON--Anne Jefferys, 82, of Vero Beach, FL died at home on March 15, 2005 after a long illness. Mrs. Tomlinson was born on March 17, 1922 in Bryn Mawr, PA and moved to Vero Beach in 1994 after living in Princeton, NJ and Mantoloking, NJ. Her husband of sixty years, Henry Prout Tomlinson died in 2001. During her years in Princeton, Mrs. Tomlinson was active in the Garden Club of Princeton and the Princeton Ballet Society. While living in Mantoloking, she was a member of the Seaweeders Club. Surviving are her children, Henry Prout Tomlinson, Jr. of Albuquerque NM, Melissa Tomlinson of Vero Beach, FL, Sarah Roberts Fuller of Oakland, CA, and Anne J. Tomlinson of Frederick, MD; and nine grandchildren. Donations may be made to Oldfields School in Glencoe, MD. A memorial will be held at a later date in Princeton, NJ.

A classy lady with a sparkling wit who will be greatly missed. Services Friday 11:30AM at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to the Hebrew Home for the Aged, Riverdale, N.Y.

title: Norman Mager, 78, Player Tarnished by Gambling Scandal, Dies

Mager, who lived in Boca Raton, Fla., and Port Washington, N.Y., was 78.

title: Mets Have Horse Race for Spots in the Bullpen

He figures he has earned a spot on the opening day roster, but like everyone else, he is only guessing. The regular season starts in less than two weeks, and the composition of the bullpen, beyond the right-handers Braden Looper and Mike DeJean, remains the mystery of camp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, LORRAINE
description: COHEN -- Lorraine. Passed away suddenly and peacefully on March 22, 2005 at an age of 77. She was a beloved English and Drama teacher at Teaneck High School in Teaneck, NJ for over 25 years. She was also a great theater director, actress, and debate coach. She has published three books of scenes for actors that are still used by many students everywhere. Dr. Richard Imundo and her five children, Susan, Lesle, David, Stephen and Ronald and her eight grandchildren, Nicholas, Melanie, Zachary, Phoebe, Louisa, Hannah, Maria and Jesse, as well as her siblings Greta, Anita and Robert survive her. She was an exceptional, loving, caring mother, grandmother, sister and friend. Contributions in her memory may be made to www.PhoenixTheatreEnse mble.org, or 52nd Street Project, 500 West 52nd St, 2nd Floor, NY, NY 10019. Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBINS, PERCY (BUDDY)
description: ROBINS--Percy (Buddy). Age 86. Beloved husband of Sylvia for 63 years. A graduate of NYU he served as Navigator in the US Air Corps during WWII attaining rank of Captain. He saw duty and ETO and CBI and received a Distinguished Flying Cross with Oak Leaf Cluster for extreme bravery while flying in combat zones. Returning to civilian life he co-founded Imperial Wear with his late partner Paul Cohen. It was the first store in the country devoted solely to outfitting the extra large and or tall man. He was a charter member and past president of Muttontown Golf Club. He leaves behind two daughters Bonni and Nancy and three grandchildren Tami, Kenneth and Joel. Funeral services at Riverside Nassau North in Great Neck at 10 AM Friday, March 25.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: MCI Board Reopens Talks With Qwest
description: MCI said yesterday that its board of directors had reopened merger talks with Qwest Communications International. MCI had been forbidden from talking directly to Qwest because of its current merger agreement with Verizon Communications. However, Verizon has allowed MCI to start fresh talks with Qwest, which last week raised its bid for MCI by nearly $500 million, to $8.45 billion. MCI's board is likely to decide as early as next week whether to reject Qwest's bid outright, suggest to Qwest how to improve its bid or decide that Qwest's bid is superior and give Verizon time to revise its original offer. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: In Moscow, A Design Scene With Growing Pains
description: This month, the London furniture fair 100% Design made its second outing to Moscow. While most of the exhibitors at this four-day show were international firms trawling for Russia's fabled high rollers, the organizers also tried to nurture local talent with Created in Russia, a competition for Russian designers.

title: Conference of Arab Leaders Yields Little of Significance
description: ALGIERS, March 23 - Arab leaders facing intense international pressure on issues ranging from war to democracy movements ended a two-day summit conference here on Wednesday with little to show for it. Only 13 of 22 leaders came, and the resolutions passed were of comparatively little significance, leaving critics plenty to complain about.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Police Break Up Fake Euro Ring
description: The police said they had arrested 27 people in connection with producing millions of fake euros, the largest counterfeiting scheme uncovered in Spain since the introduction of the euro there in 2002. Police officials said they seized 2.5 million euros, or $3.25 million, in fraudulent bills during the arrests, which were carried out in cities and towns across Spain, including Madrid and Barcelona. Additional sums had already been put into circulation, the police said, without specifying the exact amount. About 45 percent of the fraudulent bills detected in Spain in 2004 appear to have been made by the group, the police said. Renwick McLean (NYT)

COURT CUTS LAWSUIT JUDGMENT AGAINST PPG INDUSTRIES
description: A federal appeals court reduced by $30 million a judgment against PPG Industries in a lawsuit filed by a wood-products maker over deficient wood treatment. The Court of Appeals for the Eighth United States Circuit in St. Louis lowered the damages PPG must pay Marvin Lumber and Cedar Company and Marvin Windows of Tennessee for damage to their reputation stemming from a PPG treatment called PILT. The ruling reduced to $126.1 million a 2002 award won by the Marvin companies. PPG "is evaluating its options for further appeals" and will reserve up to $150 million for the judgment in the first quarter of 2005, said Jeff Worden, a spokesman.

OpenNetwork, based in Clearwater, Fla., has customers in the financial services, insurance, telecommunications and health care industries, BMC said. BMC shares rose 1 cent, to $15.41.

description: The City Council passed a $47.4 million operating budget yesterday for the fiscal year beginning July 1, an increase of $675,770 over the current budget. Council leaders attributed most of the increase, $513,359, to rent increases for offices at 250 Broadway. Salary increases for Council members' staffs totaled $162,411. "They're clearly hard-working city employees," said Councilman David I. Weprin, the chairman of the Finance Committee. Winnie Hu (NYT)

description: Wet Seal, a clothing retailer, is delaying until April 12 the release of its financial results for the fourth quarter and full year. No reason for the delay was provided. The company said last month that the Securities and Exchange Commission had started an informal investigation into the sale of its shares by La Senza Corporation, a Montreal retailer headed by Irving Teitelbaum, Wet Seal's chairman from 1984 to last August. The shares were sold before the stock began a slide that reduced their price by about 85 percent. Wet Seal said in December it would close 150 stores and cut 2,000 jobs.

This is, after all, just spring training, where winning, depending upon whom you ask, is no big deal.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Toshiba Ordered To Pay $322 Million To Lexar
description: The Toshiba Corporation, Japan's second-biggest chip maker, was ordered by a jury yesterday to pay $322.7 million to Lexar Media in a lawsuit over technology used to make computer chips in digital cameras, cellphones and MP3 players. The jury, in state court in San Jose, Calif., agreed with Lexar's assertions that Toshiba broke a 1997 agreement to use and co-develop the flash memory technology, used to make chips that transmit data, and then shared it with SanDisk, Lexar's largest competitor. Lexar, based in Fremont, Calif., had sought more than $1 billion in damages and a court injunction stopping the sale of Toshiba products that use Lexar's technology. Lisa Nemec, a spokeswoman for Toshiba's America Electronic Components unit, did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment.

Arts, Briefly; Tussauds Sold for $1.5 Billion
description: Tussauds Group, the two-century-old waxworks company that owns Madame Tussauds, was sold yesterday to an investment firm owned by the Crown Prince of Dubai for $1.5 billion. The group, which started as a traveling show in 1802, now has 14 million customers a year at its wax museums and amusement parks around the world, including Las Vegas, Amsterdam, Hong Kong and Times Square in New York. Under its new owners, Madame Tussauds plans to expand, possibly buying up European theme parks, the group's managers said. The purchase price is more than double what Madame Tussauds' most recent owners, the London-based private equity fund Charterhouse Capital Partners, paid for the company in 1998. Tussauds' London outpost, its oldest, was criticized in December for arranging a Nativity scene that used the soccer star David Beckham as Joseph; his wife, Victoria, as Mary; and President Bush as one of the three wise men. HEATHER TIMMONS

description: More students were admitted to their first choice for high school this year than last, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday, and 4,000 fewer students than last year will face the disappointment of not being admitted to any of their top 12 choices.

title: A Wall of Faith and History
description: Boston - "BLISS was it in that dawn to be alive," sang William Wordsworth of the French Revolution of 1789, which, insofar as laws, customs and politics were concerned, promised to wipe the slate clean and offer the human race a fresh start. A similar exhilaration seized the Western world in the autumn of 1989, when cheering crowds dismantled the Berlin Wall -- and with it, soon enough, the Soviet empire. Now many analysts are suggesting that the rumblings we hear from the Middle East presage an eruption of that sort. Is the old order in those lands about to be exploded?

description: The United States Congress and the governor of Florida have devoted extraordinary and all but single-minded energy to keeping Terri Schiavo alive. But all they have achieved so far is a bitter lesson in judicial supremacy.

title: The Springtime Blues, Back to Delight
description: BLUE may be the most sought-after color in the garden. Part of the attraction is its rarity. Blue flowers often come from places with cool summers, like the mountains, and do not thrive in most of the United States, where hot summers make it unlikely to find rivers of royal blue delphiniums, never mind the fabled cyan Himalayan poppy.

title: As Subways Slow, Riders Play Waiting Games
description: A barometer of just how bad the recent subway delays have been can be found in Sacha Newley's reading habits. Mr. Newley, a painter from the Upper West Side, has certain books that he reserves only for subway reading. Two months ago, around the time the delays began, he picked up his latest: "Moby-Dick." He's now on Chapter 107.

title: Internet Phone Service Creating Chatty Network
description: JOHN PERRY BARLOW is pretty free and open, but he's no simpleton. So when he signed on to Skype, a free Internet phone service, and a woman identifying herself as Kitty messaged him, saying, "I need a friend," he was skeptical. He figured she was "looking for 'friends' to come watch her 'relax' in her Webcam-equipped 'bedroom."'

title: National Briefing | West: California: Ruling On Fund-Raising Limit
description: A judge in Sacramento tentatively ruled that a state agency could not enforce a new regulation that limits candidates' fund-raising for ballot measures. The judge, Shellyanne W.L. Chang of Superior Court, issued a preliminary injunction after Citizens to Save California, which raises money to promote ballot measures that Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger backs, argued that the regulation, by the state's Fair Political Practices Commission, violated the First Amendment. Before the ruling becomes final, Judge Chang is to hold a hearing today. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: Corrections

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Party Official Rallies Democrats
description: A national Democratic Party leader and state Democratic officials met yesterday and agreed to try to swap lists of campaign contributors, swing voters, and other information in an effort to win more seats in New York and nationwide. Congressman Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, left, the second-highest ranking Democrat in the House of Representatives, also discussed campaign strategy and state budget talks with the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, and the Senate Democratic leader, David A. Paterson. Mr. Hoyer said at a news conference that he urged both men to link New York Republicans to the controversial House majority leader, Tom DeLay, and to national Republican plans to overhaul Social Security. Mr. Hoyer also said Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was the strongest candidate for the Democrats in the presidential election in 2008. "Every Democrat thinks that," Mr. Hoyer said. Patrick D. title: A Threat to Iraqi Women
description: Almost two months have passed since Iraq's elections, and people there are understandably impatient to see a new government take office. But the real problem isn't the delay. Lengthy haggling over cabinet posts and other turf issues was inevitable among fledging politicians with no previous experience of democratic give-and-take. What is far more troubling are the significant sections of the Iraqi population whose rights could be sacrificed when the Shiite religious parties and autonomy-minded Kurdish leaders who were the election's biggest winners cut their final deal. Those who need to worry most at this point are women, Sunni Arabs and secular Iraqis of both sexes.

The company's Celebrity Cruises unit canceled a 10-night Hawaii voyage on its Infinity vessel, which was scheduled to start March 27 from Ensenada, Mexico, to replace a bearing in the ship's propulsion system. The repair will be made after the Infinity completes a 14-night cruise through the Panama Canal. The 2,000 passengers who booked the Hawaii cruise will receive refunds as well as a free cruise. The effect on earnings will be evenly split between the first and second quarters, the company said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Insurance Workers Protest
description: Thousands of workers at India's government-owned insurance firms began a two-day strike to protest low wages and government moves to encourage foreign investment in the industry. Workers' unions said the government's offer of an 8.5 percent wage increase was not acceptable because salaries had been stagnant for the last two years. More than 100,000 employees of the country's largest insurer, the government-owned Life Insurance Corporation of India, are continuing to work while negotiating salaries with the government. Government-owned insurance companies control more than 80 percent of the country's insurance market. The government recently proposed raising the limit on foreign ownership of insurance companies to 49 percent, from 26 percent. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Bolshoi Opens Controversial Opera
description: Moscow's political and cultural elite packed the Bolshoi Theater last night for the opening of its first new opera in 30 years, a controversial work that had sparked protests and calls by some politicians for the production to be shut down. The opera, "Children of Rosental," has been picketed, right, by Moving Together, a youth group that supports President Vladimir V. Putin. The group called the opera pornography and criticized its librettist, the postmodernist writer Vladimir Sorokin, as unworthy of the Bolshoi stage. The controversy, which has dragged on for weeks, has been front-page news in Russia, leading to widespread speculation about what would happen at the premiere. But the only disruption last night was at the beginning of the opera, when several minutes passed without any music, just movement onstage, and one viewer shouted out, "Will there be any music or what?" Some members of Parliament had demanded that the director of the Bolshoi, Anatoly Iksanov, be removed for staging the opera, which depicts scientifically bred clones of Tchaikovsky, Mussorgsky and other composers living in squalor after the collapse of the Soviet Union; Mozart's girlfriend is a prostitute whose pimp poisons him. Mr. Sorokin appeared weary but pleased after the performance and was dismissive of the campaign against the opera. "I don't think about them," he said of the protesters. "They're petty. It smells of the past. It's from the Soviet era." SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Tuberculosis Rates Continue To Fall
description: Cases of tuberculosis in New York City reached a historic low last year, marking a sharp turnaround in combating a disease that was epidemic only 15 years ago, the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene announced yesterday. There were 1,039 new cases reported in 2004, a 9 percent drop from 2003 and a 73 percent fall from the peak of the epidemic in 1992, when 3,800 cases were reported. "While tremendous overall strides have been made, TB continues to largely affect immigrant groups, particularly of Asian and Hispanic descent," said Dr. Sonal Munsiff, the assistant commissioner for tuberculosis control. He added that "cases in some sections of the city have not changed significantly over the past few years, reflecting the presence of large immigrant communities from countries with high rates of TB." Marc Santora (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVY, PHILIP
description: LEVY--Philip. Age 90, on March 20, 2005. Loving husband of the late Jane Molinaro Levy. Beloved father of Paul S. Levy and his wife Karen and Dr. Linda Fagenholz and her husband Dr. Allen Fagenholz. Adored grandfather of Rebecca and Charlotte Levy and Peter, Andrew and Elizabeth Fagenholz. His life was an inspiration to those who knew him. He came of age in the Depression and made a wonderful life for himself and his family. From chopping trees in Colorado for the Civil Conservation Corps, to running a milk route for Sheffield Farms in the Bronx, to New York City Transit Officer, to New York City Fireman (rising to Inspector), to a private business career highlighted by founding and taking public a long-term healthcare company, his energy and capacity for reinventing himself was unusual. No challenge was too great for him, and he never forgot his roots. He was a man of honor who will be sorely missed by his entire family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GORDON, ALICE
description: GORDON--Alice age 89 died Wednesday March 23, 2005. Born in Detroit, MI on September 24, 1915 of Samuel and Lena Zucker. Her mother died in the flu epidemic of 1918 and she was raised by a new mother, Fanny. She grew up in Washington, D.C., and the marches of the unemployed during the early years of the Depression touched her greatly, as did the ferment of the times. At age 18, she and her husband, Hyman Gordon, set off to save the world. She raised two children and worked as a legal secretary. Her true lifelong vocation, however, was the struggle to make the world a fair and just place. Even aged and halting, she marched against the war in Iraq, and took pride in casting her vote in the 2004 election against the man who now seeks to destroy the Social Security she fought to create. The great sorrow of her life was the loss of her beloved grandson, Danny Carboni, to cancer, at age 23. She had many friends, led a full life, and left the world better than she found it. Survived by her son, Martin Gordon of Forest Hills, NY and his wife Toby and their children Tina and Michael; her daughter Susan Carboni of Teaneck, NJ and her husband Franceso; her grandson, Peter Carboni of Los Angeles; and her brothers, Seymour Zucker of Maryland & Monte Zucker of FL.

The price of fuel and utilities rose 1 percent during February, reflecting a sharp rise in residential fuel prices. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWEITZER, NATHAN

A World War II veteran, he was also a long-standing member of the Masons and the Park Avenue Synagogue. As a resident of The Hebrew Home in Riverdale, he became an accomplished and prolific painter. Endowed with a sweet, smiling, sanguine nature and unflagging courage in the face of severe disability, Nathan touched the spirits of all around him and will be sorely missed. title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Cable Company Reworks Debt
description: Brazil's largest cable television company, Net Servios de Comunicao, said it had finished restructuring 1.4 billion reais ($511 million) in debt that it had defaulted on in December 2002. As a result of the restructuring, the Mexican telecommunications company Telfonos de Mxico, or Telmex, raised its stake in the holding company that controls Net, GB Participaes, to 49 percent. The remaining 51 percent is held by Organizaes Globo, Brazil's biggest media group. Net said 98 percent of its creditors agreed to the restructuring, which reduced its debt load to 480 million reais ($175 million). Net, which has 1.42 million subscribers, said it made a net profit of 107.9 million reais in the fourth quarter, reversing a loss of 116.5 million reais a year earlier. Todd Benson (NYT)

description: Altiris, which makes software used to manage computer systems, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire closely held Pedestal Software for $65 million in cash to add network security products. Altiris said the acquisition would add to earnings starting in the third quarter, and was expected to contribute $17 million to $18 million in revenue in 2005. Gregory S. Butterfield, the Altiris chief executive, said Pedestal's customers in the insurance, health care and financial services industries offered new sales opportunities and its products would help Altiris compete with rivals like Symantec, NetIQ and BindView Development. Mr. Butterfield said he expected to raise prices on Pedestal products by as much as 20 percent, to about $800 for server computers that run corporate networks and to about $30 for personal computers. Pedestal, which is based in Newton, Mass., employs about 50 people. The transaction is expected to close by the end of the month. Altiris, based in Lindon, Utah, reported net income of $16.7 million on revenue of $166.6 million in 2004.

New York University's Tisch School of the Arts and the Rita and Burton Goldberg Department of Dramatic Writing deeply mourn the death of Charles Purpura, a renowned screenwriter and a beloved teacher of screenwriting. An outstanding mentor to undergraduate and graduate students, Professor Purpura was a brilliant story analyst and an inspirational educator whose classes, always over-registered, brimmed with wit and wisdom. He wrote the screenplay for "Heaven Help Us" and scripts for ABC, Disney, Universal, Warner Bros, and Sidney Pollack Productions. His screenwriting awards include an Emmy and a Humanitas award. title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Silent Pope Blesses Crowd
description: After two days of rumors that his health was hitting another crisis, Pope John Paul II appeared briefly at his apartment window off St. Peter's Square, blessing thousands of pilgrims before being wheeled back inside. He did not speak. Since Monday, the Italian news media have been filled with reports that the 84-year-old pope, suffering from Parkinson's disease and recovering from a tracheotomy, was not responding well to medicine and may require another stay at the hospital. The Vatican has issued no new official statements about his health, though the appearance yesterday, the usual day for his weekly public audience, seemed to ease concerns somewhat. "I don't think that the situation is alarming," Cardinal Pio Laghi, a retired senior official said, according to the ANSA news agency. John Paul is still expected to deliver his traditional blessing on Easter. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: NEW YORK LIFE SAYS EARNINGS ROSE 15 PERCENT IN 2004
description: The New York Life Insurance Company said yesterday that net income rose 15 percent last year, to $1.29 billion, as sales of life insurance and annuities surged. Net income increased from $1.12 billion in 2003, the company said. Revenue climbed 16 percent, to $17.3 billion, and sales of life insurance and annuities in the United States increased 22 percent, to $7.48 billion. The insurer, which is based in New York, is a mutual company with no publicly traded shares. The company's net worth, which is measured by subtracting its liabilities from its assets, climbed 9.5 percent in 2004, to $11.8 billion.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global PC Sales Forecast Is Cut
description: Personal computer sales worldwide will increase 9.7 percent this year, less than previously forecast, because of slowing economies in the United States and Japan, the research firm IDC said yesterday. In November, IDC forecast a 10.1 percent rise. Global PC sales are expected to increase to 195.4 million units this year, from 178.1 million last year, IDC said in a statement on its Web site. Growth in American PC sales will slow to 7.6 percent, from 11 percent in 2004, IDC said. Slow employment growth, wider United States budget and trade deficits and high oil prices will crimp domestic PC demand, an IDC analyst, Roger Kay, said. Global sales growth is expected to be more than 8 percent through 2009 as buyers replace old computers and purchase wireless devices, IDC said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REISCHER, ALFRED B.
description: REISCHER--Alfred B. Passed away peacefully on March 21st, 2005, at his home in Key Biscayne, FL, at the age of 82. Alfred was born to Sara and Ben Reischer, on July 7th, 1922. His parents, European immigrants of very modest means, entered the US just after World War I. They encouraged him to study accounting, and Alfred entered Temple University Business School. Following his graduation he served in the armed forces during World War II as a meteorologist for the US Air Force. After the war, he completed a Master's Degree in Business at Temple University and taught business classes there. Alfred then became a CPA, starting his first business, an accounting firm, in the 1950's. The business for which he will be best remembered is one that bore his name, Reischer Ford, which he owned and operated in Philadelphia in the 60's and 70's. Alfred is survived by his wife of 52 years Phyllis, his children Lisa Reischer Payton (Harry), and Matthew (Jennifer), and grandchildren Danielle, Alexa, Arianna, and Mia. Services will be held on Friday, March 25, 10:45 AM at Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapels, Miami Beach, FL, 305-531-1151. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Jewish Community Services of South Florida, 305-576-6550.

title: Glimpse of World Shatters North Koreans' Illusions
description: YANJI, China - Sitting on a bare floor in a chilly one-room apartment, Lee Hae Jon and her younger sister, Hae Sun, struggled recently for words to describe their lives since they clandestinely made their way here from North Korea five years ago. Their mother married a Chinese man and disappeared from their lives without a trace. Since then, a Chinese widow of Korean descent has taken the girls into her apartment and kept them clothed and fed. But for five years, the teenage sisters have not dared to go outside in daylight for fear of being sent back to their country, or worse, trafficked as young brides or prostitutes in this booming Chinese border city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBINS, PERCY (BUDDY)
description: ROBINS--Percy (Buddy). Age 86. Beloved husband of Sylvia for 63 years. A graduate of NYU he served as Navigator in the US Air Corps during WWII attaining rank of Captain. He saw duty and ETO and CBI and received a Distinguished Flying Cross with Oak Leaf Cluster for extreme bravery while flying in combat zones. Returning to civilian life he co-founded Imperial Wear with his late partner Paul Cohen. It was the first store in the country devoted solely to outfitting the extra large and or tall man. He was a charter member and past president of Muttontown Golf Club. He leaves behind two daughters Bonni and Nancy and three grandchildren Tami, Kenneth and Joel. Funeral services at Riverside Nassau North in Great Neck at 10 AM Friday, March 25.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Dr. Who' Mystery Solved

The source of the leak was apparently uncovered in Canada, after an investigation by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, which has a partnership with the BBC to broadcast the show in North America. The new 45-minute episode appeared on Internet file-sharing networks earlier this month, weeks before its scheduled debut in Britain on Saturday and in Canada on April 5. According to the BBC, the culprit worked for a "third-party company in Canada" that had a preview copy of the show. A spokeswoman for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation said the person did not work for the CBC but would not comment further except to say that its investigation was complete. COLIN CAMPBELL

title: STEPHEN PETRONIO COMPANY
description: Mr. Petronio choreographs tumult -- ordered tumult. For the last two decades, this adventurous choreographer has filled dances with reckless-looking movement. Yet the ferocity is channeled into rigorous and densely textured formal structures. Mr. Petronio is celebrating his troupe's 20th anniversary with a program that includes three revivals and a premiere -- or, more accurately, a preview of a coming attraction. All the works reflect Mr. Petronio's interests in such concerns as pop culture and issues of sex and gender. His new piece is "Bud," a male duet that will be the first part of "Bloom," a production to music by the singer and songwriter Rufus Wainright to be completed next year. It shares the program with "Prelude" (2000), a study in gestural abandon to music by Placebo, and two creations from the 90's. "MiddleSexGorge" (with Mr. Petronio, above) hurtles along to music by the British post-punk band Wire in a manner that is visually enigmatic as well as choreographically exciting: whereas the women in the cast wear austere costumes, the men are clad in corsets. "Lareigne," to a driving score by David Linton, suddenly juxtaposes sharp turns with unexpected stillness. Mr. Petronio is never afraid to be bold. (Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800. Tickets: $40.) JACK ANDERSON

description: If pastiche is the dominant musical style of today -- see "Spamalot" or, for that matter, listen to the hit song "Rich Girl" in which Gwen Stefani riffs on "Fiddler on the Roof" -- then Michael Friedman is in luck. One of the most nimble composers in New York, Mr. Friedman, 29, a member of the influential downtown troupe, the Civilians, can do a little bit of everything. In the last few years, he has written salsa, mod pop tunes and Andrew Lloyd Webber-style ballads. He has written musical interludes for some of this city's best genre plays -- whether it's for the moody neo-noir atmospherics of "Splatter Pattern" or the early 20th-century silent film-style piano in the superior "All Wear Bowlers," which returns to the Here Arts Center on April 22. But what makes Mr. Friedman, above, such a rare commodity is that he writes for each of these forms with precision and absolute sincerity (even when the songs are not sincere). For his next trick, Mr. Friedman has written some Irish ditties to accompany Sean Cunningham's foul-mouthed and tasteless lyrics in the musical "God Hates the Irish: The Ballad of Armless Johnny." Aiming at the audience who thought that "Avenue Q" was too tame, the tongue-in-cheek musical, which is about a one-armed Irishman whose mother is suspected of killing his dad, has something to offend just about every ethnic group. Typical is a song celebrating Irish inbreeding, which includes this lyric: "While others' blood runs red ours has got the blues/A small price to pay for keeping out the Jews." (This weekend's schedule: tonight at 8; tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m. and Sunday at 3 p.m. Rattlestick Theater, 224 Waverly Place, Greenwich Village; (212)868-4444. Tickets: $37.50.) JASON ZINOMAN

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Infineon To Open Center In Romania
description: Infineon Technologies, Europe's second-largest semiconductor maker, said yesterday that it would open a new development center in Romania to meet rising demand for semiconductors used in automotive and industrial applications. Infineon Technologies Romania will specialize in semiconductors with analog and digital functions, the company said. The new center will "enable Infineon to better serve the growing demand for smart-power semiconductors for automotive and industrial applications, which now also include applications in the field of research and development," the company said. Infineon, based in Munich, plans to employ about 50 people at the center by the end of 2005.

title: OS GEMEOS: 'CAVALEIRO MARGINAL'
description: Os Gemeos, Portugese for the twins, is the name of a Brazilian team of art-making brothers, Octavio and Gustavo Pandolfo, who were born in 1974. They are prodigiously resourceful painters, sculptors, muralists, graffiti artists, graphic designers and photographers who have exhibited internationally, and they have created a sweet, faux-innocent magic theater of an installation for their first New York exhibition. It features a gargantuan, three-dimensional, barefoot puppet (above) in a stuffed blue and red suit who lies on his side with his knees up so as to fit into the gallery. This character's head is enclosed within a big box with lavishly decorated doors opened to reveal his impassive cartoon face. Walk around behind the box and you find inside an entirely mirrored room occupied by a child-size figure of a girl in a small wooden boat. Additionally, the artists have covered the gallery walls with a yellow sky punctuated by puffy white clouds. A big round fish decorated with sequins and trailing painted peacock feathers hovers on one wall above aqua blue ocean waves that encircle the gallery, and a girl in a tall conical dress anchored to another fish is painted on the opposite wall. A near life-size houseboat inhabited by all sorts of quirky characters and animals fills the long wall. What it all means is hard to say, but the experience is transporting. (Deitch Projects, 76 Grand Street, SoHo, (212)343-7300, through April 2.) KEN JOHNSON

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: No Asylum For U.S. Army Deserter
description: The Immigration and Refugee Board denied refugee protection to Jeremy Hinzman, left, a United States Army deserter who fled to Toronto from Fort Bragg, N.C., in January 2004 to avoid serving in Iraq. The board rejected Mr. Hinzman's claim that he would face persecution or cruel and unusual punishment if returned to the United States and found instead that he "would be afforded the full protection of a fair and independent military and civilian judicial process in the U.S." Mr. Hinzman's lawyer said they would appeal the decision, during which time Mr. Hinzman, 26, would be allowed to stay in Canada. There are at least eight, and by some estimates several dozen, other American army deserters in Canada, but he is the first to apply for refugee status and have his case heard. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Deported Nigerian Student Can Return
description: A 19-year-old high school student who came to Ireland alone from Nigeria in 2002 and was deported this month along with 34 other failed asylum seekers will be allowed to return on a six-month visa to finish his senior-year exams. The government's reversal came after widespread condemnation of its immigration policies, including criticism from Diarmuid Martin, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Dublin. The case of the student, Elukanlo Olunkunle, gained attention after reports that he was put on a plane while still wearing his Dublin school uniform and that he has no family members left in Nigeria. Justice Minister Michael McDowell had refused to make an exception to a deportation order and said he did not believe the student's statements but reversed his stand after Elukanlo's Irish classmates demonstrated outside Parliament. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 5 Charged In Marijuana Ring
description: Five men were charged in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday with operating a wholesale marijuana cultivation and distribution ring out of three sites, including two near elementary schools. Peter Zuccaro, Michael Lezamiz, Leonard Palone, Joseph Iorio and Harry Gabor were charged with operating the indoor hydroponic growing scheme, which employed 15 people and had grossed nearly $12 million since 1997, according to the office of Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York, and District Attorney Denis Dillon of Nassau County. One of the growing warehouses was across the street from Public School 109 in East Flatbush, and another in the basement of Mr. Lezamiz's home in Bayside, Queens, opposite St. Robert Bellarmine School, the authorities said. Mr. Zuccaro, whom the authorities identified as the ring's leader, is in federal prison in Florida on an unrelated conviction, and is to be brought to New York next week for arraignment. The other four pleaded not guilty at their arraignments last week, the authorities said. All except Mr. Lezamiz were ordered held without bail. He was released on $5 million bail. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

A year ago, around the time of the Players Championship, Jones bought into a painting company in Bozeman, Mont., and bounced around from kitchen to kitchen, spraying and caulking with a smile.

title: A 60's Holdout and His Daughter, Searching for an Epic
description: The Jack of all trades in the new film "The Ballad of Jack and Rose," played by the brilliant actor Daniel Day-Lewis, is no ordinary man. A proud survivor of the 1960's and its utopian promise, Jack lives alone on an island with his only daughter, Rose (Camilla Belle), a doe-eyed beauty with the milky skin and ruby lips of a fairy-tale heroine. Shrunk to near-skeletal size, his bones poking right angles through his clothes, Jack suffers from two heart conditions. One will soon put him six feet under. But before that, the other may send the terminal outsider and his daughter down the path of disaster, though one shaped more by the tao of Oprah and Dr. Phil than the tragedy of Lear and Cordelia.

title: STEVE REICH
description: As part of its Composer Portraits series, the Miller Theater is devoting an evening to Steve Reich, with two of his major scores performed by the inventive So Percussion ensemble. For So Percussion (above), the timing is perfect: the group just released a fantastic recording of one of these works, "Drumming," on the Canteloupe new-music label. "Drumming," composed in 1971, is a pivotal work in Mr. Reich's catalog, and it has been getting lots of performances lately (the most recent by Tactus, a student ensemble at the Manhattan School of Music, just a couple of weeks ago). It draws on the techniques that Mr. Reich had explored in his early "phase" pieces -- works in which two lines that begin in unison move out of phase as beats are displaced, creating increasingly complicated webs of rhythm, timbre and psycho-acoustic effect. But it also looks back at his studies of African drum techniques. A performance can take on an almost ritualistic appearance; in fact, as the performers moved gradually from bongos to marimbas to xylophones and then to a combination of those instruments, plus voices and a piccolo, a listener can imagine an exotic hybrid of a gamelan orchestra and a factory production line. The other work on the program, Sextet, was composed in 1984, at a time when Mr. Reich was taking stock after the composition of "The Desert Music," a substantial piece for orchestra and chorus. Sextet, for four percussionists and two keyboard players (who double on pianos and synthesizers), begins with a figure from "The Desert Music" but then moves in its own direction. (Tonight at 8, Miller Theater, Broadway at 116th Street, Morningside Heights, (212)854-7799. Tickets are $20.) ALLAN KOZINN

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Stasi Files On Kohl Open To Researchers
description: After years of legal battling, a small part of a vast archive of files compiled by the former East German secret police, the Stasi, on former Chancellor Helmut Kohl was released to a restricted group of researchers and journalists. Last year, a federal court ruled that some 7,000-pages of files must remain "largely sealed in the future" and could be released only if the privacy of Mr. Kohl, above, were not put at risk. The chief of the agency that oversees the archive, Marianne Birthler, said that the 1,000 pages now released are unlikely to contain any great revelations. Victor Homola (NYT)

description: Pfizer agreed to buy the rights to an experimental drug for lung-cancer drug from the closely held Coley Pharmaceutical Group for as much as $505 million. Pfizer will pay Coley $50 million up front and as much as $455 million more for meeting certain goals. The drug, called ProMune, has already been tested in more than 900 patients with blood cancer and solid tumors, the companies said. Coley is based in Wellesley, Mass. Pfizer is based in New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Steel Maker Acquires Units
description: The steel maker Swiss Steel has agreed to acquire units of the German steel makers ThyssenKrupp and Schmolz & Bickenbach to more than double output and meet surging demand. The company said it would sell new shares to finance the deals, which will also more than double annual sales to about 2.5 billion Swiss francs ($2.1 billion). Swiss Steel had revenue of 893.7 million francs last year. Swiss Steel, based in Emmenbruecke, agreed to buy Edelstahl Witten-Krefeld from ThyssenKrupp for an undisclosed price. In a separate move, Swiss Steel will increase its 25 percent stake in Edelstahlwerke Suedwestfalen to 100 percent. Schmolz & Bickenbach owns most of the rest of Edelstahlwerke through its 80 percent stake in SBGE Stahl Holding. SBGE also holds a 54.6 percent stake in Swiss Steel. Benedikt Niemeyer, Swiss Steel's chairman, above, said the acquisitions would expand the company's range of products and would give it a foothold in Asia and the United States.

title: Where Second Homes Come With a Guide
description: LAST summer, as Geoff Jones prepared for his annual fly-fishing trip with his teenage son, he didn't turn to a guide service or ask fishing buddies for their advice. He called the "adventure concierge" at Iron Horse, a second-home community in Whitefish, Mont., where he owns a house. Through Iron Horse's Outdoor Pursuits program, Mr. Jones, a hedge-fund manager from New Vernon, N.J., booked a trip to the Elk River in Canada, with prime fishing spots and overnight accommodations all picked out.

title: Arts, Briefly; From Nanny to Broadway Star in 'Spelling Bee'
description: File under unusual career trajectories: next week Sarah Saltzberg, below, finishes a three-year tour as a nanny for the playwright Wendy Wasserstein's 5-year-old daughter and a few weeks later makes her Broadway debut in "The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee." Ms. Wasserstein is teaching a course this semester at Dartmouth College in New Hampshire and is taking Ms. Saltzberg with her next week on the trip as their final act as employer and employee. "We're going to Hanover on Tuesday, coming back Thursday, and the next Monday she starts rehearsing for Broadway," Ms. Wasserstein said. Ms. Saltzberg had been acting Off Broadway in "C-R-E-P-U-S-C-U-L-E" -- the play "Putnam County" is based on -- while working as a nanny. Ms. Wasserstein said that when she saw the play, she encouraged her friend William Finn, the composer and lyricist, to turn it into a musical, and he and others did just that. Ms. Saltzberg stayed with the show through its transformation. The show opened Off Broadway last month and is moving to the Circle in the Square on Broadway. It begins previews on April 15 and opens on May 2. KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

description: By a vote of 15 to 4, the Supreme Court reversed a lower-court ruling from December that stripped the former dictator Augusto Pinochet of his immunity from prosecution in the 1974 car-bombing death of Gen. The ruling was based, in effect, on a technicality but it ends the investigation into General Pinochet's suspected involvement in the case. description: WASHINGTON, March 23 - In the new documentary movie "Gunner Palace," about American servicemen on duty in Iraq, soldiers rap to the camera about the anxieties and absurdities of their daily grind, occasionally grousing about the goals and the tactics of the United States invasion. title: JURY RULES AGAINST BOSTON SCIENTIFIC IN PATENT CASE
description: A federal court jury said yesterday that Boston Scientific's Nir stent infringed a basic patent held by Johnson & Johnson on such metal mesh devices, which are implanted to prop open coronary blood vessels. The case was a retrial of a lawsuit that Johnson won in 2000, when it was awarded $324 million. That jury verdict was set aside in 2002 by Judge Sue L. Robinson of United States District Court in Wilmington, Del. Boston Scientific said that it no longer made the Nir and that yesterday's loss would not affect its current business. Still, it will appeal the verdict, it said. His installation is a spectacular folly, a lumberingly chilly and theatrical construction, mirrored floor to ceiling. At 81 feet, it is a corner of what, if it were a cube, would be large enough to enclose the rotunda. Imagine a glass office tower slammed through the front of the building. You enter backstage, as it were, in shadow, under a high tarpaulin, the sight being only of scaffolding and plywood, which supports the dozens of large mirrored panels on the other side.

The construction, begun last year and scheduled for completion in the spring of 2007, will also include a renovation of the Seattle Asian Art Museum, a satellite about two miles from the main museum downtown. title: FLOWSERVE AND ITS CHIEF SETTLE S.E.C. DISCLOSURE CASE
description: The Flowserve Corporation and its chief executive, C. Scott Greer, agreed to pay $400,000 to settle allegations that they broke a rule on fair disclosure by reaffirming an earnings forecast in a private meeting with analysts. It was the first fair disclosure case filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission involving a reaffirmation of earnings, the S.E.C. said. Mr. Greer gave analysts an unfair edge over other investors in November 2002, the S.E.C. said, when he repeated a month-old earnings forecast. Mr. Greer should have followed his company's policy that earnings guidance cannot be updated without a public announcement, the S.E.C. said. An analyst who was at the meeting issued a report to his clients, and the next day Flowserve's stock rose about 6 percent, the S.E.C. said. Flowserve and Mr. Greer neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing. The company agreed to pay a $350,000 fine and Mr. Greer agreed to pay $50,000. Flowserve is based in Irving, Tex.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Idol' Redo Didn't Capture the Night for Fox
description: Despite widespread interest in Tuesday's voting mishap that caused "American Idol" to redo its program the next night, Wednesday's show did not yield big enough numbers to give Fox a victory in Nielsen's overnight ratings estimates. Yes, "Idol" -- which showed the performances from Tuesday's episode (with Jessica Sierra, right) as replayed segments during Wednesday's otherwise live broadcast in order to display the correct phone numbers for voting -- was the evening's most-watched program: 20.61 million viewers tuned in. But that total, below the talent series's usual average for the night, could not trump the CBS lineup for the evening as a whole, which was No. 1 in total viewers and households. CBS featured a new "Survivor," which it had moved because of Thursday's college basketball games, and that show led into a repeat of "CSI" and a new episode of "CSI: NY": the combination of the three brought in an average of 17.22 million viewers. Fox did manage to eke out a victory over CBS among 18-to-49 year-olds, but by a tenth of a ratings point. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILMER, REV. RICHARD H. JR.
description: WILMER--Rev. Richard H. Jr., 86, an Episcopal priest and scholar, died in Pittsburgh on March 3, 2005. He was Episcopal chaplain at Yale University and later Dean of Berkeley Divinity School. He is survived by his wife, Sarah King Wilmer of Pittsburgh; two sons, Richard IV of Arlington, VA and Stephen E. of Dublin, Ireland; three daughters, Margaret Bartlett of New Vernon, NJ, Natalie Blenk of London, England, and Christine Barkus of New York City; and 10 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on April 9 at 2 PM in Calvary Episcopal Church, Shadyside, Pitt sburgh. The family suggests memorial contributions to the National Cathedral, 3101 Wisconsin Ave., NW, Washington, DC 20016-5098.

title: Hot Springs, Ark.
description: HOT SPRINGS loves the ponies. For most of the year, this Arkansas resort town trades on its past and its considerable natural beauty. After all, it's the city where travelers came for therapeutic spa treatments in the early 1900's, where vacationing gangsters unwound during Prohibition and where President Bill Clinton spent his formative years. Nestled in a wooded valley in the Ouachita Mountains, Hot Springs is the oldest protected property in the National Park System, with luxurious bathhouses and lush, undeveloped mountain trails mere steps from downtown. But when the races are on at Oaklawn Park -- from mid-January to mid-April -- it's hard to persuade locals to talk about anything but horseflesh, handicapping and emerging favorites in the Arkansas Derby, the season's climactic event. Last year's champion, Smarty Jones, went on to win the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes. With the Oaklawn season ending on April 16, a racing weekend is the perfect way to explore this beautiful city, which seems equally proud of its storied heritage, its seamy underbelly and the place where the two overlap. PABLEAUX JOHNSON

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Quest Will Pay $16 Million To End Suit
description: Quest Software, a maker of software for managing computer databases, agreed yesterday to pay at least $16 million to end a lawsuit by Computer Associates International that claimed improper copying of software code. The agreement lets Quest resume selling its Quest Central for DB2 database management software, which was blocked by a federal judge in Chicago in July 2004, the companies said. Quest, which is based in Irvine, Calif., did not admit any wrongdoing. Computer Associates, based in Islandia, N.Y., claimed that Quest developed its software program after hiring former employees of Platinum Technology International, a company Computer Associates had acquired. The suit said Quest copied "substantive portions" of Platinum source code into its software program. Computer Associates accused Quest of copyright infringement and theft of trade secrets. Quest countered with a challenge to the validity of some Computer Associates copyrights.

description: One more post-Soviet autocracy appeared to have crumbled yesterday as the president of Kyrgyzstan, Askar Akayev, fled with his family while opposition protestors swarmed into the presidential compound in the capital city of Bishkek. It was a shabby but deserved ending to almost 15 years of rule by a man who was once praised as Central Asia's most democratically inclined leader. Of course, that is something of a backhanded compliment in a region where repressive troglodytes are the norm.

With the exception of the Baltic republics -- Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, now deeply entwined in Europe -- new political systems and new leaders emerged from the post-Soviet chaos promising freedoms but somehow managing to ensure that those freedoms led to the continuation of their power.

title: Protests Force Authoritarian Leader to Flee in Kyrgyzstan

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dell Plans New China Plant
description: Dell, the world's largest personal computer maker, said yesterday that it planned to build a new plant in southeastern China, doubling production capacity in the nation to increase sales in the North Asia region. "China is integral to Dell's worldwide development," the chairman and founder, Michael S. Dell, left, said in an e-mailed statement. The new plant in Xiamen, Dell's second in the city, will serve customers in China and Japan. Dell, based in Round Rock, Tex., is trying to drive sales in Asia, the Middle East and Europe as orders in the United States slow. Asia accounted for about 11 percent of Dell's sales of $49 billion in the year ended Jan. 28, according to the company's earnings statement. The company also has a plant in Penang, Malaysia. Judy Low, a Dell spokeswoman, declined to disclose the investment in the Xiamen plant. The factory will have annual capacity of six million units, China Business News reported yesterday.

title: Albany's Ethics Policeman Would Like More Muscle

Given the prevailing public sentiment on the strange-bedfellows relationship between government and ethics -- as in, what relationship? -- the task of policing the ethics of New York State's employees may seem as productive, and outmoded, as estimating angels dancing on a pinhead. Ludicrous. Especially when state employees can kiss their ethics violations goodbye simply by resigning or retiring.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Wants To Limit Bike Protest
description: The city is seeking to limit the monthly Critical Mass protest ride through Manhattan by requiring permits for the ride and for the use of the group's main staging area, Union Square. Critical Mass rides, held on the last Friday evening of each month, advocate nonpolluting forms of transportation. On Tuesday, city summonses were given to four Critical Mass participants, directing them to answer a city complaint seeking permits for the rides and for the use of Union Square. The complaint also seeks an order banning participants from advertising the ride. A lawyer representing Critical Mass, Norman Siegel, said it would be unconstitutional to prevent the group from advertising its activities. But a lawyer for the city, Robin Binder, said the group did not have the "right to advertise an unlawful activity." Colin Moynihan (NYT)

title: GUILFORD PHARMACEUTICALS HALTS STUDY OF SEDATIVE
description: Guilford Pharmaceuticals, which sells heart and cancer treatments, halted enrollment in studies of its sedative, Aquavan, after a recent trial showed that the product caused more side effects than a competing drug, setting off a 33 percent decline in its share price. Aquavan gave patients a deeper level of sedation for a longer period of time than the comparison drug, midazolam, Guilford said. The findings may slow the company's plan to seek clearance for Aquavan, which is in the final phase of testing generally required for Food and Drug Administration approval. A lower dose of Aquavan may be more appropriate, Guilford's chief executive, Dean J. Mitchell, said. Shares in the company, based in Baltimore, fell $1.19, to $2.34 yesterday.

But for the second Thursday in a row, an evening of basketball was not enough to pull CBS into first place on a night that its regular schedule usually dominates: NBC was No.1 in both total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. It was, however, an odd victory for the network, since "Joey," "The Apprentice" and "ER" all delivered their lowest ratings ever for original episodes. The premiere of the NBC series "The Office," starring Steve Carell, above, was sandwiched between an "Apprentice" -- in which Donald Trump nearly fired someone because he chews tobacco (and, worse, swallows the juice rather than using a spittoon) -- and "ER." "The Office," the American version of the acclaimed British sitcom of the same title, brought in a modestly successful 11.3 million viewers. description: "The Purpose-Driven Life," the best-selling book by the California pastor Rick Warren, got a quick sales boost after reports earlier this month that it helped Ashley Smith, the hostage in the Atlanta courthouse killings case, persuade her captor to release her. In the week ending March 20 , sales of "The Purpose-Driven Life" (Zondervan, 2002) jumped to more than 64,000 copies from about 12,000 the previous week, according to Nielsen BookScan. The actual numbers were probably far higher, because BookScan counts sales at outlets that make up about 70 percent of retail book purchases. "The Purpose-Driven Life" will be No.1 on the New York Times best-seller list of advice, how-to and miscellaneous books on April 3, reflecting sales for the week ended March 19, the book's 114th week on the best-seller list. (On Sunday, the book will be No. 3, reflecting sales for the week ended March 12, the week that the courthouse killings occurred.) More sales are likely to follow as publicity continues about the book's remarkable success; Mr. Warren is to be interviewed on Sunday on "This Week" on ABC. EDWARD WYATT

title: Arts, Briefly; New Who Album Delayed
