"The release date I had hoped for in the late spring or very early summer was whipped from under my nose after three years of writing," Mr. Townshend wrote in an online diary, adding that he would not tour with the Who without a new record. "It's probably my fault," he continued, "because I work very slowly in the studio, and either no one believed I was actually recording, or they got tired of waiting." Still, Mr. Townshend said the album was not canceled. In the meantime, he said he would continue to write an autobiography and record music for his short story "The Boy Who Heard Music," which he hopes to turn into an animated feature. title: Arts, Briefly; Reaching the 25-to-54's
description: On the less splashy cable channels, the ones that don't feature zeitgeist-piquing shows like HBO's "Deadwood" or Bravo's "Project Runway," it's the incremental gains that matter. On Wednesday, TV Land, known more for its reruns of "The Andy Griffith Show" than for cutting-edge original programming, featured the debut of "Chasing Farrah," a six-part reality series that follows Farrah Fawcett, right. According to Nielsen estimates, it drew an audience of 824,000: not a stunning total, but one that represented a 40 percent improvement in the time period compared with the same night in 2004. Within the 25-to-54 age demographic that TV Land targets, the increase was more than 50 percent. The National Geographic Channel is another cable network that appeals to that group of viewers, often ignored by programmers focusing on younger audiences, which are deemed more attractive to advertisers. Its Sunday installment of the "Explorer" series -- a documentary on the "Hogzilla" story, about a giant pig in South Georgia that became famous when its photograph circulated via e-mail -- attracted 1.75 million viewers, the highest total for the show this year. title: A Global View of Human Experience That Tells Some of the Stories Behind the News
description: As foreign-language films that appear in the United States are increasingly marginalized by the Hollywood-dominated marketplace, a festival like New Directors/New Films -- a joint presentation of the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center -- becomes one of the few cinematic expressions of a global perspective. A movie like "Live-In Maid" humanizes an economic crisis in Argentina that for most people is just a bunch of facts and figures in a newspaper article or a one-minute clip on television. The scary documentary "Darwin's Nightmare" portrays a world teetering on the brink of catastrophe in which, like it or not, international trade and transportation connect everyone. "Young Rebels," a modest documentary about the Cuban rap scene, shows the consequences of Communism and the longstanding United States trade embargo on this tiny island nation. An immersion in New Directors/New Films is one way to develop a perspective on the human experience that transcends international power politics and commerce. STEPHEN HOLDEN

Arts, Briefly; British Library Must Return Looted Prayer Book
description: A British government panel has ruled that a 12th-century prayer book that has been part of the British Library's collection for more than 50 years must be given back to city of Benevento in southern Italy. This will be the first restoration of an artwork plundered during World War II that was held in a British national collection. A panel set up by the government in 2000 to determine whether artworks in its national collection were inappropriately acquired during the Nazi era ruled on Wednesday that an English army captain had looted the rare missal. The ruling, which ends Benevento's nearly 30-year campaign for the book's restoration, also called for a new law easing the return of looted treasures. The prayer book, containing 290 folios in a script identified with the Benevento region, was written in the scriptorium of a monastery there. This is the third ruling by the panel since British museums agreed in 1998 to publish a list of thousands of artworks with questionable origins acquired from 1933 to 1945. Italy's Culture Ministry has long complained that the country's unique richness in archaeological and artistic artifacts has made it a favorite target of looters. JASON HOROWITZ

description: GENDLER--Paul H., Ed.D. Died March 24, at age 79, after a three-month struggle following influenza pneumonia. Lifelong educator, first as exemplary teacher and principal, then as respected superintendent of schools, and finally after retirement as founder of Language Institute For English, intensive schools for English as a Second Language at universities across the country--but always as the most amazing husband, father and grandfather. Everyone who knew him was in awe of his brilliance, wit and supreme kindness. Dearest husband of 52 years of Rochelle, beloved father of Dr. Ellen Gendler and Dr. Seth Gendler, much loved fatherin-law of Dr. James Salik and Dr. Lilia Gendler, adored grandfather of Jonathan and Michael Salik and Samantha and Clement Gendler, brother of Dr. Samuel Gendler and Lawrence Gendler. He was a man of unusual intellect, the quintessential scholar who knew everything from Shakespeare to world history, as well as being a formidable chess player and champion billiards player. His unique gifts will live on through the students he taught with whom he continued to be in contact, the people who worked for him at L.I.F.E., and the family he loved so much. The world is richer because he was in it. Services Sunday 1 PM, Gutterman's, Boca Raton, FL. description: JESSI SMITH sat at the kitchen table working on homework and talking about poetry. Her father sat across from her figuring taxes and discussing his goals for her future. The tension between them was dramatic, literally. Jessi, a senior at Irvington High School, had written the scene and was acting it out with a classmate as part of a drama workshop that sent suburban youth to the city, city youth to the suburbs and both groups to Broadway.

title: You Might Call Them Salt Water Daffies
description: There must be something in the water. How else do you explain why politicians in two shore communities -- Beach Haven and Atlantic City -- have bolted from their party?

title: Another About-Face Leaves Nets Little Time
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 26 - Two weeks ago, it looked as if the Nets had no chance to make the postseason. A week ago, it seemed that they would not only make it, but that they were also steaming toward the seventh seeding.

title: The Song of Himself
description: "DON'T you look grand!" Bobby Short shouted from behind the piano at the Caf Carlyle this past December. The packed, cheering house of 100 looked grand indeed on a weeknight, with a $95 cover charge.

title: Other Sports to Blame
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Chapter House Divided (and Rebuilt, a Few Centuries Later)
description: VINA, Calif. - SOME people say that God works in mysterious ways, but the 22 Cistercian-Trappist monks of New Clairvaux Abbey in this slightly scruffy Sacramento Valley farm community believe they have precious evidence to prove it.

title: The Interregnum
description: It saddened me that as we leave the Arafat era and turn toward new Palestinian leaders with whom we hope to establish peaceful relations, all who spoke out against terrorism and violence against innocent Israeli civilians did so because it wasn't advantageous to their end goal, rather than because violence and terror are immoral.

title: Discovering Jewish Roots on Caribbean Soil
description: WHEN Lisa Hock's son Corey was about to turn 13 and she began looking for an alternative to the routine and occasional excess of banquet-hall bar mitzvahs in Toronto, her hometown, she hardly imagined that he would end up reciting the blessings while shuffling through sand on a Caribbean island.

title: Geo-Greening by Example
description: How will future historians explain it? How will they possibly explain why President George W. Bush decided to ignore the energy crisis staring us in the face and chose instead to spend all his electoral capital on a futile effort to undo the New Deal, by partially privatizing Social Security? We are, quite simply, witnessing one of the greatest examples of misplaced priorities in the history of the U.S. presidency.

title: ONE BULLDOZER LATER
description: Andrew J. Krieger of Franklin Lakes agreed to pay $2 million to the Palisades Interstate Park Commission and $750,000 to Bergen County after being accused of bulldozing 1.5 acres of parkland adjoining his former home. Mr. Krieger was indicted in 2003 by a Bergen County grand jury on charges of theft, criminal mischief and conspiracy, charges that carried up to 10 years in prison. The department, the park and the county had sought compensatory and punitive damages from Mr. Krieger. The Department of Environmental Protection announced the settlement last Tuesday, the same day Mr. Krieger pleaded guilty to a reduced charge of criminal mischief. He will be sentenced on the criminal charges on June 24. Tina Kelley

title: Pope Makes Appearance but Is Unable to Speak
The Future of the 30-Second Spot
description: DEVOTEES of Home & Garden Television, sitting in the comfort of their living rooms on the 33rd floor of a Manhattan high-rise, probably could not care less about commercials for lawn mowers or snow blowers. If they have TiVo, they probably zap right through the ads; if not, they can just change channels.

title: Yankees' Posada Studies Pitches and Personalities
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 26 - Jorge Posada was 26, in his second full major league season, when the catching gods bestowed their rarest gift: total synchronicity with a pitcher. Posada called the pitches for David Wells's perfect game, in 1998, and the experience empowered him.

title: Groceries Everywhere, but Not a Delivery to Be Had
description: On the Web site for Fresh Direct, the online grocery that will deliver everything from ginger root to duck breast to your doorstep, there are small asterisks next to the ZIP codes 11101 and 11109, the two codes that represent Long Island City in Queens. When most shoppers from that area try to place an order, the site replies, "Unfortunately, we do not currently deliver to your neighborhood." Those customers are then told they can pick up their orders themselves at Fresh Direct headquarters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERGEN, JAMES G.
description: HERGEN--James G. One of the greatest men of The Greatest Generation on March 24, 2005. Loving husband of the late Audrey. Devoted father of his daughters Ellen and Tracey, and his sons Jim, George, Bob and Jeff. Beloved grandfather of Adrienne, Drew, James, Connor, Audrey, Kathryn and Nicole. His gentle and generous life was an inspiration to all who knew him. Born in 1917, he came of age in the Depression, served as an officer in the U.S. Army during WW II, retired as Vice President of NBC and as a senior executive of Ringling Bros. Circus World in FL. We shall not see his like again. Visiting Monday 2-5 & 7-9 PM at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, New York. Funeral Mass 9:45 AM at St. Francis De Sales Church. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: A Bus Strike Little Noted but Keenly Felt
description: YONKERS - IN the leafy reaches of northern Westchester they lumber along or at least they used to -- gears groaning on rolling suburban terrain, like hippos or elephants that have wandered into the wrong ecosystem. You can live in Westchester forever and never think of getting on a bus, never know a soul who does.

title: The Mystery Composer
description: I'VE developed a bad habit: I dump new CD's onto my iPod and then digest them at my leisure. True, the iPod's sound quality is inferior to that of a CD. But there are also unexpected benefits. The other week I pressed "Play" and was brought up short: what on earth is this?

title: AARP's Antagonist
description: Readers of Deborah Solomon's questions for USA Next's Charlie Jarvis (March 13) doubtless assumed that Jarvis was speaking in jest when he said that if his sons voted Democratic, he would "beat them with a rubber hose." Perhaps not. Jarvis's former employer, the conservative Christian group Focus on the Family, still advocates corporal punishment, albeit using a switch or a paddle rather than a rubber hose. Even so, members of AARP, like thoughtful people everywhere, should watch their backs.

title: Stuck on the Bee-Line
description: As the strike that has idled the county's Bee-Line buses drags through its fourth week, we have found ourselves wondering what planet the union negotiators are from. Wherever it is, we would like to live there, too -- it sounds like a nice place, where workers with 20 years' experience, for example, can retire at 57 with a full pension, and fully paid health benefits for life.

title: Sea Glass, Starfish, Beached Ship
description: I grew up inland. My experience with shipwrecks was limited to what I saw on "Gilligan's Island." That changed 20 years ago when I woke to a foggy dawn on Long Beach Island, looked out my window and saw an empty luxury cabin cruiser beached in front of my house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PASCAL, GRANT OLIVER
description: PASCAL--Grant Oliver, December 18, 1986 to March 24, 2005. You were taken from us much too soon. You were such a beautiful person, you never failed to end our conversations with "I love you". We will love you forever and the emptiness in our hearts will never be filled. You will always be our beloved, beautiful boy. Grandma and Poppa Grandma Aleene, Mom, Dad, Zachary, Nikki, Aunts, Uncles and Cousins.

title: The Rebirth of Bali
description: STUMBLING down Legian Street on Bali on a humid Tuesday night, Tim Picken had a buddy on one arm and a beer on the other. He poked his head into a T-shirt shop, shared a joke about the cheap prices and flirted with the passers-by. Then, before he ducked into another bar along this neon-and-booze strip in Kuta, Mr. Picken stopped laughing for a few moments, just long enough to pay his respects.

title: And Don't Even Get Her Started on the War
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EISENBERGER, LOTTE
description: EISENBERGER--Lotte. On March 23, 2005 at age 87. Born in Vienna, Austria, she emigrated to New York to escape Hitler with her husband, Walter Eisenberger, and her sister and husband Mimi and Theo Klein. Settling in Harrison in 1954, Lotte entered real estate and opened her own office, Lotte Eisenberger Real Estate at the little cottage on the corner of Harrison and Union Avenues "Right in the Heart of Harrison". A force in Westchester real estate for a half century, where she helped some families find new homes three and four times over the years, Lotte will be remembered for her special grace, personal touch, and humility. Divorced in 1968, Lotte spent many happy years with her companion, colleague and second husband Al Conklin, who died in 2000. She will be missed by all who knew her, including her former colleagues, her many friends and customers, and her family-her son, Peter Eisenberger, grandson, Nicholas Eisenberger, his wife Robin, and Al's children, Candida, Victoria and Geoffrey. A public memorial reception will be held on Sunday, April 3 from 4:30--6:30 pm at Wain wright House, 260 Stuyvesant Ave., Rye, NY. Her family requests that instead of flowers you send a donation to Habitat for Humanity International, a favorite charity of Lotte's.

title: Letters
Congressman Calls for Investigation of Railyards Bidding Process
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner, a Democratic candidate for mayor of New York, accused the Bloomberg administration yesterday of engaging in a "classic, old-fashioned back-room deal" to get a Jets stadium built on the West Side of Manhattan, and called on the city and state comptrollers to investigate the bidding process.

title: Condo Conversions In an Architectural Gem
description: ELAD PROPERTIES may be in the hot seat over its plans to convert the venerated Plaza Hotel it acquired for $675 million last year, but that does not mean it has caused a stir with all of its projects around the city in the last few years.

title: Ghostly Hospital Becomes a Live Issue
description: A PENDING state sale of the former Kings Park Psychiatric Center to a developer with tentative plans for up to 1,800 townhouse and condominium units, perhaps including a small number of lower-priced "workforce housing" units, is facing mounting opposition in Smithtown.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a roundup on March 13 about cultural events in Europe this summer misstated the ticket prices for the Edinburgh International Festival. At the exchange rate of $1.96 to the pound, tickets cost $11.75 to $113.65, with a few seats available an hour before performances for $9.75. The roundup also referred incorrectly to the precedent for the revival of "Guys and Dolls" to open on June 1 at the Piccadilly Theater. It will not be the first in London since 1982; there was one at the National in 1996.

title: Bomb in Christian Area of Beirut Wounds 5
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 26 - A car bomb exploded in a predominantly Christian neighborhood in eastern Beirut on Saturday night, the eve of Easter, wounding at least five people and destroying two factories.

title: End of the Auto Show Season: That's All There Is?
description: NEW YORK often puts an exclamation point at the end of the winter-spring season of international auto shows. This year, however, the New York International Auto Show raises an ambiguous question mark: Is that -- apologies to Peggy Lee -- all there is?

title: Justice Scalia and the Life of Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurant Scene Reflects Tel Aviv's Optimistic Resolve
description: LIKE Bali, Tel Aviv is a place all too familiar with terrorism. This balmy Mediterranean city, with its historic Bauhaus core and ancient Arab quarter of Jaffa, has to contend with cycles of terror much like other cities struggle with unmanageable traffic jams or unseasonable weather woes. The security situation informs nearly every aspect of daily life in Tel Aviv -- from the constant bag searches at malls and restaurants to the sense of suspicion that greets unattached packages or bus passengers who act oddly.

title: Texas Official Admits Missteps That Helped Railroads in Suits
description: Several months ago, the Texas official overseeing rail crossings commented in court proceedings that many in the rail industry "would consider me their friend." That may not be surprising given what the official, Darin Kosmak, has done to help railroads fight lawsuits brought by accident victims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BURDICK, RICHARD
description: BURDICK--Richard. A great loss is felt by our family and his many friends at the passing of Richard Smith Burdick, 88, on March 17, 2005 in Austin, Texas. He was predeceased by his wife of 54 years, Betty. He leaves his beloved fiance, Sherry Browne. He was the loving Father of Dorene and Bruce Burdick, and of daughter-inlaw Gwenellen; proud grandfather of Surya, Michelle, Orion, Douglass, and Melissa, and great-grandfather of Riley, Wolfie, Jake, and Amelie. He is also survived by his adored sister, Loyce and his close cousins, the Smiths: Penny, Ron, and Pat; and by the Coons cousins. Richard Burdick was born in Pittsfield, Mass. in 1916 among his treasured Berkshire Hills. A magician and writer even as a boy, he spent his stint in the Army as cowriter of This Is the Army with Irving Berlin. During that time he also wrote many stage musicals, radio dramas, and short stories. In the lifetime of a multifaceted career -writer, producer, actor, director, composer-lyricist, magician, and broadcasting executive -he enjoyed singular encounters with a mosaic of celebrated people: Ethel Barrymore, Mae West, Max Baer, Joe Louis, Tallulah Bankhead, Jimmy Durante, Gary Merrill, Helen Hayes, Kay Kyser, Dinah Shore, Duke Ellington, Dr. Dinton Cooley, Eleanor Roosevelt, President Truman, Reverend Billy Graham, and Dr. Timothy Johnson. Richard Burdick was a visionary pioneer in public broadcasting. He was a theatrical director and operations manager in early radio and he helped launch one of the first educational TV stations in the country -WUNC-TV in Chapel Hill, N.C. Following this, he was managing director at the public TV station WHYY in Philadelphia, always contributing original scripts. He was on the founding management team of WCVB , one of the top-rated TV stations in Boston which produced great quality, quantity, and diversity of local programming, and which the NY Times called the finest commercial TV station in America. He became a board member, contributing playwright ( of eleven plays), and supporter of Florida Studio Theater in Sarasota, Florida and also was cherished by other theatres including Shakespeare & Co. in Lenox, Mass. where he was a Founding Trustee member and where he contributed three plays. Richard had a talent for living, an unflagging and exceptional creative drive, and a generosity of spirit and mind that was highly motivating to his family, friends and associates. In his autobiography entitled: Next Time I Want To Come Back As a Yellow Bird, he opens with his usual flourish and excitement, asking "Do you believe in magic?" and he clearly did delight in Life's great mystery and drama; and always with his unique, Burdick wit. He closed the book with this comment: " ...as the river of Life continues its eternal flow, my personal tributary will rejoin it on its way back to the source." A memorial gathering will take place in May in his home town of Pittsfield, Mass., details to be finalized soon. Cards can be sent to Sherry Browne, 8408 Hayes Lane, Austin, Texas 78759

title: Teenage Gambling Craze: More Sinister Than Benign?
America Is Still Working on Its Abs
description: BY some measures the heyday of abdominal fitness was a decade ago. Men's Health magazine rode to publishing glory in the 1990's with a monthly cover model showing off his washboard stomach. The term six-pack entered the language of vanity. Driven by late-night television advertising, some 368,000 AbRollers, ABSculptors and other stomach-muscle strengtheners were sold in 1996, according to the National Sporting Goods Association.

title: One Surprise Investors May Love
description: ECONOMISTS, strategists, money managers and individual investors are always worried about being fooled by monthly jobs reports.

title: The Quality Cure?
description: While I was generally impressed with the ideas put forth by David Cutler in Roger Lowenstein's article (March 13), and agree that in some cases improving the quality of health care will also lower long-term costs, I take issue with one of his premises: that doctors should be rewarded for successfully manipulating the behavior of their patients. It seems that in many ways, as a society we are deciding that precious little is our own fault. Thus it makes a perverse kind of sense that it is up to me to persuade my patients to give up their unhealthy habits and to take the drugs that evidence-based medicine indicates are good for them, as well as to take the blame when a lifetime of poor choices (or simply bad genes) leads to a negative medical outcome. But where does this end? Will I be suing my accountant next year if my profligate spending lands me in bankruptcy?

title: Emily Buchwald and Jay Straus
description: Dr. Emily L. Buchwald, a pediatrician, and Jay B. Straus, a lawyer, were married last evening at the Park Avenue Synagogue in Manhattan. Rabbi Alan F. Lavin officiated, with Cantor David Lefkowitz taking part.

title: 'Fat Girl': Big
description: FAT GIRL A True Story. By Judith Moore. 196 pp. Hudson Street Press. $21.95.

title: Theater of the Phobic, With Sitcom Misfits
description: Montclair - THANKS to a batch of recent films and television shows featuring central characters with physical disabilities or mental health problems -- "As Good as It Gets," "I Am Sam," "Monk" -- Ian Walker's play "A Beautiful Home for the Incurable" doesn't feel as exploitative as it might have a decade ago. In fact, so thoroughly has this territory been mined that instead it mostly feels late to the party.

title: Inside a Condo, a Not-So-Civil War
description: EVER since the Future Condominium, a modern glass and aluminum tower on East 32nd Street, opened in 1993, Avital Shimshowitz and her neighbors have lived in simple peace and harmony, at least most of the time, in this vertical Manhattan village.

title: In Mamaroneck, Seafood and a History
description: MAMARONECK - THIS compact landmark house facing Harbor Island Park in Mamaroneck comes with the merest bit of history, as any historical trappings within its 1792 frame have long been lost. But some might be interested to know that before this building was bumped down rickety roads from Mamaroneck's higher ground to its present bay location, James Fenimore Cooper was married here in 1811 and lived here briefly.

title: Words to Dread: Let's Meet on It
description: EARLY in my career, I wrote a book about the workings of a hospital. I spent much time following doctors from bedside to bedside, and still more time following them from meeting to meeting. This hospital, ostensibly to whittle down the number of meetings, even had a Committee on Committees. The group spent most of its time working out scheduling conflicts in the hospital's meeting rooms. That was 12 years ago. Last I heard, the Committee on Committees still exists, and it still meets every few weeks.

title: Stalking the Wildlife in the Living Room
description: WHEN Cynthia Letterman, 56, a retired aerospace engineer, opens her home to visits from her 4 children and 14 grandchildren, it could become a zoo -- if it weren't one already. Among the inhabitants are coatimundis, kinkajous, fennec foxes, sugar gliders, ring-tailed lemurs, marmoset monkeys, eclectus and sun conure parrots, as well as a prairie dog named Fido.

title: Make It in Dan Tana's, You Can Make It Anywhere
description: Los Angeles - ON a Monday night at Dan Tana's restaurant, two generously proportioned men with pronounced Brooklyn accents stood waiting at the bar for a table to be ready. Wearing a velour jogging suit accessorized by a few gold chains, the slimmer of the two unfurled a roll of hundreds to pay for his drinks. The other, wearing gabardine slacks with an oversize rayon shirt, never looked away from the N.C.A.A. tournament playing on the muted televison hanging above the bar.

title: Yes, the Paint Is Deductible. No, the Beret Is Not.
description: A musician taking an 11,000-mile tour on a shoestring budget in his Volvo station wagon earns $40 cash playing guitar and singing at a dive bar in Georgia. He spends that same $40 on gas, but keeps no records. Is the money taxable?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILMER, REV. RICHARD H. JR.
description: WILMER--Rev. Richard H. Jr., 86, an Episcopal priest and scholar, died in Pittsburgh on March 3, 2005. He was Episcopal chaplain at Yale University and later Dean of Berkeley Divinity School. He is survived by his wife, Sarah King Wilmer of Pittsburgh; two sons, Richard IV of Arlington, VA and Stephen E. of Dublin, Ireland; three daughters, Margaret Bartlett of New Vernon, NJ, Natalie Blenk of London, England, and Christine Barkus of New York City; and 10 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on April 9 at 2 PM in Calvary Episcopal Church, Shadyside, Pitt sburgh. The family suggests memorial contributions to the National Cathedral, 3101 Wisconsin Ave., NW, Washington, DC 20016-5098.

title: Corrections
description: An "In the Region" article in New Jersey copies last Sunday about a condominium tower planned along the Hudson River misidentified the county for North Bergen. It is Hudson, not Bergen.

description: Alissa Beth Ticotin, a daughter of Andrea and Mark S. Ticotin of New City, N.Y., was married last evening to David Samuel Greenhaus, a son of Anita Greenhaus -Elkins of Huntington, N.Y., and Philip S. Greenhaus of Yonkers. Rabbi David M. Posner officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: 15 Minutes of Blame? Not Our Conferences
description: IN the current educational environment, it's not surprising that parents, invested as they are in their children's success at school, worry about hearing a less-than-glowing report in the 15 minutes of the seasonal parent-teacher conference.

Miss America Jr.
description: While its main pageant still does not have a television contract -- yes, the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show has a TV contract, but not the Miss America Pageant -- the Miss America Organization has announced that it will sponsor a new one: Miss America's Outstanding Teen Competition. Instead of being held in its Atlantic City home, though, the Miss America Organization will put on the teenage competition in Orlando, Fla., Aug. 17 to 20, a month before the Miss America Pageant.

title: What Next, the Grill Room?
description: Philip Johnson, who died in January, wielded so much power that even when he was in his 90's no young architect -- and compared to Johnson, all architects were young -- would risk antagonizing him by altering one of his buildings. (Yoshio Taniguchi was chosen to renovate the Museum of Modern Art in part because his scheme included restoring the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden, designed by Johnson in 1953.) But with Johnson gone, and many of his buildings approaching the half-century mark, some of them may not receive the same loving care as the sculpture garden:

title: INSIDE
description: Grass-Roots Effort Challenges Zimbabwe's Leader Zvakwana, an underground movement, is seeking to resist -- and eventually undermine -- the authoritarian rule of Robert G. Mugabe, who has led Zimbabwe for 25 years. PAGE 3

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "The right-to-die families find a more receptive audience in the hospital, as opposed to years ago when a doctor might say, My job is not to end life."

title: In a City of 8 Million People, Murder Victims Are Hard to Hide
description: "No body, no crime," goes the old saw, and New York City boasts a colorful history of people going missing forever, with no criminal case ever being made.

title: The Wounded
description: As of March 18, 11,344 American soldiers had been injured in the war in Iraq. Starting with the first tourniquet or I.V. applied at the scene of the trauma, today's war wounded experience a rapid sequence of carefully choreographed medical treatments. From the battlefield, an injured soldier is carried to a nearby combat medical facility, where doctors try to stop the bleeding, sanitize the wounds and begin treatment. If the injuries require further care, the patient is evacuated by cargo plane to a military hospital at Landstuhl, Germany, and finally transferred to a long-term-care facility in the United States. During the Vietnam War, a comparable journey took 45 days; today, it takes less than 4. The speed of the process, combined with improvements in body armor and surgical care, has made a lifesaving difference: the current survival rate among wounded soldiers is 87 percent -- up from about 75 percent in Vietnam.

title: Tribe Buries 3 on a Long Road to Healing
description: RED LAKE, Minn., March 26 - Hundreds of cars police squad cars from cities miles away, dark sedans carrying political leaders, and the ordinary, older cars of those who live here -- wound their way on Saturday through the isolated Red Lake Indian Reservation, past the high school, past the makeshift memorial for those who died here, and on to the first funeral.

title: With Its Old Standbys, N.C.A.A. Is Not Clicking With a New Generation
description: THERE has been the N.C.A.A. tournament's brand-name face to love: Vermont Coach Tom Brennan looked as if he had swallowed organic moonbeams when his crunchy Catamounts left his state's citizens leapin' in their Birkenstocks after mercifully shortening Jim Boeheim's annual attempt at turning Syracuse U. into Persecute U.

title: Finding a More Authentic Jamaica
description: IT'S not particularly easy to get to Portland parish, a lush, often rainy region on Jamaica's northeast coast. The closest airport with jet service from the United States is Norman Manley International in Kingston, which is at least two, and sometimes three, hours away by car, depending on the number of potholes, trucks, chickens, goats and bicycling Rastafarians encountered on the road.

title: Granted: Cellphones Make Life Easier. But Better? Well ...
description: This may seem a bizarre concept to younger readers, but there was a time when, say, arranging a street-corner meeting was a complex task. You would set the time and place, making contingency plans for unforeseen delays, and if you got a detail wrong, the rendezvous would misfire. (Whole movie plots revolve around such missed connections.)

title: March Madness Isn't So Crazy
description: TEANECK - TAMIEN TRENT, a senior guard on the men's basketball team at Fairleigh Dickinson University, let a majestic shot fly from well behind the 3-point arc, and the ball dropped through the hoop as the buzzer sounded, as if on an unseen track. Then Trent signed his piece of artwork by tugging at his navy jersey so every letter on the front could be seen.

title: Call Them What They Are
description: To the Editor:

title: DataBank; Fed's Warning on Inflation Weighs on Markets
description: Federal Reserve policy makers said last week that price pressures had risen recently, sending an inflation tremor through the stock and bond markets.

title: The Fax Machine: Technology That Refuses to Die
description: IF any of Rodney Eddins's accounting clients want his undivided attention at work first thing in the morning, they should shun e-mail or his telephone answering machine. Instead, they should send him a fax.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THEY say that in any affair, one person loves more than the other. In ANNE OF THE THOUSAND DAYS (1969), Charles Jarrott's sublime historical romance, it's Henry VIII (Richard Burton) who adores the young Anne Boleyn (Genevive Bujold) at first, while she finds him disgusting. He almost literally moves heaven and earth to have her, creating the Church of England in order to divorce Catherine of Aragon. But just as Anne is falling in love with him (well into their marriage), his affections wane. The film makes it clear that she's not having affairs right and left, as Henry's advisers want him to believe, but there is the matter of a male heir -- Tuesday at 9:30 p.m. on TCM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, MARGARET
description: HOROWITZ -- Margaret on March 23, 2005. Beloved wife of 64 years of Raymond. Loving mother of Judith Babcock. She will be profoundly missed. Funeral private. Memorial service to be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to your favorite art museum.

title: Cause of Mystery Ills Splits Indonesian Fishing Village
description: BUYAT BAY BEACH, Indonesia - This is a simple village where the fishermen's families live on the sea in wooden shacks lighted by oil lamps and most everyone knows one another. But the people are divided by more than just the sandy track that passes for Main Street.

title: Ms. Rose, by Any Other Name, Might Still Be a Florist
description: GUESS what Dilip Doctor does for a living? (Hint: His receptionist answers the phone, "Doctor's office.")

description: To the Editor:

title: Never Stop Moving, or Name-Dropping
description: AGE has its privileges, and Luigi, the venerable jazz-dance teacher who turned 80 a week ago, makes full use of them. Thirty seconds after you're introduced, he's gossiping in your ear; 30 minutes, and he's taking your hand, putting it on his rump and saying, "Feel that!" In an hour, you're looking at photo albums: "Here I am with Valerie Harper."

title: Man Is Killed Trying to Fight Mattress Fire in Queens
description: A 42-year-old Queens man burned to death early yesterday when he became trapped under a smoldering mattress that burst into flame as he was wrestling it into the shower, Fire Department officials said.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: In the following reports, the listed at price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLANK, H. ROBERT, M.D.
description: BLANK--H. Robert, M.D., on March 16th, 2005 at age 90. He is survived by his loving wife, Virginia; daughters, Emily (Jeff) Hawley, Melanie Blank; grandsons, Michael (Beth) Hawley, Steven Hawley; brother, Edward (Marion) Blank. Dr. Blank graduated from Temple University in 1935 and Temple University Medical School in 1939. He practiced medicine until age 84. Dr. Blank was a Distinguished Life Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association and past President of the Westchester District Branch. He was also a life member of the Westchester County Medical Society, past President of the Westchester Psychoanalytic Society and Editor of the Psychoanalytic Quarterly. He was Clinical Professor Emeritus in Psychiatry at Cornell University, New York Hospital. In lieu of flowers, friends may contribute to the Episcopal Church Home, 505 Mt. Hope Ave., Rochester, NY 14620 or the H. Robert Blank, M.D. Scholarship Fund of Temple University. To light a candle of condolence and send a message to the family, please visit at: millerfuneralhomes.com

title: Arbus's Full Frontal Oddity
description: THE revolutionary photographer Diane Arbus, who is the subject of a stirring retrospective now at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Manhattan, is one of those artists whose work is inextricably linked to New York City.

title: Count Me Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEIDENFELD, ARI
description: SEIDENFELD--Ari. We all mourn the tragic passing of four shining Seidenfeld stars, Ari (15), Noah (6), Natan (5) and Adira (5), who perished in the fire early Tuesday morning, March 22, 2005. Their smiles and love for life will remain in our hearts forever. Our heartfelt condolences to their mother Philyss, to their father Howard and the surviving siblings, Helena, Zahava & Aviva, along with their grandparents and entire family. Contributions in their memory can be sent to Project Ezra, 95 Cedar Lane, Suite 12, Englewood, New Jersey 07631. title: The Soul of the New Exurb
description: In the spring of 1996, Lee McFarland quit his high-paying job at Microsoft, sold his house and drove his Jeep Cherokee from Redmond, Wash., to Surprise, Ariz. He had come to build a church. McFarland, who was 36 at the time, knew little about leading churches and less about building them: he wasn't even halfway through the correspondence classes he was taking to become an evangelical pastor. Nevertheless, he'd been hired by a small group of Christians in an adjoining community to do just that. And so a few days after he arrived, he put on a pair of slacks and a polo shirt, said goodbye to his wife, Sandy, and their two kids, who had come to Surprise several weeks ahead of him to get settled in their new house, and set out to find believers.

title: Le Pop Star
description: Benjamin Biolay sat, shoulders hunched, in a smoky, cluttered recording studio on the outskirts of Paris. He had just returned from a month's vacation with his wife, Chiara Mastroianni (daughter of the cinematic titans Catherine Deneuve and Marcello Mastroianni), at Deneuve's country house in Normandy. He should have appeared refreshed, but instead he looked as if he had spent the month in this windowless room, chain-smoking cigarettes and contemplating the cruelty of life. The French, after all, can seem mean and aloof when they're really just feeling shy, and Biolay is no exception. He knows that he can come off as con, meaning "jerk" or "jerklike" -- the French conveniently use the word as a noun and an adjective -- when he doesn't intend to.

title: Kifaya!
description: In front of the gates of Cairo University last month, a disparate crowd of about 500 Islamists, Nasserists, secularists and activist pacifists calling itself the "Egyptian Movement for Change" demonstrated noisily before journalists and a surprisingly benign police force in 30 armored vehicles. The purpose of the protest was to bring pressure on President Hosni Mubarak. According to the Egyptian weekly Al-Ahram, one activist leader screamed out words like "poverty, torture, corruption," to which the crowd responded by shouting back one word: kifaya! At the rally's end, the protesters chanted new words to the music of the Egyptian national anthem. Instead of the Arabic for "My country, my country, my country, you have my loyalty and love," the words sung out were "Kifaya, kifaya, kifaya," the Arabic for "We have reached the end."

title: From Street Smart To Fashion Forward
description: The Brazilian brothers Fernando and Humberto Campana are internationally known for their home furnishings, elaborately made with found materials -- fabric and rope remnants, scraps of wood, even stuffed toys -- and inspired by Rio's street life and carnival culture. Brazil's largest shoemaker, Grendha, invited the designers to offer a take on the beloved jelly, a shoe invented in Brazil in the 80's and its most popular footwear. The result is the Melissa & Campana line of vinyl random-mesh jellies, with shoes in two styles (high and low) and a matching handbag. "There are no boundaries between art, fashion and design," the Campanas said via e-mail. "In a certain way, furniture is also made to accommodate the body, only on a different scale." The recyclable haut-jellies ($80 and $120) and bag ($80) come in black, white and five bright colors and can be ordered from the shop at the Wolfsonian museum in Miami Beach: 1001 Washington Avenue, (305)535-2680; for other stores, www.melissausa.com. title: Inside the List
description: WEIGHTY MATTERS: From Rodale, the same people who brought you "The South Beach Diet" and "The Abs Diet," now comes something that sounds like a diet book, but isn't quite: "How to Lose Your Ass and Regain Your Life," by none other than Kirstie Alley. Following the premiere earlier this month of "Fat Actress," her fake-reality TV show on Showtime, Alley's book makes its debut this week at No. 16, the top of the extended hardcover nonfiction list. Billed as "reluctant confessions of a big-butted star," the book is written in bite-size sentences of biting prose. It grazes over Alley's Wichita girlhood, cocaine addiction, involvement with Scientology, binge eating and things like "what is up with airline seats these days." As Alessandra Stanley recently wrote in The Times, "fat is the only taboo left in Hollywood," where "each extra pound on a woman's thighs brings her another inch closer to the primordial ooze of working-class anonymity." That doesn't seem to be on Alley's horizon quite yet. "Big offer to do Oprah Winfrey Book Club movie for CBS. O.K. to be fat," she writes in one diary entry. "Character is over hill, overweight veterinarian who has lost vivacity for life. Eagerly begin negotiations."

title: A Triple Play for New York Teams
description: Lately, New Yorkers have had a lot of opportunity to think about what the world owes professional sports. Lawsuits, charges and countercharges are flying over the proposed Jets football stadium like so many Hail Mary passes. The Nets have a deal with the city, and the Yankees could announce one soon. As it stands now, the public investment on these projects would be more than $1 billion, and that does not count the Mets, who will inevitably be heard from, or the Nascar racetrack being planned for Staten Island. While each plan should be judged on its own merits, those numbers defy reason.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GENDLER, PAUL H., ED.D.
description: GENDLER--Paul H., Ed.D. Died March 24, at age 79, after a three-month struggle following influenza pneumonia. Lifelong educator, first as exemplary teacher and principal, then as respected superintendent of schools, and finally after retirement as founder of Language Institute For English, intensive schools for English as a Second Language at universities across the country--but always as the most amazing husband, father and grandfather. Everyone who knew him was in awe of his brilliance, wit and supreme kindness. Dearest husband of 52 years of Rochelle, beloved father of Dr. Ellen Gendler and Dr. Seth Gendler, much loved fatherin-law of Dr. James Salik and Dr. Lilia Gendler, adored grandfather of Jonathan and Michael Salik and Samantha and Clement Gendler, brother of Dr. Samuel Gendler and Lawrence Gendler. He was a man of unusual intellect, the quintessential scholar who knew everything from Shakespeare to world history, as well as being a formidable chess player and champion billiards player. His unique gifts will live on through the students he taught with whom he continued to be in contact, the people who worked for him at L.I.F.E., and the family he loved so much. The world is richer because he was in it. Services Sunday 1 PM, Gutterman's, Boca Raton, FL. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Boca Raton Community Hospital, Medical ICU, c/o Dr. Bernard Kaminetsky.

Gillian lived her life with joy and gave generously of herself to others. Words cannot describe the love she instilled in all who knew her and the sadness that accompanies her passing. title: The King Is Dead, Long Live His Brand
description: THE Air Jordan sneaker turned 20 last year, and it has aged considerably better than its namesake. Throughout the 1980's and 90's, Michael Jordan did more than anyone else to transform basketball from second-tier American pastime to global sports-marketing juggernaut. But building a brand on the back of a legend works only until that back breaks. And that's what happened during his disastrous 2001-3 run as a player-executive with the Washington Wizards. He traded away Richard Hamilton, who would go on to be a pivotal figure on Detroit's 2004 N.B.A. championship squad; he mauled the career of the high school prodigy Kwame Brown; he performed on the court in a way that was solid but hardly Jordanesque.

title: How to Steal a Scene by Just Raising a Finger
description: SOMETIMES a finger can steal a scene. Now appearing in Samuel Beckett's "Endgame," the 79-year-old theater veteran Alvin Epstein compels the audience with little more than some careful movement of his hands, which peek out from the tin can that his character, the ancient Nagg, inhabits for the duration of the play. Exploring the uncertain world outside the safety of the can, those digits pique our curiosity. Like characters in their own right, they scramble meekly, but with a visible, desperate energy, around the can's rim, like hungry mice, distracting the audience from all the other action taking place on stage.

title: The Arsenal

While you wait for peas and rhubarb and all the rest to kick in, you have to rely on transitional menus that mix the new with the going-out-of-season. This menu is one way to go, and it draws influences from France (the asparagus with sieved egg), Spain (the chicken) and England (the syllabub). The recipe for syllabub, a dessert made with cream and usually sherry and citrus zest, comes in handy if you don't own an ice cream maker.

title: The Film That Runs in the Family. Both Families, in Fact.
description: THE temptation to interpret works of art in terms of their creators' biographies can be a powerful and terrible thing: the biographical approach is a fallacy at best, and at worst the snake in the garden of aesthetics. The temptation is, however, tough to resist in the case of "The Ballad of Jack and Rose," a movie about the almost unnaturally close relationship between an idealistic, sternly principled man and his teenage daughter, who live together on an island off the Atlantic coast of the United States, in a sort of pristine alternate universe constructed by him and inhabited (metaphorically) only by him and her. The film is written and directed by Rebecca Miller, daughter of the playwright and moralist Arthur Miller, who died last month. The role of the counterculture-Prospero dad is played by her husband of eight years, Daniel Day-Lewis, who is, as it happens, also the offspring of a rather imposing literary figure (C. Day Lewis, once Britain's poet laureate).

title: Paperback Row
description: THE DEW BREAKER, by Edwidge Danticat. (Vintage Contemporaries, $12.95.) These interconnected, elliptical stories, by a Haitian-American writer, capture a bitter history of corruption and violence. The title character, an immigrant living a quiet life in Brooklyn, hides a terrible secret: in the 1960's he was an enforcer of Franois Duvalier's murderous regime. Danticat constructs the shadowy Dew Breaker through the eyes of others; the final story recounts his torture and murder of a dissident preacher. Moving seamlessly between 1960's Haiti and present-day New York, the novel conveys the Haitian people's torment with "terrifying wit and flowered pungency," Richard Eder wrote in the Book Review.

title: The Week Ahead
description: PEER REVIEW -- On Tuesday, the Supreme Court will wade into some heady and portentous digital realms when it takes up the case of MGM v. Grokster. Record and movie companies will be arguing that the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit was in error when it found that file-sharing companies like Grokster and Streamcast were not responsible for copyright infringement committed by users of their so-called peer-to-peer services. Opponents have argued that a finding for MGM could hamper further business and technological innovation on the Web. In order for the entertainment industry to prevail, it will have to persuade the Supreme Court to alter a standard set in 1984, when the court found that the Sony Betamax should not be outlawed because it had a number of legitimate uses apart from duplicating movies. In its filings, MGM has argued that file-sharing services should be held liable for any misuse because advances in computer technology now make it possible to distinguish between legal and illegal file copying.

title: From Lent Into Easter
description: "I hate Lent," wrote Jonathan Swift, who was a clergyman, in 1712. He hated what he called the "sour devout Faces of People who only put on Religion for 7 Weeks." But mostly Swift hated "different diets," the symbolic renunciation that Lent implies. For most people in Swift's day, the abstemiousness of Lent occurred at what was already one of the hardest times of year, the last harvest long forgotten and the next one merely a hope for the future. You could argue that Lent was a way for people living in those times -- so different, materially, from our own -- to turn deprivation into something spiritually resonant. Solemn as Easter was, it was also a rejoicing: the end of Lent, a foretaste of harvest; a return, if only symbolically, to abundance.

The company had been considering a site in Virginia as well as the Basking Ridge location. Verizon Wireless, currently based in nearby Bedminster, would move about 2,500 employees to Basking Ridge. Another 1,000 workers may be transferred from New York to the 140-acre campus in Somerset County. Pfizer gained possession of the building when it took over Pharmacia, another drug company, three years ago. Pharmacia had just bought the site from AT&T for $210 million, but never used it. title: SO LONG, ''PAY TO PLAY''
description: Saying that New Jersey needs drastic campaign finance restrictions to restore public trust, Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey signed a bill into law last Tuesday that bans campaign contributions by companies that hold or seek large state contracts. The bill, among the most stringent in the country, prohibits any vendor who has made contributions to a candidate for governor, the Legislature or a party committee from receiving a contract worth more than $17,500. The law exempts contributions to federal candidates, because the United States Department of Transportation said such a ban might conflict with federal procedures and force the state to forfeit hundreds of millions of dollars in highway aid. title: Broke
description: In the mid-1970's, around the time the parents of several school friends began going broke and losing their small farms because of high interest rates and falling crop prices, an envelope bearing an unfamiliar logo appeared in our mailbox. I carried it to the house and set it on the kitchen counter next to the radio my mother was listening to as she fried liver and onions on her old stove. She opened the envelope with a paring knife and drew out the thin, rectangular hard object I had been fingering through the paper. I remember the odd expression on her face -- a mixture of optimism and apprehension -- as she held the novelty out to me and said, "It's a BankAmericard." About a week later the kitchen radio was replaced by a portable TV set. By the next summer, when the banks started foreclosing on our neighbors' farms, my mother's old stove had been replaced as well, a microwave oven stood beside it and the BankAmericards in my parents' wallets had been joined by American Express cards.

title: Smooth Move
description: StriVectin-SD In 2003, the data collectors in the beauty division of the N.P.D. Group, which tracks retail purchases, noticed the sales of something called StriVectin-SD. "We said, 'What is this product?"' Timra Carlson, president of N.P.D. Beauty, recalls. In theory, the stuff was meant to reduce the appearance of stretch marks, but that hardly explained why it was doing so well at department-store beauty counters. So the firm did a study, based on its own polling, and found that about 75 percent of buyers were using it on their faces as a wrinkle fighter. StriVectin, Carlson says, "appealed to a specific consumer who was savvy about this type of product." It is not unheard of for consumers to invent new uses for a product, but the way that Klein-Becker, StriVectin's maker, has chosen to handle this instance is both unusual and, apparently, effective. Last year, sales of StriVectin, which costs about $135 for six ounces, reached $64 million in department stores, more than any other skin-care product, according to N.P.D.

title: Working the Latte Beat
description: Years ago while working in a Philadelphia coffee shop, I was told not to charge policemen for their drinks. The idea was to encourage them to hang around and deter crime. In Washington recently, I noticed that my local cafe employed the same policy. Sure enough, a couple of latte-sipping cops were often stationed outside. But isn't this a form of bribery and hence unethical? Thomas Catan, London If you're right, and those cops are comped, this is indeed petty bribery, engendering not only bad policing -- patrol assignments should be based on the needs of each locale, not the availability of free mochaccino -- but bad ethics. Nobody wants to live where bribery is endemic, where you have to pay off the mailman to get a letter or to "tip" the sanitation men if you don't want to live within a wall of garbage. You should not act in ways that promote corruption and undermine the predominant honesty of municipal employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TEELE, THURSTON FERDINAND ''TONY''
description: TEELE--Thurston Ferdinand "Tony". 70, chairman and founder of Chemonics International, Inc., died March 21, 2005, after a long battle with lymphoma, at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington, D.C., with his wife and children by his side. Mr. Teele was an active, compassionate humanitarian who was loved and will be missed by many throughout the world. Mr. Teele was born in New Rochelle, NY, and grew up in Needham, MA, where his father Stanley F. Teele was a faculty member and eventually dean of the Harvard Business School. Mr. Teele attended high school at Buckingham, Brown and Nichols in Cambridge, MA, where he excelled at varsity sports. At Amherst College, in Amherst, MA, he earned a B.A. in political science, while playing football and serving as editor of the school paper. He earned an M.A. in economics from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, Tufts University, Medford, MA, and completed the coursework for a Ph.D. (abd) in economics from Georgetown University, Washington, DC. Mr. Teele, a longtime DC resident, began his career as a foreign service officer, working as a political officer in Greece and as an analyst in the USAID executive secretariat. From there he focused his career on economic development, living and working in such countries as Afghanistan, Liberia, Nigeria, Thailand and Turkey, until he founded Chemonics. Mr. Teele served as Chemonics' president from its founding in 1975 until 2002 when he became chairman of the board. Originally a one-man business, the company today has over 2,000 employees in 95 countries and is a leader in sponsored economic development worldwide. Mr. Teele is widely considered a pioneer in global economic development. Mr. Teele was a strong proponent of a culturally appropriate, results-oriented approach to economic development. He worked to raise awareness of international development by serving as vice president and board member for the Campaign for U.S. Global Leadership, board member for the Society for International Development, and co-chair of the International Development Task Force of the Professional Services Council. As an associate professor, he taught a course on economic development at Georgetown University, and was frequently a guest lecturer on this topic at numerous institutions. A natural linguist, Mr. Teele spoke fluent French and was comfortable speaking Spanish, German, Thai, Turkish, Portuguese, Greek, and Farsi. With a lifelong love for business and personal travel, he visited more than 85 countries on 5 continents. In spite of his illness, he continued to travel on behalf of Chemonics, visiting countries such as Afghanistan, China, Mongolia, South Africa, Denmark, and France over the past two years. Mr. Teele's legacy is his respect for people, his passion for development, and the values he lived every day. He achieved his dream to make the world a better place. He is survived by his loving wife of 23 years Barbara C. Teele, formerly of Dothan, AL, and five children: Ted Teele of Pittsburgh, PA, Stacia Teele of New York City, NY, Mark Carmichael of Scottsdale, AZ, Kristy Teele of Ledbury, England, Allan Teele of San Francisco, CA, and nine grandchildren. Mr. Teele is also survived by his brother Perry Teele of Bradford, NH, and his sister Melissa Woodbury of St. Augustine, FL. Family will receive friends at a memorial service at 12:30 pm on Saturday, April 2, at the National City Christian Church, 5 Thomas Circle, NW, Washington, DC. A reception will immediately follow at the Andrew Mellon Auditorium, 1301 Constitution Avenue, NW. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to the Waldenstrom's Macroglobulinemia Program, (Attn: "Tony Teele Research Fund") and sent to Dana Farber Cancer Institute, D1B07-Christopher Patterson, 44 Binney St. Boston, MA 02155. For more information, go to www.chemonics.com.

description: MANDELBAUM -- Moshe. Died March 24 at 92. As a soldier in the Polish army he survived the Nazi blitzkrieg. After crossing the countryside he returned home to his pregnant wife Tanya. Within months he was taken from his home to the first of eight concentration camps that he would endure over the next 51/2 years. His wife and their son Chaim were killed at Auschwitz. Moshe never saw his child. After liberation, he bravely joined the search for Nazis and collaborators. He later married Elsa Klein and emigrated to Israel. He is survived by his wife, three children, seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild. His strength of will, optimism and triumphant spriit continue to serve as an inspiration. Through all the suffering he considered himself lucky. Moshe, we are lucky to have known you.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Complaints By Cyclists
description: Participants in the Critical Mass bicycle rides again accused the police yesterday of trying to thwart the group's protests. Officers arrested 37 cyclists as they left Union Square on Friday night, and seized 50 bicycles locked nearby, the police said. The rides take place on the last Friday of each month to advocate cleaner forms of transportation, and participants have had several confrontations with the police. Last September, the police sawed through locks and seized bicycles in Midtown. In October, a federal judge enjoined the police from sawing locks during that month's ride unless bicycles belonged to people being charged or were locked in places that obstructed traffic or people. The lawyer Norman Siegel, above, who has represented members of Critical Mass, said the seizures were "without legal basis." But a police spokesman, Jason Post, said, "Only bikes in violation of the law were seized." The cyclists arrested on Friday were charged with disorderly conduct. Colin Moynihan (NYT)

Paid Notice: Deaths   JEROME, IDA JUDITH INTRATOR
description: JEROME--Ida Judith Intrator. Dee Jerome, age 77, died Saturday, March 26 at St. Peter's Medical Center, New Brunswick, NJ. A resident of Monroe Township, NJ, Dee was the loving mother of daughters Deborah Jerome-Cohen and Mimi Krumholz. She was the proud grandmother of Specialist Matthew Lee, U.S. Army, Aaron Lee, Tess Cohen, Seth Cohen, Spencer Cohen and Paul Krumholz, and generous mother-in-law of Roger Cohen and Andy Krumholz. She was the devoted wife and indispensible partner of the late Jack W. Jerome. Dee was born and spent her early childhood in Vienna, making her one of that shrinking cohort who experienced and survived the monstrous storm of Nazi violence. Her father and mother, Michael and Miriam Intrator, took the family out of Austria shortly after the Anschluss, making their way first to Belgium and then through occupied France. The family made its way to Portugal, where on August 16, 1941, they found passage among 765 other refugees on the Spanish freighter Navemar--one of the last voyages of escapees from Europe. Dee's children and grandchildren bear in their hearts eternal, existential gratitude for her family's valor and persistence. Her intelligence, humor and immense energy were a gift to us all. Our family is particularly gladdened that Dee lived long enough to know of the safe return earlier this month of her eldest grandson, Matthew, from Iraq, where for the past year he has served in harm's way the country that gave his grandmother safe haven.

description: Brazil posted a smaller-than-expected primary-budget surplus of 4.05 billion reais ($1.47 billion) in February as a bulging social security deficit offset a jump in tax revenues, the central bank said. While the surplus, which excludes interest payments on public-sector debt, was down 64 percent from January, it was still an improvement on the surplus of 3.3 billion reais that the government posted in February 2004. With the February fiscal data taken into account, the government has run up a primary surplus of 86.29 billion reais over the last 12 months, equivalent to 4.8 percent of gross domestic product, which is well ahead of its target for a year-end surplus of 4.25 percent of gross domestic product. The government uses the surplus to pay down its debt, which was equal to 51.3 percent of gross domestic product at the end of February. The data reflect the fiscal performance of federal and local governments and state-run companies. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: An End To I.M.F. Borrowing
description: Brazil said it would not renew its $41.7 billion loan agreement with the International Monetary Fund when it expires this week, putting an end to years of dependence on I.M.F. bailouts. In announcing the decision, the finance minister, Antonio Palocci, left, said the country's economy was on sound footing and no longer needed the fund as insurance against external financial shocks. Brazil has been under successive I.M.F. loan agreements since a currency crisis in 1998, and is the fund's biggest borrower, with $24.6 billion in outstanding loans. Mr. Palocci said the government remained committed to fiscal responsibility and would continue to run a high primary-budget surplus to pay down its debt load. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TORRIANI, ALBERT J.
description: TORRIANI--Albert J., 91, of Brooklyn, entered into eternal rest on March 26, 2005. He is survived by Ronnie, his loving wife of 61 years, dearest father and father-in-law of James & wife Sandra, Linda, Bob and wife Arlene, Ronald and wife Barbara. He is also survived by six grandchildren. He worked for many years with the international Ladies Garment Workers Union and was an ardent advocate of the trade union movement. He also taught labor relations on a volunteer basis at the Xavier Labor Institute in New York City. Al was proud to be a Liberal Democrat and was an avid New York Yankee fan. He will be missed by all. Immediate services will be private with a memorial service to be scheduled at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 633 3rd Ave. NY, NY 10117 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HASSENFELT, MARJORIE (SALLY)
description: HASSENFELT -- Marjorie (Sally). Broadway stage manager and theater consultant, died on Friday after a long battle with MS, according to her companion, David Pleva. She was fifty-two. Ms. Hassenfelt, during her career, served on Broadway as a stage manager for "42nd Street", "Annie",and "Fiddler On The Roof" (at the State theater at Lincoln Center). She was the Executive Director of The New Amsterdam Theater Company, in New York, and recently served as a theater consultant. Ms. Hassenfelt was born in Atlanta, GA, lived in Southern Pines, N.C., and was a graduate of The N.C. School of the Arts, in Winston Salem, North Carolina. She worked initially in New York as resident stage manager for the drama division of The Juilliard School under John Houseman, at The Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, CT, and for The Pauline Koner Dance Consort (The American Dance Festival 1978). In addition to working with national tours, regional theater, offBroadway and summer stock, she was involved with the Berkshire Theater Festival, Shakespeare In The Park, and The Milwaukee Repertory Company. In addition to her companion, David Pleva, she is survived by two brothers and a sister, Stephen C. Hassenfelt, of Greensboro, NC, Harold E. Hassenfelt, of Wilmington, NC, and Maureen H. Clark, of Southern Pines, NC. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, from 3-5 P.M. at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue at 70th Street, and a family burial service at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, Glendale Springs, NC.

description: Saks Inc., which owns the Saks Fifth Avenue department store chain, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had opened a formal investigation into whether the company improperly collected as much as $21.5 million from vendors. Saks, which disclosed on March 3 that the S.E.C. had begun an informal inquiry, said it received a notice on March 24 that the investigation was formal, a designation that means that S.E.C. enforcement lawyers can subpoena information from the company. Saks said its internal review of collections of vendor discount allowances would be completed by next month, one month later than it had previously expected. Saks, based in Birmingham, Ala., has said that it intends to reimburse vendors for collection of the allowances, which primarily occurred between the 2000 and 2002 fiscal years. (Bloomberg News)

description: Key Energy Services said yesterday that it expected to miss a March 31 deadline to file its 2003 annual report, saying that a restatement of those results was not complete. The company, an oil services provider based in Midland, Tex., said that it had notified the New York Stock Exchange of the delay and expected the exchange's operator to start the process of delisting Key Energy shares shortly after the deadline lapsed. Key Energy, which began the restatement process more than a year ago, is reviewing the way it accounted for equipment and other fixed assets. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSS, WALTER J.
description: GROSS--Walter J., 85, died peacefully at home in Kings Point, New York after a 10 year bout with Alzheimer's. Walter's insight, intellect and his creative vision set him apart. His love of his family and friends was paramount and he is survived by his wife of 65 years, Barbara Gross, his daughter, Susan, son Robert and only grand daughter Lora. Walter is a 60 year veteran of the Real Estate Industry, having started his first job at age 17. In 1961 Walter and his partner, William Rechler of Reckson Associates created the first planned and largest Industrial Park and office Complex in New York State, Vanderbuilt Industrial Park In Happauge. Walter's career in real estate spanned from developing to managing property. He was a visionary in developing Eastern Long Island and is responsible for building and managing over 10+ million square feet of property for clients including B.F. Goodrich, Sears, EAB and The Prudential. He bought and managed hotels in New York City including the Parkside Hotel at Gramercy Park, Madison Square hotel at Madison Square and the California Hotel in Midtown. Walter was a Veteran of the Army Corps. of Engineers and served in the South Pacific. He earned his engineering degree from the University of Alabama. In 1999, Walter received a lifetime achievement award from the Association of Better Long Island honoring him for his vision, energy and most of all his ethics. He also served as Chairman of the Board for Reckson Associates since its inception. Walter will be sorely missed. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, March 31st at 10:30 A.M. at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, New York: 150 Hicks Lane, 516.482.5701.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAPERSTEIN, RABBI SANFORD E.
description: SAPERSTEIN--Rabbi Sanford E. Temple Beth Am, The Reform Jewish Congregation of Merrick mourns the passing of Rabbi Sanford E. Saperstein. Rabbi Saperstein became Rabbi Emeritus in July 1984 after serving as Beth Am's spiritual leader since 1957. Under his creative leadership for over a quarter century, Temple Beth Am pioneered innovative educational and spiritual programs that set standards of excellence for Reform Jewish congregations. On a national level, he served on the Commission on Mental Health at the invitation of President Jimmy Carter. For many years he was a member of the Board of Governors of the New York Board of Rabbis as well as Chairman of the Committee on Judaism and Health of the Central Conference of American Rabbis. Rabbi Saperstein earned a MA in Marriage and Family Counseling from Columbia University and a MSW from Adelphi University. He was awarded his Doctor of Divinity, honoris causa, from H.U.C.-J.I.R. More recently Rabbi Saperstein introduced a course in Jewish studies at New College, which is affiliated with the University of South Florida. He was an avid sailor and tennis player, and endeared himself to his congregation by being a warm, caring and supportive friend and Rabbi. We will forever miss him. Ronald N. Brown, Rabbi Daniel M. Rosenfeld, Cantor Natilee Mintz, President

Mr. Allen, Lee Entertainment and Vivendi Universal Entertainment will sell shares after the May 27 release of the film "Madagascar," DreamWorks Animation said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Allen is taking advantage of an almost 40 percent increase in DreamWorks Animation's shares since the company's initial public offering in October. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ATI To Settle Insider Trading Case
description: ATI Technologies, the world's second-biggest maker of computer-graphics chips, has agreed to a settlement with the Ontario Securities Commission in an investigation of insider trading by executives including the founder Kwok Yuen Ho. The terms of the settlement were not released pending commission approval, the commission said yesterday. Mr. Ho, and his wife, Betty Ho, were accused of trading 494,900 ATI shares between April 24 and May 2, 2000, while they were aware that the company's earnings and revenue would fall short of forecasts, the commission had asserted. By selling the shares, the couple avoided a potential loss of 3.35 million Canadian dollars ($2.7 billion), the commission said. The commission, Canada's main securities regulator, had scheduled hearings for the company, based in Markham, Ontario, that were to last until June 3. An ATI spokesman, Chris Evenden, did not immediately respond to a request for comment. The company had maintained there was no wrongdoing on the part of any executive. A commission spokesman, Eric Pelletier, did not immediately return a phone call seeking comment.

title: LIGAND SAYS RESULTS OF CANCER DRUG TRIALS DISAPPOINT
description: Ligand Pharmaceuticals said yesterday that two studies had found that its drug Targretin failed to prolong life when used with chemotherapy against the most common form of lung cancer. The company's stock fell 29 percent. The company is seeking expanded approval of Targretin to treat non-small-cell lung cancer. The drug is already sold to treat a form of skin cancer. An initial review of the trials showed no increase in overall survival or survival after two years compared with patients treated using chemotherapy alone, the company said. The results were a setback in Ligand's bid to expand Targretin sales as growth slows for its biggest product, the Avinza pain treatment. Stock in the company, which is based in San Diego, fell $2.35, to $5.88 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARSWELL, DONALD
description: CARSWELL--Donald. Donald passed away after a life well lived on March 25, at age 75, due to leukemia. He was a wonderful husband, father and grandfather who embodied the virtues of compassion and charity. His wit and humor were legendary, and will live on in the memories of all who knew him. He was a masterful golfer who taught the game to two generations of Carswells. His career accomplishments at and beyond NBC were significant and too numerous to list, but never outshone his dedication to community service or the importance he placed on "doing good." He is survived by his wife, Lois; his children, Anne, Alex and Bob; his grandchildren, Phillip Tang, Julia Tang, Tom Carswell and James Donald Carswell; and Cassie II, the latest in a line of "practically perfect" black standard schnauzers. He also leaves a brother, Robert. We will all miss him immeasurably. Those who knew and loved Donald may join us to celebrate his life on May 8, 2005, at 11 AM at the Palm House of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Contributions in his memory may be made to Poly Prep Country Day School, 674 92nd St., Brooklyn NY 11228; the Brooklyn Hospital Center, 121 DeKalb Ave., Brooklyn NY11201; or the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Ave., Brooklyn NY 11225.

Following the lead of his beloved late wife Rose, he became a devoted supporter of the ATS Women's Division, reaching the level of Technion Guardian, representing the highest commitment to the ATS, the Technion and Israel. He also served on the ATS Board of Regents. His generous support of numerous Women's Division (WD) projects includes the Rose Goldenstein Memorial Scholarship Fund, WD Priority Scholarship Fund, and a variety of WD Medical Engineering Projects. In recognition of his outstanding support for and frequent hosting of Technion students, the annual Women's Division student-anddean luncheon was renamed in his honor. Republicans seem determined to change the rules so Democrats will no longer be able to stop judicial nominations with the threat of a filibuster. If they're acting out of frustration, it's understandable. In the past we've been frustrated when legislators tried to stop important bills from passing by resorting to the same tactic. The filibuster, which allows 41 senators to delay action indefinitely, is a rough instrument that should be used with caution. But its existence goes to the center of the peculiar but effective form of government America cherishes.

description: The Acxiom Corporation, which makes database-management software, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Digital Impact for about $140 million to add the company's Internet marketing software. The purchase price, $3.50 a share, represented a 53 percent premium to Digital Impact's closing price of $2.29 last Thursday. American markets were closed Friday. Digital Impact, which is based in San Mateo, Calif., sells e-mail and online marketing software to companies like Marriott International and Gap Inc. The acquisition will make Digital Impact's technology available to Axciom customers like BankOne, Capital One and Philip Morris. This month, Digital Impact's board rejected as inadequate an unsolicited offer of $69.6 million, or about $2 a share, from InfoUSA. Shares of Axciom, which is based in Little Rock, Ark., fell 31 cents, to $21.06. Digital shares rose $1.16 to $3.45.

To compensate for limits on stockpiling, AmerisourceBergen and other distributors are seeking new contracts that provide them with fees from drug makers for distributing medicines to pharmacies and hospitals. title: Fuel for South Asia's Arms Race
description: The United States has far better ways to reward Pakistan for its helpful but selective pressure on Al Qaeda and the Taliban than President Bush's decision last week to break with 15 years of policy and sell Pakistan high-performance fighters whose only plausible use is to threaten India. The worst thing for these two nuclear powers, which have fought three wars against each other since 1947, is to encourage them to engage in a new, American-fueled arms race.
