Paid Notice: Deaths   FORREST, RICHARD STOCKTON
description: FORREST--Richard Stockton. A mystery writer whose novels were published in the U.S., U.K., Japan, Italy, Finland, France, Germany, and Sweden, died on Monday March 14, 2005. He was seventy-two, and lived in Charlottesville, VA. Mr. Forrest's first novel, "Who Killed Mr. Garland's Mistress," was nominated for The Edgar Award. He published over two dozen novels, eight of which, formed The Lyon and Bea Wentworth Mystery Series. Mr. Forrest also wrote several novels under the pseudonym "Stockton Woods," including "Game Bet" and "The Man Who Heard Too Much." In 1987, Mr. Forrest, his first wife, Mary Bolan (a geriatric nurse who passed away in 1996), and son, Christopher Forrest (a physician), together wrote "Retirement Living" and "Nursing Homes." In the past two years, Mr. Forrest has published several novels serialized in Japan and a new mystery published this year in the U.K. entitled "Death In The Secret Garden." Mr. Forrest is a descendent of Richard Stockton, a signer of the Declaration of Independence. He is survived by his wife, Patricia Hale Forrest, who owns New Plays For Children. Mr. Forrest is also survived by six children, including Remley Forrest Mann (an educator in the U.K.), Katherine Forrest (a partner with the law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore, LLP), Bellamy Forrest (Key Set Production Assistant for "Law and Order: Special Victims Unit"), Richard S. Forrest, Jr (with the International Labor Organization In Geneva), Christopher Forrest, M.D., Ph.D. (on the faculty of Johns Hopkins University), Mongin Forrest (the permanent Representative of the Danish Parliament to The European Union), fourteen grandchildren, and two step children, Laura Whitton Secor (a writer) and Robert Whitton (a businessman in Hawaii).

Technology Briefing | Deals: NetIQ To Sell WebTrends Unit
description: The NetIQ Corporation, which sells software to manage computer networks, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its WebTrends unit to the private equity fund Francisco Partners for about $94 million in cash. NetIQ bought WebTrends, based in Portland, Ore., for $148.2 million in stock in April 2001 to add products that analyze spending by Web site visitors and enlarge its base of potential customers. The company has been focusing on security products in the last four years and the Internet analysis business was not part of its strategy, the chief executive, Charles M. Boesenberg, said. Shares of NetIQ, based in San Jose, Calif., fell 15 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $10.85.

title: Arts, Briefly; Artists' Tax Breaks Stir Irish Ire
description: Names like those of the singers Elvis Costello, below, and Sinead O'Connor and the playwright Conor McPherson on a newly published list of 1,512 musicians, writers and artists exempted from income taxes on their creative work have touched off populist demands in Ireland that they start contributing to the national treasury. The tax break, a legacy of the former prime minister and self-proclaimed aesthete Charles J. Haughey, is widely seen as unnecessary aid to people who already have achieved success. The novelists Frederick Forsyth and Michel Houellebecq, the singer Lisa Stansfield and members of the band Def Leppard all moved to Ireland to take advantage of its provisions. But the Arts Council, a national financing body, said the exemptions are needed to support artists who make less than the minimum wage and whose income varies from one year to another. It said its research found that, in 2001, more than half of the tax-exempt artists earned less than 10,000 euros ($12,900) a year and that 87 percent earned less than 50,000 ($64,000). The policy is to be formally reviewed later this year by Ireland's Department of Finance. BRIAN LAVERY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSS, WALTER J.
description: GROSS--Walter J., 85, died peacefully at home in Kings Point, New York after a 10 year bout with Alzheimer's. Walter's insight, intellect and his creative vision set him apart. His love of his family and friends was paramount and he is survived by his wife of 65 years, Barbara Gross, his daughter, Susan, son Robert and only grand daughter Lora. Walter is a 60 year veteran of the Real Estate Industry, having started his first job at age 17. In 1961 Walter and his partner, William Rechler of Reckson Associates created the first planned and largest Industrial Park and office Complex in New York State, Vanderbuilt Industrial Park In Happauge. Walter's career in real estate spanned from developing to managing property. He was a visionary in developing Eastern Long Island and is responsible for building and managing over 10+ million square feet of property for clients including B.F. Goodrich, Sears, EAB and The Prudential. He bought and managed hotels in New York City including the Parkside Hotel at Gramercy Park, Madison Square hotel at Madison Square and the California Hotel in Midtown. Walter was a Veteran of the Army Corps. of Engineers and served in the South Pacific. He earned his engineering degree from the University of Alabama. In 1999, Walter received a lifetime achievement award from the Association of Better Long Island honoring him for his vision, energy and most of all his ethics. He also served as Chairman of the Board for Reckson Associates since its inception. Walter will be sorely missed. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, March 31st at 10:30 A.M. at Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, New York: 150 Hicks Lane, 516.482.5701.

That contract was awarded by officials who had no idea the son even worked for the company. This was a grievous lapse, for which the United Nations is now paying the price as critics accuse it of conflicts of interest and corruption in high places.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PILLSBURY, JOHN SARGENT
description: PILLSBURY--John Sargent, Jr., age 92, of Wayzata, MN, died on March 28, 2005. He was a graduate of St. Paul's School in Concord, NH, Yale College and the University of Minnesota Law School, where he was Editor-in-Chief of the Law Review. Following his military service as a Lieutenant Commander in the United States Navy during World War II, he practiced law as a partner of Faegre & Benson in Minneapolis until 1956. From 1956 until his retirement in 1977, he was the Chief Executive Officer of Northwestern National Life Insurance Company (now ING-ReliaStar). He was very active nationally in life insurance industry affairs, serving as Chairman of the two principal industry organizations, the Institute of Life Insurance Association of America (now combined as the American Council of Life Insurers). He also served as a director of The Pillsbury Company, Northwestern National Bank, Boise Cascade Corporation and Northwestern Bell Telephone Company. Very active in community and civic affairs, he was a Founding Director of Twin Cities Public Television, Chairman of the Board of the Minnesota Orchestra and Chairman of the Community Chest Drive (the predecessor of the United Way). He was also very involved in Yale University alumni affairs. Always cheerful and welcoming, good-humored and appreciative, he thrived on the company of his family and friends, and they in turn admired and respected him and returned the great affection he showed for them. He is survived by his wife of 68 years, Katharine Clark Pillsbury, his sons, John S. Pillsbury, III of Telluride, CO, Donaldson C. Pillsbury of New York City and Dr. L. Harrison Pillsbury of Washington, DC; his daughter, Katharine P. Jose, of Chestnut Hill, MA; his sister Ella P. Crosby of Wayzata, MN; his brother, George S. Pillsbury, of Wayzata, MN; 14 grandchildren; and 8 great-grandchildren. A service celebrating his life will be held at the Wayzata Community Church on April 19, 2005 at 3:00PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to Minnesota Orchestra or Twin Cities Public Television.

description: A Union County sheriff's officer was wounded in a shooting late yesterday afternoon that left one man dead, the authorities said. The Union County prosecutor, Theodore J. Romankow, said the officer, whom he declined to identify, was in fair condition at University Hospital, Newark. He had been shot in the left cheek, and the bullet was lodged in his skull. "He's in surprisingly good condition," Mr. Romankow said. "He's conscious and talking to his family." The prosecutor said that four sheriff's officers went to a home on Walker Avenue about 5:15 p.m. to serve a warrant on Michael Johnson, 34, for failure to pay child support. Mr. Johnson, he said, jumped out of a first-floor window, began to run and fired several shots, one of which wounded the officer. The other three returned fire, killing Mr. Johnson. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Micron Posts Earnings Of $117.9 Million
description: Micron Technology, the nation's largest maker of computer memory chips, said yesterday that it earned $117.9 million in the second quarter after it cut production costs enough to keep pace with declines in chip prices. Net income was 17 cents a share in the period ended March 3, compared with a net loss of $28.3 million, or 4 cents, a year earlier, the company said in a statement. It was the first profit in the second quarter in five years. Sales rose 32 percent, to $1.31 billion, from $991 million. Micron, based in Boise, Idaho, has improved manufacturing processes to keep costs in line with declining prices of its main products, the semiconductors that act as the principal memory for personal computers. The company is the third-largest producer in the $26.4 billion memory chip industry, behind Samsung Electronics and Hynix Semiconductor of South Korea. The profit topped the average estimate of 15 cents a share among the 23 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. Micron shares rose 14 cents, to $10.26, in after-hours trading after the results were released. In regular trading, the shares fell 5 cents, to $10.12.

title: Sharon Clears Final Hurdle in Gaza Pullout Plan's Path
description: JERUSALEM, March 29 - The Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, won a victory on Tuesday night over his own party and the settler movement for which he had been the champion. In a vote of 58 to 36, with one abstention, Parliament passed the $62 billion state budget for this year, ensuring that Mr. Sharon's government will survive and that he will carry out his plan to dismantle all 21 Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip and four small ones in the northern West Bank.

title: MEDTRONIC ORDERED TO PAY ETEX $50 MILLION IN FAILED DEAL

Medtronic had agreed to buy Etex of Cambridge, Mass., in March 2002 as long as a bone-graft product that Etex was developing met certain standards. But Medtronic, based in Minneapolis, rejected the product and canceled the deal.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: RedEnvelope Forecasts Wider Net Loss
description: RedEnvelope, which sells jewelry on the Internet, forecast a wider fourth-quarter net loss yesterday and said its chief financial officer had resigned. RedEnvelope shares fell as much as 33 percent, their biggest decline ever. The loss in the period ending April 3 may be as much as $3.5 million because of lower-than-expected demand for Valentine's Day gifts, RedEnvelope said yesterday. The company, which is based in San Francisco, previously had predicted that it would break even or have a profit of as much as $500,000. The chief executive, Alison May, said RedEnvelope, which has posted a loss in three of the last five quarters, overestimated how much it would make on each item sold during the quarter. The company said it had to discount more Valentine's Day merchandise than expected, had more returns than anticipated and found a budgeting error. Shares of RedEnvelope fell $3.20, or nearly 28 percent, to $8.40.

title: In Vermont, a Bid to Legalize Physician-Assisted Suicide

title: Where to Take Thoreau and Dr. Atkins
description: PARTING company with most literary scholars, utopianists and ovo-lacto vegetarians, I like to think that when Henry David Thoreau wrote in "Walden" that he wanted to "live deep and suck out all the marrow of life," he wasn't dabbling in metaphor. He was fantasizing about dinner, his pent-up carnivorous impulses breaking through his reputed meatless resolve.

title: Pretty Good for Leftovers
description: In Italy nothing goes to waste when Parmigiano-Reggiano is made. The leftover whey is fed to the pigs that are destined to become prosciutto di Parma. The cream that remains after the milk is skimmed off for the cheese is used to make a rich (83 percent butterfat) butter. It's a pale, unsalted, cultured butter with a lovely whiff of pungency that gives it real character on a slab of country bread. It is also good for finishing a risotto or melting over tender asparagus. The Montanari & Gruzza brand is $5.69 for eight ounces at Fairway.

title: How Can General Motors Remake Itself?

Now, with its market share falling toward 25 percent, General Motors is struggling to revive its core business -- selling America its cars, trucks and minivans -- and seems in need of a few good ideas.

Paid Notice: Deaths   MAZZOLA, PATRICIA
description: MAZZOLA--Patricia, 63, died at her home in Kent, CT. on Wednesday, March 23, 2005. Pat received a BSN from Cornell University in 1964 & a MBA from Columbia University in 1984. She had a 31 year career in nursing at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She served as Chairman of the Department of Nursing for 15 years, from 1981-1997. Instituted under her leadership were many innovative changes that influenced the practice of nursing. These included but not limited to, Primary Nursing; Collaborative Practice; Flexible Scheduling; Development of a Master's Degree Program with Columbia University, and the implementation of the Nurse Practitioner and Clinical Nurse Specialist Advanced Practice Roles. In addition to serving as the longest chairman of the department, she was the first recipient of the Enid A. Haupt Chair of Nursing. In addition to family and friends, Pat leaves behind her legacy of true generosity of spirit and person. She deeply affected the lives of all those she came in contact with. Her generosity, wisdom, integrity, strength of character and knowledge of herself and others, will remain with all of us who knew and loved her. She will truly be missed. A Special remembrance service, followed by a gathering of friends & family to celebrate Pat's life, will be arranged in the near future. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be sent to New Milford Hospital Regional Cancer Center, 21 Elm Street, New Milford, CT. 06776.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Flatbush: Woman Collapses and Dies During a Fight
description: A customer in the Magic Touch beauty salon at 611 Flatbush Avenue collapsed and died yesterday during a scuffle with another woman in the salon, the police and a witness said. The police did not identify the dead woman, but said she was 47. A longtime friend, John Pekun, 57, of Brooklyn, said that her first name was Bidi and that she was the aunt of the salon's owner. Shortly before noon, Cory Brown, 25, said he was walking past the salon when a woman emerged and offered to braid his hair. When she went inside to get an advertising flier, he said, Bidi complained that the open door was letting in cold air. Bidi then grabbed the other woman by her hair, Mr. Brown said, and the women scratched and bit each other, he said. "All of a sudden, it looked like she went into cardiac arrest," Mr. Brown said of Bidi. "She fell back into a chair." She was taken by ambulance to Kings County Hospital Center, where she was pronounced dead at 12:15 p.m., the police said. An autopsy will be performed to determine the cause of death. Ann Farmer (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Big Day for Superheroes
description: "Countdown to Infinite Crisis," the follow-up to last year's top-selling comic-book murder mystery, "Identity Crisis," is on sale today from DC Comics. The 80-page title, selling for $1, was produced by a who's who of talent, including the writers Geoff Johns, Greg Rucka and Judd Winick and the artists Rags Morales and Phil Jimenez. "Countdown" has fueled rampant speculation among fans since its cover, depicting Batman cradling a body, was leaked in December; but planning for the story began about two years ago, said Dan DiDio, the DC Comics vice president for editorial. "It's an exciting moment," he said. "I feel like all the work that we've done is finally coming to fruition." "Countdown" reveals a conspiracy that results in the murder of a superhero and sets the stage for several mini-series that will explore DC's criminal underground, mystical realms and more. Those stories will lead to "Infinite Crisis," by Mr. Johns and Mr. Jimenez, a sequel to the 1985 blockbuster "Crisis on Infinite Earths," which greatly revamped and redefined DC's superheroes. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Illegal Immigrants Readied For Deportation
description: Forty-one illegal immigrants convicted of various crimes at home are being deported to their native countries, federal and Nassau County law enforcement officials announced yesterday. The authorities seized 25 immigrants yesterday, in addition to 16 picked up in recent months. All were sent to a detention center in Pike County, Pa., in preparation for deportation. Many were convicted of sex crimes, including three rapists whose victims were 11, 12 and 14 years old, the officials said. Most were from Latin America, the Caribbean and South Asia and have "no legal right to remain in the country," said Salvatore Dalessandro, of the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency. No other actors have been cast, and a script has yet to be written. Paid Notice: Deaths   SAUERHAFT, STAN
description: SAUERHAFT--Stan of Armonk, New York, a leading public relations expert on mergers and acquisitions and corporate communications counseling, died in his sleep on March 25 at age 78. His death followed a valiant struggle with Alzheimer's Disease as well as cancer. A graduate of the University of Michigan with a BA and MA in Creative Writing, he enjoyed a brilliant 50-year career in public relations. Hundreds of clients benefited from his expertise while serving as Executive Vice President and Director of Hill & Knowlton and, more recently, as Vice Chairman of the Board of Burson-Marsteller Worldwide. Mr. Sauerhaft was elected a Fellow of the Public Relations Society of America, the Society's highest recognition. He authored countless articles on public relations practice and principles, as well as the business books The Merger Game and Image Wars as well as the novels End Game and Dead Cat Bounce. He donated his time to valuable industry and civic organizations including the West Point military academy, the LS&A College of his beloved University of Michigan and the Institute for Public Relations Research and Education. He was a longtime member of The Union League Club in New York City, Burning Tree Country Club in Greenwich, Ct, the Authors' Guild Inc. and several industry associations. Mr. Sauerhaft served his country as a Staff Sergeant in the Army from 1944-1946. He was a gifted, avid, competitive sportsman: a nationally ranked senior platform tennis player, a golf partner one could count on to make a crucial putt, and a masterful pool player. Mr. Sauerhaft is survived by his wife of 53 years, Rosalie, their children Richard and his wife Doreen, Douglas and his wife Nancy, Robert and his wife Robin; his grandchildren Roger, Shelley and Lindsey Sauerhaft, and Sarah Jackson; and his faithful Labrador Retriever Caesar. His sons will forever remember his advice: "If you can't outthink them, outwork them. But better yet, try to do both" and "the best luck seems to befall the hardest workers". A Memorial Service will be held May 24 at 4 PM at The Union League Club in New York City.

title: F.D.A. APPROVES BRISTOL-MYERS'S NEW HEPATITIS DRUG
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved a new Bristol-Myers Squibb treatment for chronic hepatitis B. It is one of the first products emerging as a result of the company's new emphasis on in-house drug discovery. The oral antiviral treatment, Baraclude, received the unanimous endorsement of an F.D.A. advisory panel on March 11. The panel found that a potential risk of tumors was not significant enough to outweigh the benefits of the drug, or even to warrant a "black box" warning. The review of Baraclude, also known as entecavir, was accelerated by the government after regulators said it addressed a serious unmet medical need. The drug's approval was viewed as a positive development for Bristol-Myers, which has lost patent protection on several of its drugs, including the breast cancer treatment Taxol and the antianxiety medication BuSpar. Baraclude has a potential market estimated at more than $500 million. Stephanie Saul (NYT)

title: PFIZER WINS APPROVAL FOR NEW FORM OF DEPO-PROVERA
description: Pfizer, the world's largest drug maker, said the Food and Drug Administration approved a new form of the company's Depo-Provera birth-control shot as a treatment for pain caused by endometriosis. The product, called depo-subQ provera 104, won approval as a contraceptive in December, Pfizer said yesterday. It contains 30 percent less hormone than the original Depo-Provera, which may reduce bone density after prolonged use. Depo-subQ, administered four times a year, is the first new treatment option for endometriosis pain in 15 years, Pfizer said. The condition affects one in 10 women of child-bearing age and can lead to infertility, according to the company.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ATI Will Pay To Settle Insider Trading Case
description: ATI Technologies, whose founder is being investigated for insider trading, agreed to pay 900,000 Canadian dollars ($742,120) to settle allegations that it misled investigators and delayed disclosing financial information. The Ontario Securities Commission said yesterday that the payment consisted of a voluntary penalty of 500,000 Canadian dollars and 400,000 Canadian dollars in costs. ATI also agreed to provide a letter to the commission confirming that it had instituted new procedures on trading shares and corporate governance, the commission said. The Canadian regulator asserted that ATI executives, including the founder and the former chief executive, Kwok Yuen Ho, were aware in late April 2000 that the company would not meet fiscal third-quarter profit forecasts. A news release saying ATI would have a loss was only issued on May 24, 2000, it said. ATI's payment "constitutes a significant penalty for the acknowledged misconduct," the commission said. Officials of ATI, the world's second-largest maker of computer-graphics chips, provided "untrue" and "misleading" information to investigators, the regulator said in documents it released. During the inquiry, the company told investigators it had decided on May 16, 2000, to issue a news release, 10 days after senior managers made the decision, the commission said. By selling shares before the news was released, Mr. Ho and his wife avoided a loss of about 3.35 million Canadian dollars, according to the commission.

description: EBay said yesterday that it had selected BBDO Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, to replace another Omnicom agency, Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, which had worked for eBay since 1999. EBay unexpectedly dismissed Goodby, Silverstein late Tuesday.

Tyranny's Full Tank
description: Washington - THE skyrocketing price of oil in the last two years has translated into a projected 42 percent increase in net oil export revenue for OPEC countries. While the global economic impact of this jump remains unclear, it also threatens to have a perverse political impact: even as the Bush administration pushes the promotion of democracy in the Middle East and elsewhere, market forces have given oil-rich autocratic regimes new revenue with which to dispense patronage and buy off popular discontent.

title: Arts, Briefly; Viewers Leave 'The Office'
description: Last Thursday, NBC sandwiched the series premiere of "The Office," its remake of the popular British comedy, between two of its top 20 shows, "The Apprentice" and "ER." Nestled there, "The Office," with Steve Carell, above, did fairly well, attracting 11.3 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. Its debut in its regular Tuesday slot was another matter: leading out of the struggling "Scrubs," the sitcom drew a feeble 5.93 million viewers. It came in fourth during its 9:30 time period, behind ABC's "Rodney," CBS's "Amazing Race" and Fox's "House," which yielded its biggest numbers yet. The strength of "House" and, of course, "American Idol" brought Fox a victory in all key measures in Tuesday's ratings race. CBS was second in households and among adults 18 to 49. The network's two-hour "Amazing Race," featuring more villainous deeds by the "Survivor: All-Stars" winner Amber Brkich and her fianc, Rob Mariano, drew the series' highest viewer total in three years. KATE AURTHUR

description: Several large orthopedics manufacturers said yesterday that they had received subpoenas from the Justice Department, seeking information about the industry's relationships with surgeons who implant artificial knees and hips.

title: Compete With Caution Against Past Employer
description: Howard Gray and Mark Browne, longtime friends who had worked a combined three decades at Pitney Bowes, the world's largest maker of postage meters and other mailing equipment, left the company three years ago to compete with their former employer. Mr. Gray, who was a district director for Pitney Bowes, and Mr. Browne, who was a sales representative, started Nexxpost in January 2002 in the basement of the Seattle home of Mr. Gray's parents.

title: Columbia and a Chair Endowed With Rust
description: A broken chair rests upside down inside a lot on the southwest corner of West 130th Street and Broadway. The steadfast sentry has braved snow and rain, heat and cold. A melancholy soul would say it is a lonely remnant of a career, a life, a useful past.

In the Competition for DVD Rentals by Mail, Two Empires Strike Back
description: YOU might not imagine that there's a single movie-distribution channel left to invent. These days, a movie can reach you by pay-per-view, on a plane, at the video store, on a TV movie channel, on the Internet, at the front of a Greyhound bus, in the second row of a minivan or even -- get this -- in a movie theater. (Hey, it could happen.)

title: Acting prime minister not ready to quit yet
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Industrial Output Falls
description: Japan's industrial production showed the biggest decline in a year in February, led by decreases in electronic parts and machinery. Production fell a seasonally adjusted 2.1 percent from January, when it rose 2.5 percent, a report by the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry said. Production of machinery and other capital goods fell 3.1 percent, the biggest drop since September, the report said. Production of electrical machinery fell 4.5 percent from the previous month; electronic parts and devices fell 1.6 percent. General machinery fell 1.7 percent. Local and overseas orders for Japanese-made machinery are falling because of slower demand in China and the United States, said Kazuo Mizuno, chief economist at Mitsubishi Securities in Tokyo. "This suggests that capital spending won't be able to lead the economy," Mr. Mizuno said.

title: A Literary Star Who Finds Art in Happiness, Not Pain
description: In London, where people study the literary pecking order more closely than we do, Ian McEwan is currently ranked the best British novelist of his generation. It is only a matter of time, he believes, before the mantle passes to Kazuo Ishiguro, who has a new novel just out, or to Julian Barnes or Salman Rushdie, who both have books coming later this year.

title: Flight Attendants Reject Concessions at Continental
description: Pilots, dispatchers and mechanics at Continental Airlines voted to accept pay and benefit cuts, contributing to a company goal to reduce annual costs by $500 million. But flight attendants at the airline rejected the cuts, their union announced early today, putting the overall concessions in jeopardy.

title: Panel Says 'Dead Wrong' Data on Prewar Iraq Demands Overhaul
Stadium Brawl and Family Drama Vie for Spotlight
description: If Cablevision loses its bid to block the Jets from building a stadium above the railyards on the West Side of Manhattan, which is likely to happen today, its pugnacious chief executive, James L. Dolan, will be a double loser.

title: Candidates Show Up at Gathering, Separately
description: There is a mayoral primary going on in New York City, although at times, with such low wattage, it can be hard to tell. Consider yesterday. At a meeting organized by Hunter College students that was ambitiously anticipated as the candidates' first face-to-face debate, the Democratic front-runner took a pass and the candidate running second in the polls arrived nearly an hour and a half late. A moderator also decided not to show up.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank: Palestinians Fire At Leader's Headquarters
description: Palestinian gunmen opened fire at the Ramallah compound of the new Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, while he was there, but no one was hurt. The attackers belonged to Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, an armed faction of Fatah, Mr. Abbas's political movement. They began shooting after a number of them were forced out of the compound, where they were given refuge by the previous leader, Yasir Arafat, The Associated Press reported. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: The Long and Winding Road, to Work: Many Travel 90 Minutes or More, One Way
description: If extreme commuting were an Olympic event, there would be no better place to train for it than in New York and northern New Jersey, a report released yesterday by the Census Bureau shows.

Filling In the Many Gaps in American Surrealism
description: The story of Surrealism's influence on American art is often boiled down to a three-man relay: Matta passed the torch of automatic painting to Arshile Gorky, who slipped it to Jackson Pollock, who raced across the finish line to Abstract Expressionism.

title: Supreme Court Removes Hurdle to Age Bias Suits
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 - Workers who sue their employers for age discrimination need not prove that the discrimination was intentional, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday.

title: Wolfowitz reassures Europeans on his goal
Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Woman Charged In Husband's Killing
description: A 19-year-old woman was arrested yesterday and accused of conspiring to kill a man she had recently married as part of what one investigator said was a plot to commit life-insurance fraud. The woman, Lory Scott, a video store clerk who lived with relatives in an apartment in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, was charged with second-degree murder in the December 2003 death of Nubian Knight, 37, a security officer at Kings County Hospital Center. She married him several months before his death as part of a plot she had developed with another person, according to the investigator, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Mr. Knight was found dead in his apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant. He had been beaten on the head and his throat had been slashed. The investigator said the police were not sure whether Ms. Scott committed the killing or was present when Mr. Knight was killed. Under state law, however, a person believed to have conspired in a killing can be charged with murder. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Kurt Eichenwald
World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Brawl In Parliament
description: Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, the nationalist leader of the Liberal Democratic Party, has brawled before in Parliament's lower house. He has attacked opponents with orange juice, spit and invective. He has peppered floor speeches with profanities. Yesterday, he went too far, even by the standards of Russian politics. Parliament censured Mr. Zhirinovsky, a deputy speaker and repeated presidential candidate, after he spit at another deputy, prompting a brawl involving at least 20 lawmakers during a debate over the results of a regional election, which he claimed had been rigged against members of his parties. His punishment: a ban on speaking at parliamentary proceedings for 30 days. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Prospects in Florida Derby Finally Looking Brighter for Zito
description: The story could always change between now and the Kentucky Derby, but this remains the season that whatever can go right will go right for the trainer Nick Zito. Zito is 0 for 16 in the Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park, but he has stumbled upon a situation for Saturday's $1 million prep for the Kentucky Derby that makes it difficult to see him losing.

description: ATLANTA, March 30 - As Terri Schiavo lies dying in a Florida hospice, the fierce debate over end-of-life decisions has moved into statehouses across the country, bringing new scrutiny to who should make the decision to stop life support.

title: California's First Lady Builds a Different Role
description: SACRAMENTO - There are 16 million women in California, and Maria Shriver is only one of them. But as she strode past the potted palms and the oil paintings of aging gray-haired former governors earlier this month to address the Legislature -- the first time in modern history a California first lady had taken the rostrum without her husband -- it was difficult not to sense the symbolic import of the state's alpha female.

description: Holcim, one of the world's largest cement makers, spent $220 million to take control of Cemento de El Salvador and expand operations in Central America, the company said. More than 300 Cemento shareholders accepted an offer of $7.35 a share, Holcim said. Holcim, based in Jona, Switzerland, lifted its stake to 64.2 percent with the transaction, from the 20.3 percent it has held since 1998.

title: LA JOLLA PHARMACEUTICAL SAYS IT WILL CUT 60 JOBS
description: La Jolla Pharmaceutical, which is developing drugs to treat autoimmune diseases, will eliminate 60 jobs, or more than a third of its work force, to save money for research. The cuts will begin immediately and are expected to save $1.3 million in the first quarter and $200,000 in the second quarter. La Jolla said the cuts were necessary for the company to keep testing its lupus drug Riquent. The company said this month that the Food and Drug Administration was unlikely to give Riquent an accelerated review after the drug failed to show statistical significance in a Phase 3 trial. La Jolla, based in San Diego, plans to apply for approval of Riquent in Europe, said Trista Morrison, a spokeswoman.

title: Arts, Briefly; Pop Charts: 50 Cent Remains at No. 1
description: For the fourth week in a row 50 Cent's "Massacre" (Interscope), the first blockbuster hit of the year, has easily held the top spot on the Billboard charts. It sold 329,000 copies last week, bringing its total sales to just over 2.6 million, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The second-best-selling album, for the second week, is the 18th volume of the "Now That's What I Call Music!" pop compilation series, which sold 269,000. "The One" (Sony), above, a new release from the R&B singer Frankie J, made its debut at No. 3, with 130,000 in sales, and Queens of the Stone Age's new "Lullabies to Paralyze" (Interscope) reached No. 5 with 97,000 copies. But a big winner in last week's sales was Green Day's "American Idiot" (Reprise). A strong seller for the past several months, it remains at No. 4 but jumped nearly 40 percent in weekly sales to 103,000, bringing its total to 3.1 million since it was released in September. BEN SISARIO

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Job Cuts At Software Maker
description: I2 Technologies, a software maker, said yesterday that it would cut its global work force by 15 percent as part of a plan to reduce its operating expenses to below $70 million, from $85 million in the fourth quarter. I2 had about 2,000 full-time employees as of Dec. 31, the company said in a regulatory filing. They included about 800 research and development workers in India and the United States and about 300 in sales and marketing, the filing said. Cuts will affect most divisions and regions, a spokeswoman, Beth Elkin, said. I2 Technologies, which is based in Dallas, makes business software.

Paid Notice: Deaths   SAUERHAFT, STAN
description: SAUERHAFT--Stan of Armonk, New York, a leading public relations expert on mergers and acquisitions and corporate communications counseling, died in his sleep on March 25 at age 78. His death followed a valiant struggle with Alzheimer's Disease as well as cancer. A graduate of the University of Michigan with a BA and MA in Creative Writing, he enjoyed a brilliant 50-year career in public relations. Hundreds of clients benefited from his expertise while serving as Executive Vice President and Director of Hill & Knowlton and, more recently, as Vice Chairman of the Board of Burson-Marsteller Worldwide. Mr. Sauerhaft was elected a Fellow of the Public Relations Society of America, the Society's highest recognition. He authored countless articles on public relations practice and principles, as well as the business books The Merger Game and Image Wars as well as the novels End Game and Dead Cat Bounce. He donated his time to valuable industry and civic organizations including the West Point military academy, the LS&A College of his beloved University of Michigan and the Institute for Public Relations Research and Education. He was a longtime member of The Union League Club in New York City, Burning Tree Country Club in Greenwich, Ct, the Authors' Guild Inc. and several industry associations. Mr. Sauerhaft served his country as a Staff Sergeant in the Army from 1944-1946. He was a gifted, avid, competitive sportsman: a nationally ranked senior platform tennis player, a golf partner one could count on to make a crucial putt, and a masterful pool player. Mr. Sauerhaft is survived by his wife of 53 years, Rosalie, their children Richard and his wife Doreen, Douglas and his wife Nancy, Robert and his wife Robin; his grandchildren Roger, Shelley and Lindsey Sauerhaft, and Sarah Jackson; and his faithful Labrador Retriever Caesar. His sons will forever remember his advice: "If you can't outthink them, outwork them. But better yet, try to do both" and "the best luck seems to befall the hardest workers". A Memorial Service will be held May 24 at 4 PM at The Union League Club in New York City.

title: Europe on Wolfowitz as Banker: Once Chilly, Now Tepid
description: PARIS, March 30 - Paul D. Wolfowitz came to Europe on Wednesday as a supplicant for its good will, shedding his image as a unilateralist hawk and entreating his hosts to approve him as the world's banker for the poor.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Siemens To Acquire Manufacturer
description: Siemens, Europe's largest engineering company, plans to buy a German maker of ship motors and windmill turbines from Citigroup for 1.2 billion euros ($1.5 billion) to expand its automation division. The purchase of the company, Flender Holding, will add 6,700 employees and about 1 billion euros in annual revenue, Siemens said. Flender, which is based in Bocholt, will help Siemens expand its line of equipment for wind power companies, an industry that it entered last October with the purchase of Bonus Energy of Denmark. Siemens is based in Munich.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Anti-Mubarak Rallies In 3 Cities
description: Hundreds of demonstrators from Egypt's small opposition movement, Kifaya, or Enough, defied a police ban and turned out in the streets of Cairo, Alexandria and Mansoura to protest for free elections and political reform. In Cairo, thousands of policemen stood shoulder to shoulder to block the demonstrators from reaching the Parliament building. The Kifaya movement opposes a fifth six-year term for President Hosni Mubarak, who has governed since 1981. In Cairo, Safwat el-Sherif, the secretary general of the governing National Democratic Party, said the party wanted Mr. Mubarak to be its candidate in the country's first contested presidential elections later this year. Mona al-Naggar (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: After Indonesia Quake, Inconsolable Grief Yanti Iman cried as an uncle, right, dug a hole today in the ruins of a house to find the bodies of her parents and siblings on the little Indonesian island of Nias.

title: Wolfowitz tries to ease EU worries over bank
Solid Choice on Trade
description: President Bush's choice of Rob Portman, the Ohio congressman, to succeed Robert Zoellick as the United States trade representative was a solid if unglamorous pick for the job of prying open markets abroad -- thereby helping American workers -- while also keeping this country's markets open -- thereby helping American consumers. Mr. Portman, a moderate Republican, gets along well with the skeptical Democrats to whom he must now sell the virtues of free trade.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Court Allows Examination Of Student
description: A federal judge ruled that an American student accused of plotting to assassinate President Bush could be examined by doctors to try to determine whether he was tortured while he was imprisoned in Saudi Arabia for 20 months. The student, Ahmed Abu Ali, must notify the court by April 25 if he plans to introduce evidence of torture or other related claims at his trial in August, the judge, Gerald Bruce Lee, said. Prosecutors have said that Mr. Abu Ali, a former valedictorian at an Islamic high school in Northern Virginia, was a member of Al Qaeda. John Files (NYT)

title: MOLSON COORS PLANS TO MARKET BEER IN RUSSIA
description: The Molson Coors Brewing Company will begin selling beer in Russia as early as next month. Molson Coors plans to spend $16 million in the next four years to market Coors Fine Light in the country. The beer will be made by a Russian brewer, the OOO PIT Company, in Kaliningrad. The company plans to start selling the beer in Moscow and St. Petersburg in April or May. Molson Coors, which was created by the merger of Molson and Coors last month, is based in Golden, Colo.

description: TOKYO, March 30 - The struggling Mitsubishi Motors said Wednesday that it would seek as much as 1.3 billion yen, or $12 million, in damages from seven former executives for their roles in a 20-year cover-up of manufacturing defects.

title: Judge Blocks Rule Allowing Companies to Cut Benefits When Retirees Reach Medicare Age
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 - A federal district judge on Wednesday blocked a Bush administration rule that would have allowed employers to reduce or eliminate health benefits for retirees when they reach age 65 and become eligible for Medicare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WASSER, SYLVIA
description: WASSER--Sylvia. On March 30, 2005 at age 81. Beloved wife for 56 years of Adolph. Loving mother of Steven (Stephanie) and Daniel (Marcia). Cherished grandmother of Jacqueline, Merrill, Maddie, Caryn, and Melissa. A spirited woman guided by Jewish ethics with a love of learning and intellectual curiosity, her determination and remarkable ability to rise above adversity were an inspiration to all who knew her. Services Thursday, March 31, 12:45PM, at "Riverside-Nassau North Chapels", 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: RUBY TUESDAY LOWERS ITS FORECASTS FOR EARNINGS
description: Ruby Tuesday, an operator of casual-dining restaurants, cut its forecast for the fiscal fourth quarter and said net income for the first quarter would decline on higher advertising costs and lower same-store sales. Profit in the fiscal fourth quarter is expected to be 40 cents to 43 cents a share, less than the company's previous forecast of 42 cents to 47 cents. Net income in the fiscal first quarter is expected to be 37 cents to 42 cents a share, compared with 44 cents a year earlier. Sales at stores opened more than a year, excluding franchises, fell 10.2 percent in the first four weeks of the fiscal fourth quarter. The company, based in Maryville, Tenn., released the forecast after the close of market trading.

title: High Atop a Hotel, Zoom Service
description: A new thrill called Insanity has landed in Las Vegas atop the Stratosphere Casino Hotel and Tower, one of the tallest buildings west of the Mississippi River. At full speed (40 miles an hour), the ride uses centrifugal force to turn passengers nearly face down some 900 feet above the pavement. Insanity, designed by Interactive Rides in Logan, Utah, joins three other rides at the hotel and is touted as the one "for riders whose minds are already blown." Tickets are $8; at 2000 Las Vegas Boulevard South, Las Vegas, www.insanityride.com.

title: MarketWatch Creator Hired to Run Digital Unit at CBS
description: The CBS division of Viacom, which lost last year in its bid to acquire the financial news Web site CBS MarketWatch, announced yesterday that it had landed a critical component of the business after all.

title: Hold That West Side Decision
description: A round of rock, paper and scissors might be more fair than what has passed for process in awarding development rights for 13 acres over railyards on the West Side of Manhattan. So-called open bidding produced just three offers, partly because it was rushed and skewed in favor of the New York Jets' proposed stadium. A vote expected today by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which owns the rights, could turn out to be little more than a charade.

title: County Panel Says School Is Exempt From Bias Law
description: The Westchester County Human Rights Commission has said it does not have the authority to investigate the banning of a gay student group at New York Medical College. The commission said that because the school, based in Valhalla, has ties to the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, it is exempt from the county's antidiscrimination law.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Syria: Assad Pardons Kurdish Rioters
description: President Bashar Assad released 312 Kurdish prisoners in a special amnesty, the official Syrian Arab News Agency announced. The Kurds were detained last March after a series of violent antigovernment demonstrations in the northeastern town of Qamishli, on the Turkish border. Most had been held without trial, and they had become a rallying point for the Syrian opposition, as well as a focus of criticism by human rights activists. Anwar al-Bunni, a lawyer for the Kurdish prisoners and the head of the Syrian Human Rights Organization, called the release a surprise. Katherine Zoepf (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Stem Cell Bill Passes
description: By a vote of 35 to 2, the State Senate passed a bill authorizing embryonic stem cell research, including a type of research opposed by Gov. Mitt Romney. The vote endorsed a procedure that involves inserting the nucleus of an adult cell into an egg cell to form an embryo that can produce stem cells. Mr. Romney, a Republican, has said he will veto any bill authorizing it. The House will debate a different version of the bill today. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Jerry Springer': The Aftermath
description: Flooded with 55,000 complaints before and 8,000 after its January broadcast of the irreverent but award-winning West End musical "Jerry Springer: The Opera," the Governors Program Complaints Committee of the BBC has voted 4 to 1 to reject the objections. The committee, which is charged with deciding if transmitted programs meet BBC editorial standards, codes and guidelines, said of the program that "although the offense to religious beliefs caused to sizable numbers of people should not be underestimated or taken lightly, its broadcast was justified because the outstanding artistic significance of the program outweighed the offense that it caused to some viewers." Featuring Jesus, Mary and God as Jerry Springer's guests, the televised musical, a satire on Mr. Springer's confessional program, also received 2,200 supportive messages. Meanwhile, a Christian group, the Christian Institute, is pursuing a judicial review against the BBC for the broadcast. The BBC said, "This is a separate legal matter and is so far the only legal action ongoing, and because it is ongoing we can't comment further at the moment." PAM KENT

title: The Lyrics Are Perfectly Clear, in Welsh
description: Gruff Rhys had just arrived from Wales with a guitar in his hands for a concert recently, and though he was very friendly and smiley and polite, he looked a little stiff. Standing amid the skyscrapers of Midtown Manhattan, there was one thing he badly wanted to do: take the tram to Roosevelt Island.

Technology Briefing | Services: Consultant Forecasts A Loss
description: Shares of Tetra Tech, a consultant and technical services provider, fell almost 17 percent yesterday after the company forecast a loss of more than $50 million in the current quarter. Tetra Tech made the forecast after the close of trading Tuesday. It said it had losses in units that help companies design and build wireless telecommunications networks and that it was talking with a customer about not completing work on a contract. Tetra Tech had previously forecast a profit of 15 cents to 17 cents a share in the period, down from a profit of 23 cents a share a year earlier. Shares of the company, which is based in Pasadena, Calif., fell $2.53, to close at $12.46.

title: James Lebron, a Wizard at Moving of Art, Dies at 76

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Couple Found Dead In Home
description: A man and a woman were found dead in a Douglaston home yesterday evening, and the police said they were investigating whether they had suffered carbon monoxide poisoning. According to the police, the man, 50, and woman, 49, whose names were not released, were found dead in their home at 242-22 Oak Park Drive around 7:30 p.m. A car in the garage was left with the ignition in the on position, the police said, although the car was not running last night. The additional testing will begin immediately, and the results may be ready to submit to the Food and Drug Administration, which asked for the studies, later this year or in early 2006, Biovail said. The agency's action is a blow to Biovail's plan to start manufacturing Tramadol ER for the United States market this year. The F.D.A. may take six months to review the new results. Stock in Biovail, which is based in Mississauga, Ontario, fell 10 percent.

The accord -- which was reached during a visit by the Spanish prime minister, Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero, who also attended a summit conference on Tuesday with Mr. Chvez and the presidents of Colombia and Brazil -- signaled closer ties between Madrid and Caracas and underscored Spain's increasing independence from Washington. They have little in the way of assets to pay the bill, and now a tax court judge has turned down what may have been their last hope to avert financial ruin. Their troubles underscore how taxpayers can be tripped up by stock options if they do not know how to handle them properly. The options the Speltzes thought had made them wealthy instead brought on their current troubles.

title: Arts, Briefly; They're Just Wild About Harry
description: Come July, there will be no escaping the new Harry Potter novel. Scholastic Inc., its American publisher, plans a first printing of 10.8 million copies of this latest of the J.K. Rowling books, "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince," right, USA Today reported yesterday. That figure represents four million copies more than were initially printed when the last Potter adventure was released, in 2003. The total might also be a record for first printings of a hardcover general-interest book, although there are few authoritative sources to confirm that. Publishers routinely overstate the number of copies in a first printing, and the rule of thumb is to divide an announced first printing by two to get the real number. But Scholastic's estimate is probably closer to reality. In 2003, it printed 6.8 million copies of "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix" in the first run, and 5 million of those sold on the first day. That was because of the large volume of pre-orders, a phenomenon that is recurring this time. "We are hearing from our accounts that the pre-orders are phenomenal," Barbara Marcus, the president of Scholastic, said in a statement. Scholastic, however, would not divulge how many books have been ordered so far. EDWARD WYATT

Susan Lambiase, associate director of Children's Rights, an advocacy group that sued the state over its failure to protect children, told the judge that her group was concerned about how the state investigates allegations received through its child abuse hot line and those regarding foster children. She said it was also concerned that the state would miss its June 30 deadline to find placements for children with mental health problems who are in juvenile detention. Tina Kelley (NYT)

description: COCHRAN--Johnnie L. Jr., Esq. The Board of Directors and staff of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone Development Corp. are deeply saddened by the loss of the chairman of our board. title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the businessman and diplomat Sol M. Linowitz on March 19 misspelled the surname of a critic and essayist who was an alumnus of Mr. Linowitz's alma mater, Hamilton College, and misstated the man's postgraduate affiliation with it. The alumnus was Alexander Woollcott, not Woolcott. He was visiting the campus when he saw Mr. Linowitz in a student production and urged him to take up the stage professionally; he was not the director of the school's drama program.

title: M.T.A. Expected to Approve Jets' $720 Million Plan for Stadium
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has thrown his support behind the Jets' $720 million bid for the rights to build a stadium over its railyards on the West Side of Manhattan, all but assuring that the authority's board will approve a sale to the team at its meeting this morning, according to two people who spoke yesterday with the chairman, Peter S. Kalikow.

title: LABORATORY CORPORATION OF AMERICA TO BUY ESOTERIX
description: Laboratory Corporation of America said it had agreed to acquire Esoterix for about $150 million in cash. Esoterix, based in Austin, Tex., provides specialty reference testing, Laboratory Corporation said. The purchase will enhance Laboratory Corporation's position in the industry, its chief executive, Thomas Mac Mahon, said in a statement. The purchase is scheduled to close by the end of June. Laboratory Corporation, based in Burlington, N.C., has acquired or tried to buy at least 11 laboratory or testing companies in the last five years.

title: Is 2 1/2 Too Old to Be a V.P. for Design?
description: FOR some people having a baby disrupts careers; for others it makes them. A new generation of parent-entrepreneurs -- many of whom are survivors of the Internet boom and bust -- discovered an unfilled market niche when they began looking for baby gear and children's furnishings that met their standards for form and function. Now they are rejuvenating the field, applying their own design sense and giving consumers new choices.

description: WERTHMAN - RAND -- Dr. M.J. Of Redlands, CA, formerly of Chicago, IL, and New York, died on March 25, 2005. She was a well known speaker, college teacher and author of "Behavioral Managed Care." At the time of her death, she was an administrator at Kaiser Permanente, Fontana, CA. title: Dr. Wilfred G. Bigelow, 91, a Pioneer in Heart Surgery, Dies

World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Offer For Bank
description: The Dutch bank ABN Amro bid 6.3 billion euros ($8.1 billion) to buy Banca Antonveneta of Italy. ABN, which is based in Amsterdam, bid 25 euros ($32.30) a share for the 87 percent of Antonveneta that it does not already own. Antonveneta, which ranks among the 10 biggest banks in Italy with 1,000 branches, is based in Padua and has a strong foothold in the northeastern part of the country. The bid is subject to approval by Antonio Fazio, left, governor of the Bank of Italy. Mr. Fazio has blocked such proposals in the past, but he has been told by the European Union to open the country to foreign investors. On Tuesday, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria of Spain offered to buy Banca Nazionale del Lavorno, based in Rome, for $8.5 billion in a stock deal. Eric Sylvers (NYT)
